HEADLINE: U.S. Trade Gap Widened to $6.97 Billion in April

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18

 BODY:
The long-predicted plunge in American exports to the slowing economies of Japan and Western Europe finally took place in April, and the trade deficit widened to $6.97 billion, the Commerce Department reported today.
Only a modest increase in exports to poor and middle-income countries and a drop in imports from Japan and Canada prevented the overall deficit from expanding even further, from $5.58 billion a month earlier. Sales of American goods in Japan dropped 18.1 percent from March, while sales to Western Europe tumbled 13.6 percent. 
 Figures for any single month can be highly volatile, and a drop in aircraft exports and a rise in oil imports accounted for much of the deterioration. But trade experts were nonetheless surprised and disappointed that the deterioration had come so soon.
"For a long time, exports have been holding up whatever economic growth we've had," said Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., the president of the Economic Strategy Institute, a liberal Washington research group. "And now, just when it's looking like the economy is getting going, the exports are losing steam. Shoot, why can't things all go right at the same time?"
Stephen S. Roach, senior economist for Morgan Stanley in New York, was more optimistic, pointing out that the United States now depends on Latin America and Southeast Asia for its growth in exports while sales to other rich countries bob up and down without showing strong trends in either direction.
The announcement of slumping exports to Japan came just a week after Tokyo announced its 17th consecutive increase in its monthly trade surplus, to $7.87 billion, and as the House is preparing to vote on a broad trade bill that would force the Bush Administration to pursue a more confrontational trade policy.
Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan is due in Washington at the end of this month, and the White House is expected to play down conflicts that could embarrass President Bush before the November elections. President Bush's state visit to Tokyo in January turned into a public-relations disaster at home after trade issues came to the forefront, and both sides are eager to avoid a repeat of that experience by focusing on political and military issues this time.
Today's weak report is likely to sharpen the differences here over whether the trade gap is the fault of Japan or the United States, a debate that has droned on for more than 20 years with sometimes superficial changes.
How static the discussion has become was clear today at Congressional hearings and meetings on the nation's relations with Japan, including an appearance by Takakazu Kuriyama, the new Japanese Ambassador, before a luncheon of a group of lawmakers who advocate a more confrontational trade policy.
In his first appearance on Capitol Hill, Mr. Kuriyama was quick to chide the United States. "Your deficit, as you know, is not directly related to our surplus and has to be dealt with through macroeconomic management in this country," he said. "More and more people in this country are aware of it."
Representative Frank R. Wolf, Republican of Virginia, immediately interjected, "A lot of it is our own fault, but a lot of it is your fault."
But Mr. Wolf then went on to ask Mr. Kuriyama about lobbying by Japanese companies in the United States, dropping the issue of how to reduce the trade deficit.
When a panel of Japan experts appeared this morning before the Congressional Joint Economic Committee, the discussion this morning was similarly inconclusive and descriptive rather than prescriptive.
C. Michael Aho, the director of economic studies at the Council on Foreign Relations, in New York, echoed the Japanese ambassador's remarks. "Our problems with Japan are home grown," he said. He elaborated later, saying, "What Japan is doing is exposing our weaknesses, in investment, in education, savings and all that."
James Fallows, an author and journalist, countered that the American trade deficit with Japan was not unique. "The Germans and the Koreans don't have the same problems dealing with their schools that we have, they do have the same problems dealing with Japan," he said.
Mr. Aho and Mr. Fallows agreed that the United States should pay more attention to Japan. But of the Joint Economic Committee's 20 members, only Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana, and Senator Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico, bothered to show up for this morning's hearing.

HEADLINE: New Claims by Jobless Drop

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18

 BODY:
The number of first-time claims for unemployment insurance edged down in early June, the Government said today in a report reflecting the painfully slow recovery.
The Labor Department said 407,000 Americans had filed applications for benefits, down from a revised 409,000 a week earlier. The figures are adjusted for seasonal variations. 
 Claims in the previous week had originally been estimated at 407,000. Economists expected an improvement to 400,000 to 405,000.
"It is beginning to look as if we have stagnated at these levels," said Steven Wood, an economist for Bank of America. The number of unemployment claims will have to drop, he said, to produce significant economic growth in the second half of the year.
A closely watched moving average of claims was 406,500 for the latest four-week period, the same as that for the four weeks ended a week earlier, which was a 19-month low.
The recent pause in improvement in the claims numbers does not foreshadow any immediate improvement in the unemployment rate, which jumped from 7.2 percent in April to an eight-year high of 7.5 percent in May.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Cuts Florio's Plan in Its Budget

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 18

 BODY:
The leaders of the Republican legislative majority announced today a $14.6 billion budget for 1993 that cuts Gov. Jim Florio's spending plan by $1.1 billion.
Reducing the Democratic administration's request for all but three departments and agencies -- the Personnel and Agriculture Departments and the Governor's office -- the Republicans made their cuts largely in programs intended to help the poor and the middle class. 
 The plan, submitted to the State Senate and the Assembly as a 216-page bill, would result in thousands of layoffs among middle managers and unionized workers alike.
 
Change and Fear
 "This budget is about change, which is why I expect it to receive criticism from those who support the status quo and fear change," said the Assembly Speaker, Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian. "They want this budget to be everything to everyone, but the economic climate in our state does not permit that to be the case."
Under the State Constitution, the Legislature must present and the Governor must sign a balanced budget before July 1, the start of the fiscal year.
The Republicans, with two-thirds majorities in both houses of the Legislature, are expected to win approval of their plan easily. The Governor can delete items from the budget or try to persuade the Legislature to alter it, but he cannot restore any cuts.
After weeks of anticipation, members of both houses gathered today in the Assembly chamber to hear Mr. Haytaian and the Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, deliver political speeches about the budget but offer no details.
 
'Betrayal' of Public Trust
 "The actions of this administration are a betrayal of the public trust," Mr. Haytaian said. "The Legislature has corrected the budget mistakes that have been made during the past two years and those that have been finally admitted during the past two days as well.
"And I have another message for our Treasurer and Governor: the Legislature is doing its part to solve our state's problems. It's time for you to stop sabotaging our efforts and to begin working in the best interest of our citizens."
Mr. Florio, who did not attend the joint session, issued a statement with a series of questions. "Is money being taken out of one pocket at the same time it's put in the other pocket?" he asked. "Is this a budget designed to be a solid blueprint for where New Jersey will go over the next 12 months, or is it something patched together to get us by through July 1?"
Wrangling over the budget is usually partisan, but the process has been especially bitter this year, and today's events were no exception. The speeches were clearly intended to put a Republican cast on the budget process and to deflect any blame for cuts toward Mr. Florio and his fellow Democrats.
 
'A Lot of Pain'
 One issue that quickly produced dispute was layoffs. Both Mr. Florio and the Republicans expect savings through the attrition of 2,500 jobs. In addition, the Republicans said their budget would result in 1,500 to 2,000 layoffs, mostly among managers, though some blue-collar workers would be affected. A senior administration official disputed those estimates, saying the total number of layoffs produced by the Republican budget would be closer to 7,500.
"It's a lot of pain for a penny," said Anthony Cimino, director of the State Personnel Department, recalling the Republicans' rollback of the sales tax to 6 percent from 7 percent last month, which cost the state $608 million in revenue.
Under the Republican budget, the Department of Human Services would lose nearly $190 million from the $3.7 billion Mr. Florio had requested. Included in the reduction is about $20 million in general-assistance services to the poor.
In many instances, the impact of the Republican plan is not so clear.
For example, the Republicans show what seems like a modest $5.5 million cut from Mr. Florio's $51.8 million request for the Public Advocate's office. But the bulk of the remaining money will go to the Public Defender's office, which is part of the Advocate's office. The savings are achieved by eliminating the public-interest advocacy program, the citizens' complaints program and $500,000 from the central office budget, which represents most of the staff. The result is that the Public Advocate no longer has the staff or the funds to take another state agency to court.
"They have kept the body, but they have made sure that the body can't speak or hear," said the Public Advocate, Wilfredo Caraballo.
The Republicans cut $24 million in direct services to welfare recipients. And they eliminated affirmative-action and equal-employment-opportunity programs in every department, consolidating them under the State Personnel Department. They also provided $200,000 for the Department of Environmental Protection and Energy for the disposal of dead deer.
The Republican plan also cuts $385 million from the $685 million Mr. Florio had recommended for the homestead rebate program.
Under their plan, Mr. Haytaian and Mr. DiFrancesco said, senior citizens remain eligible for the rebates they received last year, as much as $500. But they have limited the rebates to $90 for other homeowners with income of less than $40,000 a year and to $30 for renters. The plan eliminates rebates for those in subsidized housing and for some students in campus housing who had been eligible.
 
Emphasis on 'Savings'
 The Republicans released a budget summary and a sheaf of documents that spoke of "budget savings" rather than cuts and concentrated on increases in some programs instead of reductions that would cripple or eliminate others.
The Republicans listed "savings" in 21 of the state's 24 departments and agencies. The only areas granted increases over the Governor's requests were the Agriculture Department, which was given $941,000 more than the $13.3 million Mr. Florio sought, and the Personnel Department, with an additional $3.7 million, raising its budget to $34.2 million.
The Republicans did not alter Mr. Florio's request for $5 million to run his own office. And they cut $739,000 from the legislative budget but by eliminating such items as a County and Municipal Government Study Commission ($285,000) and paring $500,000 from a $2.3 million allocation for a commission to study sex discrimination in state laws.
Mr. Haytaian and Mr. DiFrancesco made only oblique references to layoffs. "We have achieved $65 million in budget savings through a thinning out of the salary-rich, middle-management bureaucracy in each department," Mr. DiFrancesco said.
"Our budget sends a clear message to state departments and agencies," Mr. Haytaian said. "Taxpayers are our No. 1 priority, not preserving state bureaucracy and excessive spending."

HEADLINE: Chicago Merc Plans Largest Trading Floor

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
Moving to adjust to its explosive growth over the last decade, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange is expected to announce today that it plans to build the world's largest trading floor.
Exchange officials said yesterday that the expansion, which would cost $26.6 million and take a year to complete, would double the Merc's trading capacity to about 70,000 square feet. The Merc has outgrown its trading space three times in this century. 
 The plan underscores the rapid transformation of the Chicago futures markets. In the last decade or so, the markets have moved from an almost incidental financial arena for mostly Midwestern ranchers and food companies to a booming industry trading a variety of complex financial futures contracts that has overtaken many competitors in its innovation in new products and systems. Now, pork bellies and three-month Eurodollar deposits are equally at home on the exchange.
 
Electronic Trading System
 Word of the expansion plans comes less than a week before the planned start by the Merc of an electronic trading system. Known as Globex, it will open up a new era for 24-hour trading on an exchange.
Under the new building plan, which was approved Wednesday by the Merc's board, an unoccupied floor four stories above the current trading floor will be used for 16 new trading pits and 770 member firm booths. The Merc currently has 30 pits.
When the construction is done, the interest rate and currency groups, which now occupy about half of the Merc's trading floor, will be moved to the new floor.
The construction will be financed out of the exchange's cash reserves. An analysis of the Merc's financial position by the exchange with Goldman, Sachs & Company concluded that the project could be financed in that way without any special assesments on member firms or any increase in clearing fees, the exchange's main source of revenue.
The need for more space is largely the result of the Merc's expansion into a growing, increasingly esoteric number of futures contracts, based on everything from currencies to interest rates to stock indexes. In a little less than nine years in its current home, the C.M.E. Center, the volume of business at the Merc has grown 222 percent.
The exchange's growth has become painfully obvious to floor traders in the last two years. This year alone, an exchange official said yesterday, the Merc has spent $1 million on construction to relieve overcrowding in the trading pits.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Advance in Price

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities ended higher yesterday after the announcement of weak United States trade figures that suggested the economic recovery would be slow and keep interest rates from rising sharply.
Led by shorter maturities, prices rose after the Commerce Department reported that the trade deficit surged 25 percent in April, to $6.97 billion, the widest monthly gap in 17 months. 
 Exports fell in April, a sign that overseas demand weakened, while imports rose, suggesting United States demand was being directed overseas. The report suggested "the economy is still struggling," said Charles Lieberman, director of financial markets research at Chemical Securities Inc.
The April trade data suggested to some economists that the gross domestic product for the second quarter may post a slower growth rate than the 2.4 percent annual rate seen in the first quarter.
 
30-Year Bond Yield Down
 The Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bond rose 8/32 of a point at 102 8/32 , pushing down its yield to 7.79 percent from 7.81 percent on Wednesday. The two-year note rose 2/32 , to 100 13/32 , yielding 4.90 percent.
Demand for short-term securities encouraged a further steepening of the yield curve to what economists said was the widest spread ever between the two-year and 30-year securities: 290 basis points, or 2.9 percentage points.
Much of the buying in the short end was linked to belief that the weak trade data improved chances that the Federal Reserve could further lower its Federal funds rate target, now presumed to be 3.75 percent.
"The market has been trying to get an assessment of what second-quarter gross domestic product is going to look like," said Matthew Alexy, senior economist at the First Boston Corporation. "It looks as if individuals with high forecasts have had to fold up their tents."
The Labor Department also reported that first-time jobless claims in the week that ended June 6 were nearly steady at 407,000. The number from the previous week was revised upward to 409,000 from 407,000.
"The market has been looking for claims to fall," said William Dudley, senior economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The claims were still above the key 400,000 level, which some economists believe could portend weak hiring for the entire month of June.
"The failure of claims to decline reinforces the notion that the employment picture is only improving at a modest rate," said Dudley.
Economists say the United States recovery needed an improvement in the employment picture to increase lagging consumer demand.
Late in the day, Treasury securities remained firm after the Fed reported its key M-2 money supply was unchanged in the latest reporting week, which ended on June 8.
 
Money Growth Below Target
 The latest M-2 data meant growth was still $10 billion below the Fed's target rate of 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent a year, said Kathleen Stephansen, an economist at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation.
Bills were mostly firm yesterday. The discount rate on three-month bills was unchanged at 3.61 percent; the six-month bill rate was down two basis points, at 3.70 percent, and the one-year bill rate was down three basis points, at 3.90 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Supercollider Contractors Criticize Vote to Halt Work

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Halting work on the supercollider in Texas would have little near-term economic impact on the leading suppliers of components to the project, but the country could pay dearly in the long run, industry executives say.
The House of Representatives voted on Wednesday to block continued construction of the superconducting supercolliders. Suppliers to the $8.4 billion project contend that it is a means to develop the skill and capacity to build high-tech materials like superconducting magnets in large volumes and to demonstrate their reliability. The payoff, they say, would be in commercialization of such technology in a variety of applications in transportation and energy production and distribution. 
 "What we would be missing is the chance to build an infrastructure that would make superconductivity attractive in a variety of applications," said Richard Hora, vice president of energy business for the Space Systems division of the General Dynamics Corporation, one of three leading magnet contractors for the project.
Superconductors are materials that have no resistance to electricity and powerful magnetic fields. They are currently used in magnetic resonance imaging, which doctors use along with X-rays and CAT scans to diagnose what is going on inside a human body without surgery. Superconductivity researchers believe that the technology will one day be used for magnetically levitated trains, which would travel at high speeds without the friction of metal wheels on rails; for reducing energy losses in electricity transmission, and for storing electricity more efficiently.
Makers of superconducting equipment were not the only ones counting on the collider to open new business horizons. Construction companies see the project as a way to get valuable experience with new tunneling equipment and techniques at a time when the worldwide trend is to put more urban roadways and rail services underground, said Robert Prieto, director of corporate development for Parsons Brinkerhoff Quade & Douglas Inc., the New York-based firm overseeing engineering and construction at the site.
More than 18,000 contracts related to work on the collider have been let to thousands of companies and over 100 universities in 46 states, according to the National Association for the Superconducting Supercollider, a Washington-based lobby.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Platinum Posts 4th Decline On Weak Economy in Japan

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Platinum futures prices swooned yesterday to their lowest level in a month on another round of bad economic news from Japan, the world center of platinum investment.
"The platinum market is suffering from the Nikkei blues," William O'Neill, Merrill Lynch's senior futures strategist, said, referring to a drop in the Japanese stock market's Nikkei stock average to a five-and-a-half-year low. 
 Platinum for July delivery fell $3.50 on the New York Mercantile Exchange to $358.40 an ounce, the lowest settlement for near-term deliveries since May 18.
Platinum has fallen $11.70 in four consecutive drops that halted a two-month rally from less than $340 an ounce to just over $370.
The selling has fed on a steady stream of negative signals involving Japan, where the metal is heavily used for investment, jewelry and -- as in the United States -- as a component in automobile pollution-control systems.
On Monday, Japanese Government officials said industrial demand for platinum was likely to fall this year because of the weaker market for Japanese cars.
Platinum traders in the United States expect large sales of physical platinum from Japan as investors there unload their holdings to raise cash for stock-market margin calls. In the last seven trading days, the Nikkei has fallen a total of 1,799.48 points, or 10.08 percent.
A weaker dollar supported gold and silver futures on New York's Commodity Exchange.
June gold rose $1.40, to $342.60 an ounce; July silver rose 0.2 cent, to $4.092 an ounce.
Lumber for July delivery soared the permitted daily limit of 5 cents to $244.80 for 1,000 board feet on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange on news of a Canadian pulp and paper workers' strike.
July sugar deliveries tumbled 0.24 cent, to 10.81 cents a pound, on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange amid profit taking after a four-day rally that lifted sugar to its highest level in nearly a year.
Crude oil trading remained quiet on the New York Merc ahead of today's United Nations-Iraq meeting in Vienna, which could lead to a sale of Iraqi oil.
Crude oil for July delivery slipped 3 cents, to $22.26 a barrel; July heating oil rose 0.22 cent, to 61.21 cents a gallon; July unleaded gasoline fell 0.38 cent, to 65.21 cents a gallon; July natural gas fell 1.4 cents, to $1.591 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: $25 and Under

BYLINE: By Eric Asimov

 BODY:
It's a verifiable equation: when a Government falls anywhere in the world, restaurants rise in the United States. Let's face it, political change rarely cures poverty or resolves antipathies, but it almost always benefits American diners.
After the Vietnam War, Vietnamese restaurants opened all over the United States, run by new immigrants and catering to a ready market of refugees missing the tastes of home as well as to Americans. After Governments changed in Iran, Ethiopia and, most recently, Haiti, new restaurants sprouted up all over, replaying this centuries-old American process of immigration and assimilation. 
 Such was the case with Caravan, a four-year-old Afghan restaurant owned by Ibrahim Muhammed and Ghulam Haider. Mr. Muhammed had been the chef at the Afghan Embassy in Washington for four years when he decided to seek asylum in the United States in 1979 for political and economic reasons. Mr. Haider, his cousin, was then a refugee from the war in Afghanistan, staying in the United States Embassy in India. Mr. Muhammed helped Mr. Haider come to New York, where he attended City College. On finishing his studies, he and Mr. Muhammed, who had cooked at and managed a number of restaurants, decided to open their own place in New York.
Seeking a foothold in crowded, touristy midtown, they chose a steamy block on Eighth Avenue near the theater district, an urban counterpart to the barren, rugged terrain for which Afghanistan is famous. Adventurous diners must traverse a Khyber Pass of adult-video stores and similarly seedy establishments to reach Caravan, but their reward is a quiet, calm refuge where they can relax over savory kebabs and fiery stews.
The carpeted, rectangular dining room, seating about 85, holds neat rows of tables covered with soft tablecloths and bearing red linen napkins. Tapestries depicting folky mountain scenes line the walls, and sinuous music lilts quietly in the background. Mr. Haider, a gracious presence in the dining room, is quick to offer suggestions or recommendations as he brings over a basket of oblong wedges of fresh flatbread.
Ashak ($3.50), steamed scallion-and-meat dumplings covered with a refreshing mint-scented yogurt sauce, is a delightful way to start. Sambusa ($2.95) is a spicier appetizer, crisp fried triangular turnovers containing chickpeas, ground beef and mixed vegetables, served with a yogurt-and-lemon dipping sauce. Boulanee kadou ($3.25) is an unusual fried turnover filled with pureed pumpkin, fragrant with cinnamon and nutmeg and almost sweet enough for dessert.
All 10 kebabs come with enormous portions of nutty basmati rice and grilled tomatoes. The naan va kebab ($9.95), minced beef mixed with onions and spices and fashioned into a submarine-size cylinder, is spicier than the shishlick ($10.25), a domino row of tender chunks of grilled beef. Morgh ($10.75), bite-size chunks of chicken breast marinated in lemon and then grilled, was almost hidden in the rice. Only the bareh kebab ($10.75), grilled lamb marinated in yogurt, was tough.
Even the satisfying kebabs can't overshadow the delicious peppery slow-cooked stews, including chalow sabzi ($9.25), tender lamb served in a sauce scented with coriander and garlic over rice with spinach, and quorma badenjan ($9.25), another lamb dish, served with eggplant, onion, peppers and tomatoes. There is also an array of vegetarian dishes.
Desserts, including a creamy rice pudding ($2.25) and a gelatinous saffron pudding studded with nuts ($2) are a bit of an afterthought, a bland contrast to the spicy fare.
Four years at Caravan have taught Mr. Muhammed and Mr. Haider a lot about running a business in America, they say. Like the importance of ambition and expansion. They are now planning a second restaurant on the Upper East Side.
 
Caravan
741 Eighth Avenue, at 46th Street, Manhattan, (212) 262-2021.
Best dishes: Scallion-and-meat dumplings; chickpea, meat and vegetable turnovers; minced beef kebab; chicken kebab; lamb-and-spinach stew, and lamb-and-eggplant stew.
Price range: $10 to $16.
Credit cards: American Express, Diner's Club, Mastercard and Visa.
Hours: Noon to 11:30 P.M. daily
Wheelchair access: all on one level.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
Melting Pot? Simmering Nicely

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Right-wing critics of public broadcasting should be cheered tonight by an essay, in prime time, that is upbeat about America from a man who has been known to consort with neo-conservatives.
"The First Universal Nation," at 9 P.M. on Channel 13, is an installment of "Ben J. Wattenberg: Trends in the 90's." It is Mr. Wattenberg's description of the American melting pot, which he finds to be poppling vigorously and productively. In this energetic hour, the author and television commentator looks at immigration, intermarriage and the worldwide taste for American pop culture. 
 Mr. Wattenberg, who specializes in mining the meanings of statistical data as a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative think tank, notes that the immigration rate is back up to a million a year, about the same as at the turn of the century. But the mix has changed: about 85 percent of today's newest Americans are not of European ancestry. At the Gaithersburg Intermediate School in Maryland, he finds students from 41 countries, apparently getting along just fine.
Although Mr. Wattenberg concedes that intergroup animosities have not vanished (a black New Yorker is seen shouting at a Korean New Yorker, "This is my country, not yours"), he accentuates the positive. While attending a wedding in Baltimore between a Greek Orthodox woman and a Presbyterian man whose mother belongs to the Daughters of the American Revolution, he notes that ethnic and religious barriers to marriage have all but collapsed in the last 20 years. He finds encouragement in the fact that black-white intermarriage, too, is climbing, although it is still relatively rare.
His conclusion: At a time when ethnic and racial divisions are being emphasized by press and television, "the melting pot is alive, flourishing, expanding."
One must hope so; the message is much more heartening than the general run of election-year coverage. But viewers may detect a certain wishfulness in this hour, which was financed in part by the John M. Olin Foundation and the Donner Foundation, prominent supporters of conservative causes. Mr. Wattenberg, sleeves rolled up, glasses on forehead, makes an energetic salesman for America, with a salesman's tendency to play down the less shiny aspects of his product.
Relying on history and faith, he promises that the current symptoms of group dissension will be ameliorated as the American dream takes hold among the new immigrants. Matters like the nation's economic prospects, the appearance in the inner cities of youths who are notoriously resistant to assimilation and the implications of the multi-culturalism are given scant attention.
Mr. Wattenberg's optimistic revisionism is most striking in the hour's final segment, on the Americanization of world culture. Along with Hollywood movies, soap operas and Euro Disney, America is sending forth values like individualism and upward mobility, he emphasizes. He does not pause to scrutinize the content of what is being exported.
The message being delivered to the world, he says, is this: "In America everything is possible." That is pretty much Mr. Wattenberg's message, too.
 
'States of Mind'
Channel 13
Friday at midnight
This seven-part PBS series on how people are getting along these days around the United States has a somewhat less optimistic spin. Workers in Idaho are trying to figure out how to keep their jobs in the logging industry without disfiguring the land, and leaders of a poor black community in Arkansas are trying to improve life for their children. A largely Hispanic community in Denver is trying to revitalize a neighborhood battered by industry, and old-time religion is holding together the residents of a rural West Virginia town. And people in tiny Shoshone, Idaho, have been hit by crime and poverty, just like people in Milwaukee and Philadelphia, the scene of tonight's intermittently interesting opening episode, direly titled "Crisis in Philadelphia."
 
'Pillar of Fire'
TNT
Sunday at 10 P.M.
This two-hour documentary is a distillation of a 19-hour Israeli version of the birth of Israel, from the Dreyfus court-martial to the establishment of the state in 1948. It is embellished with evocative old photographs and newsreel clips and the narration of Jason Robards.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Utah Utility Bonds

 BODY:
To take advantage of the lower interest rates in the debt market, the Intermountain Power Agency of Utah is offering $242.8 million in power-supply refunding revenue bonds to yield a maximum 6.45 percent for an issue due in 2021, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. Serial bonds with shorter maturities are priced to yield from 3 percent in 1993 to 5.1 percent in 1997, 5.85 percent in 2002 and 6.25 percent in 2007. For investors interested in other long-term issues, the financing includes a bond issue due in 2012 priced to yield about 6.393 percent. Underwriters said the tax-exempt issue was rated double-A by both Moody's Investors Service Inc. and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: Last Stand for the Adirondacks?

BYLINE: By John B. Oakes; John B. Oakes, former Editor of the Editorial Page of the The New York Times, was a member of Gov. Mario Cuomo's Commission on the Adirondack Park in the 21st Century.

 BODY:
The 100th birthday celebration of the Adirondack Park may yet be turned into a wake.
Timberland owners with huge holdings, real estate speculators and their lawyers have converged on Albany, posing as "moderates" and friends of the "little man." They are, in reality, extremists who would weaken zoning rules, sell off shorefronts and brook no further interference with their "right" ultimately to devastate, for short-term gain, one of the great natural and scenic resources of the United States. 
 Yet New York's voters don't have a clue about what is going on.
The immediate question is this: Why does the majority leader of the Republican-controlled Senate, Ralph J. Marino of Oyster Bay, continue to allow the park's most implacable enemy in the Senate, deputy majority leader Ronald Stafford of Plattsburgh, to wield absolute veto power over all legislation affecting the park?
Senator Stafford, whose district includes less than half the park's six million acres, has chosen to honor the park on its centenary by introducing a bill that would in effect abolish it. It would do so by wiping out the Adirondack Park Agency, which enforces the already inadequate regulations governing the park. Senator Stafford would also reduce the size of the park by eliminating privately held land from its boundaries.
Without Senator Stafford's consent, not even the mildest of bills to halt the park's downward slide has the slightest chance of enactment.
The economic bases for the park's 130,000 permanent residents are the forest products industry and the tourist industry. Both are threatened by the intense speculative pressure (slowed only by the recession) that will inevitably lead to a breakup of large holdings in the timber country and consequent loss of jobs, and of recreational and scenic quality, while at the same time increasing water, air and noise pollution.
This is not only the 100th anniversary of the creation of the Adirondack Park, it also the 20th anniversary of comprehensive land use regulations for the more than half of the park's area that is privately owned. These controls have proved increasingly inadequate.
Many of the most fragile areas, such as lakefronts, have already been subdivided, and houses have been scattered over hillsides and ridge tops, degrading the park's "unique open space and wilderness character," as Gov. Mario Cuomo describes it.
This decline of the park during the past 20 years has undermined the quality of life of the people who permanently live there, the economy of the people who work there and the recreational and spiritual enjoyment of the millions of people who visit there yearly.
Three years ago, Governor Cuomo appointed a commission, at least half of whose members were from the Adirondack region, to figure out how best to cope with the increasing pressures on the park and at the same time to help its chronically depressed economy, which has kept per capita income the lowest of any rural area in the state.
The Governor found the commission's recommendations regarding the park and its economy too strong and politically too hot to handle. But after two years of political give and take (mostly give by Governor Cuomo), he came up with a proposal of his own that would have at least protected shorelines and made a start on what the park and its residents need if its values and their livelihoods are to be enhanced.
Early this week, however, the Assembly approved a much more comprehensive bill that has the backing of the Speaker, Saul Weprin. It would give needed support to permanent residents of the region through community development, would strengthen protection of the shorelines and back country and would establish an Adirondack Trust Fund.
Passage of this bill would be something to celebrate for the park's 100th anniversary. The Legislature established the park, and now it has the opportunity to insure its survival.
But the Weprin bill won't get to first base unless the Republican leaders decide that what happens to the Adirondacks is not a local issue -- like, say, Plattsburgh's sewer system -- but of lively concern to the people of New York State and beyond: those who live in it, those who work in it, those who visit it and those who love it.

HEADLINE: As Bishops Meet, Catholics Voice Differences With Church's Doctrine;
Little Hope Seen for Letter on Women

BYLINE: By ARI L. GOLDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 18

 BODY:
The chairman of the committee of Roman Catholic bishops that has worked for nine years to draft a pastoral letter on women said after a divisive debate among the bishops today that it would take a miracle to pass the letter when it came up for a final vote in November.
"We're going to give it a try, but that's going to be a miracle," said the chairman, Bishop Joseph L. Imesch of Joliet, Ill. 
 Pastoral letters, which require a two-thirds' majority of the country's 286 active bishops, are formal teaching documents that in recent years have dealt with how to apply the doctrines of the church to current issues. In recent years, the American bishops have adopted letters on war and peace and on the economy.
The effort to draft a letter on women has proved to be the longest and most difficult of these exercises. Other letters have been passed usually with only a few negative votes, and no one here could remember a case where a letter had to be abandoned.
Bishop Imesch's pessimistic assessment of the letter's chances of passage was reinforced at the end of the debate when the president of the body, Archbishop Daniel E. Pilarczyk of Cincinnati, asked for an informal vote to determine whether to continue the discussion on the document when the bishops meet in Washington in November. While a majority of the bishops stood as a sign they were in favor, Bishop Imesch said it was clearly less than the two-thirds' majority that will be needed to adopt the document.
The third draft of the 81-page letter on women, which Bishop Imesch said was going to be the last, has tried to steer a moderate course between the demands of the Vatican and the voices of American Catholic women pressing for change. The document condemns sexism as "a moral and social evil," but follows Vatican dictates denying women ordination to the priesthood and condemning abortion and contraception.
An earlier draft, calling for a discussion on whether women can serve as priests, was rewritten after objections from the Vatican, which refuses to entertain the question. The revised draft allows for dialogue only on including women in lesser ministerial roles like deacon and acolyte.
 
Sentiment Against Letter
 Today was the first time in the process that the full conference of bishops had an open debate on the draft.
In introducing the third draft to his colleagues, Bishop Imesch acknowledged that it has forged "a unique alliance" of those on the left and the right against the letter "while not satisfying women's groups at either end." Still, he urged the bishops to look favorably on the effort, and added, "Do we dare say we have nothing to tell Catholic women?"
While many bishops like Joseph Cardinal Bernadin of Chicago called for adoption, bishops on both ends of the spectrum in the debate said it would be best to bury the letter now.
Bishop John R. Sheets of the Diocese of Fort Wayne-South Bend, Ind., said the document failed to "alert the faithful" to the dangers of feminists who see God as both male and female and deny the maleness of Jesus.
Bishop Elden F. Curtiss of Helena, Mont., agreed, saying, "Radical feminist theology is a sin." Other conservative bishops criticized the draft for giving women "the false hope" that they could be ordained as deacons by inviting a discussion on the subject.
At the other end of the spectrum was Bishop Charles A. Buswell, the retired bishop of Pueblo, Colo. He not only called for dialogue on women in the ministry but also on their ordination.
Bishop Buswell said the pastoral letter should be dropped because it deals more with "our own concerns and the concerns of the Vatican than the concerns of women." He added that the church itself was guilty of sexism "in denying half of its membership" the priesthood.
Other liberal bishops did not go as far as to call for the ordination of women, but they too called for the dropping of the letter because it did not go far enough in dealing with the concerns of women.
Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland of Milwaukee faulted the letter for not measuring up to the intellectual standards the bishops set in earlier letters.
But Bishop Austin B. Vaughan, an auxiliary from New York, criticized the document for being too weighty. "If I can use the current political rhetoric, this document is addressed to the intellectual elite," he said, "and that's not what we need at this time."

HEADLINE: RUSSIA AND I.M.F. FAIL AT AN ACCORD

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 19

 BODY:
Negotiators for the International Monetary Fund ended a round of talks with the Russian Government today after failing to win Moscow's compliance with several harsh demands for changes in its economy in return for billions in foreign loans.
Officials involved in the talks said that several major issues remain unresolved and that the next round of talks could occur early in July, before President Bush and the leaders of the other major industrial nations hold their annual economic summit. This year, the meeting will be held in Munich, Germany, and is to be attended by President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia. 
 Neither the Russians nor the I.M.F. commented publicly on the talks, beyond the statement of an I.M.F. official that "progress continues to be made."
But with most of the I.M.F. team members returning to Washington over the weekend, there was a feeling that an agreement was unlikely before the Munich meeting, and that the talks could spill over into August.
 
U.S. Frustrated at Delays
 Delays in the talks have been a source of open frustration among Bush Administration officials, who have begun calling on the I.M.F. to ease some demands on Russia and not delay an aid agreement provided Russia commits itself to broad changes.
In Washington this week, Russian and I.M.F. officials appeared to recognize that the Munich summit meeting might occur without an I.M.F. agreement.
Michel Camdessus, the fund's managing director, and Yegor T. Gaidar, Russia's Acting Prime Minister, issued a joint statement Thursday saying that the two sides were "in basic agreement on the crucial objectives of an economic strategy."
The Bush Administration has publicly pushed for an agreement ahead of Mr. Yeltsin's arrival in Munich on July 8 to meet with Mr. Bush and the leaders of the six other major industrial nations -- Britain, Germany, Canada, Japan, France and Italy. But today the Administration seemed resigned to the possibility that this might not happen.
A senior Bush Administration official in Washington said in a telephone interview today that while the Administration "very much wants an agreement to happen by July 6, not having one would not be fatal."
 
Asks I.M.F. to Ease Demands
 The official added that although the Administration had asked the I.M.F. to ease up on some of its demands, it was not asking the fund to compromise its standards so that Russia could become eligible for a $24 billion aid package.
An I.M.F. stamp of approval is also supported by Washington and Moscow to encourage foreign investment in Russia, which Mr. Yeltsin described this week as even more essential than the $24 billion in aid.
"What we are feeling, particularly after Mr. Yeltsin's visit to the United States, is that as soon as possible, we want an agreement," the Administration official said. "We are saying to the I.M.F. that if you can come to a solid agreement that addresses the fundamental issues, that is important."
Specifically, he cited the need by Russia to reduce its budget deficit, keep tighter controls over its money supply and establish a fixed exchange rate for the ruble so that the Russian currency can readily be exchanged for dollars or other western currency in international money markets.
The most significant remaining obstacle to an I.M.F. agreement, according to Western and Russian officials, involves the money supply and the exchange rate.
 
Questions on Ruble
 Some 13 republics of the old Soviet Union say they intend to use the ruble as their currency for the time being, and the I.M.F. insists that all agree to adhere to a common monetary policy -- preferably one that keeps interest rates high, loans hard to get and as few rubles in circulation as possible.
With such measures in place, the ruble's value in relation to other currency presumably would rise, and the ruble could then be exchanged for dollars and other hard currencies at a stable rate. Achieving a stable exchange rate is viewed by the I.M.F. as the first step to foreign investment, because profits from such investments could then be converted to dollars and sent home.
Endorsing the I.M.F. approach, the Yeltsin Government has asked the republics to agree by Sept. 1 to a single monetary policy, with the Russian central bank probably calling the shots.
Among them, only Ukraine is openly opposed to a monetary policy run from Moscow, but its opposition is considered a big problem.
The Yeltsin Government does appear to be on the verge of fulfilling its promise to declare a single exchange rate for the ruble by July 1 -- one that would replace the half-dozen rates now in use.
These range from 130 rubles to the dollar on the black market down to 55 rubles to the dollar that the Government gives to exporters for some of their hard currency earnings.
The unified rate is expected to float initially at about 120 rubles to the dollar. The Government would buy dollars from Russian exporters at this rate and sell them to importers to pay for foreign goods. This would also be the conversion rate to pay the interest on foreign debt and to repatriate profits from foreign investments.

HEADLINE: Rival of Haiti's Ousted President Is Installed as the Prime Minister

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, June 19

 BODY:
Marc L. Bazin was installed today as Haiti's Prime Minister in a ceremony that was attended by many of this country's leading politicians and businessmen but shunned by foreign diplomats and supporters of the deposed President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
Mr. Bazin, a 60-year-old lawyer and former World Bank official, was appointed to the post over Father Aristide's objections by Haiti's army-backed Provisional President, Joseph Nerette. 
 In a gesture that Haitian officials said is intended to leave open the possibility of Father Aristide's eventual return as President, Mr. Nerette resigned from office with the swearing in of Mr. Bazin. Father Aristide, Haiti's first democratically elected President, was overthrown in a violent army coup in September.
In his inaugural speech, given in a sweltering, chandeliered hall of the National Palace, Mr. Bazin declared that his mission was to "take up anew the dossier of negotiating a national solution acceptable to all the parties."
"We will be ready to meet the Rev. Father Jean-Bertrand Aristide, no matter where, no matter when, and without any reservations," he said.
United States diplomats and officials from the Organization of American States, which imposed an embargo on Haiti in October, have insisted that no internationally acceptable solution to this country's crisis will be possible without first allowing Father Aristide a say in forming a new government.
Speaking today in French Guiana, Father Aristide repeated his opposition to Mr. Bazin, a longtime political rival who placed a distant second in the December 1990 elections.
Foreign diplomats and Haitian political analysts said eventual acceptance of Mr. Bazin as Prime Minister was further called into question by irregular voting procedures used to secure his nomination in the Legislature. Mr. Bazin's nomination was approved last week by less than the majority of senators required by the Constitution.
In an interview at his home on Thursday, Mr. Bazin repeatedly stressed his aim of ending Haiti's diplomatic and commercial isolation as well as its violent political divisions by restarting negotiations with Father Aristide and the O.A.S.

HEADLINE: Senate Votes to Extend Jobless Aid, Creating Another Bush Veto Threat

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 19

 BODY:
Setting up another showdown with President Bush on a touchy election year issue, the Senate voted today to prolong benefits automatically to the long-term unemployed in times of recession.
The Senate measure, which was passed by a voice vote, would not raise taxes to pay for the benefits, as would a more expensive version passed on June 9 by the House. But a senior White House official said Mr. Bush would veto either form of the legislation, not only because he considers both too expensive but because he opposes making a permanent change in the unemployment insurance system now. 
 Should the President carry through with the threat, hundreds of thousands of unemployed people could lose their benefits after July 4, when the current extension expires.
Since many of the recently unemployed come from the middle class, Democrats say that Mr. Bush could suffer political damage if he vetoes the bill. But Administration officials counter that because the President is willing to extend benefits in less costly package, it will the the Democrats who ultimately take the blame.
 
Compromise Foreseen
 In the event of a veto, however, both sides foresee negotiations to come up with compromise legislation.
The Senate bill would extend the current unemployment benefits until March 6, 1993, and would automatically continue payments as long as the national unemployment rate remains at 7 percent or more. The number of weeks of benefits -- 33 or 26 depending on a state's unemployment level -- would be reduced once the unemployment rate fell below 7 percent for two consecutive months. The bill would cost the Treasury $5.4 billion over five years, but it includes tax collection provisions that would more than offset the costs by 1998.
"The hard human evidence of recession requires us to respond," Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who is the principal sponsor of the bill, said during the floor debate. "So despite some positive signs the economy is on a gentle upswing, the situation remains grim for 9.5 million unemployed Americans. And the need for this new legislation is clear."
A senior White House official said the Administration was willing to consider permanent changes in the unemployment system but needed more time to study various options. Speaking of the Bentsen bill, he said, "We think it costs too much money. If they want the veto fight, they'll have it. It won't do them any good politically, and it won't help us either."
Before approving the Bentsen bill, the Senate rejected by voice vote an alternative proposed by Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, which would have provided up to 20 weeks of extra coverage through January 2, and up to 10 additional weeks through March 6. At that point, unlike the Democratic versions, the program would have terminated.

 
Bills Must Be Reconciled
 Before it reaches the President's desk, the Senate bill must be reconciled with a House version that differs in a number of ways. While the Senate would give states the right to waive the additional benefits, the House bill sets an automatic national standard that would replace the current system of irregular extensions of benefits with one granting at least 13 weeks of benefits in states where the unemployment rate is 6 percent or higher.
In recent days, White House officials have spoken with Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader, to discuss possible compromises. But today, Senator Bentsen and Representative Thomas J. Downey, the Long Island Democrat who was the chief author of the House bill, said they were in no mood to settle for less than permanent changes.
"If George Bush wants to tell unemployed workers to drop dead after July 4, that's his problem," said Mr. Downey. But he added that should the President veto the bill, the Congress would send him back another bill "with one or two accommodations."
Mr. Bentsen, in a separate interview, said he had been ready to compromise with the White House but "they did not come with any serious offer until we already passed the bill through the Finance Committee." The Texas Democrat said he was still hopeful the President would not veto the legislation.
Should the Administration be accommodating, Democrats are more likely to send the President the Senate version. A blanket veto threat, on the other hand, is likely to attract the more generous House version.
The Senate version attempts to avoid raising taxes by accelerating the collection of corporate taxes and penalties on withdrawals of money from individual retirement accounts and other annuities. But the House bill would reduce itemized deductions for high-income taxpayers by 2 percent for each $2,500 of adjusted gross income above $157,900 for couples who file jointly. It would also limit to $1 million the tax deduction a company could declare for wages paid to its executives.
The House version would raise the Federal portion of extended benefits from 50 percent to 75 percent. The Senate version retains the current 50-50 ratio.

HEADLINE: Yeltsin's Bandwagon Rolls Into Canada to Cheers and Applause

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OTTAWA, June 19

 BODY:
Stopping in Canada after his visit to the United States, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia was welcomed here today as a man of "courage and purpose" and won commitments similar to those obtained in Washington for more trade and investment.
The Russian leader, who arrived here on Thursday evening from his whirlwind tour of the American grain belt, spent a heady day visiting politicians, businessmen and just ordinary people and winning applause almost everywhere he went. 
 After laying a wreath at the National War Memorial, to the dismay of his security officers he took an impromptu stroll up Parliament Hill, telling one group of cheering onlookers, "I would like to embrace all the Canadians at once."
 
Speech Before Parliament
 In a speech before the Canadian Parliament, the Russian leader, continuing his plea for greater Western economic assistance to support democratic reforms, said he looks at Canada and realizes what Russia has missed because of its "nightmare of totalitarianism."
He noted similarities between the countries -- their vastness, multiculturalism and polar reach -- but said there are considerable differences in their living standards because of the damage that was done to Russia by 70 years of Communism.
While making no direct reference to Canada's unity crisis, Mr. Yeltsin said Canada's experiences in resolving differences between the central Government and the provinces hold great interest for Russia, itself rent by nationalist forces.
"We will be your students," he told the assembled legislators. The speech was punctuated with frequent applause and standing ovations, much as were his comments earlier in the week to Congress.
At a news conference, Mr. Yeltsin again called on the International Monetary Fund to be less demanding in the conditions it is setting for a big aid package and said his July 8 meeting with Western leaders in Munich will not be a success unless Russia is allowed to reschedule debts over the next two to three years.
Mr. Yeltsin has been invited to the economic summit meeting of the leaders of the seven most important industrial countries, as was Mikhail S. Gorbachev, as leader of the old Soviet Union, last year.
The Russian leader said he expects this participation to continue, making the Group of Seven a de facto Group of Eight.
As for the I.M.F., he told reporters and senior officials from both countries gathered at the news conference that the fund "cannot approach Russia like other countries."
 
Signs Economic Agreements
 "Russia is unique," he said.
Because of the magnitude of changes now taking place, he said, "it is impossible to go by the letter" on the various conditions the fund is seeking, like reduction of the Russian budget deficit to zero.
Although Canadian officials have recently pointed out that Russia has been falling behind on repayments of earlier credits to finance grain and other items, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and Mr. Yeltsin signed a series of agreements today that further extend Canada's economic cooperation.
In one of the accords, Canada grants most-favored-nation trading status toward the Russians, lowering tariffs to levels that already apply to other friendly nations. This parallels action taken earlier in the week by Congress.
Canada will also take these actions:
*Raise its technical assistance to countries of the former Soviet Union from $25 million to $100 million over three years. Russia gets two-thirds.
*Offer $200 million of insurance to companies planning investments in the Russian petroleum and construction industries.
*Provide technical assistance and promote investment to help Russia convert defense industries to civilian production.
*Set up a Yeltsin Democratic Fellowship of $10 million to train Russian managers in Canada.
*Give a three-year $30 million aid package to Russia and other countries from the former Soviet Union and East Europe to help promote safety in nuclear power plants.
"The attitude of the Government of Canada is to help Yeltsin succeed," Mr. Mulroney said, standing next to the Russian leader.

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels

 BODY:
Father's Day is here, and a lot of fathers aren't. The flight of fathers from the home is one of the great social changes of recent years -- a vast ozone hole in the family ecology.
There is a debate among those who find the causes and the cures of this change in economic forces, those who emphasize government policies and those who point to basic American beliefs and moral standards as well as everyday culture. It is simply inconceivable that a shift of this magnitude, or a sensible discussion of that shift, could occur without involving all these things. 
 In 1960, 8 percent of American children were living with their mothers as the only parent. Today that figure is 22 percent. Another 8 percent live with a mother and a stepfather, and 5 percent more are in some fatherless arrangement. In short, a third of the nation's children live apart from their biological fathers.
In 1960, 1 out of 20 births was to an unmarried mother. Today the figure is more than 1 out of 4. If a change of that proportion took place in atmospheric warming, the world's seaports would have been flooded and its farmlands turned into deserts long ago.
"Never before in our nation's history have so many children grown up without a father's presence and provision," David Blankenhorn, president of the Institute for American Values, a small New York research organization dealing with family issues, said yesterday at a Washington meeting.
Homes without fathers can be models of love and courage, but homes without fathers are also among the likeliest to be visited by poverty, domestic violence, juvenile crime and teen-age pregnancies. "If current scholarship proves anything," Mr. Blankenhorn has written, "it is that children who grow up without their fathers are worse off -- economically, educationally, psychologically, every way we can measure -- than children who grow up with their fathers."
Yet in all the comedy and commentary inspired by Vice President Dan Quayle's recent speeches on "family values," the bulk of attention has been focused on "single mothers" rather than on the real issue of absent fathers.
Actually, the bulk of attention has been focused on Mr. Quayle himself. His critics call his oratory polarizing, and they say his crusade in fact puts up obstacles to a serious discussion of the topic. And he is an easy target for those who would prefer to avoid it.
Mr. Quayle says the breakdown of family structure is primarily a matter of our culture -- we are "reaping the whirlwind of decades of changes in social mores" -- and secondarily a consequence of poor government policies. He says scarcely a word about the economy.
Mr. Blankenhorn, in fact, argues something similar. His favorite metaphor in talking about fatherhood is a "cultural script" -- a social story, a set of cues, an ideal character and a classic plot line that shapes, guides and at time pressures men into a certain sense of who they are and how they should act. Like the Vice President, Mr. Blankenhorn emphasizes the role of opinion leaders and cultural elites in telling or reshaping the "prevailing story of fatherhood."
But that analysis is a far cry from Mr. Quayle's stark picture of "two cultures -- the cultural elite, and the rest of us," the one upright, the other "guilt free," respecting "neither tradition nor standards" and believing that "all life styles are equal."
In reality, America has not one but a number of cultural elites: the universities, the national news media, the makers and brokers of popular entertainment like movies, television and music, the presiding geniuses of advertising, religious leaders, foundation executives and so on.
They each not only honor certain traditions, standards and ways of life and reject others (and are anything but "guilt free"), but they are also often quite antagonistic to one another in their prevailing values.
If Hollywood and Harvard converge to give a particular twist to our norms about family, fatherhood and marriage, the reason deserves serious analysis. As Mr. Quayle himself says, "a sneer is not an answer."
What has emerged is a war of sneers. As Mr. Quayle assails his critics in the "cultural elite," they accuse him of hypocrisy, pointing to the Administration's opposition to measures that might arguably shore up economically endangered families, or launching attacks on the rich kid from Indiana (who can't even spell "potato") lecturing the poor on their morals.
The effect of these attacks is to sweep the cultural questions about fatherhood and family off the public agenda. And it is not true that everyone agrees on those more philosophical questions about family norms, disagreeing only on the practical means to strengthen them.
Last month, Mr. Blankenhorn shared the platform at a New York political meeting with Betty Friedan. Both agreed on many things, but where Mr. Blankenhorn spoke of "fathers," Ms. Friedan spoke of "parents."
Asked whether children were better off with two parents, she said "at least two parents" and went on to endorse "all kinds of families" and family "support systems." Presumably, two women, two men or half a dozen of either might be as serviceable as a mother and father. Tomorrow should not really be Father's Day but Second Parent's Day.
Mr. Blankenhorn believes that such a vague "cultural script," in which gender-neutral parents are celebrated rather than mothers and fathers, is doomed to failure. Ms. Friedan puts a higher priority on avoiding all appearances of stigmatizing broken or nontraditional families than on the need for a clearly defined "cultural script."
Both are debatable positions. Both should be debated thoughtfully, along with other questions about sexual ethics, government incentives, economic pressures. That discussion is not very likely in the atmosphere created by the Vice President's speeches.

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Fall on Interest Rate Outlook

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday, depressed in part by a belief that interest rates will not fall anytime soon.
The price of the Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond fell 11/32 point, or about $3.44 per $1,000 in face amount. Its yield was 7.83 percent, up from 7.79 percent late Thursday. 
 Bonds were initially helped by a report from the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, which said its monthly economic index declined in June. Signs of a sluggish economy generally produce higher bond prices because they improve the chances that the Federal Reserve Board will ease interest rates.
But the impact of the Philadelphia report was short-lived. Bond prices fell in part because of comments from a Fed governor, who suggested interest rates would not decline. The governor, Edward Kelley, indicated that inflation-fighting, not stimulating the economy with lower rates, would be the central bank's priority in coming months.
 
Hurt by Irish vote
 Bond prices were also dragged down by the approval of the European unity treaty by Irish voters. Concern over the fate of the treaty, which would create a common European currency, had caused some investors to move money from Europe to the United States bond market.
Another factor depressing bond prices was the rebound on the stock markets, which slowed the flight of money from stocks to bonds that occurred as stock prices declined in recent days.
In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, short-term maturities were 3/16 point to 5/16 point lower, intermediate maturities were 3/8 point to 13/32 point lower, and long-term issues were down 11/32 point, Telerate Inc., the financial information service, reported.
The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face amount.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 3.11, to 1,233.36
Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 3.72 percent. Yields on six-month bills rose to 3.88 percent. Yields on one-year bills climbed to 4.15 percent.98 percent.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was quoted at 39/16 percent, down from 311/16 percent late Thursday.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 9623-32, unchanged from Thursday. The average yield to maturity remained at 6.54 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Thin Trading; Gold Declines in New York

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced in thin trading on world currency markets yesterday amid fresh hope for European unity.
Gold prices fell after advancing in overseas trading. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $340.80 an ounce, off $1.80. The Republic National Bank said gold slipped $1.40 an ounce, to a late bid price of $340.70. 
 Traders said the dollar was supported somewhat from Ireland's ratification of the Maastricht Treaty, which outlines a plan for European economic and political union.
But the vote did not entirely eradicate the uncertainty created two weeks ago by Denmark's surprise rejection of the treaty.
"This vote hasn't really clarified that much," said Earl Johnson, a vice president at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. "Traders are now looking past it and saying what about France?"
France is expected to hold a referendum in September on the treaty, which would create a single European currency and a central bank.
Any indications of cracks in support for the treaty have led investors to buy German marks, since Germany is perceived to be the most economically independent nation within the European Community. Indeed, Mr. Johnson said that there would have been a huge movement into marks had the Irish rejected the treaty.
Meanwhile, other factors continue to limit the dollar's gains. Traders remain disappointed with the pace of economic recovery in the United States, and interest rate differentials still favor other currencies.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 126.92 Japanese yen, from 127.63 yen at Thursday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 126.90 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 127.00 yen, up from 126.80 yen on Thursday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.8595, from $1.8660 late Thursday. In New York, it cost $1.8590 to buy one pound, less expensive than Thursday's $1.8635.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.5730 German marks, up from 1.5670; 1.4195 Swiss francs, up from 1.4135; 5.2960 French francs, up from 5.2785; 1,190.25 Italian lire, up from 1,187.00, and 1.1973 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1985.

HEADLINE: The Rise and Fall of the Floral Tie

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

 BODY:
Father's Day fashion quiz: The bright floral-print tie you receive tomorrow will make you look:
(a) Out-of-date
(b) Floriferous
(c) Garnished
(d) Visible at night
(For answer, read on.)
Unlike most fathers, Bert Pulitzer will awaken tomorrow knowing that his gift won't be a tie. Mr. Pulitzer does not even need to buy a tie; he makes them. 
 This year, he can count himself among the lucky. The tie industry is undergoing a ritual fashion cleansing, and department store racks nationwide are dripping with the jetsam. The prime offender: those bright floral ties seen on men everywhere.
"They are finished," said Nonnie Moore, the fashion director for GQ, the men's fashion magazine.
Who is there to lament tie designs cruelly struck down in their prime? How mighty once the yellow power tie or the square-bottomed Rooster that so proudly crowed.
But even as the bright floral tie wilts under fashion's cruel gaze, the story of its creation, marketing and apparent demise remains vital if only because a few hours do remain to make suitable exchanges.
It seems almost ironic that Mr. Pulitzer, who will be relaxing tomorrow with his gift, should have played such a key role in the creation of the bright floral tie. But he is the first to admit it.
"We started florals in 1987," he said. "My wife, Betsy, said to me, 'You have to do florals in men's wear.' She brought in three old Oriental blankets, and those were the designs we started with."
Initially, these new and exotic designs by Bert Pulitzer Tiemakers commanded a heady price -- $52.50. But then some Italians, normally known for their impeccable taste in ties, stepped in and changed the course of history. "They are some mill owners in Italy that made brothers and sisters of our designs," Mr. Pulitzer said, using the trade term for copies. "The following season just about everybody had them."
It is not unusual for "everybody" to jump on a fashion bandwagon. But in the case of the bright floral tie, there were unfortunately more imitators than usual.
According to Robert Beauchamp, the fashion director of Esquire magazine, the forces of our nation's economic travails are impinging on the tie industry. Mr. Beauchamp said that suits are too expensive and people are buying ties instead. As a result, fashion companies are cranking out ties by the ton to try to make up the shortfall. "There has been an explosion of people doing ties," Mr. Beauchamp said.
Jerry Andersen, the executive director of the Neckwear Association of America, a trade group based in New York, agreed. "Ties usually perform well in a recession because it is the simplest way for people to upgrade their wardrobes," he said.
This type of competition can mean good things for the public, like cheaper ties. Last Father's Day, the bright floral tie was reaching the height of its popularity; the price began to plummet. Some were seen selling for as little as $37.50. Then this spring, the market collapsed. The current opening price at Macy's is $20, but the seriously interested are encouraged with a 50 percent discount.
That could be a signal for some to stock up. But even Mr. Andersen, whose job it is to say nice things about ties, has little hope for a bright-floral resurgence soon.
"As an association executive, I will never say that anything is dead, because I will get 27 calls from different people," he said. "But I would say that if the question is 'Is this where the direction is?' the answer is no."
 
Shrinking Shapes
 Those who receive a bright tie with a big geometric design tomorrow should not take heart from the bright floral tie's plight. As with many of the nation's industrial giants, downsizing is a popular theme among tie makers.
"The trend is toward neat little figures, little scenics," Mr. Pulitzer said, referring to squares, circles and others shapes that appear on ties. "A year ago they were three inches tall, now they are three-quarters of an inch tall. It was just overkill."
Speak to Ms. Moore of GQ about this trend toward traditionalism and her enthusiasm is visceral. "We think ties today are fabulous," she said. "We are showing updated versions of traditional reps, with two or three stripes. But they have new colorations like apricot with navy, not like the old ties where the colors were boring."
Yes, but even these updated versions of the classic rep may seem pale and tired soon, so the truly conservative gift giver might want to consider other options like cologne, golf tees or a metal toothpick.
As for Mr. Pulitzer's gift, Betsy Pulitzer is willing to share the secret: "Our daughter is going to give him a book about fly-fishing."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 25, 1992, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on the Consumer's World page on Saturday about neckties misidentified the company with which Bert Pulitzer is associated. Since 1987, Mr. Pulitzer has been the design director of XMI, a label owned by TBS Marketing Inc.; he no longer has any connection with Bert Pulitzer Tiemakers.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House;
President Portrays Himself As Best Choice for Economy

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., June 19

 BODY:
One day after Ross Perot drew a rousing crowd in this bastion of conservatism, President Bush sought today to persuade skeptical Orange County business executives that he could best lead the nation to economic recovery.
 Mustering the power of his office to press that point, Mr. Bush announced that he would rescind a Federal rule that officials said would mean millions of dollars in savings each year for contractors converting technology to nonmilitary use. In a further attempt to make the case that he offered more than words, he waved a copy of a plan that he said was a roadmap for controlling Federal spending. 
But not every member of the Industrial League of Orange County, an business advocacy group, was swayed. While they crowded into a hotel ballroom in Irvine for Mr. Bush's luncheon speech, nearly every audience member randomly interviewed said he or she voted for the President in 1988 but was now torn between him and Mr. Perot, the Texas billionaire who is an unannounced independent candidate.
 "I supported Bush in the past, and I think the jury's still out," said Stan Taeger, a Republican who runs a high-rise property management company here. "I've been disappointed with what Government has been able to do with business and the economy. It might be time for someone else to try, someone who's really a businessman running the country."
 
'Strange Year'
It was not long ago that a Republican business executive would never dare admit to harboring an interest in a contender outside the party. But as Mr. Bush put it today, this is a "strange year," a year when the troubled economy has driven even staunch party loyalists to look for an alternative.
 After ticking off his usual economic remedies -- from passage of a line-item veto to a budget-balancing amendment -- Mr. Bush acknowledged that the economy has been particularly bad in California. Essentially, he told his audience that they should trust him to see the economy through to better days.
 "In California, as everyone in this room knows, it is a challenging time," he said. "It's been a tough time. But you've risen to the challenge before." He said "defense conversion puts Orange County back in the business of job creation, a skill that you mastered in the 80's with the high-tech start-ups that made this area famous."
 Senator John Seymour, a Republican from Orange County who met with Mr. Bush today, said in an interview that the popularity of Mr. Perot here could be linked directly to the economy. "He's a big threat," he said of the Texan. "I blame much of the Perot factor in California on a very painful, very painful recession. When people are hurting, they're going to strike out against whoever's in charge."
 In private meetings with Republicans here over the last two days, officials said, Mr. Bush was bluntly warned that the economy and Mr. Perot posed serious threats and that winning California might be hard for him in November.
 Mr. Bush sought to reassure the executives that he, too, was a businessman at heart.
 "Forty years ago I did start a business," he said, "and that made me, I think, have some sensitivity and understanding what it means to take risks, to meet a payroll and to add to the productivity of this great country."
