HEADLINE: Too Few Benefit from Monopolies in the Skies

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 I take exception to several conclusions that you and many of the experts you quote reach in your May 22 Economic Watch article on the airline industry battle for dominance of the skies.
 In 1978, Congress deregulated the airlines to allow a natural formation of highly competitive industry, encourage new entrants, create jobs, increase airline efficiency, hold down costs and make it cheaper to fly. What you call consolidation, and I term creeping monopolization, has halted entry by new carriers and sabotaged established carriers in deregulation and entrants (of the 14 relatively alarge new airlines estabished since 1978 only America West survives). The industry is losing jobs -- 150,000 in the last four years. Productivity and profits among the three major carriers are low and sinking lower; revenues are not keeping up with costs.
 I think readers will recognize that we need more competition, not less. I would also take issue with the following areas in your assessment:
 *To hold up Southwest Airlines as the little engine that could paints an incomplete picture. Southwest has indeed achieved one of the lowest cost structures in the industry, a record America West has matched. But neither America West nor any other airline has the leegislatively mandated advantage Congress gave Southwest in 1978, with the Wright amendment.
 Southwest profits significantly from the monopoly it has created at Dallas Love Field. Its fares in the Texas market are considerably higher, compared with those elsewhere in its system (particularly on routes also served by America West.) With artificially high profits from Texas passengers, this "special advantage" as you call it, contributes roughly $75 million to the bottom line annually and allows Southwest to subsidize its operation in markets where it competes with other carriers or loses money. Without this legislative monopoly, Southwest would be losing money like everyone else.
 Southwest has driven ticket prices on competitive routes way below cost. The carrier will continue to subsidize predatory pricing conditions in other markets as long as it holds onto its monoppoly at Love Field.
 * Rapid growth has been cited by many as a major contributor to the downfall or financial problems of a number of airlines, including America West. But America West, like Southwest and others, found that the only way for the smaller lines to survive was to grow beyond our original market niches. The more sucessful we were with new routes and new markets, the fiercer the competition was to grow or be swallowed up.
 * The competitive advantages conferred on the Big Three -- American, United and Delta -- by frequent-flier programs, computerized reservations systems and landing slots are hardly water over the dam.
 The proprietary Sabre and Apollo computerized reservations systems contribute $400 million annually to the bottom line for American and United, and offset losses from ticket sales. America West alone contributes more then $3 million a month to revenue transfers. Add to that the booking advantages and incentives built into the system, and you have an overwhelming cost advantage, a formidable barrier to entry and a dangerous concentration of air traffic in the hands of a few carriers.
 * The argument that competition among relatively few airlines will keep prices in line with costs is folly. It hasn't happened yet -- performance and profitability are down, and prices in no way reflect costs -- nor is there any indication from the United States oil and gas, automobile and steel industries that it will. Industrial consolidation has meant a market closed to innovation, job creation, productivity and fair pricing.
 * Optimism about new entrants is misplaced. Of the 14 large airlines formed after deregulation in 1978 only America West survives, and it operates in Chapter 11. Sure, the industry makes room for new entrants, but it penalizes those that become too big, too successful or too aggressive. By restricting access to airports, the large airlines quash those entrants who attempt to compete on the more popular routes.
 Monopolies represent and protect inefficient industries. Unless the Government uses its antitrust powers to preserve the airline industry's competitive integrity, the result will be even less efficiency, higher fares, fewer passengers, and, ultimately, re-regulation. And that's something no one wants.
 
EDWARD R. BEAUVAIS
Chairman, America West Airlines
Phoenix, June 1, 1992

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Boise, Idaho;
Home -- and Corporate Expansion -- on the Range

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

DATELINE: BOISE, IDAHO

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH it was already mid-afternoon, the cafeteria at the 220-acre regional campus of Hewlett-Packard Company, on a grassy plain just outside of this midsized city, still reverberated with the buzz of talk.
The need for working space has grown fast at the regional campus here, said Don Curtis, general manager for the company's site operations in Boise, as he walked a visitor through the building. The vast cafeteria is doubling as conference space until a 180,000-square-foot building -- the seventh to go up since the Boise campus opened in 1973 -- is completed in the fall. 
 What is happening at Hewlett-Packard is the norm rather than the exception here these days.
The city is becoming increasingly attractive as a business environment because of its high-quality labor pool, low crime rate and relatively inexpensive land and housing. And retail construction has also been booming ever since a regional mall was built in 1988.
In the last five years, Micron Technology, which develops electronic memories for computers, has added 650,000 square feet to its 250,000 square feet of headquarters space and leased 100,000 square feet of manufacturing space downtown.
In May 1991 it bought an additional 197 acres for $2.2 million and in October it took an option on 110 more 110 acres, all adjacent to its existing campus in the southeast section of town.
The sites are all on grassland over which cowboys traditionally drove their herds. Today, the fence around Micron's swelling headquarters limits those drives, acting as a sort of symbolic arena where the old West confronts the new.
Moreover, Micron, aware that so many companies and developers in town are also contemplating expansion, recently created a new subsidiary called Micron Construction to bid for the work.
Little wonder, then, that cranes are beginning to outnumber corrals in this 40-square-mile city.
"I've seen more construction cranes in the last five years than I saw in the previous 30," said H. Wayne Gibbs, Boise's director of planning.
For a city that used to be the butt of jokes -- for its never-ending supply of sagebrush, sheep and potatoes -- Boise has come a long way on its contemporary journey from spuds to semiconductors. It is yet another example of the 90's economic miracle of middle America, reflected in the transformation of similar cow towns like Sioux Falls, S.D., and Omaha.
A record $125 million worth of commercial construction is due to be completed in Boise in 1992, the fifth year that the figure has been around $100 million, according to the Boise City Planning Department. In the mid and early 80's such construction rarely topped $35 million.
Between 1988 and the end of 1991, 6.5 million square feet of space was put up, more than doubling the retail space and adding 20 percent to the commercial space.
MOST of the new buildings low, with four stories or fewer, and covered with a sandstone-like stucco that blends easily with the city's rim of caramel-colored hills.
Some are further shielded from sight behind high banks of grass, a response to strict environmental regulations that characterize the attitude towards growth of a latecomer like Boise.
The $125 million in construction for 1992 represents a broad mix of office, research and development and retail space, virtually all of it being built to suit. What is missing is the speculative space that doomed commercial property markets elsewhere.
"We're too small to interest the spec builders," said H. Larry Leasure, chairman of White Leasure Clark Company, commercial brokers in Boise.
Moreover, during the bustling 80's, when that sort of development was popular, he said, all three of Boise's base industries -- farming, mining and lumber -- were depressed. Further dampening speculation was the stubborn refusal of the city fathers for almost 25 years to approve a regional shopping mall unless it was downtown. The major national retail chains refused to come to town unless the mall was built in the suburbs along a highway.
In 1987, a new administration finally compromised, with a million-square-foot regional mall called Boise Town Square approved for the very edge of the city. By then there was such a pent-up demand, said Mr. Leasure, that the first mall spawned spin-off malls around its perimeter.
Micron Construction, for example, is to be the general contractor for the expansion of Franklin Towne Plaza, a 328,000-square-foot shopping center owned by Gary Hawkins, a local retail developer. To be completed later this summer, it will add 58,000 square feet of retail space and fulfill the continuing demand by national chain stores for a presence in Boise.
The extension will provide Mr. Hawkins with his favorite kind of retail complex -- something he characterizes as a "category killer." It consists of large warehouse-sized spaces favored by high-volume discount retailers.
He likes them, he says, because each company take lots of space and is willing to prelease before construction. And they sign leases of about 20 years with predetermined annual increases, something a smaller shopkeeper is unlikely to do.
The retailers say they are attracted to the space because it gives them access to the exploding population of Boise, which grew 25 percent between 1980 and 1990, from 102,000 to 126,000, and is still rising fast.
The office expansion is a result of the growth of locally based companies like Micron and Albertson's (a supermarket chain), the expansion of outside companies like Hewlett-Packard -- which is based in Palo Alto, Tex. -- plus the rising prosperity of local people and the companies that service them.
These companies say they like Boise because utilities are relatively cheap and the quality of life attracts and holds the best talent.
"Our people can be on the ski slopes in an hour," said Mr. Curtis of Hewlett-Packard. "We've got rivers, lakes, mountains. The housing is still affordable. The cultural events are accessible. The crime is low. Boise's the way American was. It keeps people here."
Then there is the caliber of labor. "A lot of the people here come to us from farming and ranching," said Nick Edwards, plant operations manager at Micron, "and that makes them hardworking. We can attract a lot of outsiders, too."
Indeed, people like to remark that every time there is an earthquake or a riot in California the job applications start rolling in, with Boise -- with its low crime, big sky, colorful outdoor cafes, river walks and balmy climate -- looking more and more like Camelot.
BUT even paradise has drawbacks. From a commercial property standpoint, problems are arising in the number of small shops that now lie empty both downtown and along neighborhood strip centers. These vacancies are a direct result of the drawing power and discount potential of the malls.
Older office space has been equally wounded, said Mr. Leasure, by the glamorous new office buildings that the increasingly prosperous local companies have been seeking. As a result there is an overabundance of B and C space, which keeps rents as low as $10 a square foot, including services, a figure that has hardly changed in 10 years. The glut has also affected Class A space, keeping those rents under $20 a square foot.
All of which provides welcome ammunition for the folks who are lobbying for a cap on further growth -- people like the residents of a condominium next to St. Luke's Medical Center who are protesting a nine-story hospital expansion because it will include a four-story parking garage beside their backyard.
"We know we have a great thing going here," said Mr. Curtis. "You can't blame us for wanting to hang onto it for just a little longer."

HEADLINE: Merchants vs. Blind Vendors: A Battle Over Feeding Rights

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
SUNLIGHT poured through the windows of the State Department of Labor's employee cafeteria here while a steady stream of state workers bearing plastic trays picked up a sandwich here, a soft drink there.
At a row of tables near the windows, solitary diners removed cellophane-wrapped lunches from brown paper bags. In the center of the room, clusters of employees, their meals finished, chatted or played card games to fill the time before they would have to return to their desks. 
 For Henry Ingra, a 39-year-old blind man who manages the 165-seat cafeteria, the audible bustle of satisfied customers was music to his finely tuned ears.
But just three blocks away, in the offices of the Trenton Downtown Association, an organization of retailers, the success of cafeterias like Mr. Ingra's has evoked a different reaction. For the retailers, the idea of scores of state workers' spending their lunch hours indoors on a pleasant afternoon spells nothing but trouble for the local economy.
Those divergent perceptions have led to a battle between Trenton's merchants and the blind vendors who manage all but one of the 15 food service areas in public buildings scattered throughout the capital.
"What they're trying to do is just put us out of business," said Mr. Ingra, referring to recent demands by the retailers' organization that state officials close all employee cafeterias and snack bars in public buildings in Trenton. "We've been in this city for over 50 years, and nobody ever complained. But now that the good times are gone and some of the big companies have moved out, they're blaming us for their problems."
Mr. Ingra, who has been legally blind since birth, is president of the Blind Vendors Association, which represents the 65 blind men and women who manage cafeterias, newsstands, snack bars and vending machine locations in public buildings across the state. The association has collected 10,000 signatures on petitions to keep the cafeterias and snack bars open.
Robert Ricci, on the other hand, who is executive director of the Trenton Downtown Association, represents more than 200 commercial and professional establishments in the capital. Mr. Ricci's organization maintains that the blind vendors have hurt local businesses by making it a little too convenient for state employees to stay in their buildings during lunch hours rather than being out in the streets patronizing restaurants and stores.
The association recently commissioned a $10,000 study that concluded that the potential economic impact of the blind vendors' food services on merchants, restaurants, the City of Trenton and the state itself amounts to nearly $10 million a year.
"We're saying that the creation of this cafeteria space has provided these vendors with an unfair competitive edge against the private market through the use of public dollars," Mr. Ricci said.
At the core of Mr. Ricci's argument is the fact that the blind vendors pay no rent for the spaces they occupy. Nor do they pay for any of the equipment, like ovens and tables and chairs, or even for some supplies, like cups, plates, knives and forks.
"It's a turnkey operation; they literally walk right in," Mr. Ricci said. "That's some piece of change they're saving, sailor."
 
Operate Under 1937 Law
 The vendors operate their businesses under a 1937 state law that allows blind people retail space in public buildings rent free and sell prepared food, prewrapped sandwiches and other snacks to employees and members of the public who use the buildings.
Mr. Ingra says that the Business Enterprise Program, as it is known, provides blind people with meaningful employment, keeps them off public assistance and allows them to function in a sighted world with a greater sense of dignity.
"It creates the situation where you get employed and stay employed," he said. "You don't have to bounce around from job to job."
Currently, Mr. Ingra said, there are 14 blind vendors in public buildings in Trenton, including those who run two full-service cafeterias -- the one he runs in the Department of Labor building and another in the building housing the Department of Environmental Protection and Energy. The remaining locations are snack bars or vending machine locations.
 
Convenience for State Employees
 And though the blind vendor program clearly benefits the vendors themselves, Mr. Ingra said, it is also a convenience for state employees because it gives them a choice of staying in their buildings to eat -- including the chance to "brown-bag" their lunch and eat it in the cafeterias or snack bars -- or going out to restaurants.
Mr. Ricci, however, sees a trend. "The Labor Department building also has a little store in there, where they sell stockings and cards," he said. "What's the next step? Are we going to put a tire place in there so you can have your tires changed too?"
The state workers, he said, are receiving a hidden "fringe benefit" that was never contemplated when they were negotiating salaries and benefits.
"Where is it that the government stops baby-sitting and wet-nursing the employees?" Mr. Ricci said.
The blind vendors, he said, have an unfair advantage over restaurants in that the money the vendors save by not paying rent and other expenses can be passed along in the form of lower prices to customers. The cafeterias, he said, can afford to sell food at 20 to 50 percent less than ordinary restaurants.
 
Retailers Advocate Closings
 Mr. Ricci's organization recently called upon state officials to immediately close all the cafeterias and to phase out seven snack bars over a three-year period.
And though officials have not yet made any response to the demand, the blind vendors feel that the state is complying with the association's demands in a subtle though no less damaging way.
"The state says it's not closing anything, but their track record doesn't indicate that," Mr. Ingra said. In fact, he said, two cafeterias have already been closed -- the one in the State House Annex that Mr. Ingra managed until last year when it was closed while the building was being renovated and another in the old Legislative Office Building across the street, which is scheduled to be renovated.
Mr. Ingra said officials had no plans at this point to provide cafeteria space in either building when the renovations are complete.
In addition, Mr. Ingra said, a snack bar in the old Division of Motor Vehicles building is also scheduled to close once the division's new building is ready for occupancy. The new building, he said, will not include a new snack bar.
 
Concern About Finding Work
 Andrea Bartow, a 41-year-old blind woman who runs the snack bar there, said she was concerned about her ability to find another job when the snack bar closed.
"I guess I'd have to do like everybody else and go on an unemployment line," Ms. Bartow said, while greeting customers from behind her cash register, which announces the amount rung up. Most of the people who eat in her 40-seat snack bar, she said, bring their own lunches, while the snacks, soft drinks and coffee they buy provide her with a decent living.
"We're just trying to give a good service for the people in the building," Ms. Bartow said. "Nobody's tying their hands to keep them in the building."
Some state employees say the concerns voiced by the retailers association may be misplaced.
"I think they're being greedy," said Julia Roman, a Department of Labor employee. "And I don't think it would help them that much even if they closed these places. People would just eat at their desks. I can't afford to pay $5 or $6 every day to eat out."
Beatrice Leon, a co-worker, agreed.
 
Retailers Complaints 'Exaggerated'
 "The lunches out there are very expensive," Ms. Leon said. "But here, for $2 or $3, I can get a good meal."
Ron Parent, the assistant supervisor for the Business Enterprise Program in the State Division of Human Services, said the retailers association's complaints are clearly exaggerated.
"I find it hard to believe that 14 blind vendors keep 13,000 state employees in their office buildings at lunch time," Mr. Parent said. "It seems to me that they're just blaming downtown Trenton's economic conditions on us."
Meanwhile, Mr. Ingra said: "I'm constantly looking over my shoulder because the building I'm in is being renovated floor by floor. I've asked what's going to happen when they get to this floor. But so far I haven't gotten any answers."

(Photographs by Chet Gordon for The New York Times) (pg. 4)

HEADLINE: Guardian of the Newest Wildlife Refuge

BYLINE: By ELISABETH GINSBURG

DATELINE: VERNON

 BODY:
THE skunk cabbages that dot the swampy sections of the Wallkill River flood plain were already as big as beach balls. Fiddlehead ferns, coveted by urban gourmets, were poised to unfurl, and yellow-and-black-striped tiger swallowtails fluttered over them in twos and threes.
Fifty years ago, trains passed by this lush growth on tracks running parallel to the river. And on a recent afternoon, Sylvia Pelizza walked along that old railroad bed, pointing out wildlife and plants, and spoke about preserving them. 
 Ms. Pelizza, a 32-year-old Pueblo Indian, is the manager of the still embryonic Wallkill River National Wildlife Refuge in Vernon. Her goal, and that of her employer, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, is to "preserve and enhance" the Wallkill flood plain and adjacent uplands as a wildlife habitat.
The reserve is a Federal project, but it will become an integral part of New Jersey's "greenway system," a state plan to protect natural resources and foster economic development in northwestern areas of the state.
As it now exists, the refuge consists of about 190 acres of land, an avalanche of documents and a series of continuing negotiations. Ms. Pelizza, who is the youngest refuge manager in the Fish and Wildlife Service and one of only a handful of women in similar positions, will oversee its expansion and help to develop a management plan for the next three to five years.
If all goes smoothly, the Wallkill preserve will eventually encompass 7,500 acres along the Wallkill River, stretching from New Jersey northward into Orange County in New York State.
As early as the 1700's, the Wallkill River flood plain was referred to as "the drowned lands." The predominantly soggy topography (which makes it especially desirable as a waterfowl habitat) has, in the past, been both an asset and a liability.
Early settlers could not cultivate much of the rich soil because of heavy spring flooding. Damming eventually lowered the water table, but legal wrangles between millers and farmers that arose from that damming took a large part of the 19th century (1826 through 1871). Afterward, the New Jersey section of the fertile flood plain was used for growing corn, hay and other crops.
During centuries as an active flood plain, the Wallkill Valley protected itself from development. Now as industrial and residential building encroaches on the area, it is no longer immune from such activity.
 
Fifth One in the State
 By the late 1980's, the Fish and Wildlife Service began taking steps to make the Wallkill Valley flood plain (and adjoining lands) the fifth national wildlife refuge in New Jersey. The others are the Cape May National Wildlife Refuge and the Edwin B. Forsythe National Wildlife Refuge at Cape May, the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge at Basking Ridge and the Supawna Meadows National Wildlife Refuge at Salem.
Recently, as Ms. Pelizza drove along the eastern perimeter of the refuge, she pointed out properties already acquired for the refuge and those still in private hands. The acquisition process may take up to 25 years, because acreage is acquired only from willing sellers. This means that even a property replete with the black ducks, redheaded woodpeckers and bog turtles that the Government seeks cannot become part of the refuge until the owners want it to.
But when landowners have the will to sell, the Government sometimes lacks the means to buy. In such situations, nonprofit organizations like the New Jersey Conservation Foundation and the Trust for Public Land buy specific tracts within the proposed refuge area and hold them until the Fish and Wildlife Service can find funds to cover the price.
"The first piece of land was an old dairy farm," Ms. Pelizza said. The acreage, which was put up for sale at a 1989 sheriff's auction, was sold to the New Jersey Conservation Foundation. The Fish and Wildlife Service finally bought the parcel from the foundation last January.
 
'We'll Keep the Good Barn'
 In a era when tales of wasteful government spending abound, Ms. Pelizza points to an example of thrift on the old dairy farm. Two barns stand on the property, one a solid structure, the other in an advanced stage of dilapidation. "We'll keep the good barn and use it as a storage space for equipment," she said.
The dedication ceremony for the Wallkill Refuge was held on May 2 at the West Valley Sports Club in Vernon. Ms. Pelizza drove to the club, which is slated for inclusion in the preserve. The club, she said, has two years to relocate (a Government-assisted process) before the property will be converted to its eventual use.
As she strolled through a pristine soccer field close by the river, Ms. Pelizza said that the field, which floods naturally each spring, would probably be underwater for most of the year when it belongs to the refuge. Reaching the muddy river bank, she spotted a profusion of raccoon tracks and spoke about the possibilities for public access to the area.
"There may be fishing and limited hunting," she said, noting that the hunting of waterfowl will probably be prohibited.
Like the raccoons, some refuge denizens make themselves scarce when humans are around. Ms. Pelizza has seen evidence of bears as well as the animals she most hopes to see -- bobcats. Neighboring farmers hear coyotes howl in the night, and abird watcher in the area has seen a barred owl (which is classified as endangered).
Like the waterfowl that will stop at the refuge on their spring and fall treks, the new manager migrated to New Jersey from distant parts. Ms. Pelizza was born in New Mexico a family of outdoor aficionados. After high school, she enrolled in pre-veterinary studies at the University of New Mexico.
A change in her major, to wildlife management, enabled her to take advantage of a Government-sponsored "co-op" program that enabled students in that field to combine course work with actual job training. After graduation, program participants are placed in Fish and Wildlife Service jobs.
Ms. Pelizza's first job, at the Attwater Prairie Chicken Refuge near Eagle Lake, Tex., changed her life, she said. She met a Fish and Wildlife Service biologist, Charles Pelizza, who became her husband. She also experienced a high-humidity environment for the first time and learned to tolerate it.
The couple pursued their careers, working at refuges in California, Delaware and Michigan. More than once, they faced the problem of finding two management jobs on the same refuge, or at least on nearby refuges.
The opportunity at Wallkill turned the Pelizzas' career paths in different directions. Mr. Pelizza took a job as a biologist with responsibility for New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania refuges, and Ms. Pelizza became manager of the Wallkill refuge.
"It's worked out well," she said. "I'm more managerial, and he's more field oriented." Both commute from a home in Pennsylvania, sometimes to the same place.
Decisions about usage of various parts of the refuge will not be made until the management plan has been completed. Beginning next month, experts from diverse fields -- biologists, land management, public access and the like -- will convene to assess, plan, discuss, argue and ultimately concoct a scheme for optimum use of the land. All usage must be consistent with the primary purpose of the refuge.
Now, like one of the fledgling birds it seeks to protect, the Wallkill Refuge is poised for takeoff. As Ms. Pelizza stood on a ridge watching a pair of turkey vultures swoop over a faraway pasture, she said, "There is no feeling more exhilarating than being part of a brand-new refuge."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Sylvia Pelizza, manager of Wallkill River National Wildlife Refuge in Vernon. If all goes smoothly, the preserve will eventually encompass 7,500 acres along the Wallkill River. (Photographs by Frank C. Dougherty for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Price Wars Are Not Good For Profits

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
All across America last week, money managers typed lower numbers into the spreadsheets on their personal computers and concluded the personal computer industry is in trouble.
When the smoke had cleared, Compaq Computer had lost 13 percent of its market value, Apple was down 18 percent, Dell had lost 33 percent and AST Research had shed 17 percent. The market value of the four had dropped by $1.9 billion in the week. 
 The reason for the decline was simple. Compaq said it would introduce a line of "aggressively priced" personal computers. Compaq, responded an executive of mail-order discounter Dell, "will not out-Dell Dell." Dell's margins, he said, will shrink.
The reaction reflected a belief that a battle of the titans is under way on the pricing front, with small competitors to be crushed as profits vanish for all. An index of six makers of I.B.M. clones was down 18 percent from its 1992 high even before last week. Now it is off 33 percent.
"Wall Street focuses on sentiment, and right now it is incredibly negative," said Roger B. McNamee of Integral Capital Partners, who owned Dell going into the bloodbath and who bought more. Eventually, he argued, the fear of collapsing margins will be replaced with greed for the prospects of higher sales.
For the economy, the personal computer industry may be providing another warning of a sub-par recovery in corporate profits. Consumers are far from eager to spend, and many foreign economies are weak. That will put pressure on profit margins in many industries, and companies that try to raise prices on internationally traded goods are likely to prompt a surge of imports and lose market share rather than gain profits. The trade deficit is likely to keep rising.
The fate of the computer stocks also provides a reminder that the stock market has not been all that healthy of late, even if the Dow Jones industrial average had been making new highs until three weeks ago. Even with last week's drop of 69.01 points, to 3,285.35, the Dow is up 3.7 percent in 1992, but many stocks peaked in the euphoria of early January and have since been falling.
The good stock market of 1991 reflected hopes for a better economy, but it also helped to realize them by opening the door to capital for many companies that needed it badly. It has gotten harder and harder to sell initial public offerings, as was shown by the withdrawal of a planned $1 billion offering last week by GPA, the big aircraft leasing company. GPA has promised to buy billions of dollars worth of planes in coming years, and it needs more capital. It is in no danger of collapse, but it needs investors who are willing to bet that airplane prices will continue to rise as they have in the past.
Unfortunately, the saga of the personal computer makers is an indication that deflation these days is a bigger threat than inflation. The stock market might be healthier if the reverse were true.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Trembling in Japan and Mexico

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
It was rough for stock markets around the world last week. But it was especially bad in Japan and Mexico.
One market, Mexico, has been a high-flyer. Japan was just trying to lift its chin off the floor. But both, like markets around the world now, are vulnerable because of economic uncertainty and coming elections. 
 In Tokyo, the Nikkei index of 225 stocks fell to new 1992 lows as it settled to levels not seen since the fall of 1986. The Nikkei index is down 57.6 percent since the market hit its all-time high of 38,915.87 on Dec. 29, 1989.
The market, the worst performer in the world this year, had rallied after slumping to 16,598.15 April 9. But last week it was undermined again by a sluggish economic outlook, a government that seems unwilling to provide some stimulus, expectations of sharply declining earnings and political uncertainty as key Japanese elections approach.
And although the Nikkei rallied 473 points to close at 16,519.87 on Friday, the outlook for Japan is still glum, even more so than in other weakening markets. The economy is not recovering as fast as hoped, so earnings expectations are crumbling. The French and British markets fell last week for similar reasons.
According to the Institutional Brokers Estimate System in New York, earnings in Japan are projected to drop for the third year in a row in the fiscal year that ends in March 1993. This would be the first three-year decline since World War II. The estimates as of last week showed a decline of 1.4 percent for the year ending in March 1993, compared with drops of 19.9 percent in 1992 and 2.7 percent in 1991.
To make matters worse, the estimates keep falling. In February, the earnings of the companies in the Nikkei index were projected to increase 1.3 percent. Since then, all the revisions have been downward. Rick Pucci, vice president at Institutional Brokers, said the pace of the decline was accelerating again in June. (The only reason the 1993 estimate has not declined even more is that it uses fiscal 1992 estimates for comparison, which were also were cut drastically.)
These numbers seem to be overshadowing one positive sign in Tokyo: that the nearly 60 percent fall in the market has exposed some stocks that are good values. "From a valuation point of view, the market looks good," said Mr. Pucci. "But the estimates are dropping at such a rapid pace that it is too early to get back into the market."
In Mexico, the outlook after last week's plunge is not as sour. Douglas A. Campbell, president of D. A. Campbell Company in Santa Monica, Calif., an institutional broker, said the 12 percent fall in the market over three days has made it a little more attractive because it is less overpriced.
The 5.9 percent fall on Wednesday -- the sharpest one-day decline since 1987 -- was an abrupt turnabout for the stock market that was the best performer in dollar terms in the Financial Times world index in 1988, 1989, 1990 and 1991 and the second-ranked market this year. Although the market rose on Thursday and Friday to close at 1,686.25, it was still down 7 percent for the week.
The Mexican sell-off was prompted by concerns that included the slow progress of free-trade negotiations with the United States and objections raised to an agreement by Ross Perot, the likely independent candidate for U.S. President. The projected economic benefits of such an agreement have provided much of the fuel for the tripling of the Mexican stock market's value over that last 18 months.
In addition, the Mexican Government has been raising short-term interest rates, always a bad move for a stock market, to slow growth and curb inflation. With billions of dollars in new stock issued and billions more waiting in the wings, the market is glutted.
Most important, the market was undermined by a 12.5 percent drop in its premier stock, Telefonos de Mexico or Telmex, the privatized telephone company.
Telmex accounts for about 30 percent of the Mexican Bolsa index and about 30 percent of the market's capitalization. "The Mexican market depends on a single stock more than any other market that I can think of," said Luis Luis of Scudder, Stevens & Clark in Boston. "It often accounts for over a third of the daily trades and is the only major Mexican company that is liquid in both the United States and Mexico." Telmex is traded as an American Depository Receipt on the New York Stock Exchange.
And Telmex seems to be held in what Mr. Luis calls weak hands, apt to sell quickly at any sign of bad news, dragging the market down with it, as happened last week. Telmex is owned by many investors and institutions that are not used to the volatility of Latin American markets, he said. They have only bought the stock because they need some exposure to Mexico and it trades in New York.
The fall in Mexico has been especially hard on these new bettors, who came into the market as the Government raised interest rates to tighten economic policy and as many earlier investors, including Mr. Campbell, were becoming cautious and even taking some profits.
The market reached its peak on June 1, when the Bolsa index closed at 1,907.38. It drifted down since then and plunged last week. Those who bought the most recent Telmex issue of more than $1 billion worth of stock must not be pleased. The A.D.R. was issued at $56.50 and closed on Wednesday at $45.375. Even with a two-day rally since then, Telmex is just back to $47.75. The example of Telmex is a warning to investors interested in any popular market where one stock can play such a dominant role.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Temperature Is Rising for Mr. Brennan

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
When Edward A. Brennan took the helm of Sears, Roebuck & Company in 1985, the company's future seemed solid.
But it turned shaky as the retailing environment changed, forcing Mr. Brennan into the role of a cost cutter fighting a defensive battle. In the last few years, Sears slipped from its position as No. 1 retailer in the United States to No. 3, behind Wal-Mart and K Mart. And many shareholders have howled for the company's breakup to realize the value of its many parts, which include Allstate, Dean Witter and Coldwell Banker. 
 Things haven't gotten any easier lately. Last month, Mr. Brennan weathered a rocky annual meeting at which discontented shareholders showed surprising strength on a variety of issues. The company responded last week by loosening up a number of corporate governance rules. "It's a nice start," said one leading dissident, Robert Monks, adding, however, that more was needed.
Meanwhile, Mr. Brennan has been trying to cope in the last two weeks with charges by California and New Jersey regulators that Sears auto centers had duped customers.
The company's initial response -- denying the charges and calling them politically motivated -- was criticized by public relations and crisis management experts as not responsive to the consumer issue. Ultimately, Sears ran newspaper ads signed by Mr. Brennan pledging that the company would satisfy its customers.
Does Mr. Brennan, who is 58, feel like events are ganging up on his stewardship? He was philosophical in a telephone interview late last week. "I think that's part of the job," he said. "We have had a fairly full plate, and that seems to be the way things develop."
But he is not the only company chairman feeling the heat, he added. "The economy has been difficult for the last two years," he said. "It's simply a very busy time for everybody."
Maybe so, but his seat has got to be feeling a little hotter these days than the others.

HEADLINE: Czechoslovakia's Wall Street Brigade

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

DATELINE: PRAGUE

 BODY:
"Okay, you ex-Commies, let's rock and roll!" The voice of Axl Rose of the Guns 'n' Roses rock band boomed across Prague's vast Spartakiadni stadium, built to display the prowess of Communist athletes but now hosting a hirsute mass of newly capitalistic youths apparently intent on recreating Woodstock. Strobes flashed, fireworks flared, videos rolled. The jeans-clad Czechoslovak crowd seemed suitably wowed.
But a small group of neatly coiffed gentlemen in the audience displayed a certain ennui. Ex-Wall Streeters rather than ex-Communists, they were plainly finding it awkward to rock 'n' roll. 
 What else to do, however, on a spring night in Prague when you have left your wife and children behind in Manhattan or Connecticut, abandoned the likes of Dean Witter and First Boston in mid-career, and given yourself to a lonely existence devoted to the transformation of a Communist state into a market economy?
"We play tennis and we've started a basketball group, but mainly it's work, work, work," said Thomas S. Douglas, a former director at Prudential Bache. "This is a deal junkie's heaven."
Mr. Douglas, 43 years old, is one of a 15-member group of American bankers and financiers who have formed the Crimson Capital Corporation. (Yes, echoes of Harvard.) Spurred by a mixture of midlife crises, vague idealism and simple curiosity, the 15 have dumped Wall Street and the Hamptons for Prague and one-room homes at the Forum Hotel here.
Paid by the United States Government, they have since September been Czechoslovakia's deal makers. Their goal: to find buyers for the thousands of companies the nation is selling as it hurries toward capitalism, to expedite deals while insuring that the state gets a fair price.
"Having worked 20 years on Wall Street, I asked myself whether I could go to my grave having done just one thing or, having hit 40, should I try something else?" said Alistair Keith, a 45-year-old former partner at Brown Brothers Harriman. "And the thing that decided me when I came here was that, amid a total shambles, there was this incredible enthusiasm coming from actually helping to transform a country."
 
Americans in the Lead

 
 The relationship between the Czechoslovak Government and Crimson is unique in Eastern Europe; nowhere else have Americans managed to reach a position of such decisive influence in the conversion of an economy. Whether there will eventually be a backlash against what a populist politician might portray as an invasion by Uncle Sam remains an open question.
For now, however, the team's results have been dramatic, and the group is popular. Total foreign investment committed to Czechoslovakia over the past year reached $5 billion, including almost $1.4 billion from United States companies that had previously shied away. The pace of privatization overall raced ahead faster than elsewhere in the former Soviet bloc.
A report this month from the Privatization Minister, Tomas Jezek, underscored the warm relationship. It estimated that the team's Wall Street-honed negotiating skills had achieved improvements averaging 353 percent on the value placed by the Government on assets to be sold.
Among the companies with which the United States group has negotiated deals on behalf of the Czechoslovak Privatization Ministry are Philip Morris, which has agreed to pay $413 million for control of the Tabak cigarette maker; American Standard, which is paying $25 million for the Keramicke zavody Teplice toilet maker; K Mart, which has acquired the Prior & Maj department store chain for $118 million, and Coca-Cola's Australian bottler, which bought the Prazske soft drink concern for $89 million.
"Our culture is closing deals," said Mart Bakal, a former Drexel Burnham director who leads the Crimson team. "We reckon if we we can't get things done, why be here?"
But the very pace of these and other transactions raises questions of central importance to all former Soviet bloc countries as they seek to switch to market economies.
Will the disposal of large swaths of an economy to foreign corporations inevitably provoke a political backlash? What alternative is there when domestic capital is scarce? Will the Czechoslovak method of pushing for rapid privatization, ardently preached by Finance Minister Vaclav Klaus, be vindicated? Or do the more cautious methods of Hungary and Poland provide a better model for Russia as it too confronts the core issue of disposing of state property?
A recent United Nations Economic Commission report on Eastern Europe pinpointed these problems. "Where the balance lies between the advantages of foreign direct investment and the potential for an erosion of economic sovereignty which it entails . . . is something that still needs to be worked out," it said.
 
Is Faster Better?

 
 Already, within Czechoslovakia, sharp differences have emerged. Vladimir Meciar, the populist leader who was the big winner in Slovakia in the nation's elections this month, opposes Mr. Klaus's rapid economic reforms. These reforms include a mass sale of shares in 1,446 state companies to the public through a complex voucher system, as well as the sales to foreigners. Indeed, differences between Mr. Klaus and Mr. Meciar on various issues are so great that a break-up of the 74-year-old Czechoslovak federation has been suggested.
Even in the wealthier, more populous, Czech lands, there is opposition to Mr. Klaus. "The privatization process speeded by these U.S. financiers must be slowed or the whole country will be dominated by international conglomerates," said Zbynek Kozel, deputy international secretary of the center-left Social Democratic Party. "It's a dangerous sellout."
Despite such uncertainties, the United States has adopted a firm position: the faster privatization goes in Eastern Europe, the better.
"Czechoslovakia stands out because it is the place where large-scale privatization has reached take-off stage," said Robert Barry, the coordinator for United States assistance to Central and Eastern Europe at the State Department. "The problem with proceeding case-by-case as in Hungary, or in stop-go fashion as in Poland, is that you end up wasting a lot of time and money. Our assistance is going to flow to the places where most privatization is taking place."
In fact, of the $35 million that Mr. Barry said had been committed to the region this year by the United States Agency for International Development (A.I.D.), close to half has gone to Czechoslovakia.
Some of that money has in turn gone to pay for the services of the team of American financial experts. "I can't tell you what exactly we're making," said Mr. Bakal, "but it's less than a fifth of what we could earn in the real world." One estimate in Prague is that they are each paid $500 to $950 a day, although that must cover all their expenses, including hotel, food and travel. Also, unlike the Wall Street experience, they make no commissions on their deals, or bonuses for their work.
It was the initiative of Mr. Bakal, a 41-year-old Harvard-trained lawyer, that brought the group to Prague. After the collapse of Drexel -- from which he emerged unscathed -- and a spell as president of a computer company called Tigera, he was casting around last year for something new.
The uncharted economic territory of Eastern Europe lured him, and in Czechoslovakia he found unbridled chaos in the embryonic Privatization Ministry. There were just 27 employees, including drivers and secretaries, and all deals were being hammered out around a huge, typewriter-littered U-shaped table.
Two major deals -- the $6.4 billion sale of the Skoda automobile works to Volkswagen and the $44 million sale of Rakona detergents to Procter & Gamble -- had already closed. But they had left Czechoslovak officials with an uneasy feeling that they were out of their depth.
"We realized we needed financial know-how and that foreign experts could pass on something of tremendous importance," said Miroslaw Zamecnik, economic adviser to President Vaclav Havel.
But, as John Rogers, an A.I.D. official in Prague, put it, "How many Czechs can sit down with a tough U.S. or German corporate lawyer without getting taken to the cleaners?"
A deal, initially for three months, was struck between Mr. Bakal and Deloitte & Touche, the accounting firm that held an A.I.D. contract to provide financial expertise in Czechoslovakia. In effect, Deloitte subcontracted part of its work to Mr. Bakal. He proceeded to set up Crimson Capital (after his alma mater, Harvard), and gather a team to work for it.
"I felt it was a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to transform an economy and write the textbook as one went along," said Mr. Bakal. "I figured the chance of success was probably about 5 percent. But if we succeeded, we'd be big heroes; and if we failed, nobody would blame us."
On a personal level, however, it was not an easy decision. The move to Prague divided Mr. Bakal's family, leaving his wife and son in a newly acquired house on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, while he and his daughter searched out the dubious comforts of the Forum Hotel.
In similar fashion, Mr. Keith left his wife and two children in Manhattan, and Mr. Douglas, his family in Connecticut. Michael Gold, a management consultant, left his wife and two children even further way -- in Los Angeles. As a result, they all tend to work three or four weeks nonstop and then return to the United States for a five-day break.
Why embark on such a crazed life? "The big change from Wall Street is that you feel good about yourself," said Mr. Bakal.
And it does seem clear that their frenetic activity is making a difference. Conditions in the Privatization Ministry were initially terrible. Indeed, Mr. Keith was obliged to negotiate Coca-Cola's $89 million investment on a bench in a corridor. But as trust grew, the ministry provided a series of rooms with personal computers for the team to use. Mr. Bakal even attends weekly cabinet meetings where he advises ministers on the privatization process.
The Privatization Minister, Mr. Jezek, has been generous in his praise of Mr. Bakal's team. In his recent report, he said, "They have both greatly facilitated the privatization process and substantially improved the terms of the transactions."
The report added that the bankers had been successful in insuring that technical and marketing know-how was transferred to the Czechoslovakian companies, that as many jobs as possible were safeguarded, and that in a highly polluted country the new owners would move factories to sounder environmental policies.
Charles Jelinek-Francis, the Privitization Ministry's director of foreign investment, said Crimson is "taking us on the fastest road from here to there, which we believe is the only way to instill a capitalist culture."
 
A Need to Say No

 
 At first, the tough negotiating stance of Mr. Bakal's group caused alarm. "We'd spend all day saying no to offers from foreign companies that had expected a walkover, and the ministry officials would get very agitated because they did not want to lose the deal," recalled Mr. Douglas. "But in the end they saw it worked."
Stewart A. Halpern, who worked eight years in investment banking at the First Boston Corporation before coming to Prague this year to work with Mr. Bakal, recalled how he lured competition into one deal in order to substantially improve an offer that had already been approved by the Czechoslovak Government.
The initial offer, from Lekyam Murtaler, an Austrian paper maker, valued Czechoslovakia's largest paper distributor, Ospap, at $24.2 million. It also said staff at the company would be cut to 570 from 700 by 1994. But by luring a much larger West European paper maker into the bidding, Mr. Halpern said, he persuaded Murtaler to raise its bid to $34.4 million and to continue to use Czechoslovak mills as suppliers of 90 percent of raw materials for three years.
Such successes have gained recognition. What is happening in Prague, said Mr. Barry of the State Department, "is a model for the kind of thing we would like to do throughout the region." Mr. Jezek, he said, had recently asked for assistance to be continued for another year and money had been found for this purpose.
But he acknowledged that political problems had emerged. "Clearly attitudes differ between Mr. Klaus and Mr. Meciar over the pace of privatization, and it is hard to evaluate how this will evolve," he said. "Our own view is that a slowdown will create stresses and strains."
As for Crimson Capital, it is settling in for the long haul. Mr. Bakal does not think the current political tensions will slow investment because he is convinced any change in the status of Czechoslovakia would be peacefully negotiated. And he argues that any violent backlash against the rapid push to private enterprise, much of it foreign-owned, "is at least a generation away."
 
 
 
NEXT: ALL OF EUROPE
 For the men of the Crimson Capital Corporation, moving to Czechoslovakia amounted to an escape from Wall Street and an opportunity to do something more worthwhile than merely make money. "It was a chance to make a difference," said Bruce P. Bybee, who quit a job at Prudential Bache to join Crimson.
Which is not at all to say they have lost their instinct for business opportunities and profit. After close to a year in Prague, they say that their long-term plan is to turn their operation into a private investment bank working throughout Eastern Europe.
"We've developed a commanding position in international banking in this area of the world and the greatest knowledge base of businesses in Czechoslovakia," said Mart Bakal, head of the group. "Our intellectual assets are unique and the opportunities enormous, so sure I'd like to develop this into a private bank." He suggested this could happen within two years.
Up to now, Mr. Bakal and his colleagues have scarcely lived like private bankers. Every time they visit the United States, they must vacate their rooms at the Forum Hotel and stash their things in a basement. On return, there is a a new room.
"There are some real sacrifices," said Alistair Keith, a Crimson man from Brown Brothers Harriman. These sacrifices, including long hours, amount to what the Crimson group calls its "sweat equity." The sweat has produced a reputation. Mr. Bakal has had inquiries from from Croatia to Hungary about helping in the privatization processes there.
Of course, this reputation has been built at the expense of the United States taxpayer. The people at Crimson are being paid by the United States Agency for International Development. Is it right, then, that they should go private with the expertise they have gained?
"When advisers in a foreign country want to stay there and go into private business, I don't know if there's a clear answer as to whether that is a good thing," said John Rogers, an A.I.D. official. He declined to comment further.
For Mr. Bakal, however, there is no doubt that the opportunities will eventually require independence. "There's an enormous amount to do in other countries," he said, "and as investment bankers, our instinct is to take charge."
 
 
 
THE MAKING OF A DEAL IN CIGARETTES
 The Crimson Capital Corporation's essential contribution to Czechoslovakia has been to provide financial and negotiating know-how that has enabled the state to make far more money off its asset sales than it might have otherwise. Nowhere has this been more evident than in the sale of the Tabak cigarette manufacturer to Philip Morris.
Tabak is not a very profitable company. It made about $2 million in 1990. But it is large -- annual sales total about $176 million -- and it has a 55.7 percent share of the 30 billion-cigarette Czechoslovak market.
With cigarette consumption stagnant or falling in Western Europe and the United States, such a big share in a growing market carries a premium. Moreover, many Western cigarette manufacturers saw Tabak as an ideal base from which to export to Russia and central Asia.
An initial public tender was organized last October by Nomura International P.L.C. It attracted bids from Philip Morris, R.J. Reynolds and the French cigarette group Seita, among a total of seven offers for the whole of the company and four for a portion. The highest bid, from Philip Morris, valued Tabak's equity at $250 million, according to the Czechoslovak Privatization Ministry.
Intense lobbying of the Czechoslovak Government by several Western cigarette manufacturers now began. Sell all of Tabak? Only part with a a minority stake? By March of this year, the government, sensing the potential in such intense interest, decided to bring in Crimson Capital to help oversee the sale.
A revised tender was then organized by Crimson Capital with Nomura making clear that the state wished to cede control of Tabak and inviting higher bids. Philip Morris raised its valuation of Tabak's equity to $348 million and agreed to put a total of $413 million into the company, including modernizaton and a capital increase. The closest rival offer was from R.J. Reynolds at $291 million.
"We got an extraordinary price," said Mr. Bakal. "These kinds of multiples don't exist in the West."
Louis Camilleri, Philip Morris International's vice president for Eastern and Central Europe, would say only that "The bidding process was very open and transparent," adding that the company saw phenomenal growth potential in the East European and Russian markets.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/June 14-19

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL
 
Boris Yeltsin, Dove and Democrat, Comes to Call on Washington 

When Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin visited the United States last week, he came as a peacemaker and as a democrat. As a peacemaker, he entered into a nuclear arms reduction agreement of unrivaled proportions. As a democrat, he warned that democracy in Russia remains fragile. Mr. Yeltsin asked the West for aid. But freeing up the $24 billion America and its wealthy partners already pledged to help Russia become a market economy can only be done by the International Monetary Fund. In exchange for freeing the funds, the I.M.F. has demanded harsh changes, including a balanced budget in Moscow -- not even the United States is capable of that -- and removal of price controls on oil. Russia has not said nyet, but it has said not just now. Last week, the Bush Administration called on the I.M.F. to ease up or risk destabilizing Mr. Yeltsin's democratic government. The I.M.F. is not likely to act very soon.

The Maxwells' Serious Trouble
 
When investigators at Britain's Office of Serious Fraud arrested Ian and Kevin Maxwell, sons of the late media magnate Robert Maxwell, and Larry S. Trachtenberg, an American adviser to the family's businesses, it was part of a seven-month investigation. The charges included stealing from the Maxwell companies' pension funds and conspiring to defraud two Swiss banks. According to the investigators, $1.6 billion is missing from the Maxwell companies and funds. Inquiries will continue, the office said.

A Global Model of Slow Growth
 
The United Nation's blue-helmeted peacekeepers may be on the front line, but its army of number-crunching economists also do their part. Each year they feed data from 70 countries into a computer model and come up with their World Economic Survey and forecasts. The first global recession since World War II "will turn to recovery in the industrialized world this year,"said Barry Herman, a U.N. economist. But nowhere will growth be brisk. According to the survey, the U.S. will grow by 1.6 percent this year; Canada by 2.5 percent; Japan by 1.9 percent; and the industrial world as a whole by 1.7 percent. Eastern Europe and Russia "will continue with their difficulties," Mr. Herman said.

McDonnell Jettisons the Jumbo

For a cash-strapped company like the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to say it would bring out a new 500-seat jumbo jet in the midst of a global slowdown and a cutthroat shakeout among United States airlines, was a daring move, to say the least. But McDonnell failed to bring in a single order for its double-decker plane, and its primary investor, a Taiwanese group that included the Government, decided not to risk the $2 billion the company said it would need to do the development work. Last week, McDonnell announced it would delay its MD-12 program until next year. "All we're doing is recognizing the reality of the marketplace," said John Thom, a spokesman for the company.

The Fizzle in Buying American
 
Americans still love foreign-made goods, while recession overseas has dampened demand for American products, The result? The Commerce Department said America's trade deficit widened to $6.97 billion in April.

Is Detroit Inefficiency a Myth?

For all of Detroit's grumbling about foreign competition, a study by the Economic Strategy Institute in Washington said it costs the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation less than their Japanese rivals to build small cars. Ford can put together a set of wheels for $5,415 while it costs Chrysler $5,841. It costs Toyota $6,216 to make a small car. But critics contend America's overall advantage comes from a cheaper dollar, not more efficient plants. Toyota can still put together a car in less time any American company. And what about quality? "We did an evaluation," said Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., one of the study's authors. "The Japanese have a slight edge. Several years ago, per hundred cars, the Japanese had 100 defects, we had 500. Today we have 25 defects per hundred. The gap is narrower," he said.
 
Last week a British media company controlled by a group of Saudi Arabian investors made a cash bid of $3.5 million for the United Press International news service. It is up to the bankruptcy court to decide the outcome.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
Bellying Up to the Buffet
 
If you're going to dine at a Pizza Hut restaurant, it might be helpful to wear trousers with an elastic waistband. After testing the concept for four months, Pizza Hut, a unit of Pepsico Inc., began last week to offer all-you-can-eat buffets piled high with pasta, salads and pizza, for $3.99 at selected restaurants. The pastas and salads have been added to the menu to entice those who are seeking lighter fare. By the end of the year, Pizza Hut buffets will be tempting tummies and busting diets at 2,000 locations across the country. Initially, the buffets will be open for lunch, where Pizza Hut's business has been flat. Dinner buffets are expected to follow. "It is phase one of our effort to revitalize our dine-in business," said Steven S. Reinemund, Pizza Hut's president.

A Transition at Time Warner
 
Steven J. Ross, chairman and co-chief executive of Time Warner Inc., gained a reputation as a savvy deal maker with oodles of charm, a knack for managing creative people and a penchant for rewarding himself mightily. Mr. Ross made $78 million last year. But last week Mr. Ross informed Time Warner's stockholders that he would take an indefinite leave while he struggles to overcome cancer. Assuming Mr. Ross' duties will be Gerald M. Levin, Time Warner's newly elevated co-chief executive. But Mr. Levin has his work cut out for him. Mr. Ross was in the midst of finding foreign investors to help Time Warner reduce its huge debt. Wall Street believes Mr. Levin is up to the job. The company's stock opened the week at $106 7/8 and finished at $110 1/8.

And Next, Coals to Newcastle?
 
While the delegates were schmoozing in Rio at the Earth Summit about how to preserve the world's environment, United States Windpower Inc., based in Livermore, Calif., was busy making deals to sell its electric-power producing windmills to the Dutch. But unlike the wooden windmills native to the Netherlands, Windpower's machines are high-tech beasts big enough to scare off any Don Quixote. They have 100-foot wingspans. For about $25 million, Windpower will deliver 80 windmills to E.G.D., the Dutch power company.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
The Compromise on Urban Aid
 
After months of wrangling, Congress and the White House reached an agreement on an aid package to the nation's cities. The measure was approved last week in the Senate and the House. The package provides $1.3 billion for 360,000 summer jobs for youths in 75 cities. It also replenishes the coffers of the Small Business Administration and the Federal Emergency Management Agency for the $495 million they lent to repair property damaged during the Los Angeles riots and the Chicago flood in April. But like most compromises, this one was not universally liked. "It's not sufficient," said Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader.

A Cable Turnabout at the F.C.C.
 
One thing the Federal Communications Commission doesn't seem to fear is concentration of ownership of the media. Last week it voted 5 to 0 to allow broadcast television networks to buy up local cable television systems. The ruling overturns a 20-year ban on such activity. With revenues of about $18 billion, the F.C.C. decided, the cable industry can tolerate a little competition. But the vote created fear among the networks' historic partners -- the broadcast affiliates. The affiliates worry networks could bypass them by putting their best programming on their wholly owned cable systems. "What if my network now all of a sudden becomes my major competitor in the marketplace?" said Mick Schafbuch, general manager of KOIN-TV in Portland, Ore.

Productivity's Factory Factor
 
Overall productivity growth increased by 2.7 percent, the largest jump in two years, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said last week. But productivity fell by 1 percent in the nation's factories. "The numbers mirror the fact that manufacturing is still weak while services are strong," said Bob Bannon, an economist at Idea, a financial research firm in New York. "Manufacturing will turn around in the next three months."
 
The Recovery Pumps Iron
 
This recovery is certainly no Hulk Hogan, but it has at least a little muscle. Builders broke ground on new homes at an annual rate of 1.23 million last month. That was 11 percent higher than the April rate, the Commerce Department said, when housing starts fell by 17.3 percent. May's starts were the highest since February 1991. "There is a very definite recovery in place," said Edward Platt of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. But he warned the recovery will not be robust.

Supercollider Support Atomizes
 
In last week's confrontation in Congress between big science and the bigger Federal deficit, the deficit won. Congress voted to halt work on the $8.4 billion superconducting supercollider. The collider was designed to smash tiny atomic fragments into even tinier bits underneath the sands of Texas in an effort to understand how the universe is put together. More than 18,000 contracts have already been let out to thousands of companies. But while Congress saves money, industry may suffer, because some supercollider technology has commercial applications. "What we would be missing is the chance to build an infrastructure that would make superconductivity attractive in a variety of applications," said Richard Hora, vice president of energy business for the space systems division of the General Dynamics Corporation, one of three big magnet contractors for the project.

HEADLINE: When Trucks and Trains Unite

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

DATELINE: LOWELL, Ark.

 BODY:
For decades, trucking companies and railroads have eyed each other as enemies. Truckers in many cases convinced shippers that railroads only knew how to move big loads of grain, coal and other commodities long distances, while trucks, they said, could move most anything better.
Railroad executives grumbled but were unable to stem the onslaught, and trucking made huge inroads. Trucks now transport about 25 percent of the nation's freight, compared with a little more than 5 percent at the end of World War II; railroads move 38 percent of the freight now, down from nearly 70 percent just after the war. 
 Recently, however, some trucking companies and railroads have begun to make peace. Instead of battling, they have been forming alliances, and the alliances have been transforming the way freight moves. The movement began less than three years ago with the emergence of long-haul deals. A new thrust into short-haul freight, if successful, could bring a huge shift of cargo to the nation's railroads.
The agreement that started both sides rethinking the old rivalry was forged in October 1989 between J. B. Hunt Transport Services Inc., the nation's second-largest long-haul trucker, and the Santa Fe Railway, the country's seventh-biggest railway.
Instead of moving trailers by truck from Chicago to the West Coast, J. B. Hunt now hands them over to Santa Fe, which lifts them onto flat rail cars on trains dedicated to transporting containers and trailers.
While such handoffs were made in the past by specialized carriers, like United Parcel Service, no major trucking company before the Hunt-Santa Fe deal would turn over its freight-filled trailers to a railroad unless the customer demanded it. Most trucking companies, in fact, still compete fiercely with the railroads, even for coast-to-coast moves, where the railroads have been able to make inroads against truckers.
But the executives at J. B. Hunt, which now has similar deals with the Burlington Northern, Southern Pacific and Union Pacific, have taken a pragmatic stance: If a railroad can provide service as punctual and as good as trucking, why not move loads by rail?
"We're combining competitive strengths," Kirk Thompson, Hunt's president and chief executive, said in an interview at the company's new headquarters overlooking pastures and gullies here in the northwestern part of Arkansas. "It's a perfect joint relationship."
This year, 14 to 15 percent of Hunt's loads will move by rail, and the business has been growing so rapidly the company projects up to half may move that way in five years.
Most of the new business involves loads that have been taken from other trucking companies -- a trend that is forcing major competitors of Hunt, like Schneider National, to seek their own alliances with railroads.
Since railroads can move the trailers more efficiently, using less fuel and manpower, Hunt and its rail partners have been able to offer rates lower than regular trucking rates.
Graeme Lidgerwood, a trucking analyst for the First Boston Corporation, said truckers will face ever-mounting pressure from the railroads and truck-rail alliances because the cost of moving trailers long distances was so much lower by rail compared with using tractor trailers on the highway.
"The handwriting is on the wall," she said.
So far, Hunt has concentrated on the very long trips where railroads, by improving their piggyback service, have been picking up business
Next month, however, Hunt, in combination with Conrail, will take on the heart of trucking: trips of between 700 to 1,000 miles, which make up the largest portion of moves.
"No one has been able to find an economic way to do it so far," Paul R. Bergant, the executive vice president of marketing and general counsel for J. B. Hunt said.
With Conrail having developed the ability to have most of its trains arrive on schedule, or within minutes of the expected time, he believes that the two will be able to persuade shippers to take a chance and try a combination of rail and truck for distances that are now almost totally dominated by trucking.
If the venture succeeds, Mr. Bergant believes, it will cause a big shift in the way goods are now moved, with rail regaining freight that most rail executives believed had gone permanently out of their reach.
"We believe it will work, and we believe we're the perfect catalyst," he said.
When Michael Haverty, the president and chief operating officer of the Santa Fe Railway, came to talk to Hunt about an alliance in September of 1989, Hunt's top executives were ready to listen.
The growing reluctance of drivers to go long distances and spend weeks away from home was causing havoc within the industry. Turnover was so high that Hunt and other major trucking companies had to keep rigs idle because they could not find new drivers.
Even with big wage gains and new allowances for drivers to return home more often, Hunt still has a turnover of 150 percent a year, a common rate among carriers.
Tom Williams, vice president of Hunt's trucking-rail moves, recalled that not only did labor costs shoot up in the late 1980's, but insurance fuel and road taxes all soared too.
Also the rapid growth that had come under trucking deregulation in 1980, which led to the failure of many trucking companies locked into high-cost union contracts, was slowing. Hunt, which had seen its revenues swell in the late 80's, saw a leveling off as it entered the 90's.
On the railroad side, labor costs were tumbling as concessions by unions allowed companies to cut tens of thousands of jobs.
The industry had also put together a formidable weapon that could be used to compete against trucking -- high-speed, punctual trains that carried nothing but containers, mostly from steamship companies, and truck trailers steered to the railroads, mostly by shipping agents.
For years, railroads had provided high-quality service to a limited number of customers, like the Postal Service, where shipments had to arrive on time.
"There was relatively no margin for error," said Stephen H. Mitchell, a Santa Fe executive who now heads the partnership with Hunt, known as Quantum.
The problem , he said, was that even though railroads had vastly improved their performance, shippers were still doubtful.
"The time-sensitive shipment still moved on the highway," he said, "even though we had trains that could do it." To wean shippers from trucking, he added, "was a hard sell."
At the same time, however, it was becoming clear that for freight moving long distances, like between Los Angeles and Chicago, where trains with double-stacked trailers could make the run in about 50 hours, trucking had trouble staying in the race.
To make the same run as fast, trucking companies had to have two drivers in the cab so they could spell each other while keeping the truck moving with only short stops. But then it was becoming harder to get drivers to put up with such conditions, and the cost of such runs was rising because of the need for two drivers.
"The railroads were getting better," John E. Philp, the vice president of merchandise marketing for the Union Pacific, recalled, "while the motor carriers were having problems. This has driven them together."
And it appears customers are pleased with the new service.
Doug Ely, manager of transportation for the Kransco Group, which makes Frisbees, body-surfing boards and battery-powered cars for children, has found that shipping by a combination of truck and train saves about 20 percent in shipping costs. About one-third of his shipments move through Hunt.
"It's working real well," he said. The company said many of its shipments must arrive on time and that the intermodal trains now meet their schedules.
He also likes dealing with Hunt because the shipment will be handled by Hunt drivers on both ends. "It's one-stop shopping," he said.
The team effort has proved so effective that it has forced many major trucking companies to begin to search for partners.
"Motor carriers are coming to us," Mr. Philp said. "They are feeling the pressure."
Schneider National, the nation's largest long-haul carrier, has begun to move some of its Los Angeles-to-Chicago freight on the Southern Pacific railroad and will soon have an agreement with Conrail for short hauls.
"I'm pragmatic," Donald Schneider, the chairman of the Green Bay, Wis., company said. Railroad operating costs were coming down, he noted, while those in trucking have been rising again. Thus, he said, on certain long-haul moves, the railroads now have the advantage and trucking will have to adjust.
He estimated from 5 to 10 percent of Schneider's loads could move by rail by the end of this year.
North American Van Lines, the nation's sixth-largest trucking company, is in talks with Union Pacific, which could result in one of the most far-reaching agreements.
Unlike the agreements between Hunt and its partner railroads, which do not allow any other trucking company to participate, the North American Van Lines alliance with the Union Pacific would allow in other transportation companies.
For railroads, the new business is largely gravy since they do not have to make any significant investment to move the added freight. There is plenty of room on their tracks to add extra trains. But, as Mr. Mitchell, of the Santa Fe Railway, noted, railroads have expensive plant and overhead costs.
"We have huge fixed costs out there that we have to maintain," he said, "and we want to get as much freight as we can."
 
 
J. B. HUNT: A TRUCKING EMPIRE BUILT ON CHICKEN LITTER
 Johnnie Bryan Hunt is a classic Horatio Alger character who turned chicken litter into his first fortune and then used that money to build a trucking company that has become the nation's second-largest.
As the owner now of J. B. Hunt Transport Services Inc., Mr. Hunt, 65, oversees a fleet of 5,500 tractors and 12,000 trailers that streak across highways in 48 states and in Canada and Mexico. He is also worth about $250 million.
Mr. Hunt grew up in the Depression and left school at age 12 to help support his family. His first long-term job was to deliver lumber for his uncle -- but first he had to sell it.
"That was my master's degree in selling," he recalled in a recent interview.
He joined the army in World War II, providing him his first look at the world beyond his rural birthplace of Heber Springs, Ark. When he was discharged in 1947, he was 20 years old. He returned to work for his uncle, but after borrowing $10 from a friend, he went back to Little Rock to look for job and eventually became a driver for East Texas Motor Freight.
On his runs through rice-growing areas, he noticed that farmers were burning off the rice hulls after harvest. But he had what he considered a better idea: Why not use them for chicken litter, which he had sold as a youth? He raised $105,000 by selling stock, borrowed $35,000 from a bank, and in 1960 built a plant to process the hulls.
The first year, the J. B. Hunt Company operated at a loss. Johnelle, his wife, said that was one of the darkest periods in their lives because they had risked everything the plant.
But eventually the company prospered and became the world's largest poultry-litter producer.
By the late 1960's, Mr. Hunt began to look for another challenge.
In 1969, he bought a small trucking company of five trucks and seven trailers in Stuttgart, Ark., and moved it to Lowell, Ark. The company grew, but slowly, until the early 80's when the trucking industry was deregulated. The growth after that was explosive as it became much easier to get route authority to all 48 states.
Mr. Hunt said that throughout the 80's, the company grew largely by getting new business and then building its trucking operations to handle it, an approach, he said, that reflected his salesman's personality. Mr. Hunt, who is over six feet tall and likes to wear big Western-style hats with his business suits, has some simple rules for his success at selling. "I groom myself to be presentable. Polish my shoes. Get my stuff together. I call on people without an appointment. I never sit down. I stand there hat in hand, ready to go for the door."
"I never stay too long but try to leave two seconds before they want me out," he added. "That way they're eager to see me again."
