HEADLINE: At Work;
Legal Victories for Gay Workers

SERIES: First of two articles on gay and lesbian employment.

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
Gay activism has come a long way since those raucous evenings in the 1950's when a pony dancer used to jump onto the bar at a gay hangout in San Francisco and lead the crowd in choruses of "God Bless Us Nellie Queens." As the gay community prepares to celebrate its annual "pride week," which will culminate next weekend with marches in several cities, gay rights advocates say the effects of years of organizing and educating are finally being seen, nowhere more clearly than in the workplace.
Not only are gay men and lesbians variously stepping, sidling and leaping out of the closet -- according to personal style and the degree of risk they perceive to themselves -- many are no longer willing to tolerate the anti-gay policies and behavior endemic in some workplaces. "They are more willing to assert their rights than they ever were," said Paula L. Ettelbrick, legal director of the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund, a New York-based group that does test-case litigation. 
 Lambda just won a suit on behalf of a deputy sheriff in Florida who had been dismissed for being gay. In a Federal district court in Atlanta, a lesbian whose job offer from the Georgia Attorney General's office was withdrawn after she disclosed she had married her female partner in a religious ceremony won the right last month to challenge the agency's decision. And in Massachusetts 10 days ago, a ruling recognizing the legal standing of an unmarried heterosexual couple in benefit claims laid the groundwork for a challenge by gay groups.
Paralleling successes in litigation are incremental victories in state legislatures. The rights of gay people remain a "balkanization of protections," said Kevin M. Cathcart, Lambda's executive director. But since 1989, five states have included sexual orientation among the protected categories in their civil rights laws, bringing the total to six: Wisconsin, Vermont, New Jersey, Hawaii, Massachusetts and Connecticut, plus the District of Columbia. More than 85 cities now have ordinances forbidding job discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation.
And though the ultimate goal, a Federal anti-discrimination law, is likely to remain in its state of suspended animation at least until a more sympathetic political party moves into the White House, significantly more people are protected than they were when the first state law was passed in Wisconsin in 1982. "Besides the practical effects, there is the symbolism of the states," said William B. Rubenstein, director of the American Civil Liberties Union's National Lesbian and Gay Rights Project, which is litigating the Georgia case. "It's an implicit signal to Congress that a Federal law is more realistic."
Mr. Rubenstein attributes the acceleration of gains to the increasing focus on family issues among gay men and lesbians. "The AIDS crisis and the Sharon Kowalski case have made it clear for a lot of gay people the consequences of our relationships not being recognized by the law," Mr. Rubenstein said. "Hospitals have visitation policies for family members. A lover may not be considered a family member." After an eight-year legal battle with the family of Sharon Kowalski, a Minnesota woman who was left disabled by a car accident in 1983, her companion Karen Thompson was recently appointed Ms. Kowalski's guardian.
In the workplace, lack of recognition may not have life-or-death consequences, but it raises questions of fairness. Several groups report an explosion of calls from unmarried gay and straight employees interested in obtaining benefits for members of their households. Only a handful of companies offer benefits -- a form of compensation -- to nonmarried partners. "It's as if a job posting said, 'Lesbians and gay men: $30,000; heterosexuals: $40,000,' " Mr. Rubenstein said.
The demand for spousal benefits runs against a trend in business toward cutting benefits -- and against the might of conventional insurance plans. But the reason for corporate resistance gives gay-rights advocates cause for hope. "For most employers, it's not that they don't want to recognize gay and lesbian rights," said Ms. Ettelbrick of Lambda. "They find the arguments compelling, but they don't want to shell out."
But many companies face polite pressure from internal gay employee groups, and from heterosexual co-workers. "I see much more consciousness among straight employees," Ms. Ettelbrick said. Companies may eventually find that the price of the lock on the closet door is far too high.
 
 
 
A PATCHWORK OF JUDICIAL RULINGS
 The extension of rights to gay men and lesbians is a quilt of litigation stitched together issue by issue and jurisdiction by jurisdiction. Gay rights advocates got more fabric to work with earlier this month when a Massachusetts court ruled in favor of a heterosexual woman who filed for unemployment benefits when she left her job to follow her unmarried partner of 13 years to the site of his new business.
In the case, Reep v. the Department of Employment and Training, the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court ruled against the state's claim that only married people were entitled to the benefits. "They said you can't use marriage as a bright-line test," said Mary L. Bonauto, a staff attorney at Gay and Lesbian Advocates and Defenders, a Boston-based group. The court provided a list of factors to consider in evaluating the significance of a relationship.
Ms. Bonauto expects the ruling to be as significant as New York's landmark Braschi case, which allowed the lover of a deceased man to take over an apartment lease. "Now we have a building block in place to show that nonmarital gay and lesbian families also merit the protection of the law," she said.

HEADLINE: All About/Men's Fragrances;
Scents and the Modern Male

BYLINE: By TERRY TRUCCO

 BODY:
Men's fragrance is the classic Father's Day gift, particularly from wives and children stumped by what to buy for Dad. But while grateful for the annual sales boost each June, the men's fragrance industry is trying hard to take the seasonal spin off items like cologne, after shave and bath gel.
Manufacturers want to get men into the habit of buying fragrances. (Women currently buy 60 to 70 percent of all men's fragrances, often to wear themselves.) Fragrance makers are also exploring ways to persuade men to acquire wardrobes of scents, with different fragrances for evening, work and play. 
 Such efforts, fragrance makers hope, will inject a little life into a market that grew remarkably in the mid-1980's but has been flat for the last 18 months. Last year's estimated retail sales of $1 billion were in fact down four percent from 1990, according to Paine Webber, the investment firm.
Industry analysts credit this dip to the economy, which has been hard on luxury products. The spate of department store bankruptcies has also hurt the prestige end of the industry. Fernando Aleu, president of Compar Inc., which makes seven premium fragrances, estimates that bankruptcies have involved 586 of his company's prime outlets, or 25 percent of its customer base.
At the same time, manufacturers have lost profits with the increase in so-called diversions, premium products sold at a discount at mass-market outlets like drug stores and cosmetics emporiums, either with or without the blessing of the manufacturer.
The men's fragrance market, like the nearly $2 billion women's fragrance market, is also saturated with scents. Since 1978, when Ralph Lauren initiated the practice of splashy promotions with its Polo men's fragrances, more than 240 men's scents have been introduced, according from the Fragrance Foundation, an industry organization. At least 20 more scents for men are scheduled to appear this year, with names that include Enigma, Feeling Man, Safari for Men, Nautica (the bottle is shaped like a sail) and, this being 1992, Christopher Columbus.
The extremely sweet margin on a successful fragrance is the reason for this plethora of fragrance. Jack Salzman, a fragrance industry analyst at Goldman Sachs, estimates the gross profit margin can be as high as 80 percent for a successful prestige fragrance. Even when the market is flat, a fragrance can be hot. Calvin Klein's Eternity for Men, a three-year-old premium scent, had retail sales of around $38 million last year. "This market is more product-driven than sector-driven," Mr. Salzman said.
Yet the risks are high. "No one makes money the first year," said Andrew Shore, a cosmetics industry analyst at Paine Webber. "And it takes a year and a half on the market to determine if a product is a success." The failure rate of most cosmetics and toiletries is 90 percent, Mr. Shore added.
 
Promotions
First the Concept, Then the Fragrance
 The way a fragrance is introduced can be nearly as important as the way it smells. "You can have a great fragrance, but if it's not promoted, it won't go," said Mike Sweeney, vice president of sales and marketing with International Flavor & Fragrance, which produces fragrance ingredients.
Department stores are often reluctant to stock a new fragrance without a manufacturer's promise of advertisements, magazine scent strips and other promotional activities.
But an introduction with all the trimmings is costly. The initial promotional budget for Davidoff Cool Water, a leading European men's scent introduced here in September, was $6 million. And this year's budget could go up to $15 million with promotions tailored to individual department stores.
With increasingly aggressive promotions has come the practice of designing a fragrance around a concept. "In the past, the focus of a new product would be the scent," said Philippe Guerlain, president of Guerlain, the 164-year-old French perfume and cosmetics maker. "With the modern approach, it's the idea, which comes from top executives and the marketing department." Heritage, Guerlain's latest men's fragrance, which will be available next year, was designed as a classic, conservative scent "for a real man, who cries and eats sweets," according to its promotional literature. Bottle, packaging and name -- preferably something that can be pronounced by an international audience -- are central factors in building the product.
But a lavish launch does not guarantee success. The flashy introduction of Ralph Lauren's Monogram in 1985 included a party at Bloomingdale's, where salespeople dressed as butlers carried perfume bottles on silver trays. Industry members still aren't sure why the scent fizzled. "I don't think the name was exciting," said Annette Green, president of the Fragrance Foundation. "And the concept didn't appeal to American men. So much of fragrance is perception. If it doesn't fulfill your fantasies, it's not going to be a success."
 
Crossover Products
Male Versions Of Women's Scents
 The high cost of fragrance introductions is also responsible for a notable industry success -- men's versions of women's fragrances. Despite disappointments like Liz Claiborne for Men, Calvin Klein's Obsession for Men -- which helped popularize the genre in 1986 -- is still thriving, with sales last year of about $36 million.
"Using a name as an umbrella for men's and women's products is a brilliant concept," said Brenda Landry, a fragrance industry analyst at Morgan Stanley. "It spreads your ad dollar." It's also a way to keep new products in the stores. And since women account for most men's fragrance sales, the new products have names familiar to the audience scent makers want to reach.
Most women buy men's fragrances to give to men, but some actually wear them. Chanel's Egoiste, Eternity for Men by Calvin Klein, and New West, all light and fresh, are popular crossover fragrances. The latter proved so popular that its maker, Aramis, brought out New West for Women in a neat reverse. "Men's fragrances are good for women who don't want to stand out," said Allan G. Mottus, an independent industry analyst.
While women's fragrances often use exotic essences, men's are made from a smaller, predictable palette of woody, spicy and citrusy scents. "Attempts at experimentation with less traditional essences have not done well with men," said Ann Gottlieb, a fragrance authority who helped create Obsession and Eternity for both sexes. Ms. Gottlieb uses adjectives like fresh, green and bright to describe men's fragrances for the '90's.
But today's men's scents are more sophisticated than the single-note fragrances of the past, like bay rum or lemon. And men seem to want stronger scents. After shave, which accounted for 34 percent of men's fragrance retail sales last year, once dominated the market. But longer-lasting cologne now makes up 66 percent of sales, according to figures from Paine Webber.
 
Distribution
Prestige Brands at Discount Prices
 The financial troubles that beset so many department stores in recent years could change the way fragrances are sold. "The old channels of distribution are no longer in place," said Mr. Salzman, the fragrance analyst.
To increase growth and stem department store losses, manufacturers started selling more prestige products to duty-free outlets overseas at a discount. But much of this has found its way back into the United States, where it turns up in superstores, chain drug stores and cosmetics emporiums, among other places, priced more cheaply than at department stores. Department stores, in turn, have resorted to gifts as a way to make premium-priced fragrances more attractive.
Some industry analysts predict a growth in specialty retailers, like Cosmetics Plus and Cosmetics Center. "They don't want to give you an umbrella," said Mr. Salzman. "They just want to sell at a fair price." Men may be more likely to buy fragrance at such places or at the growing array of free-standing cosmetics boutiques, like the Body Shop, H2O and Origins. Men account for 10 percent of sales at Origins counters in department stores, according to the company, a division of Estee Lauder that sells natural skin products. But 20 percent of Origins' sales to men are at its boutiques in Manhattan and Cambridge, Mass.
At the same time, mass-market men's fragrance manufacturers are burnishing marketing strategies and promoting their products heavily. "Stetson is an example of a high-quality mass-market fragrance," Mr. Salzman said. "As mass-market fragrances get closer to prestige, the difference in price will seem way out of whack."
 
 
 
BLOND NO MORE
 Aging male baby boomers are creating a small but growing market for another type of grooming product -- hair color. "At one time, men were only getting color to match a hairpiece," said Dianna Reed Sandonato, technical director at Matrix Essentials, a hair products company. Now beauty salons even advertise hair color for men.
The hair coloring boomlet is driven by more than vanity, according to Diana Temple, an analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc. "Men need to look younger for work in this hay and age of corporate reorganizing and frequent job changes."
Last year, retail sales of men's hair color products were $120 million, up 16 percent from the previous year. Men's hair color services accounted for $510 million in salon revenues, up 40 percent from 1990, according to American Salon magazine. (Hair color for women accounted for $5.7 billion.)
The latest men's products are semi-permanent. Clairol Option Instant, a do-it-yourself treatment, lasts six to eight weeks.L'Oreal's new Technique Equa-Ton Homme is applied like a shampoo. "That way men don't have to be seen getting hair color," said Renee Tilton, a L'Oreal spokeswoman.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Origins, in Cambridge, Mass. (Rick Friedman for The New York Times); The interior of an Origins cosmetics boutique. (Rick Friedman for The New York Times); The fragrance counter in a Lord & Taylor department store. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

LENGTH: 2140 words

HEADLINE: Where They Stand

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
BOND had always mistrusted short men. They grew up from childhood with an inferiority complex. All their lives, they would strive to be bigger than others who had teased them as a child. Napoleon had been short. And Hitler. It was the short men that created all the trouble in the world. -- Ian Fleming in "Goldfinger"
The exact height of Ross Perot is still under debate. 
 "Six-two," said James Squires, Mr. Perot's press secretary, when asked about it.
"Very short," replied a young woman at Perot headquarters in Dallas, when someone inquired.
"O.K., we'll go with five-seven," amended Mr. Squires.
"Five-six," said Todd Mason, who wrote "Perot," a biography of the Texas billionaire. "I know because I'm five-six, and we're eyeball to eyeball."
Suffice it to say, Ross Perot may talk big about sissies and manhood and world-class campaigns, but he is the smallest major contender in a Presidential race in many years. He would just come up to the tie knot of President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton.
Mr. Bush is 6 feet 2 inches tall. Mr. Clinton's aides got the edge by saying their man is 6 feet 2 1/2.
Such quibbles are understandable. Height matters in a country that has elected the taller man in 18 of the last 22 Presidential elections.
And it has mattered since the Presidency was born. In his book, "Presidential Campaigns" (Oxford University Press, 1984), Paul F. Boller Jr. reports that just before George Washington took the oath of office, he asked advice at a dinner party about the titles under consideration for the first leader of the country: His Excellency, Elective Majesty, His Serene Highness and Elective Highness.
When Washington, who was 6 feet 2, asked about "High Mightiness," the other guests told him that the title would be all right as long as all of his successors were also powerfully built. But with a small man, they said, it would be ridiculous. (Washington finally decided on "Mr. President," much to the relief, no doubt, of most of his successors.)
Republicans and Democrats, flailing to cut Mr. Perot down to size, hope to emphasize the stature gap. As Torie Clarke, the President's campaign press secretary, noted mischievously: "I'm six feet tall, and I do have great visions, if and when there are any debates, of going over to give him a big pat on the head."
Political cartoonists are already having fun with the low mightiness of Mr. Perot. They portray him talking to opponents' knees, sitting with his feet dangling above the floor and sporting ears that are larger than his chest -- ears that are so big "he gets HBO for free," said James Carville, an adviser to Governor Clinton.
Walt Handelsman, a cartoonist at The Times-Picayune in New Orleans, said he loved to see Mr. Perot as "this little dictator in the White House, running around in a little Boy Scout outfit, giving orders to people." Mr. Handelsman has depicted Mr. Perot wearing a huge cowboy hat labeled "Perot popularity," with only his feet and ankles showing. They are tagged "specifics."
Mr. Perot, who has stood erect and thrown out his chest ever since he was a Boy Scout in Texarkana, Tex., does not seem concerned about his size. He told The Washington Post, "I never spent any time thinking about it."
Perhaps he agrees with Milton Friedman, the compact economist, who, when asked about his teaching sojourn among strapping Texans, quipped that he felt like "a dime amongst nickels."
Or perhaps, as Susan Estrich, who was Michael S. Dukakis's campaign manager in 1988, speculates, "Maybe your second billion eliminates any concern about your height."
Ms. Estrich believes that, while Mr. Perot's bragging and militaristic style may have hurt him with female voters, it has helped overshadow the issue of his size.
"If he was a short man who wasn't a man's man, you could say he was a shrimp," she said. "But I can't imagine calling Ross Perot a shrimp. I'd be afraid for my life if I did."
"Besides, Clinton's fat," she said. "So you have your choice between a fat man and a short man."
Unlike Mr. Dukakis and many other vertically challenged politicians, Mr. Perot waves away risers that would give him more height. With populist flair, he even complains about daises that put him higher than the audience.
Of course, Mr. Perot has a couple of inches on James Madison, who was the shortest President at 5 feet 4. And Mr. Perot's height has helped win him some friends in low places.
Mickey Rooney, the 5-foot-3-inch actor, who titled his autobiography "Life Is Too Short," said, "Mickey Rooney is supporting Perot." (Mr. Rooney likes to refer to himself in the third person.)
"If you're on the small side, everyone thinks you're pugnacious, but they're all Cary Grants at six feet," Mr. Rooney said from his home in California. "The Presidency is not a beauty contest. It isn't how big you are, my darling."
Belle Adler, a producer for CNN in San Francisco, who is 5 feet 1 and a director of the National Association of Short Adults, said that Mr. Perot was at the top of "our short list of candidates" and that, while the group would not endorse his platform, they would endorse "the platform he stands on."
But Mr. Perot's critics and rivals paint him as a man who has some ominous qualities associated with overcompensation for his height: they say he is a demagogue, a man with the potential to be dictatorial and authoritarian.
Elizabeth Drew of The New Yorker wrote that Mr. Perot has "the aura of quasi-fascism: Peron-style, or Mussolini-style fascism, with the hero-leader, backed by 'the people,' breaking down impediments to having his way -- all, of course, in their name."
Vice President Quayle has dubbed Mr. Perot "the temperamental tycoon," which conjures up an image of a child screaming in a highchair and banging his golden spoon.
"The record has been that short people who run for President are at a disadvantage when they do demonstrate qualities of great strength and fierceness and determination, because it's very easy to make the leap and assume they have a Napoleonic complex," said Michael R. Beschloss, who wrote "The Crisis Years: Kennedy and Khrushchev, 1960-1963" (Edward Burlingame Books, 1991). "It's very much like women who are strong are frowned at as aggressive, but in men it's considered attractive."
But in Mr. Perot's case, Mr. Beschloss asserted, it is not just stereotyping.
"He has an arbitrariness and an instinctive ability to act on the basis of his own will after consulting a wide array of people," the historian said. "He has a tendency to have excessive faith in his own powers of judgment. He's an iconoclast to the point where he doesn't take advice terribly well."
Washington has had its share of short, tyrannical personalities over the years.
When the late John G. Tower, the peppery Texas Republican lawmaker who liked to say, "My name is Tower but you can see I don't," was called "Shorty" by a Capitol elevator operator, the operator got early retirement.
David Myers, a psychology professor at Hope College in Holland, Mich., and Henry Biller, a psychology professor at the University of Rhode Island, wrote "Stature and Stigma" (Lexington Books, 1987) with Leslie Martel. The professors cite studies showing that in business, romance and politics, people tend to perceive a link between a man's height and positive personality traits.
"Not to get too psychological about this," Dr. Biller said, "but some of it has to do with looking up at daddy and assuming power and size go together."
Dr. Biller also said that studies showed that no matter how tall someone is, they usually want to be taller.
In an interview with Esquire magazine in 1983, Robert Mitchum said of John Wayne: "Duke was six-four but he wore four-inch lifts and a 10-gallon hat. He had a station wagon modified to fit all that paraphernalia. He even had the overheads raised on his boats so that he could walk through the doorways with the lifts on."
Tall people have been known to fuel the paranoia of the short by expressing some moral superiority.
John Kenneth Galbraith, the economist and author, who is 6 feet 8, recalled in his memoirs that when he met Charles de Gaulle, the 6-foot-2-inch French President noted with disdain that Mr. Galbraith had been speaking to a short man.
Mr. Galbraith wrote: "I said he obviously agreed with me that the world belongs to the tall men. They are more visible, therefore their behavior is better and accordingly they are to be trusted. He said that he agreed and added, 'It is important that we be merciless with those who are too small.' "
George Tames, the longtime White House photographer for The New York Times and author of "Eye on Washington" (HarperCollins, 1990), captured many memorable images of Lyndon B. Johnson using his height, 6 feet 3 inches, as a tool of political persuasion.
"As Barry Goldwater once said, if Johnson could not persuade you any other way, he would lean over you and breathe in your mouth and deprive you of oxygen," Mr. Tames said in an interview.
In 1988, USA Today noted that Mr. Dukakis, a slope-shouldered 5 feet 8, was the shortest nominee of a major party since the Republican Thomas E. Dewey, also 5 feet 8, lost to 6-foot-2-inch Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1944 and to 5-foot-9-inch Harry S. Truman in 1948. The newspaper found those facts in a book called "Too Tall, Too Small," by John Gillis, a Canadian psychologist.
The dark-haired, mustachioed Dewey was wounded by a widely quoted witticism that he looked like "the little man on the wedding cake." Similarly, Mr. Dukakis faced a raft of insults about his size when headlines proclaimed the race between "the shrimp versus the wimp" and Republicans belittled him as "the little Duke." Roger Ailes, the Bush media guru, dismissed the Massachusetts Governor as "a narcissistic little fellow."
Mr. Dukakis did not help matters when he broke an unofficial rule of Presidential races -- make sure your Vice Presidential choice is shorter than you are -- and appeared tucked under the arm of Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, 6 feet 2.
(As Vice Presidents, both Lyndon Johnson and George Bush would instinctively shrink a bit when they were in the room with their shorter but more charismatic Presidents, John F. Kennedy and Ronald Reagan.)
Just as the petite Geraldine Ferraro had used a riser in her debate with George Bush, Mr. Dukakis tried to even the score with Mr. Bush by standing on a three-inch mound artfully built beneath the carpet behind his lectern. But it did not work to his advantage in the end, because it only made the six-inch difference in their heights more striking when Mr. Dukakis stepped off the mound to shake hands with Mr. Bush.
Johnny Carson joked that the Democrat wanted the candidates to debate from the crouch position. Republicans suggested that Mr. Bush's opening line at the debate should be, "Come down off that soapbox and look me in the tie!"
It was the same story in 1976. While Gerald R. Ford, six feet tall but known as a klutz, was worrying about getting his water glass braced to his lectern so that he would not knock it over, Jimmy Carter, 5 feet 9 1/4, was arranging to have lecterns of different heights.
Gerald Rafshoon, Mr. Carter's media adviser, recalled that the Carter camp agreed to a neutral-colored backdrop, which the Republicans thought would disguise Mr. Ford's thinning gray hair better than a blue backdrop would. In return, the Republicans agreed to place the lecterns farther away from each other so that the contrast in height between the two candidates would not be so stark.
"We said, 'We'll give you some hair if you give us some height,' " Mr. Rafshoon said.
The most famous lectern incident occurred last year, when Queen Elizabeth, who is 5 feet 4, stepped up to a White House lectern set for President Bush and virtually disappeared -- except for her bobbing broad-brimmed hat, dubbed "the Talking Hat" by the British press.
It has been suggested that as more women are elected, voters will become more accustomed to leadership coming in all shapes and sizes.
Representative Barbara Boxer, the 4-foot-11-inch California Democrat who is running for the Senate, is clearly banking on that. She advises audiences to elect her because Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, a Maryland Democrat who is also 4 feet 11, "is really looking forward to working with someone she can look in the eye."
Senator John Seymour (5 feet 6), Republican of California, is being challenged by Dianne Feinstein (5 feet 9), former Mayor of San Francisco, in the November election, and is trying to keep his sense of humor about having to look up to his opponent.
"Abraham Lincoln was once asked how tall a man should be," Mr. Seymour said. "And he responded by saying, 'A man should be tall enough so that his feet touch the ground.' "

HEADLINE: For the Rich in the 80's Cost of Giving Went Up

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your May 24 discussion of a study by three Treasury Department economists who found a fall in average charitable giving by high-income Americans does not include one of the study's most fascinating findings. The authors show that if one assumes that the 1979 patterns of charitable giving among the rich persisted into the 1980's, one could predict almost exactly the decline in the 80's. 
 The 1979 data suggest that, with the changes in income and tax incentives of the 80's, average giving by millionaires should have decreased 42 percent. The decrease was 39 percent. That's about as close as decade-ahead economic projections ever get.
The accuracy of the projection is crucial because it suggests that the rich did not somehow become "greedier" in the 80's. Rather, they merely responded to incentives as their counterparts did in the late 70's. So why did average donations decline?
Although their incomes increased, changes in Federal tax policy made it 64 percent more expensive for millionaires to make donations. When some activity becomes more expensive, the rich, like the rest of us, do less of it.
 
HARVEY S. ROSEN
Professor of Economics, Princeton U.
Princeton, N.J., June 2, 1992

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
To Mexico, High Court Sounds Like A Bully

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
By nearly all accounts but his own, Humberto Alvarez Machain is an unfortunate choice as a cause celebre. Even to Mexican officials, the heavyset, 44-year-old gynecologist suggests the drug-related corruption that has stamped Guadalajara, Mexico's second-largest city. In Los Angeles, where he now occupies a prison cell, prosecutors know Dr. Alvarez as the man who in 1985 injected stimulants into a dying American drug enforcement agent, Enrique Camarena Salazar, to keep him conscious while Guadalajara drug traffickers tortured him with a red-hot pipe.
Yet to many Mexicans, Dr. Alvarez has also become a symbol of the arrogant and unbridled exercise of American power. Agents of the United States Drug Enforcement Administration arranged and paid for the bounty hunters who abducted Dr. Alvarez from his Guadalajara offices in April 1990. And last Monday, the United States Supreme Court ruled that since a bilateral extradition treaty did not specifically rule out such kidnappings, they were not illegal and Dr. Alvarez could be brought to trial. 
 A few weeks before negotiators are expected to complete a North American Free Trade Agreement, Dr. Alvarez was also an untimely reminder of the mistrust that American and Mexican leaders have sought to overcome in bringing their vastly unequal societies closer together. Mexicans have long been nervous about closer ties and stronger competition with the United States, which already shares more than two-thirds of all Mexican trade. But the Court decision served to jog commentators' memories of Ronald Reagan in Central America, the cold war and even of Teddy Roosevelt.
The concerns of Americans were amply illustrated in the saga of Mr. Camarena. For months after his murder, United States officials prodded their Mexican counterparts about the case and got nowhere. Eventually, the identities of Mexicans indicted in the case suggested good reason: one was the brother-in-law of a former President; another, a former head of the Federal investigations police.
 
The Imbalance of Power
 That the United States never bothered asking Mexico to extradite Dr. Alvarez is beside the point, American officials contend; Mexican policy has been not to hand over its citizens. Mexico's President, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, was in no position to hear such arguments, having been accused incessantly of selling out Mexican sovereignty for free trade. Within hours of the court ruling, his Foreign Ministry said it was suspending all D.E.A. activities in Mexico.
From then on, the case of Dr. Alvarez seemed to evoke nothing so much as the imbalance of power in the Mexican-American partnership. After complaints about the retaliation from Washington, Mexico retracted the suspension in an abrupt, embarrassing shift. Officials said they had received assurances of American respect for Mexican sovereignty and did not want to give drug traffickers a reprieve; therefore, the D.E.A.'s 39 agents in Mexico were reinstated "temporarily."
As for Mexico's demand that the 1978 extradition treaty be amended to rule out any more kidnappings, diplomats declined, noting that similar treaties with 102 other nations would probably have to be modified as well. To Mexico's renewed insistence that Dr. Alvarez be returned for prosecution, the most direct answer seemed to come from Los Angeles: Federal officials there were talking about trial dates.
The focus of Mr. Salinas's attention during the episode was obvious. From the startof trade negotiations, the agreement has meant infinitely more for Mexico than for the United States or Canada. But as the country's trade and current account deficits have ballooned, even the expectation of a trade accord among foreign investors has become essential to Mexican economic stability. Last week, as the flap over Alvarez Machain was added to the slowness of the trade talks and Ross Perot's apparent opposition, values on the Mexican stock market plummeted for three straight days.
In selling free trade to their respective constituencies, the two Governments have concentrated intensely on the future -- at times, critics say, to the point of closing their eyes. While massaging the deep, defensive nationalism of their countrymen,, Mexican officials have dropped their old talk about American imperialism. Whatever shortcomings American officials see in Mexico's democracy, environmental policies and justice system, they no longer talk much about them.
Substituting pragmatic management for principled stands, however, has solved only some problems. A recent spate of ransom kidnappings around Mexico, for instance, suggests that corrupt police officials may still pose a serious problem even if fired from their jobs. And Mexican diplomats insisted that they were not satisfied that the Alvarez abduction could not take place today.
In recent months, they noted, Mexico has lodged a series of protests over American police and Border Patrol agents crossing into Mexico in pursuit of fleeing suspects. And two days before the Court ruling on Dr. Alvarez, two American private investigators apparently hired by a bail-bond company crossed into the state of Sonora and seized a Mexican convicted in absentia on cocaine charges in Arizona. After protesting the abduction, Mexican officials sought what they called the logical remedy: They asked that the two American bounty hunters be extradited for trial in Mexico.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
For Clinton, Attention Grows, Problems Remain

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.

 BODY:
Bill Clinton is getting 4,000 letters a day, fielding so many requests for broadcast interviews that he canceled plans to buy a half hour of network time last week and generally garnering more attention than he has been able to attract since the emergence of Ross Perot.
But the likely Democratic nominee is also hurting for cash, struggling to boil his message down into vote-getting form and carrying on a loud and nasty spat with Jesse Jackson. 
 It is not the best of times for the Arkansas Governor, who never seems to get very far past one piece of rough water before he is confronted with another. His campaign organization, beset with the growing pains that accompany every nominee's move from the primaries to the general election, is buffeted by rumors of impending resignations and internal strife nearly every week.
And the latest round with Mr. Jackson, who has made plaguing Democratic nominees something of an art form, has continued just long enough to risk becoming a long-term liability that could outweigh the short-term benefit Clinton strategists had hoped to gain in standing up to the not universally popular Mr. Jackson.
 
A Lasting Threat
 But temporary setbacks are one thing. The more enduring threat for Mr. Clinton lies with the problems that bedevil him personally. During the last several months, the pulse takers of conventional wisdom who reside in Washington ascribed Mr. Clinton's weakness to "character" problems while conceding that he was a good campaigner.
But, in reality, it took several crucial weeks for Mr. Clinton to realize that a key part of what constitutes good campaigning this year occurs in an arena he had been relatively unused to: the unfiltered eye of television talk shows. Since the California primary, he has learned this lesson with a vengeance, hopscotching from Arsenio Hall's late-night show to the morning network talk shows and then to glitzy MTV in rapid succession.
"You break through by having a message that's compelling about yourself," said Stan Greenberg, the Clinton poll taker who remains convinced that voters are far more open about learning more about Mr. Clinton than about George Bush.
Still, polls published during this period continue to show Mr. Clinton stubbornly entrenched in third place behind President Bush and Mr. Perot. Mr. Clinton said recently that even his Little Rock barber, summoned to the governor's mansion to cut his hair on a visit home a week ago, asked him about Mr. Perot.
And when he does get a platform from which to preach the undiluted message of economic reinvestment that he is convinced Americans want to hear, Mr. Clinton still finds that the most common response is infuriating. Even at this late date -- and even though he has all but secured his party's nomination -- voters are still unfamiliar with what he stands for.
In a recent interview, Mr. Clinton revealingly called it the "disability" he inherited by having survived a bruising primary process. In order to beat back one potential scandal after another from New Hampshire to New York, he became accustomed to giving exhaustive -- if not always direct -- answers to every question.
Some of this was in his nature. He kicked off his campaign by delivering three sober and now largely forgotten policy speeches at Georgetown University. And anyone who remembers the speech he gave to nominate Michael Dukakis at the 1988 Democratic convention knows just how long-winded he can be.
But in the age of the video campaign, his tendency to give a dozen reasons and justifications for every policy he proposes has hobbled Mr. Clinton's ability to reintroduce himself to voters prior to the convention. Ross Perot may not be much on specifics, but he is lively.
Mr. Clinton recognizes some of this.
"I was wrong to believe that if I went to Georgetown and gave these three really detailed policy speeches and put it together in a plan explaining and establishing me as a different kind of Democrat with traditional values and the interest of the Democratic Party at heart but a willingness to be pro-growth and demand personal responsibiity, offer some really new ideas for empowering people, that somehow all that would get through," he said as his limousine glided through San Antonio. "And I just don't think it does."
His strategists grit their teeth when they hear him speak in run-on sentences like this. So he has begun repeating the same points in shorter bursts, occasionally warning his audience that he is "beginning to sound like a broken record."
George Stephanopoulos, the campaign's communications director, called this part of "a constant and continual process" to hone the candidate's message. The campaign, he said, is not in desperate straits, even though 200 campaign workers were forced to forgo paychecks because of what the campaign delicately called a "cash flow problem" -- it was $2.7 million in debt to one bank as of last month. One reason for the shortfall is that the campaign does not accept contributions from political action committees, which are allowed to donate more than the $1,000 limit imposed on individuals.
Mr. Stephanopoulos and others in Mr. Clinton's campaign betray little nervousness over their prospects. Little more than a week ago, they point out, they were having trouble getting any attention at all. Now they feel they are getting the hearing they need.
"If you gave me $3 million today, I wouldn't spend a penny on TV," said Mr. Stephanopoulos. "We can't get any more than we're getting."
But for all their current optimism (Mr. Clinton's advisers are convinced they won last week's bitter little war of words with Jesse Jackson over the Governor's criticism of the rap artist Sister Souljah, who Mr. Clinton said had advocated racial violence), the Clinton strategists know they still have a long way to go and are counting on the three-way race to remain competitive. Although the polls show them a distant third, they still envision offering voters a choice between a strengthened Mr. Clinton and a weakened, exposed Mr. Perot. "The question is, is he too big a risk, or is Clinton too big a risk?" Mr. Greenberg said of Mr. Perot.
And although Mr. Clinton is happily talking more about himself than about Mr. Perot these days, it remains a real possibility that he will soon have little choice but to mount a frontal assault on the Texan.
"If the press doesn't push Ross Perot to say what he'll do for the country, Bill Clinton certainly will," said Bruce Reed, the Clinton campaign's deputy manager for policy. "The debate is still beginning."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Russia and Ukraine: Condemned to Get Along

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
It was scarcely an accident that while Boris N. Yeltsin was politicking his way through Washington, the President of Ukraine, Leonid M. Kravchuk, was in Paris on a state visit of his own. There, Mr. Kravchuk not only talked about aid but actually got a little -- credits of 500 million francs, about $95 million.
It must have amused Francois Mitterrand and Mr. Kravchuk, who are not normally known for their sense of fun. Mr. Mitterrand has been a cactus under Washington's saddle for many years now; Mr. Kravchuk, now the head of an independent state, is Mr. Yeltsin's biggest foreign-policy headache. 
 But just as France and the United States are condemned to get along on the most crucial issues of security and world trade, so are Russia and Ukraine. It's not only that Russia had its birth in the 9th century in Kiev, and that 13 million of Ukraine's 52 million people consider themselves Russian. Ukraine accounted for 18 percent of the Soviet Union's agricultural output and 20 percent of its industrial production, and the two economies are irretrievably interlinked.
Lenin went so far as to state: "If we lose the Ukraine, we lose our head."
There are many people hoping that Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Kravchuk, in their public spats these days, manage not to lose theirs. In fact the two seem to understand each other pretty well, having both risen through the Communist nomenklatura, and they will meet on Tuesday, in their own first, official summit at Dagamys, near Sochi, to ensure they understand each other better.
But there is always the possibility that the careful show Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Kravchuk must perform for their respective nationalists will somehow, one day, get out of hand, particularly if some Russian and Ukrainian villagers go at it.
Psychologically, it has been a particularly wrenching divorce, with many Russians, like a wronged or oblivious partner, refusing to believe that separation is forever. Pressed, no Russian will admit that Russia makes any sense without Ukraine or Belarus; many believe that in his Russian soul, Mr. Yeltsin agrees. And as Mr. Kravchuk reconstructs a system of apparatchik-style personal power without real political or economic reform, Ukrainians begin to wonder if independence will bring them more than provincial status.
Mr. Kravchuk's bargain with the nationalists who supported his election has been simple: He and his ex-Communist apparatus would build an independent Ukraine in return for keeping power and control of the economy, which is almost entirely unreformed.
For the nationalists, the current situation is a great improvement on Ukraine's three previous efforts at independence, most recently in the chaos that followed the Bolshevik revolution. For Mr. Kravchuk and his officials, they get to rule largely by decree, and the perks of independence, like Paris summit meetings, are not unappreciated.
Mr. Yeltsin's problem is different. His nationalists, including his own Vice President, Aleksandr Rutskoi, are part of a conservative opposition in the parliament and major state enterprises that resists Russia's diminished status and radical economic reform.
Thus Mr. Yeltsin has no desire to give his nationalists more ammunition on such difficult, Ukrainian-centered issues as the Black Sea Fleet, nuclear weapons and Crimea. Crimea is a favored resort (and home to the fleet), which the Ukrainian Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev capriciously handed over to Ukraine in 1954, in what was then a meaningless administrative decision. Now Crimea is the latest theater for the Yeltsin-Kravchuk show of public acrimony, mixed with calmer personal conversations.
After all the posturing, Crimea seems headed toward some finessed form of autonomy, allowing Russians to visit as they like, without visas. But Mr. Kravchuk's efforts to dilute the Russian majority in Crimea by welcoming the return of about 150,000 Crimean Tatars, a group deported en masse across the eastern Soviet Union by Stalin, could lead to a blow-up.
Economic problems, however, could be more serious. The Soviet foreign debt of $60 billion to $80 billion is to be shared among the successor states. But Russia complains that it is the only country paying, and that Ukraine in particular is not.
Ukraine also objects to Russia charging world prices for oil, as the I.M.F. urges. Traditional trade meant cheap Russian oil for cheap Ukrainian food, and Mr. Kravchuck's Government would like to maintain that deal, even if Ukraine's own inefficient agriculture is no longer self-sufficient in grain.
Moscow is also furious that its effort to control money supply is being undermined by Moldova and Ukraine, which are issuing large amounts of credit unsanctioned by Russia's Central Bank.
The currency relationship is crucial. Ukraine now says it will move from its weakening Ukrainian ruble coupons -- now worth only 70 percent of the Russian ruble -- to its own currency, the hrivnia, in August or September. But massive amounts of rubles still circulate in Ukraine, and Russia worries about them. If dumped into Russia, they would mean a 20-percent jump in money supply, which could produce hyperinflation.
These issues, unfortunately, are less easily finessed, even by politicians as skilled as Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Kravchuk. The hrivnia may create more problems than Crimea.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 2; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1384 words

HEADLINE: A Trip And a Half;
Yeltsin's Visit Seals a Bond; The Details Will Test It

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Every summit meeting has its photo, and surely the one that will endure from last week's will be that cozy family snapshot of Russia's President, Boris N. Yeltsin, standing on the White House lawn with one arm around Barbara Bush and the other around President Bush, with the Bush family dog Millie at their feet. The picture could be in a scrapbook labeled: "Uncle Boris Comes to Visit." And the caption would have Mr. Yeltsin saying to the Bushes: "So! Great to be here! What's for dinner?"
In that picture are hints of the many contradictory impulses behind this summit. There was an innocent warmth in the smiles of these two former adversaries, but it masked the frustrating, messy domestic realities in their respective countries that will continue to complicate the relationship. There was the big-hearted charisma of Mr. Yeltsin, who came to Washington tossing off tantalizing tidbits about American prisoners of war and his undying commitment to economic reform. He was the Russian Ross Perot, a blunt breath of fresh air without the details. 
 But there was something else in that photo too -- a bit of a wince in Mr. Bush's eyes as Mr. Yeltsin grabs him by the shoulder. It looked like the wince provoked when a distant relative comes to you for money -- the wince, perhaps, of Americans realizing that in winning the cold war what they have won is not a peace dividend but a bill.
In this case, though, the guest is offering to do a lot to earn his welcome. And that could make the bill well worth paying. The arms control agreement that Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Bush hammered out will, once implemented, effectively strip both countries of the first-strike nuclear weapons that left the world a hairbreadth away from nuclear destruction for 40 years. The economic agreements they concluded open paths that have never existed for trade and investment between Russia and the United States.
 
Details . . . and Courage
 The question now, though, is not whether this meeting made a difference -- it clearly did -- but whether it will make a lasting difference. The answer lies entirely in the follow-up. It is the details, off camera, in the hardscrabble reality of the Russian and American political landscapes, that will ultimately decide the lasting value of this summit. These details will determine whether Americans and Russians look back on this collaboration as the first of many, or as the high point of a summer friendship that didn't quite work out once the grind of daily life resumed.
Many factors will be in play, in three arenas.
First, the United States Congress. Mr. Yeltsin's performance there was a political tour de force. His speech was both a persuasive statement of his commitment to economic reform and a political challenge to American lawmakers to come up with their long-promised aid package for Russia. Having preceded his speech by forging an arms control accord with Mr. Bush that promises to slash the two countries' combined nuclear arsenals from 21,000 warheads to 7,000 by the year 2003, Mr. Yeltsin had put his missiles where his mouth was and he felt entitled to ask Congress to put its money where its mouth was.
The paradox for Mr. Yeltsin is that the more unthreatening he makes Russia -- the more missiles he scraps -- the more Congress seems to feel it can dawdle on his aid request. But there may be more at stake in how Congress meets the aid challenge than Russia's fate alone.
"Yeltsin's visit actually crystallized the fight for the soul of the Democratic Party now that the cold war is over," said Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, who loudly denounced fellow Democrats who oppose aid. One part of the Democratic Party, he said, is in danger of lapsing into a provincial, protectionist, isolationist mode, as the Republicans did in the 1920's, and one part wants to carry on the internationalist spirit of Presidents Wilson, Truman and Kennedy.
"One of the reasons that I think my party is in trouble," Senator Biden said, "is that it has not demonstrated to the American people that it has the raw political courage to do and say things that are not popular, like giving aid to Russia at this time.
"You know what came across to me and so many of my colleagues who were in that chamber when Yeltsin spoke? It was: 'Damn, that guy has courage.' What I want to ask some of my colleagues is: 'Why do we think that if we like that sort of courage in other leaders, our constituents won't like that same kind of courage in us?"'
It looks now as if the Senate may indeed approve the aid package. But in the House, where everyone is up for election, prudence rather than courage is still the fashion of the week. While they shouted "Boris! Boris! Boris!" as Mr. Yeltsin spoke, many House members mumbled afterward that they would still like to take the pulse of their own constituents before voting yes on aid.
Mr. Yeltsin faces complications in the Kremlin as well. Much was learned about him during this visit and most of it seems encouraging. The man is a leader. Just as he took a historic decision to defy the coup plotters last August, so he took an equally historic decision to abandon the doctrine of nuclear parity that had for so long existed between the United States and the former Soviet Union. When this new treaty is fully implemented by 2003 there will definitely only be one superpower in the world, since Russia will have given up its most potent and advanced missiles, while agreeing that Washington can retain many of its. When a Democrat as prominent as Senator Biden calls an arms treaty negotiated by a Republican President "maybe the best deal in the history of arms control," you know it is good.
But the year 2003 is a long way away, and a lot can happen between now and then, particularly in a Russia that is still disintegrating around the edges. This gets back to details and one troubling thing about Mr. Yeltsin: Like many visionary leaders, he is not big on details. The way he tossed around unsubstantiated reports about the possibility of American prisoners of war in Russia did not inspire confidence. He meant well, perhaps; but, as one Administration official put it, "he's got the whole damn Pentagon turned upside down looking for these people."
Mr. Yeltsin was no doubt feeling pressure to show Americans why a country that is no longer their enemy and is neither rich nor stable should still be treated as important. But ultimately this can't be done through gimmicks. It has to be done the old-fashioned way: Building free markets and democracy on sound foundations. That is what would earn America's attention and respect. But it will take a lot of detail work.
Adding to Mr. Yeltsin's problems, remarked Dimitri K. Simes, a Russian affairs expert at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, is that the Russian President must start delivering soon. But he is dealing with a Government, a parliament and a country that are still not ready for radical reform, and still not aware that the hard part has just begun. So the only quick boost can come from the outside.
But that infusion of Western cash is tied to Mr. Yeltsin's ability to meet minimum International Monetary Fund standards of reform -- which gets back to the importance of the details. Eventually he will have to produce the economic equivalent of his arms control treaty -- reforms so sweeping that they irreversibly alter the status quo and prove to the world that his regime truly is an economic departure from the past. It is much easier, however, to cut warheads than wages.
Finally, over at the White House. What political impact will this successful summit meeting have for the stumbling Bush campaign? Probably not much. To begin with, few Americans have ever voted for a President on the basis of his performance on arms control, a subject so abstruse few officials understand it, let alone voters.
More fundamentally, Mr. Bush, like Mr. Yeltsin, is a victim of his own success. The more Mr. Yeltsin becomes unthreatening, the more Congress can feel complacent about helping him. And the more Mr. Bush puts the cold war to bed, said the Republican political analyst Kevin Phillips, "the less we have to worry about having a President who is an expert in dealing with such issues."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House Race;
WHITE HOUSE RACE AT EMOTIONAL PEAK MANY WEEKS EARLY

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, June 20

 BODY:
As if the general election were weeks and not four months away, President Bush, Gov. Bill Clinton and Ross Perot today engaged in the sort of full-blown campaigning that is usually reserved for the home stretch.
Mr. Bush, echoing the theme Vice President Dan Quayle has been sounding lately to woo conservatives, criticized "liberal elitists" in a speech in Los Angeles. Then he ventured here, into Mr. Perot's backyard, where in a reference to the Texas businessman he told the state Republican Convention that there was "too much at stake, as we say here, to buy a pig in a poke." 
 Mr. Perot, meanwhile, completed a three-day, four-city swing by taking his independent campaign to solidly Democratic Massachusetts, where he addressed a rally at the Boston Commons.
And Governor Clinton, the winner of the Democratic primary contests, campaigned close to home in Arkansas with an appearance in Conway, a town north of Little Rock.
 
Campaign Calendar Skewed
 Such energetic campaigning is unusual at this stage of a Presidential season. Party nominees ordinarily devote the late spring and early summer to resting, raising money and plotting strategy for their party conventions and beyond.
But Mr. Perot's candidacy has turned the race, and the campaign calendar, upside down. It has been hard to switch on television in recent days without seeing one of the three candidates, their wives or other surrogates.
Mr. Bush, in a three-day trip to the battleground states of California and Texas, sought to reassure environmentalists who may be enticed by Mr. Clinton, as well as conservative business executives intrigued by Mr. Perot.
At a few appearances, he departed from typical Presidential decorum by inviting questions, and he took a stroll among bathers on a California beach.
While an estimated 8,000 delegates at the Texas convention welcomed Mr. Bush with virtual nonstop ovations and chants of "four more years," the crowds at other stops in the last three days were polite but not particularly enthusiastic.
Mr. Perot, in his own three-day swing through California, Colorado and Massachusetts, drew mixed responses, from the excited to the curious. He went to Colorado and Massachusetts to recognize that his volunteers had gathered enough signatures to put his name on the general election ballots.
 
Muskets and Horses
 The trip had the trappings and feel of a full-fledged Presidential campaign. In Boston today, supporters, many in Colonial garb and carrying muskets, paraded with floats and bicycles to Boston Commons for the candidate's speech in the heart of the home state of Michael S. Dukakis, the Democrats' 1988 Presidential nominee.
Boxes representing Mr. Perot's petitions were hauled on an 1898 freight wagon, pulled by eight draft horses. The boxes actually contained packing material since the petitions themselves were turned in Friday.
Mr. Perot's speeches have evolved into a standard campaign set piece that he recites repeatedly, the way other candidates do. He exhorted the audience to remain involved in politics after the general election.
"Do you understand that if you send me to Washington and you go back to your lives after November, all of the things you've dreamed about happening will not happen?" he said. "You have got to stay in the ring, shoulder-to-shoulder with me, or this will not happen. Is that a deal?"
 
Clinton Shifts Emphasis
 Mr. Clinton, who has done far more campaigning across the country than his two rivals this year, has for the last two weeks emphasized television appearances in which he has made direct appeals to voters or interest groups. He has also spent time sparring with the Rev. Jesse Jackson over his comments about a rap performer, and he has worked on refinements in his economic proposals, which he plans to announce in coming days.
Today, he journeyed 30 miles north from Little Rock to Hendrix College in Conway, where he boasted to several hundred cheering students that his administration had done more for black people than any other in the state's history. "I'm proud of my civil rights record," Mr. Clinton said.
The major difference between the campaigning today and what might be expected in the thick of a general election race is that the candidates are holding back on direct personal attacks. Mr. Bush and Mr. Perot have avoided citing their rivals by name, preferring thinly veiled attacks.
In both of Mr. Bush's speeches today, he singled out an unnamed rival, asserting: "Unlike one of my opponents for President, I don't believe the only way to confront a massive deficit is with a massive tax increase. And that's in quotes because that's what he said."
At first, aides traveling with Mr. Bush said they did not know whether he was referring to Mr. Clinton or Mr. Perot or both, but they later said his comment was directed at Mr. Clinton.
Seeking to diminish Mr. Perot's reputation as the candidate with business experience, Mr. Bush at several stops recalled how he had started a Houston oil company. The President also sought to reassert his credentials as a transplanted Texan, pledging in Dallas that he would build his Presidential library in the state "and when my work is over I'll come back here."
Mr. Perot does not need to mention Mr. Clinton or Mr. Bush when he rails against the state of American politics. And Mr. Clinton takes pains never to mention Mr. Perot by name, though he has sought to present himself as the alternative to Mr. Bush and Mr. Perot: a Washington outsider with government experience.
While Mr. Bush told his Texas audience to "wait until August and we'll roll up our sleeves and get in that campaign mode," he seemed to be in it already. Abandoning the pledge he made on Thursday to hold his fire for now, the President shook his fists as he attacked Mr. Perot without mentioning him by name.
"Snappy answers and glib talk will not get the job done," he said. "Let somebody else become the darling of the talking heads on television."
Noting that some people ask him why he cannot "bring the same kind of purpose and success to the domestic scene as you did in Desert Shield and Desert Storm," Mr. Bush said, "The answer is, I didn't have to get permission from some old goat in the United States Congress to kick Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait."
Before heading to Dallas, Mr. Bush this morning addressed the Howard Jarvis Taxpayers Association in Los Angeles, a group that has carried on the spirit behind Proposition 13, the tax-cutting measure that California voters passed 14 years ago.
 
Bush's Favorite Target
 Although he has presided over the largest Federal budget deficit in history and abandoned his pledge of "no new taxes," Mr. Bush waged a rhetorical assault against his favorite target: liberals in Congress.
"Again and again," he told the audience of fiscal conservatives, "the liberals in Congress have said no to spending reform. It's no wonder that Americans keep clamoring for stricter limits on the power and cost of Government."
Then, glancing off the theme that the Vice President has been emphasizing, Mr. Bush said, "And when liberal elitists ridicule you and say we have social problems because of you -- because you're 'greedy' -- well, naturally, you stand up and fight back."
 
'Special Hall of Shame'
 The President denounced those in the House of Representatives who last week opposed a constitutional amendment for a balanced budget. "And pay attention to the Democrats who belong in a special Hall of Shame," Mr. Bush said, referring to the 12 Democrats who listed themselves as co-sponsors of the amendment and then voted against it.
"They did that to curry favor with their party bosses in Washington," Mr. Bush said. "We know better than to expect these people to discipline themselves."
Mr. Bush also sought to bask in the afterglow of the arms agreement that he and Boris N. Yeltsin, the Russian President, announced this week. But in the question-and-answer-sessions that Mr. Bush invited, hardly anyone asked him about Mr. Yeltsin. They wanted to know about the economy and domestic programs.
In another departure from ordinary Presidential behavior, Mr. Bush took an unexpected walk on the Corona del Mar Beach in Southern California. He drew hundreds of well-wishers, but caused so much disruption that Secret Service agents hurried him back to his limousine after only a few minutes.

HEADLINE: More Children Are Employed, Often Perilously

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
After nearly disappearing from American life, child labor has re-emerged and proliferated in the last decade. Even the recession does not seem to have stemmed the tide, and investigators say many of the children are working in dangerous jobs.
Federal statistics indicate that at least four million children ages 14 to 18 are legally employed. But about half that many other children work illegally, either because businesses or family members pay them in cash to avoid taxes and minimum wages, or, more ominously, because they work too many hours, late hours, at hazardous jobs, or are under 14 and thus too young to be working at all except on farms.
 
Children Working Everywhere
 No one knows exactly how many children work illegally, but Philip J. Landrigan, chairman of the Department of Community Medicine at Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York, estimated the number at about 2 million. Evidence from a variety of sources -- the Labor Department's strike force, the General Accounting Office, states' investigations and emergency-room records -- suggests that children work illegally in the fields, in the garment industry, in fast-food restaurants, on construction sites and in mines, sawmills and gas stations. 
 On the job, they suffer amputations, burns, deep cuts and electrocutions. At least several hundred a year are killed, according to investigators at the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health. Other children work late on school nights, in violation of state and Federal laws, and sometimes fall asleep in class.
Jeffrey Newman, executive director of the National Child Labor Committee, a nonprofit organization founded in 1904, said he is seeing a return of child labor scandals reminiscent of those that occurred at the turn of the century. "I see the same kind of exploitation that occurred then, in sweatshops, in the fields, in unscrupulous business practices that occur behind closed doors," he said. "It's very sad and it doesn't speak well to our understanding and commitment to children."
Dr. Landrigan, who organized a recent conference on child labor, laid the blame for the growth of legal and illegal child labor on three factors:
*More and more families slipped into poverty in the 1980's and early 1990's and needed income from their children's work;
*Immigrants flooded the nation, often from countries where child labor is routine, providing a pool of people ripe for exploitation;
*And state and Federal governments cut their budgets for inspecting workplaces, making the discovery of violations less likely.
Mr. Newman said that economic factors over the past decade have contributed to the problem. "There are two times when child labor is really affected by the economy," he said. "When the economy is really in the doldrums or in an extreme recession, businesses often seek out young people because they can pay them less and take advantage of them." On the other hand, he said, "When the economy is up, child labor again begins to climb because businesses need more people and they can hire young people at lower wages."
 
Historically Defies Regulation
 Mr. Newman and others added, however, that a major contributing factor to the increase in child labor has been lax enforcement of state and Federal laws. Federal laws prohibit children under age 16 from working during school hours and limit the number of hours they can work after school and on weekends. Certain jobs, like mining, logging and roofing, are prohibited for anyone under age 18. In agriculture, restrictions are less stringent; hazardous work is prohibited until age 16.
But child labor has a long history that complicates attempts to restrict or regulate it, said Dr. David Rosner, a historian of medicine at Baruch College in New York. "We have very deep-seated social and cultural values that play against serious attempts at protecting kids," Dr. Rosner said.
Many Americans are deeply ambivalent about child labor, he said. "We see work as redemptive and as a morally legitimate method of self improvement."
The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, recently found evidence in data from the United States Department of Labor that the number of illegally employed minors had almost tripled since 1983, rising from 9,200 to 27,500 last year. But Dr. Charles Jeszeck, an economist who did the analysis, said those numbers grossly underestimate the problem because they derive from woefully inadequate surveillance and reporting systems.
 
166,000 15-Year-Olds WorkersIllegally Employed
 Dr. Jeszeck and his colleagues found one indication of underreporting when their search of 1988 census data revealed that at least 166,000 15-year-old childrenwere working too many hours or in occupations, like construction, that are prohibited for children that young. More than half were working in prohibited jobs, Dr. Jeszeck said.
A recent investigation of 4,700 businesses by the Labor Department found that nearly 5,000 minors at 1,300 businesses were working illegally.
Dr. William Halperin, the associate director for surveillance at the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, called the magnitude of illegal child labor "astounding." And he said the statistics gathered so far are "the tip of an iceberg," because there is no systematic data collection and many injuries and even deaths are not reported.
One problem is simply discovering violators, given the relatively few inspectors the Federal Government employs for that purpose. For example, Dr. Landrigan said, the National Occupational Safety and Health Administration has 2,000 inspectors, and the Labor Department has another 1,000 wage-and-hour workers, who are responsible for detecting illegal child labor as well as violations involving adults. That combined force equals only a fourth of the 12,000 inspectors who work for the Fish and Wildlife Service.
 
84-Year Inspection Cycle
 Jay Mazur, president of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, said that OSHA has so few inspectors that it would take 84 years to get around to inspecting all the workplaces for which it is responsible; it would take 25 years just to visit every high-hazard workplace for a surprise inspection. With such inadequate resources, he said, "we are fighting, to put it mildly, an uphill battle."
New York State, which has some of the toughest laws restricting child labor, also has the nation's only state task force to look for labor-law violations in garment-industry sweatshops. But there are only 15 inspectors assigned to inspect New York City's estimated 4,000 to 6,000 factories where small contractors hire workers to sew clothing. And the inspectors say that when they enter a building, factory owners on one floor quickly warn others in the building, and children are hastily sent away.
 
Suspiciously Young Workers
 Last Monday morning, while New York schools were still in session, two inspectors checked on J. J. Fashions, a 7th floor factory on West 37th street in Manhattan. Wires dangled from the ceiling of the room, where about 50 women and a few men toiled at sewing machines and ironed stacks of bright orange net jackets.
One of the inspectors, Angelo Valdevitt, thought that a few of the workers looked suspiciously young. He approached a solemn, chubby-cheeked girl who was nearly hidden by a rack of clothes and, speaking gently in Spanish, explained that he was not from immigration and was not there to report her if she was an illegal immigrant. Then he asked her name, where she was from and how old she was. The girl, who identified herself as Patricia Flores from Mexico, said she was too nervous to remember her birthday and that she had no identification with her.
One recent study, by Dr. Letitia Davis, director of the Occupational Health Surveillance Program at the Massachusetts Department of Public Health, found that annual injury rates for child workers in Massachusetts are 3 1/2 times the adult rate of 8 injuries per 100 full-time workers.
Almost everyone who has examined the issue of child labor has uncovered sad stories of children who were maimed or killed.
 
Tales of Pain and Death
 Congressman Tom Lantos of Calif., the chairman of the Employment and Housing Subcommittee of the House Committee on Government Operations, held hearings last year where he heard testimony from Matthew Garvey, who worked in a car wash in Laurel, Md., when he was 13. His leg was ripped off by a blowing machine.
Mr. Lantos also heard from the parents of Michael Hucorne of East Stroudsburg, Pa., who was killed at age 17 while working in a supermarket, illegally operating a machine that compresses cardboard boxes. And he heard from the parents of Kevin Curley of West Pittston, Pa., who was killed at age 15 while working in a bakery. He was cleaning a dough mixing machine, a prohibited job, when he was pulled inside it.
Valerie Wilk, a health specialist with the Farmworker Justice Fund, Inc., an advocacy group, told of 14-year-old Joel Compos, who fell asleep while working in a farmer's field in Washington State at 2:30 A.M. and was run over and killed by a truck.

The recession and lax enforcement have contributed to a rise in child labor. (Photographs by Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times) (pg. 22)

International 3-15
 
BOSNIANS RECOUNT SLAUGHTER 
 Muslim Slav villagers say that Serbian forces stopped a bus north of Sarajevo, ordered passengers to lie down and then opened fire, killing 47 men. Human rights groups compare such attacks in Bosnia and Herzegovina to killings of civilians in Nazi-occupied Europe. 1
 
CZECHOSLOVAKIA'S TATTERED SEAM
Czechoslovakia gave the appearance of a nation sliding step by step toward dissolution, but political leaders of the country's two republics stressed that the breakup was not yet sealed. 1
 
TOWNSHIP CHASES OUT DE KLERK
South Africa's President ventured into a black township to show concern for victims of a massacre, but was chased away by residents. An ugly mood exploded into violence, and police fired into a crowd. 1
 
THEORY ON SLAIN MAFIA BUSTER
A month after the slaying of Italy's top Mafia investigator, theories about the killing are multiplying. Investigators wonder if it was linked to his inquiries into a new drive by the Mafia and Colombian drug dealers to flood Europe with cocaine. 3
 
MEA CULPA TO EUROPEANS
Faced with a backlash from Europeans suspicious of plans for still greater regional integration, the European Community has turned penitent, admitting that it failed to keep the public informed. 12
