HEADLINE: Insurance Plan Worries Beach Residents

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
LAST October, the raging winds and high tides of a sudden storm washed out homes in dozens of communities along the Atlantic coast. It was yet another reminder for shorefront homeowners of the fragility of their claim to the beach.
"We were lucky," said Andy Rudtke, sitting on the deck of his home in Davis Park, a Fire Island community where the Halloween storm swept away three houses. "In the 30 years that we have been here, we have seen some damage. We had our roof blown off. We lost our deck in a winter blizzard. There is no escaping the part that chance plays when it comes to the forces of nature. It can be frightening." 
 As fearful of hazardous weather as most of the summer residents of Davis Park and other shore communities are, on the horizon is a threat potentially more damaging than a hurricane. A measure now before Congress would restrict the availability of Federal flood insurance on beachfront properties vulnerable to erosion and flooding, raising the financial risks of a washout. The proposal, part of a housing bill, passed the House last year and is now being considered by the Senate.
Even without the threat of the loss of the Federal flood insurance, beachfront ownership is a bittersweet mixture of rewards, risks and expenses. Bank financing for waterfront property is difficult to find and insurance rarely covers all the costs of repairs or rebuilding after flood and storm damage. Some Long Island owners have seen not only their houses but also the dune lots on which they were built washed out to sea.
Yet the waterfront's appeal endures. On Fire Island, a 32-mile barrier reef off the South Shore of Long Island, there are 17 communities with 4,000 beach homes. Most of the development has occurred since World War II, and the houses that dot the scrub landscape range from cheaply built one-room cottages to highly styled multilevel dune residences.
"The availability of Federal flood insurance is not what leads people to own beach houses," said Henry Schwier, a real estate broker who specializes in properties on the Jersey Shore. "As long as there are beaches, people will want to live there."
The bill before the Senate has many components, including stricter building and rebuilding codes. But the piece of greatest concern to owners of beach homes is the part that would significantly change the Federal Flood Insurance Program.
THE insurance is now available to nearly every owner in flood hazard zones like beach communities. The policies provide coverage of up to $245,000 of the insured value -- $185,000 for the structure and $60,000 for contents. Premiums are based on property values and whether the house was built before or after local flood-level maps were drawn. The average cost for an older home is about $300 a year, but newer properties cost closer to $900.
Mr. Schwier, for example, says he pays about $600 a year for covering a waterfront property he owns valued at about $150,000.
The cost of flood insurance for properties closest to the water could rise as high as 10 percent of the value of a home, if it had to be insured privately.
The proposed legislation has given some who are in the market reason to pause.
"It seems to me that if flood insurance were not available," said Anthony Grella, who is looking for a summer home on the Jersey Shore, "the value of a property would be lower. We are still in the market but I will be paying attention to the insurance issue."
Alan Brockman, a lawyer who has represented sellers and buyers in beachfront sales on Long Island, said the loss of Federal insurance would affect more than new buyers.
"Some owners could lose their mortgages," he said. "The loss of flood insurance could be interpreted as a violation of the terms of the mortgage agreement."
Even with the Federal program in place, lenders are cautious about waterfront homes; although many make loans for second homes on easy terms, they have stiffer qualifications for beach properties.
"The theory of mortgage lending is based on a hierarchy of debt and the level of risk," said John A. Ward 3d, president of the Chase Manhattan Financial Services Corporation, a national mortgage company. "Most people would do anything to protect their primary home. But when personal finances are in trouble, the payment on the second home sometimes is the first to go. For loans made on waterfront properties, there is an added risk based on location."
He said his company requires borrowers buying beachfront properties to make higher down payments than on primary residences of equal value. And they must have the financial resources to cover any loss.
"That can be a personal financial capability to cover the loss," he said, "or substantial insurance coverage that goes beyond flood protection offered by the Federal program." Even if a loan applicant meets the financial requirements, Mr. Ward said, the loan could be rejected.
"The other factor that would come into play on a beachfront property would involve the concentration of risk," said Mr. Ward. "We would not lend to a strip of beachfront homes. The chance that all could be lost at one time would be too great."
Louis Pennachio, owner of a home on Fire Island since the early 70's and president of the Davis Park Association, said that in his community, the most vulnerable to the loss of Federal flood insurance could be people who bought 30 years ago or more, when some lots first sold for $3,000 and $4,000.
"Some homes here are now valued in the $200,000 to $300,000 range," he said. "Some people who have been here a long time are concerned because property values have risen to the point where rebuilding or repairing after weather damage might not be possible without insurance."
One of Mr. Pennachio's neighbors, whose home was washed away last October, is close to completing its replacement. It is rising on a part of the property just behind the house lost in the storm, at a higher level.
The builder working on the project last week declined to give the cost of the new two-story house but he acknowledged that it would be larger and sturdier. On the dune just below the new house are reminders of last fall's storm. There, twisted pieces of a wooden deck are embedded in the sand and the corner of a chimney pokes through it. And up and down the beach, staircases that last summer carried beachgoers over the dunes and down to the shore now end in midair.
EROSION damage threatens more than beachfront homes. Lawrence Kane, whose family owns a home on Long Island Sound in Wading River, L.I., has seen serious erosion of a seaside cliff bring their cottage closer to the water's edge. As a result the Kanes are learning that the costs of maintaining a waterfront home sometimes surpasses the original investment.
"My family bought here in the early 60's as a place that we all would share," he said. "The cottages were not expensive and are not fancy at all. They are not winterized, but we sit on a beach cliff with a fantastic view of the Sound."
Two years ago the Kanes invested $5,000 to restore an eroding portion of the cliff abutting their cottage, only to see the Halloween storm chew away the restored area and more.
"The restoration work we did in 1990 was totally obliterated by the storm," said Mr. Kane. "Instead of having a mildly sloped cliff, we now have a severe drop of some 10 or 15 feet and our cottage is now within 10 feet of the cliff."
Engineers have told him that a lasting remedy would be to reinforce the base of the entire cliff. The cost could be has high as $2,000 a linear foot. Because the Kane family cottage is on land that is owned as a co-op in which shareholders have joint ownership of about 25 acres, he is hoping to convince other owners that the cliff-repair project would benefit all. But Mr. Kane is not sure the inshore shareholders will agree to building up property in front of the shorefront cottages.
"As a community," he said, "we have been able to handle most of the common costs without many disagreements. But this is not a cheap project. I wonder if the people behind us will think that if we leave things as they are, the next big storm will take away even more of the cliff and make their homes waterfront property."
Waterfront property owners who strongly oppose the pending legislation assert that it is little more that a device of environmentalists to evict them from the beach. Proponents of the bill say the Federal treasury should not subsidize, through inexpensive flood insurance, the repair and reconstruction of homes in erosion hazard zones, which by their very existence are a threat to the nation's fragile shoreline.
But without the insurance subsidy, many shorefront homeowners would have to give up their homes. Either they could not get private insurance or the premiumn would be prohibitively high.
Because the risk zones have not been identified in the bill, no one can say which areas or how many property owners would be affected. But some shore communities in this region, including barrier islands like Fire Island on Long Island, which have emerged as summer resort areas, and Long Beach Island in Ocean County, N.J., are likely to be among them.
"I can understand an argument that asks, why should the public pay to protect the Whelans' home?," said Dr. Elizabeth Whelan, who recently renovated the Long Beach Island home with her husband, Stephen. "But the motivation behind the legislation is not financial fairness. It is being used to get people off the beach."
Any owner insured under the Federal flood program who loses more than 50 percent of his home can qualify for the insurance only if the reconstruction occurs above the flood level.
Currently, owners of beachfront properties built before flood level construction standards were set pay 55 cents for every $100 of coverage up to $45,000 of value, and 45 cents for every $100 of coverage beyond that.
The owners of beachfront homes built above the flood level for their areas pay 93 cents for every $100 of coverage. The rates drop by nearly half for coverage of homes built two feet above the minimum flood level requirements.
Since the initiative made its way into a housing bill last year, homeowners and real estate professionals have rushed to mount an aggressive lobbying campaign to block its passage in the Senate. One argument they make is that the threat of repeated damaging storms as well as the cost of protecting their homes against them has been overestimated.
GERARD STODDARD, president of the Long Island Coastal Alliance, said that the insurance program is not really a subsidy. "The flood insurance agency's own statistics say that coastal properties represent about 3 percent of the policyholders and make up less than 3 percent of the claims," he said.
Another argument they make is that rather than being a destructive force, beachfront homeowners in some areas, like the Fire Island communities, are guardians of the beaches and dunes there.
"It has been the painstaking buildup of the dunes with sand-holding plants over the years that has kept erosion from being as great as it could have been," said Mr. Stoddard. "Without plantings and snow fences, more of the beach and dunes probably would have washed away."
Fair Harbor, on Fire Island, is one of the communities has has imposed a local tax to pay for such preservation measures as snow fencing, dune-grass planting and beach raking.
Another issue some owners use to defend their presence on the beach is their economic contribution. Frank Jones, supervisor of the Town of Islip, which has within its jurisdiction more summer communities than any other towns on Long Island. Mr. Jones said that together they contribute about $8.5 million a year to Islip's tax base.
"The Fire Island communities pay their way," said Mr. Jones. "But their taxes are not a windfall for us."
Mr. Jones said that a significant portion of the property taxes paid by Fire Island owners goes to service their communities. The town is responsible for the boardwalks, which take the place of streets, and for the sewer and water systems.
"As far as impact on the economy," he said, "if these communities were to disappear it would hurt businesses that depend on the summer owners, like the ferry or restaurants. But Islip's economy would not be severely damaged."
"There is no doubt that the owners are very responsible," Mr. Jones added. "They really do their part to protect the beach and the dunes. But there is an aspect of self- preservation to all of it. If the dunes go, they go."
 
 
 
THE PROPOSAL'S RESTRICTIONS
 IF the National Flood Insurance, Mitigation and Erosion Management proposal becomes law, new construction standards and insurance rules would be adopted for communities in the Federal flood insurance program. For waterfront areas, three different erosion zones would be identified, taking into account the rates of erosion in 10, 30 and 60 years.
In areas most vulnerable to erosion -- the 10-year zone -- owners of existing properties would be required either to demolish their buildings or relocate within two years. If they relocate, they may qualify for continued Federal flood insurance benefits up to a maximum of $245,000 in coverage for building and contents. If they don't relocate, they are entitled to no more than 40 percent of the insured value of their properties on the first claim. After that, the owner could get no Federal benefits.
In 30- and 60-year zones, there would be limits on new construction and substantial improvements on existing buildings, but owners would not be required to demolish or relocate.
In New York, the Coastal Erosion Hazzard Areas Management Program limits reconstruction of waterfront properties in erosion zones that suffer more than 50 percent storm damage. Owners can be required to rebuild inland or prevented from rebuilding at all. The law is in effect in most areas, but not yet on Fire Island.
In New Jersey, most storm damaged homes can be rebuilt without restrictions. But larger structures, like hotels, are subject to laws restricting redevelopment in erosion zones.
In Connecticut the Coastal Management Act imposes rigid standards on the construction and rebuilding of structures in areas subject to erosion.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Using an Air-Conditioner
 
Question: I live in a rental apartment in a building converted to a co-op. I am 82 and do not plan to buy my apartment. The building has central air-conditioning but there are times before it is turned on in the spring and after it is turned off in the fall, or when it is not working, when my apartment is hot. 
 I would like to buy and install my own window unit, but the building's management has refused to let me do it. Do they have the right of refusal? . . . Gertrude Goldsmith, Jamaica, Queens
 
Answer: Maybe. It would depend on the terms of your lease and whether your apartment is adequately wired.
According to Joseph D'Agosta, acting deputy director for the office of rent administration, if your lease does not specifically prohibit it and the wiring is adequate, they cannot prevent it. Mr. D'Agosta said that if the air-conditioning system has been provided for rent-regulated tenants, the system must meet certain standards, including that coils be 58 degrees or lower. If your system does not meet this standard, you may want to file a reduction-in-services complaint with the Division of Housing and Community Renewal.
If your apartment is adequately wired for an air-conditioner, there should be at least one branch circuit outlet in the apartment. A standard electrical socket would not accommodate a plug-in air-conditioner. The code requires that the outlet serve just the air-conditioner. The problem is that in some centrally air-conditioned buildings, these outlets may be omitted.
 
Noisy Neighbors
 
Question: I purchased a co-op apartment a few years ago. After moving in, I discovered that the people who live above me are noisy. Their footsteps start becoming audible at 6:30 A.M. In the last 18 month the noise level has risen. Polite notes to them and the building's management agent have not helped. My letters to the co-op board have been ignored.
Our proprietary lease says that 80 percent of the floor area is to be carpeted. The noise upstairs has cost me the enjoyment of my apartment and deprived me of sleep. Is there anything I can do? . . . Karen Hochman, Manhattan
 
Answer: Yes. You can file a suit against the board seeking enforcement of the terms of the proprietary lease. Enforcing rules on noise is among the most difficult matters for boards and managing agents. But since the carpet rule is part of the co-op's documents, you have the right to see that it is observed.
Before taking legal action, you might ask a member of the board or management company to spend time in your apartment so that they can appreciate the disturbance. If you proceed with the suit, notify your board, in writing, of your intention.
 
Parking Fee in Co-op
 
Question: My co-op has a small parking garage for owners. There has been some dissension over the fees and how they could be used to generate income for the co-op. Are there legal or other guidelines a co-op board should follow in setting fees? . . . Ellen Stern, Manhattan
 
Answer: The board would have the right to decide what to charge unit owners who have parking or garage spaces in the building. But according to Philip Sharfstein, an lawyer who specializes in real estate matters, the fees may be subject to regulated increases established by the Division of Housing and Community Renewal.
"If the spaces were a required service for rent- regulated tenants," said Mr. Sharfstein, "any parking fee paid by them would be subject to regulated increases just as regulated apartment rents are."
However, tenants who purchased their apartments would no longer be subject to fee limits once they became owners.
The Internal Revenue Code requires that 80 percent of a co-op's gross income be derived from tenant-shareholders in order for them to deduct real estate taxes and mortgage interest rates paid by the co-op.
"But amounts received from tenant shareholders are considered part of that gross income," said Mr. Sharfstein. "Therefore the corporation would not be limited in the amount it may charge them."

HEADLINE: Streetscapes: Model Tenements;
Far West on 42d St., A 1901 Innovation

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
SOME buildings, like the block of model tenements on the East River from 78th to 79th Streets that Peter Kalikow wanted to demolish, attract the fervid attention of preservationists.
In their efforts to save the complex they held walking tours and news conferences and won celebrity endorsements and landmark designation. 
 Others, like the model tenements at the southwest corner of 42d Street and 10th Avenue, just barely hang together, ignored by landmark activists. If they got some attention, they, too, might be saved, although a complex of conflicting interests stands in the way.
The movement for model tenements matured in the 1890's after decades of proposed reforms failed to change the way most poor people were housed.
In 1894, Ernest Flagg, a young, socially connected architect, published a plan proposing a switch to 100-foot front modules -- rather than the prevailing 25-foot front -- substituting large, central lighted courts for small, individual ventilation spaces.
A group of philanthropists established the City and Suburban Homes Company in 1896 to build model tenements and selected Flagg to design a series on West 68th Street, since demolished.
Flagg was a prickly, contentious egotist and City and Suburban retained other architects for their later projects, like the Kalikow complex, while still using Flagg's concept. So Flagg founded the New York Fireproof Tenement Company and in 1899 filed plans for 11 buildings, with 1,519 rooms for 470 families in a complex at the southwest corner of 42d Street and 10th Avenue.
He completed them in 1901, while City and Suburban was still struggling with its decade-long projects. The exteriors are intelligent but modest, salmon-colored brick with plain marble lintels and simple limestone doorways -- the antithesis of the showy glitz that private tenement developers paid for.
Each 100- by 100-foot unit embraced a large square central light court and had windowed stairways at each of the four corners. Four firewalls broke up the complex into compact cores of apartments without long hallways, anathema to Flagg.
These were the first fireproof tenements in New York, with a structure of steel and concrete instead of the conventional, less expensive wood joists.
Flagg's tenants were hardly the unwashed tenement dwellers of the lower East Side -- the 1905 census lists almost all of them as being born in the United States or England and with solid working-class jobs, with only a few laborers and factory workers. In a 1906 article, Flagg claimed the tenements brought in a 6 percent return.
Flagg and other tenement reformers failed to persuade private tenement developers to adopt their schemes. When the 25-foot module was effectively outlawed in 1901 by the Tenement House Law, private builders still clung to the minimum economic lot frontage, 40 or 50 feet, even when building on multiple lots.
Parts of Flagg's complex were torn down in 1935 but the four corner buildings have survived, owned by Flagg's heirs until 1971, when they were full of rent-paying tenants.
NOW the two buildings at the corner are closed, and 502 West 42d Street is half empty. Only 506 West 42d Street is full of tenants.
According to Fred Papert, director of the private, nonprofit 42d Street Redevelopment Inc., a succession of developers seeking to rebuild the site have harassed tenants to vacate the structures.
In 1991, the First New York Bank for Business took the buildings back in foreclosure. But the current owner can receive no rent until the harassment findings are cleared, to which all tenants must agree.
There are four tenant groups in the two occupied buildings, mired in bitter disputes about inside dealing, buyouts, services and other issues. Meanwhile, the buildings are slowly sagging into a gritty decay.
While most New Yorkers see the revival of far west 42d Street with theaters and apartments as a good thing, some of the tenants do not. Lawrence Flower, vice president of one of the tenant groups, says that the revival only makes the property look more attractive for demolition and redevelopment.
Ken Schechter, managing agent for the bank, calls the situation "a big mess" of competing interests that he has been unable to resolve. "This is a reason to give up on the city," he said.
On the one hand the remaining tenants have effectively preserved their buildings -- vacant structures would have been demolished long ago. But forces beyond their control divide them and this favors further decline rather than improvement.
"We don't know what will happen," said Mr. Flower. "I can beat the meanest landlord in the city but I can't deal with these tenants."

HEADLINE: Representatives Clash on Redistricting

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20

 BODY:
Unaccustomed pawns in the game of redistricting, frenzied members of Congress from New York have been maneuvering with obvious desperation for the slightest advantage, provoking a series of barely concealed clashes within the delegation.
In one of the latest squabbles, the quintessential Brooklyn schmoozer, Representative Charles E. Schumer, squared off against Representative Jose E. Serrano, the Bronx reformer, who surprised his colleagues by supporting a redistricting plan inimical to incumbents. 
 The two Democrats declined to discuss the confrontation. But members of the delegation swear by the showdown. They say Representative Schumer was infuriated last month by Representative Serrano's written support of a Federal court redistricting plan to create three predominantly Hispanic districts.
"I hear you really did us," Mr. Schumer is said to have complained to Mr. Serrano, the Puerto Rican native who had been counted among supporters of a state court redistricting plan, which is more generous to incumbents. "You're making it very difficult for me to go and get you that seat on appropriations."
Delegation members point to the incident as an illustration of the explosive passions and unbridled power plays provoked by the continuing battle over redistricting. Since it will play a major role in determining which incumbents survive, redistricting has come to dominate the lives, conversations and meetings of New York representatives.
 
Careers at Stake
 "Two members from the delegation can't talk to each other without attracting a crowd," said Gary L. Ackerman, the Queens Democrat who may have to run against another veteran incumbent, James H. Scheuer. "It's like a super magnet: the more iron filings you get, the more powerful the attraction. You start talking and it attracts others. Everybody knows what you're talking about and wants to join. It's sort of a cordial paranoia."
But it has not always been so polite, many members of the delegation acknowledge in private. With careers and dreams at stake, the drawn-out tension has rubbed nerves raw. "This process makes Chinese water torture look like a quick and painless extraction of a tooth with Novocain," said Representative Stephen J. Solarz, the veteran Brooklyn Democrat. "It just keeps going on and on and on."
Although the election is approaching, the end is not yet in sight. Earlier this month, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo signed a redistricting plan passed by the State Legislature. But he forwarded it with a recommendation that it be reworked to the Justice Department, which must review the lines to insure they comply with the 1965 Voting Rights Act by giving adequate representation to minorities. The Federal plan remains in limbo until the Justice Department makes a decision.
The Governor's move has led tempers to flare. Publicly, the delegation has sought to present an image of camaraderie and shared suffering. But behind the closed doors of delegation meetings, members say, longtime friends have found themselves at each other's throats. "There are a lot of cruel things happening," said Representative Charles B. Rangel, the Harlem Democrat, who declined to go into details. "All the warts are showing. Friends today, adversaries tomorrow."
 
Pre-emptive Attacks
 Once or twice, the battles have become public. The most notorious is the skirmish between Mr. Ackerman and Mr. Scheuer. Their behind-the-scene feud broke into the open recently when Roll Call, a newspaper on Capitol Hill, suggested that Mr. Ackerman leaked the names of the main culprits in the House check-cashing scandal. In a pre-emptive fax attack, Mr. Scheuer, who was on the list, distributed the story to New York reporters. Mr. Ackerman denied the charge. And his staff retaliated by calling attention to an article in The Washington Times that noted that Mr. Scheuer was one of four Representatives to take their spouses to the Earth Summit in Brazil at taxpayer expense.
Delegation members, at least, gave Mr. Scheuer the call. "Ackerman's hurt himself very badly," said one New York City congressman. "Despite his denial, his fingerprints are all over the thing."
Feelings are particularly charged because many Representatives, who are accustomed to wielding power and who have donated tens of thousands of dollars to state legislators, now find themselves with little influence over the outcome. "It's very difficult, humbling to go into a new area" Mr. Rangel said.
Members of the delegation say the infighting can only become more bitter as the election approaches and members condemned to share a district are forced to begin campaigning against one another. "You're going to see a bloodbath," said one delegation member, who noted that some of the state's most powerful incumbents appear almost certain to end up in the same districts. "We haven't seen the worst of it yet by any means."
The skirmishing may not end with the election. Mr. Ackerman says the battles are not only the epilogue to national population shifts, but also a preview of the competition likely to dominate New York City politics as the fastest-growing minority groups, Hispanic people and Asians, seek to assert themselves. That, he predicts, will provoke confrontations with blacks, the city's dominant minority.
"Blacks were the protected class," he said. "Now, it's almost like move over boys, there's a new minority in town."
That is disputed by other delegation members. Mr. Rangel notes that redistricting is always contentious and predicts that the delegation, especially its minority members, will coalesce after the election. But for the moment, probably the only unifying threat is anger at the state Legislature. New York representatives complain that state lawmakers put too little emphasis on seniority and did not do enough to protect incumbents. That has been a major factor in convincing several Congressmen to retire.
 
Congressional Casualties
 Frank Horton, the dean of the delegation, two weeks ago interrupted a meeting of New York representatives to order them all to run for re-election. "We can't afford to lose anyone," said the Rochester Republican, the ranking minority on the Government Operations Committee. "I want to see everyone of you back."
The next week, Representative Raymond J. McGrath, the ranking New York Republican on the powerful Ways and Means Committee, announced he was retiring. Then David O'B. Martin of Canton, a veteran Republican who has used his seat on the Armed Services Committee to grab large slices of the Federal financial pie for his economically distressed district, said he would not return.
Finally, Mr. Horton gave up. Citing redistricting, which seemed likely to force him into a re-election battle against a longtime friend, Representative Louise M. Slaughter, a Democrat, the 72-year-old Republican announced he would become the sixth member of the delegation to retire at the end of this term.
 Yet the article acknowledged that both men had declined to discuss the conversation with a reporter. It implied that other New York Congressmen had done so, but it failed to make clear that they were the source of the direct quotation. Such a second-hand version should not have been placed in quotation marks; if paraphrased, it should have been described as an account from other Congressmen.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 25, 1992, Thursday

An article on Sunday about Congressional redistricting depicted anxiety among members of New York State's Congressional delegation afraid of losing their seats. As an illustration, the article reported a squabble between two Democratic Representatives, Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn and Jose E. The article reported that Mr. Schumer was "said to have complained" to Mr. Serrano: "I hear you really did us. You're making it very difficult for me to go and get you that seat on appropriations."

HEADLINE: Mayors in Both Parties Voice Frustration

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, June 20

 BODY:
As the United States Conference of Mayors gathers here for its annual meeting, both Republicans and Democrats are voicing frustration with what they see as the Federal Government's inability to act on even the most pressing matters. But some hope that the need to gather support in a three-way Presidential race may help break the gridlock.
At a news conference to open the meeting on Friday, the organization's vice president, Mayor William J. Althaus of York, Pa., said the $1.3 billion urban aid bill passed by both houses of Congress on Thursday was "a fine down payment." But he added, "Until last night, seven weeks after the riots in Los Angeles, the Federal Government at both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue had enacted nothing." 
 Mr. Althaus, a Republican, also criticized the Presidential campaign. "We have people shouting at each other," he said. "People criticizing TV characters. People criticizing rap singers. Everybody is criticizing somebody, and we're not getting anything done."
Mayor Raymond L. Flynn of Boston, a Democrat who is president of the mayor's conference, had to leave Houston on Friday to deal with a disturbance that erupted during a concert at Boston's City Hall Plaza the night before. But in prepared remarks that he left behind he bemoaned the "politics of paralysis" in Washington.
 
'Bread-and-Butter Issues'
 "There always seems to be some diversion," Mr. Flynn said, "a short-lived economic upturn, a fraudulent 'balanced budget' proposal or some visiting dignitary that keeps the President and Congress from dealing with basic, bread-and-butter issues for the American people."
The conference is a nonpartisan organization whose members represent cities with populations of at least 30,000. During its 60-year history it has become a major voice in Washington for the nation's cities.
The conference's six-day meeting here will become a focal point for the discussion of urban issues next week. On Monday, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the presumed Democratic Presidential nominee, as well as Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp will address the mayors. Both President Bush and Ross Perot, the undeclared independent Presidential candidate, declined invitations to address the conference, each citing schedule conflicts.
Also on the program are addresses by the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, among others.
 
Inattention Is Criticized
 At the news conference on Friday, Mayor Bob Lanier of Houston was asked how Mr. Perot's candidacy might affect the cities' efforts to win attention. A land developer who was elected last year in a nonpartisan contest, Mr. Lanier said, "If I am selling shoes, I'd rather have three people out there wanting my shoes than just two."
While he said it would be logical to expect Presidential candidates to direct appeals at cities, Mr. Lanier expressed some exasperation that this had not occurred even after the rioting in Los Angeles. "I suspect it is because they have not fully thought out their programs," he said. "It's not because they are so wonderful that they want to keep them secret for a while."
The mayors have specific proposals of their own and are raising questions about ideas that have gained prominence since the violence in California.
A major component in the conference's urban aid package is a call to increase spending on Community Development Block Grants from the $3.4 billion already appropriated for this year to $6 billion for the 1993 fiscal year. The figure is based on a survey in which 184 cities were asked how much of an increase they could spend on specific proposals within a year.
First enacted by the Nixon Administration, the block grants provide Federal aid for a wide variety of local activities like job programs, public works and drug abuse treatment. Much of the grants' appeal lies in their being tried and true.
 
Skepticism at New Program
 "It is a proven program," Mr. Althaus said, "one that works, one that is there. You do not have to create anything new."
Many mayors were skeptical of the Bush Administration's new "weed and seed" program, which would start with tough law-enforcement efforts to remove known criminals from inner-city neighborhoods and then turn to crime- and drug-prevention programs along with other services aimed at revitalizing the community.
The Administration has asked Congress for $500 million in the next budget for such programs, which would be administered by the Department of Justice.
At an appearance before a conference panel Friday, Timothy Shea, an associate deputy attorney general, was repeatedly asked how much of the $500 million would be taken from existing programs. After saying that "games can be played with the numbers," he said the new financing totaled $290 million.
Mayor Norman B. Rice of Seattle said later, "That leaves a lot of mayors wondering whether signing on to 'weed and seed' just means they'll loose funding for programs that already exist and are successful."
In addition, a resolution submitted to the conference by Mayors Paul Soglin of Madison, Wis., and Paul Helmke of Fort Wayne, Ind., raised other concerns about the new program. Their resolution calls for the law-enforcement and community-help segments of the program to take place simultaneously so that the program does not appear to be simply a police crackdown. The resolution also requests that mayors rather than Justice Department officials be responsible for developing the local programs.

HEADLINE: Koreans Rethink Life in Los Angeles

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 20

 BODY:
Jin Lee was one Korean shopkeeper who tried to do everything right. He held barbecue parties for his black customers, sponsored a neighborhood basketball team, donated money to an anti-gang youth group and was active in a black-Korean church organization.
But when rioting swept the neighborhood where he owned a grocery store, his efforts went for nothing. Like hundreds of other Korean shopkeepers, he lost his store to fire. 
 "We're not sure what we're going to do now," said Mr. Lee, whose family also lost five other small businesses in the inner city. "Financially and emotionally, we're not ready to go back. We are very frustrated and very angry, and also we are afraid."
 
Battered and Stunned
 Six weeks after the riot, in which some 2,500 Korean-owned enterprises were damaged or destroyed, the nation's largest Korean-American community is economically battered and emotionally stunned.
One after another, shopkeepers and community leaders said in interviews that they had been brought up short in their headlong pursuit of an American dream of success through hard work. They said they had learned a hard new lesson in stereotyping and political disenfranchisement.
"It has been a very rude awakening for many Korean-Americans," said Jerry Yu, executive director of the Korean American Coalition, a local advocacy group.
Abandoned by the overburdened police as their shops were looted and burned, many Korean shopkeepers now feel they are being forgotten by government leaders as they seek to recover from their losses.
Among other things, they are the prime victims of a new city ordinance aimed at limiting the number of liquor stores that reopen in South-Central Los Angeles, the area that was at the heart of the rioting.
 
'Lip Service'
 "Some of us thought we were participating in the political process in a way that was meaningful," said Angela Oh, president elect of the Korean American Bar Association of Southern California. "But when it came down to our hour of need, it became very clear that our participation and contributions were perhaps not very meaningful."
Korean merchants complain that government promises of immediate aid have not been honored and that Small Business Administration loans require documentation that most informally operated Korean businesses do not have. They also say they are unfairly stereotyped as successful, self-sufficient and politically irrelevant.
Local leaders say the mutual aid system in which Korean businesses support each other with group lending falls far short of the needs of a community that has suffered as much as $400 million in damage.
As Mr. Lee put it: "We are sick and tired of all this lip service. We want to see dollars in our hands. Our ears are happy but our stomachs are still empty."
 
'It's a War Zone'
 Like Mr. Lee, most Korean shopkeepers remain hesitant about reopening their businesses in the mostly black and Hispanic South-Central area that has come to rely on Koreans for its basic needs.
"Some are saying they would rather die than be back in South-Central," said Kyeyoung Park, an anthropologist at the University of California in Los Angeles. "It's a war zone there. Since 1990 about 25 Korean merchants have been shot by robbers."
But Ivan Light, the author of "Immigrant Entrepreneurs" (University of California Press, 1988), a study of Koreans in Los Angeles, noted that in the end, most shopkeepers would have little choice but to return.
Despite being stereotyped as prosperous, most of the shopkeepers are poor immigrants who work long hours and often remain in debt for years.
"There will be some pulling out," Mr. Light said, "but most of them don't have any options. That is their livelihood. If they walk away, they have to find a buyer, and who is going to buy their store now?"
About one-third of Korean businesses in the city are in the South-Central area, about one-third are in adjacent Koreatown, and one-third are scattered elsewhere, he said.
For the merchants who work in other areas, South-Central Los Angeles remains a fearsome place.
"I wouldn't do business in South-Central," said Mary Seo, who works in her father's auto parts emporium, California Auto Center, in Koreatown. "I've never even been there."
During the riot, with the police nowhere to be found, armed employees guarded her father's store and tossed back out several gasoline bombs that had come crashing through the windows.
 
Complaints About Rudeness
 Mrs. Seo said there was some validity to the stereotype of Korean merchants as brusque, a manner that draws frequent complaints from black customers.
"Some Koreans are rude," said Mrs. Seo, who is 27 years old and who came to the United States as a small child. "When I first went back to Korea I cringed, those people were so rude. Then I went to New York and I realized it's just like New York. It's really fast-paced and very loud."
But a Korean who works in the South-Central area, Neil Hun, said the stereotypes on both sides were false.
"It's just a matter of communication," said Mr. Hun, 23, who works at his uncle's gasoline station. "It's not prejudice, because I never have any problems."
The 1990 census showed that 145,000 people of Korean extraction lived in Los Angeles County, although local estimates put the number much higher. Nearly half of this population supports itself with small retail businesses.
 
Third of Businesses Affected
 By the community's own count, the rioting affected more than a third of the 6,000 Korean-owned businesses in the county. More than half of all businesses destroyed during two days of looting and arson were Korean-owned, Mr. Yu said.
Los Angeles, with its Korean newspapers, radio and television stations and restaurants, is the strongest magnet for the 20,000 Koreans who migrate to the United States each year.
But Mr. Yu said the intense publicity the riot received in Korea may have changed forever the rosy image of the United States and may slow the flow of immigration.
"People had these images of wide, tree-lined streets in mostly quiet neighborhoods, where most Americans are white," he said. "My parents live in Korea. They told me that like everyone around the world they saw the violence in Los Angeles, and they are wondering now, 'Well, do I want to go and live there?' "

HEADLINE: STATE DEPT. AIDE TO TESTIFY ON IRAQ

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20

 BODY:
In a compromise with Congress, the Administration has decided to let a committee hear the testimony of a State Department official who warned his superiors in October 1989 of evidence that United States loan guarantees to Iraq had been diverted to weapons, including "nuclear related equipment."
The testimony by the official, Frank Lemay, a State Department legislative management officer, is a concession to the House Judiciary Committee made this week. The White House denied a committee request earlier in the week to allow the testimony of two Presidential aides: C. Boyden Gray, the White House counsel, and Nicholas Rostow of the National Security Council. 
 The actions came as part of a debate over the Administration's Iraq policy, with critics asserting that American appeasement led to the invasion of Kuwait in August 1990.
Mr. Lemay's 1989 warning came at the same time as a directive by President Bush urging Government agencies to expand economic aid to Baghdad to help moderate Iraq's belligerent behavior. An additional $1 billion in loan guarantees to Iraq was authorized the following month, of which $500 million was committed before Iraq invaded Kuwait.
 
'Nuclear Fuel Compounder'
 The committee has scheduled a hearing Tuesday to consider whether to request an independent prosecutor to investigate the Government's policy toward Iraq before the gulf war, and subsequent allegations of a cover-up by Government officials.
Mr. Lemay is the author of an October 1989 "memorandum of conversation" of a meeting between officials of the State and Agriculture Departments concerning $2 billion in loan guarantees to Iraq made by the Commodity Credit Corporation.
Mr. Lemay, then a Special Assistant to the Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, wrote that "although additional research needs to be done, it appears more and more likely that C.C.C. guaranteed funds and/or commodities may have been diverted from Iraq to third parties in exchange for military hardware."
Mr. Lemay said that "there was some indication that diverted funds and possibly direct bank lent funds were used to procure nuclear related equipment." In particular, the memo noted a "nuclear fuel compounder."
 
Officials to Testify
 Mr. Lemay's memorandum also noted "more and more indications of significant wrongdoing" on the part of the Atlanta Branch of the Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, which made $5 billion in illegal loans to Iraq, much of it backed by loan guarantees by the C.C.C. and the Export-Import Bank.
He said that Agriculture Department officials had said an investigation could "blow the roof off the C.C.C." He concluded the memo by saying that "If smoke indicates fire, we may be facing a four-alarm blast in the near future."
Some Administration officials have challenged Mr. Lemay's version of the meeting, saying it bore little resemblance to what was actually said. That raises the question of why the Administration would want him to testify.
In addition to Mr. Lemay, the Administration has also agreed to allow the Judiciary Committee to hear the testimony of Frank DeGeorge, the Commerce Department's Inspector General, who has acknowledged that the agency altered the documents it gave to a Government Operations subcommittee investigating the C.C.C. loan guarantees.
The Administration has also agreed to allow the testimony of two officials not specifically requested by the committee: Robert S. Mueller 3d, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the criminal division, and Laurence Urgenson, Deputy Assistant Attorney General in charge of the fraud division. They will dispute assertions by Representative Henry Gonzalez, a Texas Democrat and chairman of the Banking Committee, who has accused the Justice Department of delaying its investigation of the Atlanta bank.

HEADLINE: HAITI'S SPLIT SEEN AT A SWEARING-IN

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, June 20

 BODY:
His inaugural address was dedicated to the Haitian masses, but the new Prime Minister, Marc L. Bazin, spoke every word in French on Friday at the stifling official gathering of men in dark suits and perfumed women in white dresses.
The Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, for his swearing-in early last year, had the presidential sash placed on his shoulders by a peasant woman. Throughout that day, the President, Haiti's first freely elected leader, gave his speeches in a proverb-laden Creole. 
 The choice of languages by the two men -- one the priest-President deposed in a military coup, the other, a conservative political rival appointed to replace him, is far more than a matter of style, political analysts say. Rather, they say, it is a vivid reflection of the explosive divide between rich and poor in this small country.
Partisans of Mr. Bazin -- 60 years old, a lawyer and a former World Bank official -- have long promoted him as a modern technocrat and political centrist who they say is uniquely suited to bridging the gap between a fanatical left and right in Haiti.
But for Father Aristide's supporters, concentrated among the 70 percent of the population that remains Creole-speaking, illiterate and desperately poor, such arguments ring hollow.
 
'Nobody Is Being Fooled'
 "We want Aristide, and Aristide is the only thing we will accept," said a Creole-speaking vendor of fruit drinks pushing his cart in a pulsing sun near the National Palace during the ceremonies inside. "Bazin is for the rich, and now they are playing games with us. But nobody is being fooled."
Except for a scruffy handful of people who waited outside during Mr. Bazin's inaugural ceremonies carrying posters praising the new leader, there was no enthusiasm for him in evidence anywhere among the poor in this city.
Among Haiti's tiny elite, the disdain for Father Aristide is just as palpable. Although Mr. Bazin, in one of his first announcements, declared his intention to restart negotiations for an internationally acceptable solution to the eight-month political crisis that began with a violent coup in September, few expect the new Prime Minister to work seriously toward Father Aristide's return.
"The secret is to make a proposal that Washington will see as reasonable and Aristide will be unable to accept," said a businessman who supports Mr. Bazin. "Let Aristide be President again, but President of the 10th Department. We don't want him here."
The 10th Department is the term Father Aristide used to describe the large number of Haitians living outside the country.
Although many wealthy Haitians express disdain for Father Aristide because of his fondness for provocative language that they believe often flirted with incitement to violence, many Haitian intellectuals say there is an overriding class element to their antipathy.
"The bourgeoisie here has been in decline for years," said Jean-Claude Bajeux, a Haitian human rights expert. "But those who remain cling to their privileges, and that was the origin of Aristide's difficulties."
Referring to Father Aristide's background as a poor, dark-skinned person raised in a tiny outlying town, Mr. Bajeux said, "The elites could not accept having someone who reminded them of their domestic staffs governing them."
Although many doubt the chances of his success, wealthy Haitians who have never had anything to do with him before were already lining up behind Mr. Bazin in the days before his inauguration.
There was even talk among many on inauguration day of paying taxes to support the Bazin Government, something many wealthy people freely admit they have avoided in the past.
But regardless of what the new Prime Minister says in public, for many of these people, his mission must be to indefinitely forestall Father Aristide's return and somehow unlock an eight-month embargo that is beginning to inflict serious pain.

HEADLINE: Chance of a Rail Strike Grows as Talks Bog Down

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Railway officials and union leaders made little progress in negotiations yesterday, increasing the possibility of a Wednesday strike at Amtrak, Conrail and other rail lines around the nation.
Union officials argue that a strike at Conrail, which carries most of the freight in the Northeast and links up with most major railroads, would cause only limited disruptions. But Conrail officials and railway analysts say its impact would be felt within days at power utilities and factories throughout the United States. 
 "There is a risk of a nationwide strike," said Graeme Lidgerwood, who follows the rail industry for the First Boston Corporation.
But she pointed out that in past nationwide strikes Congress had been quick to intervene and that it would probably act again if the major union involved, the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, walked out. The association represents 7,800 workers at 40 railroads.
It is less certain, she said, whether Congress would halt a strike by the Brotherhood of Maintenance of Way Employees, which is negotiating separately on the contracts of 4,000 workers at the Consolidated Rail Corporation.
In a third set of negotiations, Amtrak, the nation's largest passenger railroad, faces the same strike deadline by six unions representing 7,900 workers. Besides halting service around the nation, the walkout would close Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan to commuters who use the Long Island Rail Road and New Jersey Transit and shut down the Shore Line East commuter line in Connecticut.
The primary issue in the talks are changes in work rules imposed by a special Presidential board on other unions after a nationwide railway walkout last year.
Labor relations in the railroad industry are governed by a set of procedures under the Railway Labor Act of 1926. In the current talks the parties have exhausted the options under the act, and the unions can legally strike.
 
Congress May Intervene
 Under the act, the President has the option of appointing an emergency board to investigate the dispute, as President Bush did before a nationwide walkout in April 1991. If a strike occurs and Congress believes it would severely disrupt the economy, it can intervene and impose a settlement.
Congress acted within 24 hours of the April walkout, imposing the recommendations of the Presidential Emergency Board. Since then, Conrail has won agreements with most of its unions under the pattern established by the board. The board enabled management to make major cuts in crews and provided other work rule changes that led to greater efficiency.
The unions in the current dispute, however, say such rule changes are unacceptable.
Jed Dodd, the general chairman of the maintenance workers' union, said that little progress had been made in the talks with Conrail. "It doesn't look good," he said in an interview from Washington, where the negotiations are taking place.
Mr. Dodd said that the union was seeking job security for its members. He said that Conrail had laid off 1,000 workers in the last four years and that it had sought to lay off 1,200 more through its proposed work rule changes.
The unions have also rejected the wage increases proposed by the emergency board. Mr. Dodd said his union was asking for a 3 percent wage increase and a formula to keep up with inflation. He said the increase would cost about $3 million a year.
Conrail officials say the union has asked for staffing that would double the work force, to 7,077. It says the wage increases sought by the unions would cost the railroad $103 million a year.
The maintenance union has argued that a strike against Conrail would be regional and has asked Congress not to intervene if its members walk out on Wednesday.
But Conrail, which handled about 16 percent of the industry's total freight in the week of June 6, has warned that utilities in New York, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Michigan and Delaware would be harmed by the halting of coal shipments.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Business View;
Executives Are Lending Perot an Ear

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
On a vacation cruise off Alaska this month with the chief executives of four other large companies, John W. Teets, the chairman of the Dial Corporation, found that one topic came up over and over: Ross Perot.
The conversations were a small but perhaps telling indication that if President Bush believes he can count on support from the corporate executive suite, a solid Republican redoubt if ever there was one, he may be in for a rude surprise. 
 "Perot's obviously a credible candidate, and in the circles I walk in, that's on everyone's mind today," said Mr. Teets, whose company based in Phoenix makes soap and other household products. Unhappy with the performance of the Bush Administration, Mr. Teets said he was nonetheless unsure whether he would vote for Mr. Perot. But he made clear that the Texas billionaire's candidacy has struck a chord with him.
"There has to be some change, some shock to the system to get us back on track," Mr. Teets said.
 
'Leadership and Change'
 Similar messages are emanating from corner offices and board rooms all over the country. More than a dozen interviews with top officers of companies in a variety of industries and locations turned up evidence that the nation's corporate leadership, like much of the rest of the populace, is unhappy with the notion of politics as usual and is willing to consider setting aside traditional political loyalties to take a long, hard look at Mr. Perot.
"I'm very pro-Perot because he says things with a clarity and straightforwardness that is refreshing and because he has a tremendous opportunity for leadership and change," said Michael D. Dingman, the chairman of the Henley Group, a conglomerate based in Hampton, N.H. "In the board rooms I've been in, there's increasing interest in him, even though a lot of people aren't ready to stand up and be counted."
Perceptions of Mr. Perot among business executives remain somewhat fuzzy. Corporate chiefs are looking specifically for more information about how he would reduce the Federal budget deficit, whether he would support reductions in the capital gains tax or extensions of investment tax credits and where he stands on other issues likely to affect business and the economy.
"He says some refreshing things, and he's focused in on a lot of the issues that businessmen and the public are both disturbed about," said F. Kenneth Iverson, the chairman of the Nucor Corporation, the steel company in Charlotte, N.C. "But before I would vote for him, I've got to know a lot more. I've got to know specifically what he's interested in doing."
 
Question About Patience
 Many of the executives said they liked the idea of a business executive as President and admired Mr. Perot's accomplishments in building two successful data-processing companies, Electronic Data Systems, which is now owned by the General Motors Corporation, and Perot Systems, which the Texas billionaire founded four years ago.
Frank Cruz, the chairman of the Gulf Atlantic Life Insurance Company, the nation's first Hispanic-owned life insurer, said he was particularly hopeful that Mr. Perot would put higher priority on freeing growing businesses from government regulation and making government an agent of economic growth rather than an impediment.
But as business managers, most of whom have encountered dictatorial bosses or are such bosses themselves, they said they also worry that Mr. Perot might not fully understand that as President he could no longer direct change and action in the same way he could as the autocratic head of a company.
"My question and concern is whether he has the willingness and patience to deal with the broad spectrum of values he'd have to deal with," said Dennis Gormley, the chairman of the Federal-Mogul Corporation, a maker of automotive parts in Southfield, Mich. "From what I've seen and read, I haven't seen that he has the willingness, desire or capability to deal with that diversity."
President Bush, moreover, still has many influential and vocal supporters in the corporate world who are taking the offensive against Mr. Perot. Lodwrick M. Cook, the chairman of ARCO, the oil company based in Los Angeles, said he was bothered that Mr. Perot had no real experience in foreign affairs, that Mr. Perot had been vague on where he stood on many issues and that Mr. Perot, as an outsider with no political affiliation, might find it difficult to deal with Congress and build a consensus for any action.
"Frankly, it concerns me that a political novice should seek the Presidency of the United States as his very first office," said Mr. Cook, a Republican fund-raiser and a friend of Mr. Bush.
 
Shock Treatment
 But many chief executives -- a group used to making decisions and taking action -- said Washington is in need of the shock-treatment approach that Mr. Perot's candidacy represents.
Indeed, to Mr. Perot's supporters in business, his main appeal seems to be his reputation for taking decisive action, even when it involves risk, and for bringing common sense to a public policy-making process that to them often seems disconnected from the real world.
"I don't know which guerrilla group he favors in Afghanistan, and I don't care," said Alan Greenberg, the chief executive of Bear, Stearns & Company, the brokerage and investment banking condcern. "He's a doer, he's very smart, and that's enough for me."
Some executives said they considered Mr. Perot's reputation as a man of action and accomplishment to be overblown. Several of them, including Mr. Gormley of Federal-Mogul, pointed to Mr. Perot's contentious and ultimately unsuccessful attempt to work for change within General Motors. Mr. Perot became a major G.M. shareholder when the automaker bought his Electronic Data Systems, but he later sold his stock back.
"One can say he should have had an impact on General Motors, and he did not have an impact in a positive way," Mr. Gormley said. "That either says he wasn't willing to spend the time and effort, or that he took the wrong approach or that he didn't have the capability. None of those bode well for a guy who's got to get a consensus when it comes to governing."
Surveys of corporate executives have found widely varying opinions about Mr. Perot. In a poll of chief executives of the nation's largest corporations last month, Fortune magazine found that 78 percent of those responding said they planned to vote for President Bush, with 11 percent supporting Mr. Perot and 4 percent saying they would vote for Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the probable Democratic nominee. But the magazine reported that even many supporters of President Bush said they would vote for him with little enthusiasm.
Mr. Perot's standing appears to be much stronger among people who run medium-sized and smaller businesses. A nationwide survey last month of its members by the American Electronics Association, a trade group, found that 55 percent of the chief executives who responded supported Mr. Perot. The survey found that 29 percent supported Mr. Bush and that 4 percent supported Mr. Clinton.

HEADLINE: The Tallest Fence: Feelings on Race in a White Neighborhood

SERIES: 2 Neighborhoods, 2 Worlds/First of two articles.

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, June 20

 BODY:
In a kind of simulcast version of blue-collar America, the mechanics and postal workers of Chicago's Mount Greenwood and Roseland sections emerge each weekend to start the sprinklers and trim the junipers outside prim houses with picture windows.
The two are churchgoing, workaday neighborhoods made up of people who put in overtime to pay the bills, who curse drugs and dandelions with equal indignation and who dream of a better life and maybe even college for their children. 
 The chief difference between the two is that Mount Greenwood is white and Roseland is black. They are separated by two miles, a highway and fear and suspicion so deep that many people in one community would not dare set foot in the other.
Their worlds are set up so that the races rarely intersect, coming together only briefly in the white sections of town at public places like the mall or at work, where people may know little about each other beyond names and job descriptions.
 
How It Should Be?
 "It's fine for them to live in their neighborhoods and us to live in ours," said Peggy O'Connor, a Mount Greenwood waitress. "I guess that's the way it's supposed to be. We don't need to mix."
"Blacks live in their section and we live in ours, and that's O.K.," said Elaine Pomper, who owns Bob's Service, an automobile repair shop in Mount Greenwood.
The races are left to see each other through the distorted lens of segregation, and the perspective is further warped by the competition for a shrinking supply of blue-collar jobs. Particularly for whites, it seems, what they learn about the other race often comes from television news or stereotypes passed down through the generations.
In many ways, social scientists say, the two neighborhoods represent a society that is still two nations in one, 24 years after the Kerner Commission first made its diagnosis, and as dramatized this spring by the Los Angeles riots.
"This is a country in perpetual civil war," said Andrew Hacker, a professor of political science at Queens College and author of "Two Nations" (Macmillan, 1992). "Whites are saying: 'Look at what we did for you. You let the team down.' It is as if black Americans are on probation and have to prove themselves. Blacks are saying, 'Don't expect us to be grateful just because we can sit on the bus with you.' "
More than 100 residents in these two South Side communities, interviewed by reporters of their own race, bore out this scenario, forming a picture of divided worlds where race and discrimination are defining facts of daily life for blacks and somebody else's problem for whites.
 
Differences
Two Enclaves: Separate, Unequal
 As similar as the two neighborhoods seem, their differences are telling. The gap in their median household incomes widened significantly in the 1980's. Essentially a working-class area, Roseland embraces a much greater range of incomes, including real poverty. One insurer estimates that the same policy for the same car, a 1990 Ford Taurus, would cost $1,445 a year in Roseland but $958 in Mount Greenwood, presumably because the crime rate is so much higher in Roseland.
Mount Greenwood, with a population of 19,000, is an insular, "Leave It to Beaver" world where white people can live out entire lives without ever getting to know a black person, where people rarely venture beyond understood borders.
Roseland, with a population of 56,000, is hardscrabble and rough-edged, made up of black homeowners who watched their dreams of integration evaporate in the 1970's as white neighbors moved out to places like Mount Greenwood.
The very mention of race unlocked a torrent of painful accounts from blacks in Roseland, who told of lifelong attacks and indignities and who said they felt discrimination was in some ways worse now than it was 20 years ago.
"Wherever you go you see hatred," said Clemmie Raggs, a forklift operator who lives in Roseland. "You never know where racism is going to stick its head up."
Robert Scott, a Roseland resident who is a sewer maintenance worker, said: "The institutions, the media, the politicians -- the whole system keeps the races divided. We got the opportunity to move out to white areas, but they don't want us there."
Despite frequent negative experiences with whites, most Roseland residents said they would still welcome a person of the other race into their home and would like to live in an integrated neighborhood.
The same questions drew either blank looks or impassioned diatribes about welfare and affirmative action from most whites in Mount Greenwood. Many said they would not want a black to live next door. And while many described the few blacks they knew from work as decent, they still harbored an almost instinctive animosity toward black people in general.
 
Hints of Deeper Gulf
 Some Mount Greenwood residents were at first visibly uncomfortable with the topic of race. Some declined to discuss the matter.
Their reaction suggests an even greater schism, social scientists say. "Being white in America means never having to think about it," said Joe R. Feagin, a professor of sociology at the University of Florida, who has written extensively on race relations. "The racist world is the real world for us. It's the dominant culture, the way we look at things. For blacks, whiteness is oppression."
The 1980's were much kinder to Mount Greenwood than to Roseland. The two started the decade at about the same place, with Mount Greenwood's median household income then at $21,996 and Roseland's at $18,540.
But as manufacturing jobs waned nationwide and service jobs predominated, Mount Greenwood profited. Its median income nearly doubled to $40,226 in 1990, according to Census Bureau figures. Roseland's rose at about half that rate to $28,601. When inflation is taken into account, Roseland's families were in effect making $2,700 less a year in 1990 than they were in 1980. Mount Greenwood's families were making $5,097 more.
Black people are hurt and resentful over these disparities. "Go into any white neighborhood, and you'll see businesses and parks and playgrounds with swings in different colors," said Myshawn Davis, a hairdresser in Roseland. "It's like Disneyland."
The differences can perhaps best be seen along 111th Street, the commercial strip that runs through both communities, changing personality as it goes. It is gritty and weather-beaten in Roseland, one liquor store and rib shack after another. It is fresh-scrubbed in Mount Greenwood with its appliance centers, denture clinics, drapery stores and taverns with names like Molly McGillicuddy's.
What follows are the voices of white Mount Greenwood residents, explaining how they came to form their impressions of blacks. An article on Monday explores Roseland residents' views of whites.
 
Stereotypes
Myths That Foster Wish for Isolation
 It is places like Roseland that Mount Greenwood residents ran from in the 1960's. They have little patience for talk of discrimination. And many say it is fine by them if there are no blacks around.
"I don't mind them, but I don't want them living next to me," said Peggy O'Connor, a waitress and wife of a police officer. "I don't want to be too close to them. I think they've been whining too long, and I'm sick of it."
Like other Mount Greenwood residents, Mrs. O'Connor is rarely around black people to hear the "whining" personally or to see what the trouble might be. It infuriates her that "blacks buy porterhouse steaks with food stamps, while we eat hamburgers," she said. She said she had never actually seen any blacks do this. But she has heard and read stories, and that is enough.
Stories like that take on mythical proportions in a place like Mount Greenwood. Here there is great pride in the legends of forebears who came over from the old country.
"My grandparents, when they came here from Italy, didn't ask anyone to speak Italian for them," said Adeline Barrins, a homemaker who runs a small T-shirt business in Mount Greenwood. "They became American, and they never asked for anything."
Most whites said they saw nothing stopping blacks from doing the same thing. "They feel they worked hard for what they got," said Robert T. Carter, an associate professor of psychology at Columbia University Teachers College, who specializes in the study of white racial attitudes. "It's a disguised way of saying that blacks are not worthy."
Slavery, a painful topic for blacks, is a sensitive area in Mount Greenwood, too. It comes up in conversation often as whites say that past and even current discrimination is irrelevant. "It's up to them to paddle their own canoe," said Catherine Nielsen, a longtime resident. "Don't always think about the fact that they were slaves."
The racial fear and suspicion work both ways. But the paradox, interviews show, is that black people were fearful because much of their contact with white people was negative; whites were fearful because they had little or no contact. Across this divide, stereotypes become reality.
"It's either a stabbing or a shooting," Bernadette Quinn, a hardware store clerk in Mount Greenwood, said of blacks. "Those people don't talk to each other."
 
Assumptions Without Experience
 She has never spent much time around black people to know whether this is true. But she is as convinced of this as she is that the perennials will bloom next spring. The few blacks she knows are "lovely people," she said. But she is skeptical about the rest.
That is why she would not want to live next to any. "I'd be afraid they wouldn't keep up the property," she said. "Who's to say they wouldn't rob you, or what kind of people they'd bring around?"
The disadvantages for blacks of isolation and discrimination are well documented. What is less talked about, social scientists say, is the psychic toll that segregation can take on whites. "Whites have to use a tremendous amount of energy to maintain the distortion," Professor Carter said. "Time, energy and money are devoted to creating safe environments away from black people."
When blacks appear where they are not expected, it takes some whites here time to adjust. Several years ago, Mrs. Quinn's teen-age son had a party and invited a black girl.
"She was a lovely girl when we met her," Mrs. Quinn said. "But our first impression was, 'What is she doing in our house?' We were shocked. Our son said, 'Don't worry, she's a nice girl.' And she was. She is a lovely girl. She has been back a couple times now."
But those positive feelings do not transfer to black people in general. Each time she meets a black person, Mrs. Quinn must be convinced all over again that this one is O.K.
"Where I work, we have some black people that shop there," Mrs. Quinn said. "I'm very apprehensive about it. But once you get to know them, they're very nice."
 
Suspicions
Bad Feelings Feed Themselves
 In many ways, William Knepper Jr. is the opposite of what the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. had in mind in his "I Have a Dream" message. Mr. Knepper, a 23-year-old auto mechanic, is the product of an all-white world. His parochial school was white, his block is white, his friends are white. And television is his window to the other America.
All he knows about blacks, he said, is this: "They came from Africa, and they can get away with a lot of stuff because they're black, they're a minority."
Sometimes he has to drive to black neighborhoods to get auto parts for his job. When he does, he takes a baseball bat. His few direct contacts with blacks are mostly benign, and on his turf. "The one time I ever come in contact with them is in stores, and they seem all right," Mr. Knepper said.
He is aware that being white has its benefits. "I think we still have the upper hand," Mr. Knepper said. "If I was running a business and two qualified people apply for a job, one black and one white, I would probably go with the white guy. I'd feel safer."
To Mr. Knepper, that is the way the world should be. And attitudes like his are no excuse for blacks not to try. "We have the upper hand but they can go out and get a job," he said.
Mr. Knepper is not exactly against affirmative action. "You only need a certain percentage of them in jobs, and as long as you get that percentage, the rest can be white," he said.
Mr. Knepper's father, William Sr., an eighth-grade teacher at St. Christina's, said he never had a bad experience with blacks, and feels sympathetic toward them. "From my experience with them, they're like us," the elder Mr. Knepper said. "They have the same goals, the same aspirations, the same fears. When they blame something on racism, I tend to agree with them."
In raising his three children, he said he "never pushed race one way or the other." He said he let them form their own opinions of blacks, that he tried to correct his son when he could. "Any time he said something about race, I told him, 'You don't really know,' " Mr. Knepper said.
 
Relationships
Some Closeness, Little Friendship
 Most people said they had never had a friend of the other race.
Among the few who did, whites usually had a broader definition of "friend." Some were quick to say that blacks they met at work or in service roles were their friends. Some police officers called the blacks whose neighborhoods they patrol their friends. But they said they rarely, if ever, did the things that friends do, like having them over for dinner.
Blacks were more cynical. While white co-workers called them friends, blacks said they felt more like mascots than intimates. "On the job they will laugh and joke with you," said Sebron Jones, a postal worker who lives in Roseland. "When they get off work, they're through with you."
He remembers once seeing a white co-worker at a bus stop and walking over to say hello. The co-worker turned his back and refused to answer him, apparently afraid of what people would think. Another white co-worker told Mr. Jones that he wanted to invite him to his house but was worried about the neighbors.
"I told him, 'If I want to invite you to my house, I wouldn't give a doggone what the neighbors think,' " Mr. Jones said.
Neither relationship survived. And Mr. Jones is doubtful whether blacks and whites can ever be friends. "There's never been one I could trust," he said.
 
A Family Radical
 The few whites in Mount Greenwood who made friends across the color line became suddenly aware of the anti-black sentiment.
Mary Knepper, who works at a Kentucky Fried Chicken and is young William Knepper's sister, is considered a radical in her family. She made friends with a black girl at a public high school she attended. Some neighborhood children once yelled epithets at them as the two walked down a Mount Greenwood street. Since then, Ms. Knepper has been protective. "I worry about her when she comes over," Ms. Knepper said. "If she's coming over on the bus, and she's late, I go out and start looking for her."
What happens in places like Roseland and Mount Greenwood has resonance for the rest of the country, social scientists say. "Racial tension and hostility show up first and more intensely in the working class because this group is in the immediate line of fire," said William Julius Wilson, a professor of sociology at the University of Chicago and author of "The Truly Disadvantaged" (University of Chicago Press, 1987).
"Not enough attention is given to black and white working-class folks," he said. "If you could get these groups to recognize their common interests, it would go a long way toward alleviating racial hostility."
The elder Mr. Kneppers wonders if that will ever happen. He figures that even if white hostility toward blacks ended tomorrow, "we'd still find someone to hate."
