LENGTH: 1055 words

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
A Revival for the Shakespeare Theater?

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
CONNECTICUT will soon select a private developer to revive the twice-failed American Shakespeare Festival Theater in Stratford as a nonprofit theater and May-to-October tourist destination.
 Sixteen developers have voiced interest in making proposals, to be accompanied by $100,000 security payments, by the July 29 deadline. The winner will be announced Sept. 1, although the sluggish economy raises doubts that there will be many proposals. 
The state will retain ownership, leasing the property to a developer for $1 a year. "We want to see a theater in operation for the 1993 season," said Joseph Cohen, spokesman for the state's Department of Economic Development, which has oversight.
 "State ownership is vital," he said, "to prevent a cultural gem from being developed into condos or commercial use if it fell into private hands. Furthermore, if the entertainment was distasteful or unacceptable by community standards, the state could sever the agreement."
 Founded in 1954 by directors of New York's prestigious Theater Guild on 14.5 acres on the Housatonic River, the American Shakespeare Festival Theater enjoyed initial success. Only Shakespeare was presented -- an American counterpart of the Globe Theater in Stratford-Upon-Avon in England and the Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, Ont. Built to resemble the Globe, it attracted such performers as Katharine Hepburn, Helen Hayes, Alfred Drake and Maurice Evans.
 But audiences dwindled over a 25-year period until the theater went bankrupt and was taken over by CityTrust. In 1983, it was bought by the state for $1.3 million, designated a state park and operated unsuccessfully by a board of directors. Today, the building is boarded up and deteriorated. The grounds have gone wild and the bronze statue of Hamlet contemplates a river obscured by undergrowth.
 So far only two proposals have been made public. Louis A. Burke, a South African impresario whose American ventures include the recent Broadway production of "Meet Me in St. Louis," is preparing a plan estimated to cost $100 million. And David D. Reed, a director of audience development for the Shakespeare Theater from 1968 to 1973, and his partner, Peter Kosinski, a New Haven architect, would spend around $28 million on their proposal.
 While both plans envision first-class productions of the classics, musicals, 20th-century plays and works by new playwrights, performed by a resident company and guest stars, there is a crucial difference: Mr. Reed would build an inn on state land next to the existing theater; the Burke proposal calls for a hotel on an adjacent private site.
 "To build in the park would destroy public views and access," said Vincent Chase, Republican State Represenative from Stratford. "The selection committee will be concerned about that. Stratford prefers to see it remain greenspace."
 MR. BURKE would restore and modernize the existing theater with 1,400 seats for musicals and large-scale productions and add a 700-seat theater for straight plays and a 250-seat black-box stage for intimate drama, music and lectures. An academy for graduate theater students would be revived, and the grounds, parking lots and picnic areas along the river would be refurbished.
 Supplementary revenues would be generated by a 350-room hotel, a marina and restaurants, bed-and-breakfasts and boutiques. Resident company would be housed in several antique homes that are for sale next to the site. Overall, his proposal covers some 39 acres.
 "We want to create a New England village," said Mr. Burke, "where people can come from across town for an evening, or from anywhere in the world by car, boat, train or plane -- Sikorksky Airport is minutes away -- and spend a weekend or a week." Theatrical offerings would run simultaneously in three theaters, with programs changing every few days.
 Mr. Reed's plan is limited to the on-site inn of 128 rooms, restoration of the theater, academy, and grounds, and the addition of a black-box theater and restaurant.
 "The development of hotels, shops, restaurants and marinas, as proposed by Burke," said Mr. Chase, "bodes well for the town. It would be a boost for real estate values, particularly when coupled with the recent designation of the surrounding residential area as a National Historic District. And it would be a source of jobs."
 Competition for audiences would come chiefly from New Haven, where the Yale Repertory and Long Wharf Theaters have long been among the country's top regional theaters. N. Edgar Rosenblum, director of Long Wharf, was on a Governor's committee that made recommendations for the Shakespeare Theater's operation.
 "I think the state is flogging a dead horse," said Mr. Rosenblum. "It is not a good theater physically, the location is remote for the theatergoing public and the state should be spending its money on existing professional theaters that it has cut by 31 percent."
 "In healthier days we all prospered," he said, "and one more theater wouldn't have made any difference. Now we must be concerned about competing for corporate sponsors as well as government funds."
 MR. Cohen insists that "the state will not put up a penny," but Mr. Rosenblum believes that the state as owner has an undeniable financial stake in the property.
 ANOTHER strong competitor will be the new Stamford Center for the Arts, a $16 million theater of 700 seats, with a 150-seat studio theater, theatrical training facilities and a television broadcasting component, scheduled to open in late September.
 Randy Brion, executive director since its inception, has relinquished his post to Alexander Cohen, the Broadway producer, who began a three-year stint earlier this month.
 "Each theater has to stake out its territory," said Mr. Brion. "Local people make up 80 percent of all ticket sales, and since non- profits earn about 60 percent from the box-office, they need a substantial stream of other revenue. With the real estate market as it is, it's difficult to depend on other revenues. If they are business ventures, those businesses have to be successful."
 Connecticut's legitimate theater is rivaled by that of few other states. Other theaters operating in Connecticut are the Hartford Stage Company, Goodspeed Opera House-East Haddam, Shubert-New Haven, and Westport Playhouse.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Money Matters in Eastern Europe

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
TRAVELERS going to eastern Europe this summer will probably find money a source of concern: where to change it, which currency is preferred and where credit cards and traveler's checks are accepted constitute some of the potential hassles. Russia, other parts of the former Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, the former German Democratic Republic, Hungary, Poland and Romania are gradually linking up with Western financial networks, but progress is spotty and irregular.
 This column contains a roundup of information from bureaus and contributors in Europe at the beginning of June, but it should be supplemented if possible with last-minute data from the place you are going. No guidebook can be up to date on changes, and this column too will age rapidly. 
Automatic teller machines that give you cash from your account at home through the Cirrus or Plus networks, although they are increasingly found overseas, have not yet made a big dent in the former Soviet bloc. The American Express company has set up a network to allow its cardholders to get money from accounts that they designate in advance and has installed 24-hour cash machines to dispense this money in Moscow, Warsaw, Budapest and Prague. But entry into this Express Cash network must be obtained before leaving the United States; applications may be obtained by calling (800) 227-4669. There is no charge for signing up, which takes two to three weeks, but individual transactions cost from $2.50 to $10.
 Here are the contributors' reports.
 Russia and other former Soviet republics. Hard currency, in dollars or German marks, is what makes the wheels go round here. In major Russian tourist hotels and some restaurants, charge and credit cards, preferably American Express, Visa and Mastercard, are also accepted. Under duress -- meaning you threaten to leave without paying -- hotels and restaurants will accept traveler's checks, preferably in dollars or marks.
 In other former Soviet republics, foreign hard currency is the medium of choice -- dollars, marks, British pounds, francs.
 There are two American Express automatic teller machines in Moscow, at the American Express office at 21-A Sadovaya-Kurindskaya, where rubles may be obtained, and one at the Mezhdunarodnaya Hotel at 12 Krasnopresnenskaya Naberezhnaya, where rubles or dollar-denominated traveler's checks may be obtained.
 There is no limit on the amount of foreign currency a visitor may take in and no requirement to buy a certain amount of rubles. However, visitors must declare all the currency they are taking in, and should hang on to the customs form because it, and any receipts for bank currency transactions, will be checked against the amount of currency on departure to be sure that you are not taking out more than you came in with.
 Two pieces of advice: First, rubles will be hard to convert at departure points. Second, with the uncertainty of credit cards and traveler's checks, thieves expect travelers to be carrying a lot of cash, so money should be well protected.
 Poland. The country is apparently moving rapidly into a free market economy, with lessening currency problems for tourists . Dollars as well as zlotys are accepted for major purchases, with the exchange rate set by the National Bank.
 American Express, Visa, Mastercard and the Air Travel Cards are reported to be accepted in hotels and major restaurants in main tourist areas. American Express has an automatic teller for its cardholders at its Warsaw office, Dom Bez Kantow, Krakowskie Przedmiescie 11.
 Traveler's checks in dollars, marks and pounds are accepted by the Orbis official tourist agencies, the American Express office in Warsaw and the National Bank of Poland.
 Poland's shift means that dollars can be changed into zlotys at exchange bureaus, known as kantors, at hotels, airports and rail stations.
 Travelers must still declare the amount of money taken in, and receipts should be saved for a possible check on departure.
 Czechoslovakia. Dollars are not so easily used for crowns as they may be for local currencies elsewhere in the former Soviet bloc, and crowns are not convertible outside the country at all. For travel outside Prague, it is wise to convert dollars in advance, as exchange offices may be sparse and may be shut on weekends.
 Most first- and second-class hotels -- the top two grades -- in tourist areas accept American Express, Visa and Mastercard. First-class tourist restaurants may also accept these cards and Diners' Club, too, but restaurants are less consistent, and it is wise to inquire.
 Traveler's checks in Western denominations may be used at first-class hotels but probably not in restaurants and shops. Western currency may be exchanged at hotels and banks and at exchange offices, which usually stay open until 10 P.M. There are no restrictions on the amount of foreign currency that may be brought into the country.
 Crowns may be obtained in Prague on American Express's Express Cash service at the company's new offices at 56 Wenceslas Square and from the 24-hour cash machine in front. Advances through the Visa, Mastercard and Diners' Club cards may be obtained at a Chequepoint office of the Cekobanka at Rijna 13, at the bottom of Wenceslas Square. There are two Cirrus automatic teller machines to dispense crowns being tested at the Komercini Banks at Prikope 28 and Prikope 3-5.
 Hungary. In Budapest and other major cities, most internationally accepted credit cards -- Visa, American Express, Diners' Club, Mastercard and Eurocard --may be used in hotels, high-priced restaurants and some stores. In smaller towns and stores, hard currency still reigns. American Express cards may be used to obtain Express Cash forints at machines at two company offices in Budapest, Deak Ferenc utca 10, and at the airport. Cash in dollars, through Visa and American Express cards, may be obtained at the Hungarian Foreign Trade Bank at Turr Istvan utca 9. There is a 6 percent commission .
Eastern Germany. The situation here is different because the Federal Republic, to which the former German Democratic Republic is now rejoined, was long accustomed to dealing with foreign tourists. Because this eased the way, leading credit card companies are said to be working feverishly to expand their networks into the former East German area.
 Travelers checks can be cashed at any bank or exchange office. There are American Express Express Cash machines in Schonefeld Airport in Berlin and at the Dresden and Leipzig central railroad stations.
Romania. Purchases must be made in the local currency, the lei, and hotels, restaurants and stores are generally quite careful about this. Not all hotels have exchange services, although they will try to help visitors find an exchange that is open when they are checking out.
 The most convertible currency in Romania at the moment, a correspondent reports, is German marks, with some exchange offices refusing to accept dollars for hours or days at a time. Hotels in Bucharest and a few other major cities will accept Visa, American Express and Diners' Club, but decals on a restaurant door are not reliable indicators.
 Traveler's checks can be cashed at a few exchange offices, but are even less likely to be accepted than credit cards at hotels and restaurants. There are no strictures on how much may be taken in, but customs officers may ask the amount and suggest that large amounts be declared.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 7, 1992, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A report in the Travel Advisory column on June 7 referred incorrectly to the Lake Michigan Carferry Service. It is not the only cross-lake ferry operating on the Great Lakes. A reader's letter, dated June 18, points out that the Pelee Island Ferry crosses Lake Erie between Sandusky, Ohio, and Leamington, Ontario.

HEADLINE: FILM;
Romancing the Book . . . Once Again

BYLINE: By PAT H. BROESKE; Pat H. Broeske covers movies and popular culture for Entertainment Weekly.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
In story-hungry Hollywood, executives not known for reading are suddenly thumbing eagerly through the classics. But if Hollywood is desperately seeking material, it also keeps its priorities. In the film industry, reading and writing are not nearly as important as arithmetic. Ticket sales remain the ultimate goal, and the challenge is to please the mass audience, not placate scholars or connoisseurs of literature.
When Daily Variety recently announced the sale of a script for a new remake of "The Three Musketeers," it quoted a Disney executive who bragged about the script's "contemporary edge," the hip dialogue and a buddy relationship similar to that of Mel Gibson and Danny Glover in "Lethal Weapon." What's more, the executive claimed, the remake would be faithful to Alexandre Dumas's 1844 novel. 
 In recent years, major studios have largely shied away from the classics, although they once pursued them with a passion. Adaptations of literary works have been handled mainly by small, independent companies. Recalling attempts to interest Hollywood in such books as late as the mid-80's, the director James Ivory says, "We were told the classics were poisonous." Mr. Ivory has collaborated with the producer Ismail Merchant to create a string of critically acclaimed adaptations of literary classics, most recently "Howards End," from the 1910 E. M. Forster novel.
In part, it was the unexpected critical and commercial success of some of the Merchant-Ivory films that triggered the current "classics revival." "Howards End," which was filmed for $8 million, has earned nearly $5 million on the art-house circuit, and Sony Pictures Classics, its distributor, expects the film to continue its run through next year's Oscar race. "A Room With a View," the 1985 Merchant-Ivory film that cost $3.5 million to make, went on to earn nearly $25 million and three Academy Awards.
As Mr. Ivory notes, "Good literature means good stories, good characters, good scenes."
And, as the Merchant-Ivory films illustrate, good literature can be filmed for far less money than so-called high concept fare, which is often laden with costly special effects, car chases and shootouts. What's more, studios don't have to pay fees for screen rights for works that have slipped into the public domain.
Discussing Hollywood's current penchant for literary works and the link to the industry's economic state, Fred Fuchs, a producer of the forthcoming film "Bram Stoker's Dracula," explains: "Studio executives are more conservative than they used to be. They aren't developing as many projects. When they do O.K. something, they want to know there's a story there to start with."
Certain titles also bring instant name recognition. Marketing surveys for 20th Century Fox's "Last of the Mohicans" show that while few moviegoers have read the book, most are familiar with the title.
At least two dozen literary classics are currently in development or production. They range from action-adventures such as James Fenimore Cooper's "Last of the Mohicans," opening in the fall, and Jack London's two-fisted seafaring saga "The Sea Wolf," now in development, to two Edith Wharton novels about turn-of-the-century characters stifled by social conventions. Wharton's "Age of Innocence," about an ill-fated love triangle, is being directed by Martin Scorsese and stars Daniel Day-Lewis, Michelle Pfeiffer and Winona Ryder. The Columbia Pictures movie, now being filmed, is due in the fall. Also due this fall is Wharton's "Ethan Frome," an American Playhouse production starring Liam Neeson as the doomed title character.
As the Wharton films illustrate, both small and large companies are financing these projects. Several boast big budgets as well as big stars. "Bram Stoker's Dracula," for example, which Francis Ford Coppola is directing for Columbia, is budgeted at $40 million and stars Gary Oldman, Anthony Hopkins, Winona Ryder and Keanu Reeves. "The Last of the Mohicans" will cost $35 million to $40 million and stars Daniel Day-Lewis.
Indeed, because of the high stakes involved, some of the forthcoming adaptations will undergo changes -- or rather, Hollywoodizing -- along the lines of what is envisioned for the hip but faithful "Three Musketeers."
One example is London's "Sea Wolf." Set in 1904 (the date of the book's publication), the story will be updated to modern times. "Audiences will be able to relate to it better," says Brian Grazer, who is head of Imagine Films Entertainment, the company handling the film. According to Mr. Grazer, the project was pitched to the company as " 'Deliverance' on the high seas," "a real mano-a-mano tale."
For "The Last of the Mohicans," Fox came up with an advertising campaign proclaiming, "The Last of the Mohicans Was the First American Hero." Though the story is set in 1757 during the French and Indian War, Michael Mann, the writer and director, eschews labels like "western" and "period piece." Rather, he describes the project as "a love story set in a war zone."
Not coincidentally, the story line has been altered to give the frontier hero known as Hawkeye (played by Mr. Day-Lewis) a love interest -- and a sex life. Another change involves Hawkeye's real name: Cooper may have christened the character Natty Bumppo, but in the movie he'll be Nathaniel Poe. "Natty Bumppo is kind of a silly name," explains Mr. Mann, who is best known as the producer of the television series "Miami Vice." And, perhaps predictably, the violence will be intensified. As a result, the film will receive an R rating.
Subtle changes will also be apparent in the forthcoming adaptation of the John Steinbeck novel "Of Mice and Men." Gary Sinise, the director and co-star of the MGM/Pathe film, acknowledges that his movie has some "new moments," especially in regard to the ranch foreman's lonely wife, played by Sherilynn Fenn, best known for portraying a sexually precocious teen-ager on television's "Twin Peaks."
Mr. Sinise, who stars opposite John Malkovich, emphasized that the novel's downbeat ending will not be changed: "You shouldn't do 'Of Mice and Men' if you change the ending." He went on to implore that a reporter not "give the ending away," so as not to turn off potential moviegoers.
Despite Hollywood's current coziness with literature, the industry's product is ultimately visual. Movies, at best, generally have trouble conveying the written word, even when the word is a classic. Moreover, film making is not an industry known for bookworms: during a recent visit to a studio's marketing office, a visitor notices stacks of Cliffs Notes for "The Last of the Mohicans."
When asked if Samuel Clemens scholars might approve of the adaptation of a Mark Twain novel in the works, the producer of the film replies: "Samuel Clemens? Is he a character in the book?"
Even Mr. Grazer, of Imagine Films Entertainment, admits that he hadn't read "The Sea Wolf" at the time he was first asked about about backing the project. ("I started reading it that weekend.") And James Ivory says that when studios were approached about financing "Howards End," most executives hadn't ever read the book.
In the early 80's, when Mr. Ivory and Mr. Merchant solicited studio backing for "A Room With a View," executives unsuccessfully sought to tamper with E. M. Forster's 1908 novel, about a young upper-class Englishwoman who was awakening to romance. "We were told that it had too many old characters," Mr. Ivory recalls, "so we were asked to make some younger." The film makers were also asked about giving one young character an American father -- so the cast could include a young American actor with box-office appeal.
It could be argued that it doesn't matter how Hollywood tampers with the classics. According to figures from Reading Is Fundamental, a Washington-based group that operates the nation's largest literacy program, as many as 21 million Americans may be illiterate. Statistics collected by the organization show that fewer than 25 percent of high school seniors read for pleasure; 90 percent of grade school children find television more appealing than reading, and 82 percent of these pupils prefer video games to reading.
Ruth Graves, president of the reading group, also points to an Associated Press poll, conducted earlier this year, showing that 30 percent of families earning more than $40,000 a year admitted that they had no books in their home. It's safe to predict, therefore, that many Americans will never have read the books Hollywood is adapting.
Because of the power of film, there is always the possibility that adaptations will send moviegoers in search of the originals. "That is what you always hope for," says Mr. Fuchs, the producer.
And Laurence Mark, who is producing "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn," adds: "What you want is for your movie to be such a special excursion that adults, who've already read the book, will want to pick it up again, and kids will want to read it for the first time."
Thomas Hardy's 19th-century novel, "Tess of the D'Urbervilles," appeared on The New York Times best-seller list when it was reprinted as a movie tie-in after the release of Roman Polanski's "Tess." The 1979 adaptation won three Oscars. For the movie tie-in for "Howards End," Signet Books printed 100,000 copies of a work that had been selling 5,000 copies a year for the company.
"For those of us concerned about literacy," says Ms. Graves, "you hope that audiences will know that that book could be just as exciting -- if not more -- as the movie." At one Reading Is Fundamental book giveaway, she recalls, a youngster looked through a pile of books and chose "The Wizard of Oz," explaining, "Well, I saw the movie, but I don't think it told the whole story."
 
 
 
PAGING LITERATURE
 In addition to the fall releases "The Last of the Mohicans," "Bram Stoker's Dracula" and adaptations of the Edith Wharton novels "Ethan Frome" and "The Age of Innocence," a number of other literary works are coming to the screen. Here is a sampling.
* John Steinbeck's "Of Mice and Men," about the friendship of two drifters during the Depression. Starring John Malkovich (as Lennie) and Gary Sinise (George), who also directs; adapted by Horton Foote ("Tender Mercies"); fall release; MGM/Pathe.
* Franz Kafka's "Trial," in which a man is put on trial for an unspecified offense in a nameless country. Starring Kyle MacLachlan, Anthony Hopkins, Jason Robards and Juliet Stevenson; tentative fall release; distributor pending.
* Marguerite Duras's "Lover," an erotic semi-autobiographical novel about a French schoolgirl who has an affair with a wealthy Chinese man in Indochina in the 1920's. Starring Jane March and Tony Leung; directed by Jean-Jacques Annaud; September release; M-G-M.
* Jean Rhys's erotic novel "Wide Sargasso Sea," about an English aristocrat and his obsession for a French island beauty. Directed by John Duigan; 1993 release; Fine Line Features.
* Mark Twain's "Adventures of Tom Sawyer," wherein Tom encounters murder. According to Dino Conte, the producer of the remake of "Born Yesterday," Macaulay Culkin of "Home Alone" has been asked to star. MGM/Pathe.
* Mark Twain's "Adventures of Huckleberry Finn," recording the famous journey of Huck and the runaway slave Jim. Three different adaptations are in the works, one from Walt Disney Pictures, a second from Tri-Star Pictures and a third from 20th Century Fox, which is a modern retelling written, directed and produced by John Hughes ("Home Alone").

HEADLINE: Schools, Losing State Aid, Ponder Sharing Costs

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW

 BODY:
SEVERE losses in state aid to education, coupled with growing concerns over the future of local school districts, are prompting studies to explore reorganizing and consolidating districts.
The State Education Department issued a study a few months ago on reorganizing, including consolidation and sharing administrative and instructional services. Long Island is one of six regional groups in the two-phase study, which is in the first stage of examining alternatives in districts with minimum enrollments of 1,200, 2,500 and 5,000. 
 The superintendent of Boces 2 in Suffolk County, Dr. Edward Milliken, said the first phase of the study, to be completed by the end of the month, would not include recommendations but, instead, alternatives for consolidating contiguous districts and for other approaches to sharing services.
 
Cost Efficiency Stressed
 "In some cases it may be more cost-efficient for school districts to retain their local identities for instruction, but to reorganize central offices in management and administration," he said. "This is a form of reorganization that has not yet come to New York State."
Dr. Milliken said the second phase of the study would look at the choices, decide which would be best and make recommendations.
In April the Temporary State Commission for Tax Relief on Long Island recommended consolidating the 53 school districts in Nassau County to 29 and the 71 in Suffolk to 37. Each district would have an average enrollment of slightly more than 5,000.
The report, "School Operations for Nassau and Suffolk Counties," said "bigger is better" if expenditures are to be reduced, because "larger districts enjoy greater opportunity to capitalize on the greater concentration of resources, specialization and diversity, as well as a reduction in bureaucratic redundancy and fractioned authority that might be more likely to take place within and across smaller school districts."
Former Assemblyman Arthur J. Kremer of Long Beach, a member of the commission and chairman of the subcommittee on schools of the State Commission for the Future of Long Island, said the time had come to consolidate districts.
"There is naturally some resistance among local administrators who want to protect their turf," Mr. Kremer said. "But most administrators recognize that consolidation is the blueprint for the future.
"It can't be done overnight and can't be rammed down anyone's throat. Consolidation must be based on significant money incentives from the state. The Commissioner of Education has indicated that he favors a speed-up of consolidation and mergers, and I expect that he will recommend that the Legislature step up action to enforce consolidations in school districts where appropriate."
 
From 10,000 to 717 Districts
 In 1920, the state had 10,000 districts. By 1960 the number had shrunk to 1,293. Today there are 717.
Over the years, Long Island has experienced many consolidations, including the merger of 13 districts in the 50's to become the Riverhead District and the formation of the Southampton District from four smaller ones.
For districts to consolidate, voter approval is now required, and the decision is left to the individual communities. But the new state study will also be looking at whether consolidations should continue to require local votes or if the state could mandate them.
An associate for district organization in the Education Department, Suzanne Spear, said many districts feared that they might be forced to consolidate. "There is a sense of panic," Ms. Spear said. "We've received many phone calls from people looking to buy houses who are hesitant to sign contracts until they get assurance that there will be no merger in that school district.
"Based on the history of the state, it doesn't seem likely that the local vote will be taken away. As long as the vote is there, there is no reason for concern."
 
Fault Is Found in Premise
 There is some legitimate level of anxiety among administrators, said Superintendent Bert Nelson of Hewlett-Woodmere, president of the Nassau County Council of Superintendents. The premise that there are large amounts of money to be saved with consolidation is not necessarily true, Dr. Nelson said, adding that if consolidation is at the expense of the children, then it will be negative.
"The most important consideration in school-district reorganizations must be to serve the children," he added. "The greatest red herring is that superintendents are opposed to consolidation. Hardly. Superintendents will be supportive of consolidation where appropriate, provided that the children are put first as a priority. Each community should have the right to decide what's best for itself."
Dr. Milliken said studies by some districts on the Island had found that consolidation was not always financially beneficial. In Suffolk County, a study by six small districts on the North Fork found that creating one larger district would lower taxes in three communities but raise taxes in the three others.
 
Tax Relief Called Essential
 "If consolidation doesn't provide tax relief, it won't work," Dr. Milliken said. "It must not only improve educational programs, but also lower taxes to be a win-win situation."
Under the system of state aid, merging districts have to have similar wealth levels for consolidation to be successful, Dr. Milliken said. If they are not the taxes in at least one district will increase.
The Harborfields and Elwood Districts discontinued a consolidation study after preliminary findings that there would be no significant savings in either district. Superintendent Raymond Walters of Harborfields said his district had decided not to continue with the study, because it was not financially feasible.
For consolidating districts, the state raises operating aid 20 percent for five years. The supplement decreases 2 percent each year after that.
Dr. Walters said that the long-term benefit would be minimal, and that there would be no guarantee the tax rates would decrease.
 
Salary Differences Cited
 Ms. Spear said the expenses of consolidation could run very high, especially if there is a large difference in the salaries between the merging districts. The new district would be very likely to adopt the higher salary, she said.
To be cost effective, a consolidated district should be able to put all high school students in one building, Ms. Spear added, a plan that would have been impossible in Harborfields and Elwood. There are additional costs for textbooks and uniforms when merging student populations, she said, adding that for Harborfields and Elwood a consolidation would not have been economically efficient.
Dr. Walters said that he had met with the eight superintendents in the Town of Huntington and that they would look for ways to share more services.
When consolidation is not the appropriate solution, Dr. Milliken said, districts may find that sharing services is an effective and feasible alternative.
The Superintendent of Boces 1, Dr. Raymond DeFeo, said one of the best examples of shared services was Boces, which supplies services like occupational education to students in different districts, a service that he said would be impossible for any single district to perform.
 
Greenport and Southold Share Teams
 There are many successful examples of shared services, Dr. DeFeo said. Greenport and Southold have shared 11 athletic teams and a number of courses. The enrollments in both districts are low, but together they can broaden their programs, Dr. DeFeo explained.
In a television experiment, Greenport, Riverhead and Southold offer five high school courses to students in all three districts. The program has been very successful, Dr. DeFeo said, and hope to add districts.
Some districts are eager to consolidate, but have not found successful mates. Dr. DeFeo said that Greenport would like to merge with a compatible school, but that no district was interested, because Greenport is a low-wealth, highly taxed district, and a consolidation would mean higher taxes for the merging district.
East Rockaway, with 1,150 students, is the smallest district for kindergarten through 12th grade in Nassau, and it wants to find a neighbor for consolidation, said Superintendent Robert Parry. Consolidation would be logical for districts with financial difficulties and declining enrollments, he said.
A plan to send middle- and high school students to Lynbrook and pay their tuition was rejected by Lynbrook.
"The experiment with Lynbrook seemed like a perfect marriage, and we are very disappointed," Dr. Parry said.
 
Why a Plan Was Rejected
 A proposal to consolidate the Comsewogue and Middle Country School Districts was voted down last month by the Middle Country School Board. The Interim Superintendent at Middle Country, Frank Carasiti, said the board had decided not to proceed because the district, with almost 10,000 students, was already large enough.
But Superintendent Alan P. Austen of Comsewogue said that at an earlier meeting between representatives of the districts there had been support for a merger that would have improved educational programs and reduced taxes in both districts.
"Many communities are afraid to lose their identities, and there are many misunderstandings about consolidating," Dr. Austen said. "I am confident that if the public were better educated, they would vote to consolidate. Political leaders should have the courage to force school districts to study consolidation and then let the voters decide."

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in: Great Kills

BYLINE: By JERRY CHESLOW

 BODY:
GREAT KILLS, with its calm harbor and clean beaches on the south shore of Staten Island, has been adding housing since the opening of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge in 1964 made it easily accessible to Brooklyn and Manhattan. The recession has slowed construction and sales, but brokers and local officials expect sharp increases in both when the economy picks up.
"Housing prices will take off again because the Lord isn't making any more waterfront property," said Dorothy Fitzpatrick, district manager of Community Board 3, based in Great Kills. She said the next surge could start at one of the newest developments in the community, Port Regalle. This is a 50-unit, pink-stucco condominium town- house complex off Wiman Avenue, overlooking Great Kills Harbor. A three-bedroom unit with a waterfront view is currently listed for resale at $369,000, a two bedroom unit at $320,000. Local real estate agents say the owners may be unable to get those prices. 
 "It is unrealistic to think that a two-bedroom unit in Port Regalle would sell for more than $300,000 in this market," said Lydia V. Ragucci, owner of Ragucci Realty on Amboy Road.
The community extends from the harbor up to Arthur Kill Road and is bisected by the tracks of the Staten Island Rapid Transit System. The train, which goes to the Staten Island Ferry, stops on Amboy Road, in the heart of the 19th-century business district known as "The Village." It has an "apothecary," rather than a pharmacy, with antique bottles in its window, a small department store, a hardware store, three delis, several luncheonettes and half a dozen restaurants.
"Like 50 years ago," explained Theresa Petruzelli, owner of T.J.'s Luncheonette on Amboy Road, "people walk in from home for a few things or stop off on their way home from the train station."
Mrs. Petruzelli says business has been poor over the last year, leading to local layoffs. The downtown is also hurt by a lack of supermarkets, which forces residents to shop in neighboring areas, and by competition from the Staten Island Mall, three miles away in New Springville.
The name Great Kills dates to the 1660's, when the Dutch ruled Staten Island (the Dutch word "kill" means tributary). In 1664, when the British took over, a French merchant, Jacques Guyon, got 200 acres from the crown.
Great Kills remained basically a farming community until 1860, when the B & O Railroad linked it to St. George and the ferry to Manhattan. Housing spurted with the opening of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge in 1964.
Shielded from the Atlantic by a hook of land called Crookes Point, the harbor is one of the most desirable on the East Coast for pleasure boaters.
THE point is at the western tip of Great Kills Park, a 900-acre national park built on a former landfill. Part of the Gateway National Park system, it has five baseball fields, a model airplane field, a mile-long beachfront, a public boat ramp, nature areas and a 350-slip marina run by Nichols Great Kills Harbor Park Marina on a concession basis.
Edward Tomanek, manager of the marina, says it is the largest of the six in the harbor. There are about 1,000 slips in the marinas and two yacht clubs. Slips rent for $60 to $100 a boat foot; Nichols slips rent for $65 a foot.
"Usually, we have a waiting list for slips," Mr. Tomanek said. "Now we have a few empty at the start of the season."
Some of the most expensive houses are on the streets surrounding a tiny duck pond called Jack's Pond just south of Amboy Road. Custom-built tudors, colonials and sprawling ranches on large lots on Hillside Terrace or Dent Road overlooking the pond sell for up to $350,000.
By far the most common houses are three-bedroom high ranches and colonials. Several thousand have been built since the bridge was opened. According to Mrs. Ragucci, houses on streets such as Oakdale Street or Lamoka Avenue sell for $185,000 to $210,000.
"The houses are like the people here," Mrs. Ragucci said. "They are solid, practical, family-type houses, not out to impress anyone."
Many residents also live in semi-detached duplexes. Three-bedroom units in duplexes on Dewey, Katan or Colon Avenues sell for $150,000 to $160,000. Mrs. Ragucci said many recent buyers were New York City policemen, firemen and sanitation workers relocating from Brooklyn to escape crime and congestion.
The largest multifamily complex is Kensington Gardens, an 80-unit garden co-op on Amboy Road. Studios are about $45,000, one-bedrooms $60,000 and two-bedroom $70,000. Apartments in two-family houses rent for about $600 a month for two bedrooms and $500 a month for one.
Among the newer residents of Great Kills are Thomas J. Carchietta, an analyst at the New York City Department of Environmental Protection, and his wife, Veronica, an analyst at the New York Life Insurance Company. They bought a high ranch in April 1991, just after their wedding. He grew up in neighboring Eltingville and his wife is from Queens.
"We wanted to live near my parents," Mr. Carchietta explained. "And for me, this was like moving across the street. For my wife, it's great because she was an apartment dweller all of her life and owning a home is very satisfying for her."
Mr. Carchietta said he and his wife found the community to be extremely friendly and clean. However, he believes New York City has neglected Staten Island, especially when it comes to the transportation system.
"THE main roads here are just not wide enough to handle the volume of traffic," he said. "The city owes it to us to use some of the revenues from the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge to improve our transportation system."
Many long-time residents feel that the area is getting too crowded.
"I started to feel cramped about 10 years ago," said Eileen M. Brophy, who has lived in Great Kills for 17 years. "But it's still a family place. Now, many of the older people are selling to young couples, who are fixing up the homes."
Most children from Great Kills attend Public School 8 on Lindenwood Road or P.S. 32 on Elverton Avenue, both considered by residents to be excellent. This year, P.S. 8 scored highest of any elementary school on Staten Island in New York City's standardized reading tests. The principal, Robert Sheldon, said 93 percent of his students read at or above grade level.
"Our success is due to the excellent teaching staff," he said. "All but one of the teachers has a master's in education. Perhaps more important is that the children come from a solid, stable, supportive community. They arrive ready to learn."
There are two Roman Catholic parochial schools in town -- St. Francis, a K-12 school on Amboy Road, and St. Clare School, a K-8 school on Lindenwood Road.
The students go on to intermediate School 24 on Cleveland Avenue, and either Tottenville High School in Huguenot or Susan E. Wagner High in Seaview. More than 80 percent of the graduates of each of the high schools go on to higher education. Senior classes in each of the schools consistently win more than $1 million a year in scholarships. Early this month, Tottenville won both the city's golf and boys' baseball championships.
One of the town's most stubborn problems is graffiti. Recently, the community board's youth coordinator, Christine Flynn, sent fliers to organizations and businesses asking for money and volunteers to fight the problem. They raised $3,500.
"Sometimes, we'll paint over a spot and the next day the graffiti will be back," Ms. Flynn said. "So we go back and paint over it again and again."
Among the well-known restaurants are Windjammer Restaurant and Mansion Marina, both seafood restaurants on Mansion Avenue; La Galleria, an Italian restaurant on Hylan Boulevard; Buono Pasta, an Italian restaurant on Amboy Road, and La Candela Espanola, a Spanish restaurant on Amboy Road.

Crook or Crooke? In 1874, John Crooke, a naturalist and mining engineer for whom Crookes Point is named, bought the land from Joseph Brown, who had a shipyard on the site. Local lore has it that Brown packed a pair of ivory-handled revolvers given to him by gunrunners for looking the other way when schooners unloaded smuggled weapons at the point. Construction of Great Kills Park began in 1928, when the state gave a strip of wetlands to New York City. The site was filled with 16.5 million cubic yards of earth. In 1974, the park became part of Gateway National Park.

HEADLINE: Germans Shorten Workweek for Success

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In describing the German formula for national economic success in "The Wages of German Success" (Op-Ed, May 22), Norbert Walter makes a serious but common error. He fails to stress the major reductions in work time built into Germany's highly productive capital-intensive industrial system. Using technological progress simultaneously to raise wages and reduce work time has been postwar Germany's greatest economic achievement.
The standard West German workweek consisted of six eight-hour days in 1955. German unions then pledged themselves to translate the greater productivity made possible by new technology into higher wages and a shorter workweek. Unionized industrial workers in West Germany achieved the five-day, 40-hour week in the 1960's. By the early 70's, most nonunion German workers also had 40-hour weekly schedules. 
 West German unions began looking to extended annual leave in the 70's as automation continued to boost productivity. They have been remarkably successful. German law requires a minimum of three weeks' annual paid leave for full-time employees. But the 70 percent of German workers covered by collective bargaining agreements take six or more weeks off with pay, while most others get five weeks. Average full-time German workers have two and half times more paid leave a year than their American counterparts.
German unions began a new effort to reduce the standard workweek in 1984. The unions maintained that shorter hours would counter rising structural unemployment, which they attributed to continued development of capital-intensive production. The unions accepted a real-wage freeze and granted management greater scheduling flexibility in exchange for general reductions in average workweek. Long strikes by metalworkers, printers and paperworkers forced management to accept this bargain.
Once the 40-hour barrier was broken, a general movement toward a shorter workweek started. By the end of 1990, 90 percent of West German workers had weekly schedules of less than 40 hours, with unionized workers averaging 38.3 hours. Contracts assure at least one-quarter of the German work force a 35-hour workweek by 1995.
Reducing work time has been a key to West German economic success and social stability. Americans can no longer afford to ignore this lesson. Today, the United States suffers from its failure to translate technological progress into reduced work time. Here, so-called "permanent layoffs" have long been accepted as a necessary cost of investing in capital-intensive production. And the resulting structural unemployment has been routinely allocated to fall most heavily on minority populations in what were once highly productive industrial cities. Meanwhile, most full-time workers have been asked to put in more hours for less pay.
Technological progress does not have to continue to erode the quality of American life, but it will unless the longstanding trends toward longer workweeks and greater structural unemployment are reversed. Instead of looking to Japan for a model, Americans could all live better if we emulated our other great economic rival, Germany, and created a capital-intensive economy that simultaneously meant jobs and less work for all.
 
RONALD EDSFORTH
Greenwich, N.Y., June 10, 1992
 
The writer is a visiting scholar in history and the program in science, technology and society at Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: ISRAELIS TO VOTE, FACING CHALLENGES, FEARING STALEMATE

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, June 21

 BODY:
When Israelis vote on Tuesday, they will determine the shape of a new government to shepherd them through what may be some of the biggest changes in their history.
Yet paradoxically, the final weekend of the parliamentary election campaign ended today with the politicians having discussed few of the dominant issues in any depth. 
 And as important as this vote is, opinion polls strongly suggest that Israelis may end up with a stalemate.
These surveys consistently put the opposition Labor Party ahead of the governing Likud, but without any guarantee of sufficient strength to stitch together a workable coalition with small left-wing and religious parties. Likud, even if it should confound the poll takers by getting more votes than Labor, would be similarly hard-pressed to form a sturdy parliamentary majority with the far right and with the same religious parties Labor would court.
 
Revival of Coalition Seen
 As a result, many political experts predict that Israel will end up with a revival of the broad coalition of the two major parties that prevailed uneasily and often ineffectually through much of the last decade.
Whatever happens on Tuesday -- and polls here are often imperfect guides -- it will simply be the opening bell for weeks of negotiations over possible alliances, always necessary in Israel because no single party has ever managed to win a majority in the 120-member Parliament. Like sausage-making, it is not a pretty process to watch, tending to be laden with blatant deals and even payoffs.
It raises serious questions even before the fact about how stable the new government will be to tackle some of the most important diplomatic and economic challenges this country has ever faced.
 
Touching on Bedrock Issues
 Above all, it is involved for the first time in wide-ranging peace negotiations with the Palestinians and neighboring Arab nations, touching on bedrock issues of land and security.
With the cold war over, Israel's relationship with the United States is in flux, and many Israelis worry that the Americans have turned inward and away from eternally messy foreign problems like the Middle East.
Domestically, the country is at a crossroads, having recently absorbed 360,000 arrivals from the former Soviet Union, the equivalent of nearly 10 percent of the Israeli Jewish population. Culturally, these highly educated newcomers will be an asset of incalculable proportions in the future. For now, however, they are an economic headache. There are not nearly enough jobs for them, and Israelis have watched nervously as overall unemployment has climbed to 11.5 percent.
Many Israelis are fed up, and while they are often unable to put their finger precisely on what troubles them, they sense that the country is not being run right. They are people like Shlomo Aked, who lives in southern Tel Aviv.
Normally, his working-class neighborhood is fertile territory for Likud, the right-wing party that has been in power for 15 years. This time, Mr. Aked, who basically considers himself a Likud supporter, says it is time to let the party sit on the bench for a while.
"They take all this money and give it to Hebron," he said, referring to a town in the Israeli-occupied West Bank that is a center for ardently nationalistic Jewish settlers. "What do I care about Hebron? When was the last time I was in Hebron, or in Nablus? What I care about is my neighborhood. The money doesn't go to the right places."
 
Hoping for a Few New Seats
 Labor hopes that there are tens of thousands like him ready to switch allegiances. Its strategists are not looking for seismic shifts, for that rarely happens in the Israeli electorate of 3.4 million people. Rather, they hope to lure perhaps 100,000 to 120,000 votes from Likud -- enough to win an extra four or five parliamentary seats, putting Labor in first place and giving it the first crack at forming a governing coalition.
Labor has also been helped mightily in the polls by the Russian newcomers, who resent their joblessness and who say by margins of as high as 4 to 1 that they are ready to punish Likud for not having done enough to smooth the entry into their new society.
With people who have lived here longer, Labor's sales pitch is not its platform, which differs from Likud's in its calls for reduced settlement-building in occupied lands and for territorial concessions in exchange for peace with the Arabs. Instead, Labor has staked its future on its leader of the last four months, Yitzhak Rabin, a lackluster Prime Minister from the 1970's who nonetheless enjoys more popularity than the incumbent Likud leader, Yitzhak Shamir.
Both men, whose combined age is 146, are studies in gray, so lacking in magnetism that neither one would set off an airport security detector. But many Israelis have high regard for Mr. Rabin, a former army commander and no-nonsense Defense Minister whom they consider a solid protector of Israel's best interests. While many traditional Likud supporters find Labor as a whole too soft on security matters, they find Mr. Rabin reassuring -- a safe way for them to register a protest vote without feeling that they may put the country at risk.
This inherent division between a relatively dovish party and hawkish leader has contributed to a blurring of important issues. Most were scarcely debated in the campaign, which was uncommonly tame by Israeli standards, touching off discussions among Israelis about whether they had become appallingly apathetic or rather so politically mature that they no longer punch out those who disagree with them.
Mr. Rabin talked often about eliminating "political settlements" in the territories and shifting money to social needs in Israel proper. But he said barely a word about where exactly the money would go or how specifically he would invigorate an economy that he calls anemic.
Similarly, Mr. Shamir, who has championed settlement-building and presided over greatly accelerated construction in the last two years, played down the issue, apparently in recognition that his program is not popular with many Israelis. Virtually invisible was a related matter that had preoccupied Israel for months: the Bush Administration's refusal to provide $10 billion in housing loan guarantees because of Mr. Shamir's settlement policy.
Political commentators say the lack of real ideological conflict shows that the party leaders recognize that they may soon be working together. In fact, both men give every sign of being more comfortable with each other than with their natural coalition partners to the left and the right.
 
Gains on Far Right
 In looking at where disaffected Likud voters will go, political experts say it is far from certain that they will turn to Labor.
Many seem to be moving even further to the right, with polls showing substantial gains for two established parties on the far right, Tsomet and Moledet, which are both opposed to territorial compromise. Young voters are said to be moving to the extremes in both directions, in particular toward Tsomet, which appeals to nonreligious territory hawks, and to Meretz, a coalition of left-wing parties.
But it is also possible that at the moment of truth on Tuesday many Likud voters will find that they simply cannot leave the fold, whether for ideological, ethnic or personal reasons.
"Labor's the party they love to date," said Gadi Wolfsfeld, a political scientist at Hebrew University in Jerusalem. "But when it comes down to marriage, they go into the booth and vote Likud. And the reason is they're scared. They're scared about security. They're scared about the P.L.O. And in the end they vote for what they know."
Even if the polls are on target, "Labor can win the election and still lose the government," said Yaron Ezrahi, also a political science professor at Hebrew University.
The crucial question is not whether Labor finishes first but whether it can scrape together 61 seats for a parliamentary majority. Most polls say it could do it only with the help of Israel's three Arab parties. But Mr. Rabin pledges not to form a government with them, thus honoring an unbroken political tradition.
Likud is in a similar predicament. Even if he is stronger than the polls say, Mr. Shamir will be hard-pressed to put together more than a slender majority, one dependent on the same far-right parties that walked out on him half a year ago for taking part in the peace process. It would be impossible for him to maintain such a coalition and talk peace at the same time.
That is why the experts are betting on a Labor-Likud coalition similar to one that existed, often in mutual unhappiness, from 1984 to 1990.
Who gets to sit in which chair will depend on the parliamentary seat distribution. Almost inevitably, some of the heaviest maneuvering will involve the rigorously religious parties, which will want to be included in any new government, for they exist to obtain state funds for their schools and other institutions. They are presumed to be in a weaker than normal position in this election because of the large numbers of overwhelmingly secular Jews from former Soviet territory.
Before long, the political game may get even rougher for these parties. The next vote, which is not scheduled until 1996 but could come sooner, will feature the direct election of the Prime Minister for the first time.
In theory, it should make the national leader a far more powerful figure and reduce the king-making leverage of small parties, including the religious.

HEADLINE: Black Neighborhood Faces White World With Bitterness

SERIES: 2 Neighborhoods, 2 Worlds -- Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, June 21

 BODY:
Twenty years ago, black hopes and white fears were on a collision course in picket-fenced neighborhoods around the nation as blacks pursued the dream of integration and whites ran from it. What resulted were places like Mount Greenwood and Roseland, two working-class neighborhoods in Chicago two miles apart, one now as black as the other is white.
Sebron and Marian (Mother) Jones did not want it this way. For them, Roseland represented a ticket out of the ghetto, and a yard of their own. They were one of the first black families on their block and could not wait to plant the irises and invite company over to see the neighborhood. 
 "It was trees meeting trees," Mrs. Jones remembers wistfully.
 
Integration to Segregation
 But in the end, integration meant watching white neighbors move out as fast as they could and services and businesses go with them. Twenty years later, without even moving, the Joneses are in a virtually all-black community again, back on the other side of the wall between the races now symbolized by the Los Angeles riot.
The white evacuation was so rapid that it left huge gaps in the neighborhood that have never been filled. Houses stayed vacant or were rented at rock-bottom prices set by absentee landlords. Department stores left and drug dealers moved in. Never seeming to get the money or attention they needed, the library, the schools, the parks went downhill.
Now the Joneses can hear gunshots from their dinner table and have seen drugs being sold next door. "You could sit in your kitchen and watch them selling drugs outside that back window," Mrs. Jones said. "They would look you due in the eye and keep stepping. It hurts your heart to pieces."
In many ways, people in Roseland and Mount Greenwood lead similar lives: blue-collar, bowling-on-Saturday, church-on-Sunday lives, passing each other only on street corners or in the produce line.
But it is Roseland residents who pay a high price for this segregation. They are rejected for mortgages at three times the rate of Mount Greenwood residents of the same income. They pay as much as twice the automobile insurance rates that people in Mount Greenwood do. They have to travel several miles, usually to white areas, to buy fresh meat and vegetables because there are no major grocery stores for Roseland's 56,000 people, while Mount Greenwood's 19,000 residents have two.
It is disparities like these that lead many in Roseland to regard whites with bitterness and distrust.
Even when the numbers look even, things still work against Roseland. The Chicago police assign the same number of officers to both communities. Not only does Roseland have nearly three times the number of residents that Mount Greenwood does, its crime rate is also much higher. As a result its police patrols number 51 per 1,000 crimes while Mount Greenwood has 118 patrols per 1,000 crimes, a study by the University of Illinois found.
Many whites in Mount Greenwood say that blacks in Roseland could pull themselves up if they wanted to. They point with pride to the new branch library that opened a year ago in Mount Greenwood after years of community efforts that won them the support of powerful officials in the state capital and City Hall to finance it.
People in Roseland say they do not have those connections. Both branches belong to the Chicago Public Library system. While Mount Greenwood's library has private typewriting booths and compact discs to borrow, there is not even toilet paper in the restrooms or doors on the stalls of Roseland's library. The children in Roseland read "Rumpelstiltskin" beneath gashes of peeling paint rising above the fairy-tale section. The staff is so small, with just two librarians on some days that if one is sick, the library has to close.
Every week, Roseland residents come in asking if the branch has computers or typewriters or videotapes to borrow like other libraries. The answer is always no.
"The reason they're coming to us is because they don't have them at home," said Melnee Simmons, the head librarian there. "They have sense enough to know that these things are available, but not to them."
For the past year, half the shelves at Roseland's library have been empty. Books have been packed away in anticipation of a promised renovation that for 15 years was supposed to happen any minute. Now there is talk that it might really happen this summer. Mrs. Simmons has been telling staff members to believe it when they see it.
 
Obsessions
Roseland Has Special Road Map
 Most blacks in Roseland do not have a lot of formal education but feel they have earned graduate degrees in race relations.
For them, race is a daily topic of conversation. What whites do and think and want is a life obsession and a matter of survival. Most of them have to work for whites, shop with whites and venture into white neighborhoods for services they cannot get at home.
They say they confront the stereotypes that Mount Greenwood residents seem to live by every time they step over the wall. They say they have come to expect a negative reaction, but they never get used to it. No matter how many times they are called a name or stopped by the police, one resident said, "It's like a bomb drops inside of you."
Elsie Melvin, a registered nurse, said she has had white patients who have refused to let her touch them. "They don't care how sick they are," she said. "They'll say, 'I don't want any colored nurse working on me.' "
Christopher Jones, a bus driver who is not related to Sebron and Marian Jones, said white passengers have spit on him on his bus route through white neighborhoods. As a child, whites chased him out of their neighborhood as he rode his bicycle.
Now when he and his wife, Regina, have to drive through white neighborhoods, they make sure they have a full tank of gas and enough air in the tires. "We look at it as if we're going to another state," Mrs. Jones said.
A few years ago, Jeannette Raggs, a postal worker, and her husband, Clemmie, were invited a few years ago to the wedding reception of one white co-worker. They walked in to see that the party was all white.
"The music stopped playing, everyone turned to look at us," Mr. Raggs said.
Then the father of the bride greeted them from across the room.
" 'What youse people want?' " Mr. Raggs recalled the man shouting. "Then the bride came up and said she had invited us, that she worked with my wife. Only then did that ugly, hatred look leave his face."
 
Ghosts
Stores and Jobs Are Memories
 As hard as Roseland residents work to keep the irises blooming, this is still a neighborhood defined in part by what it used to be.
Up and down Michigan Avenue and across 111th Street in Roseland, there are the ghosts of a once white neighborhood -- the Rose Bowl bowling alley, the old Gately's department store, the empty theater plastered with posters of missing children, the old flower shops and hardware stores that now sell wigs and Stroh's beer.
"This strip was booming, a gold mine," said Willie Lomax, executive director of a community group. "There were shoe repair shops, fabric stores, five hardware stores. We had restaurants with valet parking and A-1 service. Those were the days."
A few blocks away, young men sit out on porch steps with nothing to do. The occasional spit-shiny Cadillac, trimmed in gold, cruises down the street. Drug dealers, the homeowners say under their breath, cursing them as they pass.
The fathers and grandfathers of many of these young men were the meatpackers and steelworkers who came to Roseland to be near the plants and make a better life for their families. Now the plants are gone and so are the jobs.
Just outside Roseland's borders, halfway between Roseland and Mount Greenwood, is the steel plant graveyard.
Next to it sits a parking lot as long as an airport landing strip, now overrun by bushes and weeds. "All this was employees," Mr. Lomax said. "Three shifts."
Across the street are some concrete beams and rubble surrounded by grassland. "You're looking at Dutch Boy paint factory," Mr. Lomax said. "The young men you see hanging out on the corner weren't even born when this closed."
That has left residents like 28-year-old Darryl Gibson are at the economic margins. It used to ride take him two and a half hours on the bus to get to his last job earning $6 an hour as a forklift operator. He was laid off last August and has not found another job since. His family lives off his wife Linda's salary as a sales clerk.
"It's hard when you have a wife and family, and you want to do right, but don't have much education," Mr. Gibson said. "Everyone can't be a doctor or a lawyer. Everyone is not going to finish college. Everyone doesn't have connections. There should be something out there for people like us."
 
Scars
Years of Hurt Shape a Moment
 While many whites in Mount Greenwood look at race with detachment and broad-brush stereotypes, most blacks in Roseland see it is a very personal matter. They are convinced that whites neither know them nor care to.
Their attitudes are shaped by vivid, demoralizing encounters with whites from childhood to the present. For some, the wounds are so deep that seemingly harmless incidents can take on major significance.
Mr. Raggs once stood silently for several moments minutes after a white cashier put his nickels and quarters on the counter. A line formed behind him. The cashier, flustered, asked what was wrong. "You give me my money in my hand like I gave it to you," Mr. Raggs said.
Whites in Mount Greenwood see that kind of reaction as hypersensitivity. They say that something like that could happen to anybody. Blacks in Roseland can see such an incident as a final straw after a lifetime of indignities and one chance where they can demand the respect they may not get elsewhere.
"They can't even imagine what it's like to be black," said Myshawn Davis, a 25-year-old hairdresser who was chased off the schoolbus growing up in an all-white suburb. "They don't know what we go through. You try not to let this stuff drive you crazy. You'd be trying to kill every white person in the world."
While the great-grandparents of people in Mount Greenwood were learning the ways of America and starting small businesses in Irish and Italian ghettos, the great-grandparents of people in Roseland were earning pennies as sharecroppers in Mississippi or scrubbing white people's floors in Chicago.
And so blacks in Roseland say they do not want to hear about bootstraps and the work ethic. "Their fathers and grandfathers came of their own free will," Sebron Jones said. "Even if they didn't own slaves themselves, they didn't work for free," Mr. Jones said. "They got paid all those years we didn't."
There is quiet pain in the voice of his wife, Marian, as she remembers being 11 years old and going to do housework for a white woman. At about noon, the woman ordered her to stop washing the dishes.
"She made me go down into the dark basement," Mrs. Jones said. "Her husband had come home for lunch, and he didn't want any blacks in his house. I had to sit on the stairway and not move until he finished eating. When he was gone, she let me back up, and I went back to washing the dishes."
It has been more than 50 years, and she says she can still see the steps. "It gave me low self-esteem," she said. "I'm just now coming out of it."

HEADLINE: WALL STREET BOOM FAILS TO BOLSTER REGION'S ECONOMY

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Flush with profits that have surpassed the best years of the booming 1980's, Wall Street is offering glimmers of hope for the battered economies of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, but so far has failed to lift the region out of its recession.
For those who work at investment banking firms, brokerage houses and elsewhere in the securities industry, 1992 has so far proven a romp. Despite the steep decline in stock values last week, trading volume, profits and paychecks in the industry, which the Government said reached an average of more than $83,000 last year, have all set records. 
 Historically, when Wall Street prospers, so does the region.
 
Just Tunnel, No Light
 But for now, the securities industry shows few signs of sharing its resurgent wealth. Hiring is anemic, and even the brokers, bankers and financial advisers who are awash in lofty salaries and year-end bonuses have adopted a far more conservative approach to spending than in the go-for-broke period of the mid-80's.
"The spillover is not there yet," said Jeffrey M. Schaefer, director of research for the Securities Industry Association, a trade group that analyzes the results of the 316 firms that are members of the New York Stock Exchange.
A torrent of department-store closings and personal bankruptcy filings, high office vacancy rates and other economic problems across the region demonstrate that there is little hope that economic recovery is at hand, even while other parts of the country are starting to shake loose of the recession.
 
The First Step
 Still, "the securities industry has traditionally been a leading indicator," said David Brauer, an economist for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Like other analysts, he points to the stock-market crash of 1987 as the blow that pushed the region into recession, now its longest since the 1930's.
According to economists and executives in many fields, if the resurgence in the securities industry continues, it is all but certain to spill over into law firms, financial publishers, restaurants, travel agencies, clothing stores and hundreds of other businesses.
"By itself, Wall Street cannot lift us out of recession, but it looks like it is going to make a start," said Matthew P. Drennan, an economist and urban planner at Cornell University.
Yet it seems unlikely that Wall Street will soon regain the economic clout it once had. Since 1988, firms have cut their employment with unbridled fervor, eliminating 38,000 jobs in New York City alone. That has left a lean industry of 125,000 workers in the city, and one that offers little prospect of hiring back the legion that was lost.
"Management is constantly questioning whether revenues will dry up, and they are keeping the head count under control," said Samuel G. Liss, an analyst for Salomon Brothers who follows the securities industry.
In contrast to the early 1980's, when profitability surged and employment rolls swelled by 20 percent a year, Mr. Liss estimates that hiring this year may add 10 percent more workers throughout the securities industry, but no more.
"A big reason that firms are doing well is that they have cut their payrolls extensively," said Peter Drummond-Hay, managing director of Russell Reynolds Associates, an executive search company on Wall Street. "They've learned a hard lesson and are not about to unlearn it quickly."
One sector of the economy that is benefiting from the securities industry upturn, if only slightly, is real estate.
"There is a bit more of a free-spending mood," said Clark Halstead, president of the Halstead Property Company, a broker of Manhattan apartments. He said demand had increased since January, particularly among executives working on Wall Street, who have shown a preference for five- to seven-room cooperatives priced from $400,000 to $600,000.
"It seemed like they were all getting fired in '90 and '91 and now they are getting bonuses again," he said. But he said the spurt of demand has fallen far short of resurrecting Manhattan home values, which have fallen by 25 percent since 1987.
 
Office Space Still Empty
 Huge amounts of office space are still begging for tenants, particularly on Wall Street and the surrounding blocks of the financial district. Cushman & Wakefield, a commercial brokerage, said the vacancy rate in the district's most modern and prestigious buildings had improved slightly in the first three months of the year, but remained at 16 percent, far above the level during most of the 1980's.
Office vacancy rates for regional centers of business activity supporting Wall Street also remain at much higher levels; 18 percent in midtown Manhattan, 22 percent in Stamford, Conn., and 33 percent in Jersey City.
In personal spending, Wall Street executives have done relatively little to pump up the local economy.
"These people are not buying art collections or Ferraris," said Perrin Long, a securities-industry analyst who left Wall Street in 1989 and now follows the industry for the First of Michigan Corporation of Detroit. "They are not trying to double or triple their salaries by jumping from one firm to the other, and they are even beginning to think it may not be ethically correct to brag about making over $1 million a year."
Austerity is too strong a word for an industry in which year-end bonuses often come in six-figure checks, easily exceeding the life savings of a typical American family. But on Wall Street, ostentatious displays of consumption are definitely out.
 
Fridays Only for Lunch
 At Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, one of the largest law firms serving Wall Street, associates received a memo recently spelling out when they can take summer law school interns to lunch. Only Fridays are allowed.
The firm also provided a list of recommended restaurants. Hamburger Harry's and Tommy Tang's are on it. But the far tonier Bouley and Montrachet are "discouraged," the firm said.
From Drake Beam Morin Inc., an executive placement firm, comes word of a new fashion statement by Wall Street's denizens, who in the past shopped for their workaday wardrobe at Brooks Brothers, Barneys, or, if a stopover in London allowed, on Savile Row.
"Suddenly these guys are going to Macy's or Abraham & Straus," said John A. Artise, the company's vice president. If the new view of fashion is causing confusion, he added, it is only for those who still think expensive tastes are in vogue.
"We're telling our clients that if they have a $700 suit, it's O.K. to wear it, but don't flaunt the label," he said.
Painting and sculpture, virtually de rigueur for Wall Street corridors of the 1980's, have lost some of their appeal.
"Almost all business has cut back on extras, and that includes art," said Irving Blum, co-owner of the Blum Helman Gallery in Manhattan. On Wall Street, he said, art purchases "are in a malaise."
 
'Power Office Is Out'
 Another insight into the new attitude comes in interior design. Where the executive of the 1980's might have expected a rich budget to refurbish his or her work space, often with a preference for leather couches and mahogany paneling, "the power office is out," said Margo Grant, managing director of Gensler & Associates, a large Manhattan architecture and design concern.
"The rule now is this: don't spend money on image building," she said. "They want computer terminals that work, air-conditioning and a little sprucing up. That's it."
While Wall Street holds to a more conservative ethic, at least for the moment, conditions have clearly turned robust.
One broad measure is provided by the Securities Industry Association, which said net income for the New York Stock Exchange's member firms soared in 1991 to $5.85 billion from a loss of $162 million the year earlier. No previous year has come close to 1991 in profitability, except 1986, when the industry had a net income of $5.51 billion.
The association said earnings continued to accelerate in the first three months of this year, when its member firms counted $2.06 billion in profits.
 
Back to the Basics
 Experts said the surging profits came in the absence of the wave of mergers, hostile takeovers and leveraged buyouts that accounted for a large share of the investment-banking fees of the 1980's. Instead, they said, the upturn was fueled principally by a spurt in initial public offerings and the the growth of Wall Street's most basic business: trading in stocks and bonds.
Paychecks on Wall Street have risen too. According to the Federal Government, the average earnings among New York City securities industry workers, including everyone from messengers and secretaries to the partners in large firms, was at least $83,000 in 1991.
But the figure was only an estimate, based on paychecks for the first nine months of the year, and did not include year-end bonus checks. "It is a good assumption that 1991 compensation was a good deal higher than in 1990," when it averaged $82,000, said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner for the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
The Government's data portray a securities industry that remains slow to hire and may still be eliminating workers. "The restructuring may not have run its course," Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
Although more recent data are not available, he said, employment in the securities industry in New York City fell by 5,000 last year, despite expanding profits.
Still, the downsizing of Wall Street since 1988 has been modest compared with previous periods of retrenchment, according to Federal studies. Between 1969 and 1975, a period of war, inflation, recession and listless trading on the stock exchanges, the industry cut its work force by almost 40 percent, from 106,000 to 66,000.
"This is the closest thing we have to an economic roller coaster," Mr. Ehrenhalt said. If the Wall Street upturn continues, he added, "it will create a wave that affects a very substantial part of the New York economy."
In one small spurt of expansion, Wall Street firms have returned to a summer ritual of intensively recruiting business-school students as interns. Although some of the firms decline to disclose their plans, industry executives estimated that 750 students have been hired for this summer, double last year's number.
