HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Clinton Unveils His Economic Blueprint

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, June 21

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton, seeking to hone his campaign message, proposed an economic plan today that called for sharp increases in taxes on the rich and on corporations, and major revisions and reallocations of government spending of all kinds.
Mr. Clinton, the winner of the Democratic primary campaign, refined and attached price tags to ideas he has mentioned before, and he also made some significant new proposals. 
 He said that as President he would propose cutting the Federal deficit by $150 billion, roughly half the 1993 deficit estimated by the Congressional Budget office, by 1996.
Missing from the new plan was any mention of Mr. Clinton's claim during the primaries that he would be able to balance the budget within four years.
But he said that in that period he would come up with $200 billion, through tax increases and budget cuts, to expand or begin a number of Federal programs, including efforts to clean the environment and rebuild the nation's deteriorating transportation and communication systems.
 
Higher Taxes on Wealthy
 "It's time to put people first," Mr. Clinton declared when announcing his plan in a campaign appearance here.
He did not offer specifics on tax increases for the wealthy other than to say that the top 2 percent of the nation's taxpayers would be hit hardest, along with foreign corporations that had subsidiaries in the United States but now avoided many taxes.
As he did earlier in the campaign, Mr. Clinton also proposed relief for middle-class taxpayers, who he said had suffered special economic hardship in the past decade. But he has now abandoned the flat 10 percent cut he had emphasized in the primary campaign, proposing instead a system of tax credits based on family size. He offered no specifics.
 
Some Big-Spending Plans
 The Governor is a moderate who has spent much of the 1992 campaign condemning big Government spending, including programs enacted by a Congress his own party controls. But today, from the rear of a three-way Presidential race and struggling to define himself, Mr. Clinton offered some big spending proposals of his own.
"My national economic strategy puts people first by investing more than $50 billion each year for the next four years, while cutting the deficit in half," Mr. Clinton said. "These investments will create millions of high-wage jobs and help America compete in the global economy."
He caustically criticized the economic policies of the Reagan and Bush Administrations, calling them a selfish effort to help the wealthy at the expense of the rest of the nation, particularly the middle class.
"For 12 years," he said, "the driving idea behind American economic policy has been cutting taxes on the richest individuals and corporations and hoping that their new wealth would 'trickle down' to the rest of us. This policy has failed."
 
Old Ideas, New Emphasis
 The new Clinton economic strategy includes many previously proposed elements, like expanding education programs, tightening welfare rules, providing affordable health care and streamlining government programs and the Federal bureaucracy. Many of his ideas have been advocated in one form or another by other candidates in the 1992 campaign.
What was particularly different in today's plan, at least from Mr. Clinton's viewpoint, was the emphasis on taxing the rich and corporations, sharply reducing the budget deficit over four years and finding $200 billion for new programs, with almost half that money going into cleaning up the environment and renovating the nation's transportation and communications systems.
"To create millions of high-wage jobs and smooth our transition from a defense- to a commercial-based economy," the Governor said, "we will rebuild America and develop the world's best communication, transportation and environmental systems. As a prominent part of our commitment to put people first, we will create a Rebuild America Fund, with a $20 billion Federal investment each year for four years, leveraged with state, local, private sector and pension fund contributions."
 
Regulating Lobbyists
 The Clinton proposal also included new suggestions about ways to reduce the influence of lobbyists in Washington and ways to ease military personnel back into civilian life as the size of the armed forces is reduced.
He called for regulations that would require lobbyists to disclose more about their contacts and their campaign gifts, asserting it was necessary "to attack the problem at its source -- entrenched power and money."
He proposed hiring veterans to do much of the work building roads, phone networks and pollution control systems. That approach, he said, would insure "that the communities and the millions of talented workers that won the Cold War don't get left out in the cold."
All told, Mr. Clinton proposed almost $300 billion in Government savings over the next four years. Cuts in existing programs would account for about $140 billion of that, with the Defense Department taking the largest hit, more than $50 billion. He did not enumerate specific cuts in military agencies or programs.
Tax increases on the wealthy would account for another $90 billion of the $300 billion. And new taxes on corporations would bring in about $60 billion.
 
$60 Billion for Education
 The Governor also proposed spending about $50 billion over the next four years on urban housing, inner-city economic development and an extra 100,000 police officers nationwide. He proposed spending more than $20 billion on tax breaks for the middle class and the poor. And he called for spending more than $60 billion on education programs, including programs for preschool-age children and college loans for high school graduates.
Mr. Clinton said Congress must "guarantee every American the right to quality, affordable health care," and he proposed strict government monitoring of health-care costs and billing. But though health care is one of the hottest issues in the 1992 campaign, he gave only a very general description of his plan and set no costs.
 
Health-Care Plan
 "My health care plan is simple in concept but revolutionary in scope," he said. "First we will move to radically control costs by changing incentives, reducing paperwork and cracking down on drug and insurance company practices. As costs drop, we will phase in guaranteed universal access -- through employer or public programs -- to basic medical coverage. Companies will be required to insure their employees, with Federal assistance in the early years to help them meet their obligations."
Mr. Clinton said he would begin his overhaul of government at the very top of the bureaucratic heap, reducing the White House staff immediately by 25 per cent.
"Millions of hard-working Americans struggle to make ends meet while their Government no longer fights for their values or their interests," he said. "This betrayal of democracy must stop."

HEADLINE: Coloradans Raise Voices Against Jet Fighters' Din

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CRESTONE, Colo.

 BODY:
In the lonely shadows of the Sangre de Cristo Mountains, hermit monks live in spartan huts and go for a week at a time without conversation. But the prayerful silence of the Carmelite monastery here is often shattered by fighter jets zooming overhead.
As troops and planes are being recalled from overseas, and the military budget shrinks, the Air Force is trying to expand its share of air space around the country for training missions. The Air Force reasons it can save time and fuel by holding these missions closer to air bases rather than in faraway areas designated for training. 
 But residents of Crestone and the surrounding San Luis Valley complain that the missions flown by Colorado Air National Guard planes destroy the quiet of these Colorado wilds, creating the atmosphere of a war zone.
"These jets come thundering out of nowhere and really frighten you," said Brother Thomas Crutcher, a member of the Carmelite monastery. In one case, he said, a monk was so startled by the sudden roar that he lost his balance and nearly fell from a 30-foot bell tower.
 
Blown Off Bicycles
 A schoolteacher said she had seen children knocked off bicycles by the force of the wind currents from flying jets. Others say jets have buzzed cars, pick-ups and cattle.
The Colorado Air National Guard's fleet of 26 F-16 jets flies out of the Buckley Air Force Base in Aurora, a suburb of Denver about 150 miles away. The F-16's, which were used in the Persian Gulf, are much faster and, residents say, noisier than the A-7 models they replaced. A sonic boom caused by an F-16 last month rattled windows and knocked dishes from counter tops.
The Colorado Air National Guard, a division of the Air Force, says the boom was caused by a pilot who flew over the region at an inappropriate speed. The F-16 jets can accelerate to twice the speed of sound. The pilot has been reprimanded, said Maj. Thomas Schultz, a Guard spokesman.
For almost two decades the Air Force has used the skies over this stretch of countryside as a pathway to more distant training areas. Now it wants to change the designation of the region from a training path to a "military operation area," to be called the Red Eye Complex.
 
More Planes at One Time
 That would increase the number of flights over the area -- there were about 1,000 last year -- by about 10 percent. But it would also provide for jet exercises that last 30 minutes and allow for air drills on 10 days a year involving up to 50 planes.
Finally, the new plan calls for training missions to drop a chemical substance from planes to confuse the weapons' guidance systems of enemy aircraft. Residents say the substance, called chaff, consisting of silica and aluminum with a stearic acid coating, would pollute the environment.
The military also wants new flight training areas in Massachusetts and Idaho as well as other parts of the country. Pentagon policy calls for the training areas to be away from buildings.
The Air Force has hired a private concern to conduct an environmental study to determine if a flight training area would do any harm here. If no hazards were foreseen, the plan would be submitted to the Federal Aviation Administration for approval.
 
Hazard and Annoyance
 Residents here have formed what they call the Open Space Alliance to fight the Air Force's request. They contend that the proposal would add to the hazards and annoyances that the area already endures as a flight pathway. They also say that the flights would be a further hazard to the endangered peregrine falcon and bald eagle, as well as to a host of other wildlife. And they question the need for such military training, especially with the cold war over.
The switch to the F-16 jets created 80 new jobs at the air base. But residents here say they are reaping no economic benefit.
"To the contrary, it's hurting our economy, which is largely based on tourism," said Robert Phillio, a real estate agent who is running for a post on the county commission. A large draw for tourists in the area is the National Sand Dunes Monument recreation area.
As a concession to the residents, the Colorado Air National Guard has agreed that its planes will fly no lower than 500 feet if the training area is approved. The normal "floor" at training areas is 100 feet. At present the planes are supposed to fly no lower than 500 feet, but residents say they often do.
Major Schultz said the training area would be no more annoying for residents than the current flight conditions. "In fact, we will be doing more high-level flights," he said, "so they might even notice it less than they do now."
Major Schultz allowed that residents were justified to complain about buzzing and other inappropriate flying. The Colorado Air National Guard has set up a toll-free telephone number for such complaints.
But he added: "We have the obligation to provide for a strong, ready force. Some people say, 'Not in my backyard.' Well, whose backyard do they think should have it?"
The residents of this small community are so angry about the Air Force plan that they have started a newspaper, The Red Eye Sentinel, which includes a regular column of "eyewitness encounters" with jets. Some residents say the jets have flown so low that they can see the pilots' teeth.
 
$342,000 Injury Settlement
 "They keep telling us, 'Relax, it's not going to be any worse,' " said Kate Steichen, the leader of the opposition. "And we're telling them: 'It's already terrible the way it is. And you want to do more.' "
Groups that monitor military jet traffic offer evidence that the training flights pose a danger for residents. A Reno woman who was buzzed by a military jet won a $342,000 suit from the Government last year. The woman, Leslie Bunch, said she had been startled by a low-flying aircraft and lost control of her pick-up. Ms. Bunch, who was pregnant at the time, suffered a miscarriage and four broken ribs. Her two sons, ages 3 and 4, were also injured.
"We're seeing major plans for military air-space expansion around the country right now," said Grace Bukowkski of the Rural Alliance for Military Accountability in Nevada, a private watchdog group. "Rural areas are being asked to bear the burden of our national defense."
Brother Crutcher said his fellow monks at the Carmelite monastery would be forced to leave if the new flight plan is approved.
"We came here because we needed to get away from the noise," he said. "This is a matter of life and death for us. If they put this through, we simply won't be able to stay."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press Notes;
3 Dailies Join Hands to Cut Cost of News

BYLINE: By Alex S. Jones

 BODY:
INCREASINGLY, newspapers in a specific region sell advertising cooperatively. But three New Jersey dailies are trying to apply the same principle to news coverage.
The Record, which covers much of northern New Jersey from its base in Hackensack, and The News Tribune in Woodbridge, both owned by the Borg family, are on the verge of pooling some news coverage with The Asbury Park Press, owned by the Plangere family. 
 Malcolm A. Borg, chairman of his family's newspaper operation, Macromedia Inc., said he had already effectively merged the news operations of The Record and The News Tribune so that reporters from both papers do not cover the same event or issue separately.
"We're finally going to not reinvent the wheel," Mr. Borg said.
For instance, a single page for regional and national sports will be prepared for both papers; rather than having two papers cover Giants games, one will do the job. Mr. Borg said that reducing costs in a depressed advertising market was an objective of the effective merger.
Similarly, Mr. Borg and E. Donald Lass, publisher of The Asbury Park Press, plan to pool resources to cover the national political conventions and the Summer Olympics. If that works, the next step might be to produce a joint travel section that would cost more than either paper could afford on its own, and for each paper to swap articles of interest.
But Mr. Lass said The Press and the Borg papers would reserve the right to send their own reporters to the other's turf.
"We're very sensitive to losing control," said Mr. Lass. His paper would not swap enterprise and investigative articles with The News Herald, a direct competitor, or The Record, which is based about 50 miles away.
Reporters generally abhor pooled coverage because it blunts the joy of beating rivals. Editors often hate it because they have little ability to direct another publication's reporters and the standards of one paper may be quite different from another.
While newspapers within a chain routinely swap articles, the papers are rarely regional rivals.
Mr. Borg said the pooling effort was aimed at a common rival of all New Jersey dailies: The Star-Ledger of Newark, whose resources far outstrip the smaller papers.
"It's a defense against The Star-Ledger, no question about it," Mr. Borg said.
 
Hawking Papers
 "I'm seeing signs of an early spring thaw, but water is not cascading down the mountains," said Lee Dirks, a newspaper broker, of the climate for buying and selling newspapers, which has been in a deep freeze for three years.
Mr. Dirks, president of Lee Dirks & Associates in Birmingham, Mich., said that there had been a change in the market in recent months. Prospective buyers were beginning to sniff the air for prey, he said, and some of the stronger regional banks were aggressively making it known that they had money available to finance newspaper purchases.
But prospective sellers are still hanging back, disappointed at the prices that their papers are now likely to bring.
"Sellers are for the most part aware that they are unlikely to ever see the kinds of multiples in the late 80's," Mr. Dirks said. For instance, a 50,000-circulation newspaper in a growing market might sell for four to four and a half times annual revenues, compared with a 1987 price of five to six times revenues.
And these multiples would apply only to the most desirable papers, with a great potential for growth.
A very small daily with 9,000 circulation might bring as little as one to one and a half times revenues.
The difference in price reflects, in many cases, a big difference in the profit margins that the two types of papers could be expected to produce.
A study published in the spring issue of The Journal of Media Economics, a publication of California State University at Fullerton, found a great disparity in average profit margins among newspapers of different sizes.
The study compared papers of different circulations from 1978 to 1988, a decade that included both fat and lean years for advertising.
The study reported that average profit margins ranged from 6.4 percent at daily papers with less than 10,000 circulation to a high of 19 percent for those with 25,000 to 50,000 circulation. Those exceeding 50,000 circulation were almost as high, at 18.9 percent.
Mr. Dirks said these averages seemed generally accurate to him, though some papers might do considerably better or worse.
But, he said, profit margins of newspapers with circulations exceeding 100,000 would be lower than the 18.9 percent found for all papers over 50,000, because the overhead for the largest papers tended to squeeze profit margins.
 
Neuharth's Modesty
 In the matter of Allen H. Neuharth's thoughts on Ross Perot, it may have been a case of "it takes one to know a bigger one."
Mr. Neuharth, chairman of the Freedom Forum and former chairman of the Gannett Company, has never been accused of having low self-esteem. For instance, he titled his memoirs "Confessions of an S.O.B." Like Mr. Perot, he is a can-do maverick who ignores criticism and does not shrink from spending lots of money to accomplish his ends.
For example, in the last year, the Freedom Forum -- formerly the Gannett Foundation until Mr. Neuharth changed its name -- has become one of the world's most open-handed givers in the name of the organization's (Neuharth-inspired) slogan: "free press, free speech, free spirit."
The Freedom Forum now has six offices, including a new base in Zurich and a First Amendment Center at Vanderbilt University in Nashville. And in Washington, the forum is planning to open a "Newseum," which will be a museum of newspapers and journalism.
The forum, with assets of $700 million and an annual budget of $35 million, has also financed a number of grants, fellowships, seminars and other projects, including a billboard with the message "Freedom Works" in Red Square in Moscow.
Such freewheeling and free-spending habits suggested that Mr. Neuharth might have special insights into Mr. Perot, and he was asked his opinion of the undeclared Presidential candidate last week at the Freedom Forum's trustees dinner.
After reflecting for a moment, Mr. Neuharth issued his evaluation: "His ego is even bigger than mine."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
WALL STREET REBOUND COULD PAY DIVIDENDS 
 Flush with profits that have surpassed the best years of the booming 1980's, Wall Street is offering glimmers of hope for the battered economies of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, but so far has failed to lift the region out of its recession. Experts say that the resurgence could spill over into law firms, financial publishers, restaurants, travel agencies, clothing stores and hundreds of other businesses. "By itself, Wall Street cannot lift us out of recession, but it looks like it is going to make a start," said Matthew P. Drennan, an economist and urban planner at Cornell University. A1.
 
A CITY, A PROBLEM, AND AN ENIGMA
Fearing that an onslaught of ground food pulp would overpower its intricate, 13,000-mile underground network of water mains and sewers -- New York City remains the only major city in the United States to ban the use of the kitchen garbage disposer. Although many Staten Island residents and some in Queens who have modern sewer connections may use them, the reasons why the other six or seven million New Yorkers in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and most of Queens continue to lead disposerless lives are so varied, complex and confusing that it is nearly impossible to find a city official who can explain them. A1.
 
NOXIOUS ODORS RANKLE HARLEM RESIDENTS
Embittered by years of indifference and questionable promises, a consortium of New York environmental groups, community organizations and Harlem residents plan to sue the city to force an end to the incapacitating odors that have become the hallmark of the city's newest sewage plant on the Hudson River in Harlem. If it succeeds, the suit could force New York to spend as much as $100 million in immediate repairs to the plant, and millions more for the severe "physical and psychological discomfort it has caused" local residents. B3.
 
SLIWA ACCUSES POLICE OF FOOT-DRAGGING
Lisa Sliwa accused detectives from the Ninth Precinct in New York City of dragging their heels in investigating the shooting of her husband, Curtis, and has called on Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown to appoint detectives from another precinct to take over the case. B3.
 
AFFORDABLE HOUSING GOES TO COURT
Like many people in the region, Renee Coleman looked long, hard and unsuccessfully for affordable housing. But the Long Island resident's search did not end with her dissappointment. She filed a lawsuit, one that could transform local zoning regulations and racial segregation patterns in New York State. That was eight years ago. After endless rounds in lower courts her attorney is asking Court of Appeals to hear the case. Metro Matters, B2.
 
REGION
 
EXXON SUSPECT LOVED HIGH LIFE
Several days before his arrest on charges of kidnapping an Exxon executive, Arthur Seale visited the luxurious South Carolina resort of Hilton Head Island, reminisced about his life there in the mid-80's and mused about living there again and buying a a marina. "He was very likeable, very open, and very friendly," said a woman who had dined with him at the resort. "We had every indication he and his wife were considering moving here." B5.
 
SUFFOLK COUNTY POLICE JUMP SHIP
More than 250 Suffolk County police officers, fearing reduced pension benefits, have filed for retirement within the last two weeks as Suffolk legislators debated an across-the-board pay cut for all county employees. The Legislature is expected to vote this week on the pay issue and a proposal by the county executive to lay off 1,300 county workers, including 300 police officers. B5.
 
CONTRACT AGREEMENT AT CON ED
After 11th-hour negotiations prevented a possible strike by 13,000 Consolidated Edison workers, union officials confidently predicted that a tentative four-year pact would be overwhelmingly ratified by union members. B5.
 
SLOW TRAIN TO ROMANCE
Frank Field spent 20 years working for other people's railroads. Now, he runs his own. The six-and-a-half minute ride, at a maximum speed of 8 miles per hour, is an encounter with the romance of the rails and a monument to one engineer's search for perfection. B5.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
New Linkage Hinders Aid for Russia

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 21

 BODY:
The concept of "linkage" used to be at the center of negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union, as concessions on one issue often had to be compensated by the other side's backing down somewhere else.
The idea now may be passe diplomatically. But it is at the heart of political dealings between President Bush and House Democrats over aid to the nations of the former Soviet Union. The Democrats insist they won't help Russia and the rest if President Bush won't support their efforts to help Americans. 
As they have demonstrated on issues from abortion to balanced budgets, each side can thwart the other. But they have little recent experience working together to get laws enacted.
So despite Boris N. Yeltsin's smash-hit appearance before Congress Wednesday, with the reassurance it offered lawmakers of his commitment to economic reform, hopes for fast action on a substantial aid package may actually have suffered a setback later that day. After weeks of argument, Democrats gave in to President Bush, agreeing on an emergency urban bill $1 billion smaller than they wanted.
High-ranking Congressional aides said Mr. Bush "nickel and dimed us" and now must prove his bona fides by accepting their permanent changes in unemployment compensation and a serious long-term urban program.
Representative David R. Obey, the Wisconsin Democrat who heads the appropriations subcommittee dealing with foreign aid, said it was not a question of legislative blackmail but of practical politics. If the country was not convinced that domestic problems were being attacked, there would never be support for aiding Mr. Yeltsin and his counterparts.
To the argument that the issues were not related, he scoffed that "the Administration needs a reality check." He said, "The guys who put this package together don't have to run for re-election."
One of the firmest supporters of aid to the former Soviet states, Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa, was unimpressed. He accused the Democratic leaders of "gamesmanship" and said "the leadership is toying with U.S. national security interests." But he did see connection between cities and foreign aid, saying, "You can't aid the cities until you win the peace, and winning the peace requires a modest investment."
The issue will probably face two tests in Congress this week. President Bush's plan, centered on $12 billion in replenishment of the United States commitment to the International Monetary Fund, is likely to be voted on in the Senate. After some amendments to reduce Administration discretion in providing aid, it is expected to pass. "We have the horses for a very good vote in the Senate," said Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, the Republican whip.
The House is another story. There is $417 million in direct aid to the former Soviet states in the $13.8 billion foreign-aid appropriation scheduled for a Wednesday vote. That section may be attacked directly, but even if it is not, the whole bill might be defeated.
If it is beaten, Republicans will play a critical role in killing it. Because for all the public wrangling between Mr. Bush and House Democrats, foreign aid of all sorts is also held hostage by House Republicans. Few speak out in terms like those used by Senate Republicans like Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, who said, "We have to support this man who is courageously fighting for change."
Representative Dave Nagle, Democrat of Iowa and another strong supporter of post-Soviet aid, said that to pass it, supporters would need 100 Republican votes of the 166 seats the minority party holds. Mr. Leach said he did not know how many Republicans would vote for the bill, but he insisted it would be irresponsible of the Democrats to hold back for lack of Republican allies.
Democrats are also peeved with Mr. Bush because they think he is not exerting himself to win Republican support. Mr. Obey said he saw no evidence of Presidential persuasion yet. "The President has to lead," said Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana, the probable incoming chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee.
In the long run, and that may be as late as October when the Congress adjourns, everyone expects the proposal to be enacted.
"All of us recognize the politics of it are not easy," Mr. Hamilton said. But it is needed, he said, and in the long run it is "very difficult for me to believe that Congress will leave for the year without voting the package."

HEADLINE: Talk in Washington Heights: Fear, Drugs, and Now Corruption

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN

 BODY:
Three generations of Adriano Espaillat's family have lived in the 34th Police Precinct in Washington Heights, a neighborhood where relatives' businesses have flourished and some still greet the family members by name when they walk down the street.
It is only when Mr. Espaillat thinks about the fourth generation -- his own children -- that he wonders whether it is time to concede that in the struggle between civility and the chaos created by the growing drug culture, the bad guys are winning. 
 Mr. Espaillat, a long-time community advocate, does not let his 11-year-old son and 4-year-old daughter play outside without him. He has witnessed shootings in broad daylight. His grandparents, in their 80's, were recently tied up and robbed at knife-point in their own apartment.
Fear, violence and, above all, drugs have come to dominate the streets of Washington Heights. Now, the Heights and the precinct, called in police argot the three-four, which usually leads the city in homicides, is the center of a Federal investigation into possible police corruption.
 
'It's a Little Discouraging'
 Mr. Espaillat and his wife have decided, as have many others who live and work here, that the best way to change their neighborhood is to stay and fight. And this is why reports of possible corruption among the police ranks in the 34th Precinct are especially disconcerting to them and other in Washington Heights.
"When you read stuff like that in the newspapers, it's a little discouraging," said Espaillat, who said he had no direct knowledge that such allegations are true.
Throughout the territory of the three-four, in the farthest northern reaches of Manhattan, residents and merchants say there is not an area in the city that is in more need of tougher and more effective law enforcement. Life in the three-four has become increasingly fearful, they say, and it will become desperate if not even the police are on the community's side.
Walking down Broadway, near 158th Street recently, Mr. Espaillat made his way through the noisy congested streets, past vendors hawking everything from fruit juices to brassieres. In the median park that runs through Broadway, men sat under trees, intent on dominoes matches. But even as lively Caribbean music wafted through the air along with the spicy scent of sancocho, the Dominican stew, there was an air of foreboding on this, one of the most notorious drug-dealing corners of the city, the police and residents say.
Young men linger on the sidewalk, lookouts for drug dealers. They call out, "Agua, agua," which means water in Spanish, when they see the police coming, or "Bajando, bajando," which means coming down.
"You see the drug dealers' sentries everywhere," said a juice vendor who would give his name only as Nicolas. "But what can we do? We have to work and there are few jobs." He said he would not be surprised if police officers were taking bribes.
In buildings that drug dealers have taken over, the police say, small, dirty apartments with little more than a table, white powder and the equipment to package it are the hub of a sophisticated network that provides one-stop shopping for an endless stream of customers.
 
Community Groups Join Fight
 Those in the community who are working to try to drive drugs out of the neighborhood also say they would not be surprised if some police officers had been corrupted by the drug trade, pointing out the openness with which it flourishes.
"I would rather not believe it but I wouldn't doubt it," said Lucille Bulger, who heads the Community League of West 159th Street Inc.
The group was founded 40 years ago by neighbors who wanted to raise money for children's activities. Now the group has found itself more involved, out of necessity, in trying to rid the neighborhood of drug dealers.
"Some of those drug dealers must have some sort of legal support to maintain their high level of income that they will kill for," Mrs. Bulger said, explaining why it would be possible that police are involved.
She has never seen it herself, she said, and in fact her group has actually worked together with the police to close down drug operations in the basement of buildings in the area. But she said the proliferation of drugs and the high stakes have filled many residents with terror.
"Citizens who may have information are afraid," Mrs. Bulger said. "The drug vendors involved in the whole operation don't give a damn about life. They'll shoot you in two shakes of a lamb's tail."
 
Community of Immigrants
 Washington Heights is a community of immigrants, many of them newly arrived and a great number from the Dominican Republic. Many are illegal immigrants and thus more vulnerable and less likely to go to the police with their complaints.
The neighborhood wasn't always so dangerous, Mrs. Bulger said. It used to be home to Irish and Jewish and later Puerto Rican and Cuban immigrants. Its elegant apartment buildings, especially along Edgecombe Avenue, were home to entertainers, writers and other artists, she said. Leslie Uggams lived there for a time, she said, when the area was referred to as Sugar Hill.
"I will never move out of here and I have never thought of moving out of here," Mrs. Bulger said.
"I believe that the biggest mistake that anyone who has enjoyed life in this community makes is to move out," she said. "Because if you move out, who would replace you? If people in the upper economic levels had been brave enough to live and stay here after they reach that level, this would not have become the community it is today."
 
Dominicans Faulted
 Many in the community also resent that when Washington Heights' drug problem is brought up it is often attributed to the growth of the Dominican population in the area.
"It is very easy to label Washington Heights the cocaine capital of New York," said Dr. Rafael Lantigua, one of the founders of the Alianza Dominicana, a civic group. "There are maybe seven or eight blocks that have a real drug problem, but the rest of the neighborhood is calm and quiet."
Dominicans now own many of the bodegas and other shops in the neighborhood, and they recently elected Guillermo Linares to the City Council when the revised city charter created a new district in Washington Heights.
Still, while Dominicans have turned parts of Washington Heights into a community of shared values and culture, the drug problem continues.
"When I walk down this street, I go very fast," said Marcia Botex, an 11-year resident, as she hurried down Broadway near 159th Street. "I don't look at anyone, or even window shop.
"I don't feel safe until I get to the hospital," she said, referring to Columbia-Presbyterian.
 
A Higher Degree
 Mr. Espaillat, who has lived in Washington Heights for 29 years, directs the Victims Services Agency there. He and his parents moved there from the Dominican Republic when he was 10 years old. His grandparents were already living in Washington Heights when he was born.
Mr. Espaillat ran against Mr. Linares for the City Council, and lost. During his campaign, he recalled, he saw a man shot in Washington Heights.
"It was a nice sunny day, and I saw a guy bleeding to death on the street. It was an ugly sight, and fearful," he said. "For families and people who have children, it's a very scary situation.
"I remember going down the stairs in the summertime to play stickball and then running upstairs when it was time to eat and my mother never worried," he said.
"Now you can't do that," he said.
"You can argue that it's that way in many New York neighborhoods, but the degree of fear and violence is higher here.
"But it's not like the community has given up," he said. "A lot of people are working to change it. I'm optimistic."

HEADLINE: Fearing Reduced Benefits, 250 Suffolk Officers Seek to Retire

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., June 21

 BODY:
More than 250 Suffolk County police officers, fearing reduced pension benefits, have filed for retirement within the last two weeks as Suffolk legislators debated an across-the-board pay cut for all county employees.
The County Legislature is expected to vote this week on the pay issue and an additional proposal by County Executive Robert Gaffney, a Republican, to lay off 1,300 county workers, including 300 police officers. The moves are required to win Albany's approval of a county proposal to borrow up to $91 million to close a $110 million budget gap in this year's $1.3 billion budget. 
 Police officers, uncertain about the outcome here and in Albany, have been filing in record numbers for retirement. Since their pensions are based on their salary at the time of retirement, a pay cut now would mean less for them in the future.
At a meeting of the Suffolk Legislature's Public Safety Committee here last week, Robert Creighton, the Suffolk Police Commissioner, said the pay cut could cost him up to 600 more police officers -- the number of officers with 20 years or more of service who are eligible to retire. He said that would leave "a disastrous hole" in his department.
"I feel like the leader of the dance band on the Titanic," he told the legislators at a hearing last week.
 
A 'Dire' Situation
 "This is not scare techniques," he said. "I'm telling you the absolute truth. We are facing a dire, dire situation."
In pressing for the wage and job cuts, Mr. Gaffney has said projected revenues from sales-tax and real-property-tax receipts are way below anticipated levels, while expenditures for social services and other programs for those most affected by the recession have increased sharply.
His office estimates that the 10 percent pay cut would save the county $20 million and the job cuts an additional $23 million over the remaining months of the current fiscal year ending on Dec. 31.
Fearful that county legislators will have enough votes to pass one or both measures this week, police officers have been lining up in record numbers to file their retirement papers. According to Suffolk officials, 197 officers retired last year. Between January and a few weeks ago, when Mr. Gaffney proposed the pay cut, 114 officers had filed. The day after Mr. Gaffney endorsed the pay cut, 80 officers filed, beginning a long line that by last Friday had grown to an additional 250 officers.
The biggest group showed up at Police Headquarters in Yaphank last Monday, when 129 handed in their papers. The Police Department's processing center became so overwhelmed that day that it moved its operations to the headquarters cafeteria to handle the crush of officers.
Police retirement pay is half the salary earned during the final year of active service, or half the average salary earned during the last three years on the job, whichever is higher. Many of the officers applying for retirement have also earned large amounts of overtime pay this year because of the shortage of officers and an increased work load.
 
Carrying Out a Promise
 Some of that overtime and other benefits now adding to future pension checks might also be lost as Commissioner Creighton, who was sworn in several weeks ago, carries out his promise to Mr. Gaffney and the legislators to reorganize the Police Department and reduce costs, including overtime.
Mr. Creighton warned the legislators at a hearing in Hauppauge last Thursday that should there be layoffs in his department, in addition to those who are retiring, then the county could be at risk. He said the county's 2,340-member police force now had the lowest officer-to-population ratio in the country for areas with more than a million people. The county's population is 1.3 million.

HEADLINE: Batman Is Back, and the Money Is Pouring In

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, June 21

 BODY:
Batman has indeed returned. The newly opened sequel, "Batman Returns," broke box office records over the weekend and is poised to turn into one of the largest-grossing films ever.
Executives at Warner Brothers, which produced and distributed the dark, perverse and hugely expensive comedy, said today that the movie would gross a staggering $46.5 million for the weekend, a record. The previous weekend record was held by "Batman," the 1989 film that hauled in $42.7 million and then went on to be the sixth-biggest-grossing film in history. 
 Terry Semel, the president of Warner Brothers Inc., said in an interview: "It's clear that the chemistry in and around this movie -- the subject matter, the characters, the look of the film -- appeals to children, to people in high school, to adults, male and female. The film has become an event. People want to get out of the house and see this movie."
 
The Cost and the Cast
 Officially, Warner Brothers puts the cost of "Batman Returns" at $55 million. But in the never-never land of Hollywood economics, the movie, with its German Expressionist design, big salaries and maniacal special effects, probably cost anywhere from $75 million upward. The film, directed by Tim Burton, is set in Gotham City (a mythically ugly New York), and stars Michael Keaton as the caped crusader, Michelle Pfeiffer as a tantalizing, witty and feminist Catwoman, and Danny DeVito as the Penguin, an evil, neurotic Mayoral candidate who was raised by the birds.
Robert G. Friedman, the president of Warner's worldwide theatrical advertising and publicity, said delightedly over the phone: "Unlike the first 'Batman,' we tried to keep the fires low and didn't start promoting it till relatively late. We focused on the individual characters that made up the whole of the movie, their uniqueness, rather than trumpeting the movie as the event of the summer, like the first one. We opened it the first real weekend when kids are out of school. The audience is everybody, but the engine that drives the charge are kids under 20."
The mammoth size of the weekend grosses, after an opening that saw huge lines at theaters in New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, Atlanta and elsewhere, can only be illustrated by comparing it with those of other films. "Lethal Weapon 3," the bloody buddy movie, which until today had this year's highest weekend gross, took in $33.2 million on its first weekend. "Patriot Games," the adventure starring Harrison Ford, opened two weeks ago to what was viewed as an impressive weekend gross: $18.5 million.
 
Multiples at the Multi-plexes
 To promote the film, Warner's actually opened it at many theaters across the nation on Thursday night, and unleashed the movie at a total of 2,600 theaters on Friday. Because many multi-plexes are playing the film in more than one theater, it is actually being shown on more than 3,000 screens, an unusually large number.
The summer is the peak time for moviegoing, and the season's other mega-expensive epics have already opened, to mixed results. Some movies been major disappointments, notably "Far and Away," the adventure love story starring Tom Cruise as an Irish immigrant in the 1890's, and "Alien 3," the science-fiction sequel in which Sigourney Weaver battles a slimy creature. The studio that is virtually popping Champagne corks is Warner Brothers, which produced not only "Batman Returns," but also the other summer blockbuster, "Lethal Weapon 3." (The studio has also had its share of setbacks, including "The Mambo Kings" and, especially, "Memoirs of an Invisible Man.")
On the other end of the spring-summer seesaw is Universal Pictures, which is enduring a bleak season. Disappointments range from "Far and Away," which may have cost at least $60 million, or far more, and "Kuffs," "The Babe" and "Leaving Normal."
 
Light, Airy 'Lethal Weapon'
 Brian Grazer, the producer of "Far and Away," and a founding partner of Imagine Films Entertainment, with Ron Howard, the film's director, said in an interview: "I've produced 23 movies. I feel this was a really good movie, but I think it just came out the wrong time of the year. On Memorial Day weekend, people want to party, they want to crack beer bottles and have a good time. I don't know if they want to watch a period movie that's 2 hours and 20 minutes. Look, I, myself, want to see a light, airy movie this time of year: "Lethal Weapon" or "Batman." He said that "Far and Away" would probably turn out to be profitable because of Tom Cruise's strong appeal abroad.
It is conventional Hollywood wisdom, though, that when a movie performs relatively poorly, its makers inevitably blame two factors: the time of year the film opened or interference by the studio. The actual problem with "Far and Away," reviewers said, is that the film never quite manages to turn into a sweeping epic drama, in the style of "Lawrence of Arabia" or "Doctor Zhivago." Instead, it resembles a television mini-series.
The biggest surprise of the summer is "Sister Act," a comedy with an average-size budget ($20 million) about a nightclub singer, played by Whoopi Goldberg, who hides out in a convent to escape the mob. The movie's musical numbers and cheerfully droll performances by actresses playing nuns have turned "Sister Act" into a movie that could gross as much as $100 million, far more than "Far and Away" or "Alien 3." For the Walt Disney Company, which has had its share of ups ("Encino Man" and "Medicine Man") and downs ("Newsies," "Noises Off," "Blame It on the Bellboy"), the triumph of "Sister Act" is especially sweet.
 
Long Run for 'Sister Act'
 "Audiences seem to love it, and there's tremendous word of mouth building on this movie," said Richard Cook, the president of Buena Vista Film Distribution, which releases Disney films. "It's going to run through the summer."
Gayle Anne Hurd, the executive producer of "Terminator 2: Judgment Day," the 1991 No. 1 box office success, and producer of the low-budget drama "The Waterdance" about men seeking to come to terms with their spinal injuries, said: "Generally, the summer is a time for big epic blockbusters, movies that are directed to the 14-to-18-year-old male audience. With 'Sister Act,' which is a fun night at the movies, it's a case of alternative programming. A film that finds another audience. It's like 'Dead Poets Society' a few years ago. It's counter-programming."
Because of the impact of the Batman films, every studio in town shied away from opening movies this weekend. Some executives were plainly concerned that their films would be overwhelmed by the Batman phenomenon.
But Mace Neufeld, who produced "Patriot Games" with Bob Rehme, said in an interview: "Even with the humongous 'Batman' business, we seem to be holding. A film like 'Batman' brings people into the movie theaters and there's a spillover effect. People arrive at the multi-plex, can't get in or don't want to wait on a long line, so they see other films. 'Batman' is actually helping."

HEADLINE: Good Health -- and Good Politics

 BODY:
Speaker Thomas Foley is committed to bringing health care reform to a House vote before next month's Democratic convention. Standing in the way of his election-year strategy is a fractured membership, split between contradictory approaches to reform.
But consensus may not be as far out of reach as it looks. Many Democrats have taken a hard second look at the approach called managed competition and like what they see. Managed competition, which has always seemed the best idea for insurance reform on the merits, may now become the best approach for political reasons as well. 
 The Democratic leadership has split over how to deal with the crisis in health care. Medical costs are rising three times faster than inflation, and almost 40 million Americans are uninsured.
Some members of Congress favor "play-or-pay," an approach that would preserve private insurers. Employers would enroll workers in private plans or else pay a tax to enroll them in a public backup plan. Other members favor single-payer plans, like Canada's. These would eliminate private insurers and enroll everyone in a single Government plan.
Play-or-pay appeals to members who fear turning health care over to government; single-payer appeals to those who want a universal system into which everyone pays for the same basic coverage. Democrats are coming to realize that, with managed competition, they can have it all.
John Garamendi, California's insurance commissioner, has proposed a plan, now working its way through the State Legislature, that provides the best of both worlds. Employers and employees would pay a payroll tax to a regional authority, or sponsor. The sponsor would contract with private insurers to offer basic coverage, defined by the government, to any applicant at no additional cost. The sponsor would also contract with private insurers to offer members more generous plans. But buyers would have to pay for the entire additional cost, a useful brake on skyrocketing premiums.
Because the Garamendi plan builds in competition among private insurers, it appeals to some advocates of play-or-pay. And because the plan taxes everyone for identical basic coverage, it appeals to some single-payer advocates. The tax, in effect, imposes a global budget on basic health care without imposing the heavy hand of price controls.
Unable to win consensus for comprehensive reform, Democrats like Chairman Dan Rostenkowski of the tax-writing committee back piecemeal measures. They at least want to curtail repugnant practices like discriminating against applicants with certain medical conditions.
Such reform would surely be welcome but is not enforceable if imposed piecemeal. Telling insurers to enroll AIDS victims at fixed rates in effect tells the companies to lose money. That compels insurers to find loopholes. The Garamendi plan, however, would allow sponsors to reimburse insurers who enroll disproportionate numbers of people who have costly chronic illnesses.
The longer the House looks at managed competition, the better it looks. The leadership has already decided to put a managed competition bill, sponsored by the Democrats Jim Cooper of Tennessee and Michael Andrews of Texas, up for vote next month along with play-or-pay and single-payer. That's welcome news.
It's still unlikely that Congress can complete reform legislation this year, even though the crisis in health care costs obviously roils the public. But now, at least, the House seems to be finding a path through the wilderness.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Baker's Guilty Knowledge

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A Foreign Service officer named Frank Lemay ought to be a hero. He was the first to warn his bosses at the State Department that Saddam Hussein was using U.S.-backed grain loans to build a nuclear bomb.
In his memorandum of Oct. 13, 1989, he recounted a conversation with four nervous Department of Agriculture officials who had been briefed on a probe into Iraq's multi-billion dollar abuse of the Lavoro bank's Atlanta branch. 
 "Payments required by Iraq of exporters . . . may have been diverted into acquiring sensitive nuclear technologies," Mr. Lemay wrote to his superiors two and a half years ago. He reported Agriculture's Inspector General to be concerned that "commodities were bartered in Jordan and Turkey for military hardware" and that the U.S. Attorney in Atlanta (a former C.I.A. man) had indicated that diverted funds "were used to procure nuclear related equipment."
But Frank Lemay is a pariah, not a hero, at State because his memo -- made public by Representative Henry Gonzalez -- proves that State policy makers possessed the guilty knowledge of Saddam Hussein's unlawful use of American financing.
Despite that written notification of likely diversion, Secretary of State Baker leaned on Secretary of Agriculture Clayton Yeutter to extend an additional $500 million to Saddam Hussein. And despite Yeutter's 1989 pledge to the Senate Agriculture chairman, Patrick Leahy, not to issue new credits until suspicions of corruption were resolved, Secretary Yeutter -- under heavy Baker pressure -- rushed the "grain" financing to Saddam.
Mr. Lemay is one of the witnesses scheduled to testify this week before the House Judiciary Committee, as it decides whether to request that the Attorney General determine in 30 days if evidence exists of high-level malfeasance requiring a court-appointed independent counsel.
Why is Secretary Baker allowing the young F.S.O. to appear, when the White House has refused to let higher-ups testify? The answer is provided me by a colleague of his at State: "Because Frank is being set up to be discredited by the cover-up crowd at Agriculture, who have already lied to Congress. And because Frank does not know to this day what happened after his memo went upstairs."
What did happen to the Lemay warning at State? Copies went to his boss, Undersecretary for Economic Affairs Richard McCormack, who has left Government, as has then-Counsel Abraham Sofaer; to Sam Hoskinson, who has gone to C.I.A.; to State's "Mr. Iraq," Jack Covey of the Near East Bureau, and to four participants in the meeting at Agriculture.
My mid-level State source believes that McCormack took his assistant's red-hot memo to James Baker and read sections of it aloud. Amazing result: the economic oversight was taken away from Economic Affairs and assigned to "Baker's man," Robert Zoellick. From that point on, the troublesome Lemay was out of the loop.
What motivated Baker, a lawyer of legendary caution, to ignore the written report of the way our money was being diverted to Saddam's nuclear program?
A better-placed source, who keeps my essays dated 11/30/89 and 3/19/90 in his or her desk drawer, says: "At the time, this was Saddam's only ready source of major cash. And it was the only string we had on him."
String to do what? To become, in President Bush's words, a respected member of the family of nations?
"That's extremely classified. All I can say is we were asked by foreign officials at the highest levels for help on a particular matter. There was a task we wanted Iraq to accomplish and this C.C.C. program was the only way we had to pay for it.
"Our goal," he adds, "was honorable; maybe it was a fool's errand, but it was worth a try."
Who else knows the Bush-Baker motive for knowingly allowing a dictator to divert a half billion dollars in supposed grain credits to military and nuclear use?
My source will say only that the motive was "sufficiently compelling" and the men closest to Baker, then and now, were in on it. But nobody that the Bush Administration is sending to the Judiciary Committee knows the secret motive for corrupting our export program to pay off Saddam Hussein.

HEADLINE: Briton Sees AIDS Cutting Population in Parts of Africa

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 15

 BODY:
A British scientist has predicted that because of the AIDS epidemic, populations in the worst-afflicted African countries will within 20 years switch over from their present high rate of increase to an actual decrease in numbers.
In Uganda, where 1.5 million people out of a population of 16 million are thought to be infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, the current 3 percent population growth rate is likely to fall to below zero after 2002, with more people dying than being born, the projections say. 
 In 15 years, Uganda would have 20 percent fewer people than if the AIDS epidemic had not occurred. The population would be 20.28 million, instead of 24 million. Tanzania, Malawi and Rwanda, all in the central and east African belt where AIDS has hit hardest, would be similarly affected, the results show.
The projections have been made by Roy M. Anderson, head of the department of biology at the Imperial College of Science and Technology in London, who is a leader in the growing field of mathematical modeling that is used for predicting the demographic consequences of AIDS.
The results of his predictions, done with Robert M. May of Oxford University, have been presented in medical and scientific journals in the last year and were expanded on by Professor Anderson at an international conference on infectious diseases in Nairobi last week.
 
Pessimistic Projection
 Professor Anderson's results are far gloomier than those of other mathematical modelers at the World Bank, the World Health Organization of the United Nations and the Population Council in New York. They have all concluded that population growth in Africa would be curbed by AIDS but would not turn negative.
The discussion of the impact of AIDS on Africa's population comes in the wake of an assertion this month by a leading AIDS research group, headed by Dr. Jonathan Mann of the Harvard School of Public Health, that the number of people infected with H.I.V. by the year 2000 would be far higher than the 40 million predicted by the World Health Organization.
There are already 6 million Africans infected with H.I.V., and according to what are generally considered the conservative estimates of W.H.O., 10 million will be infected by 1995.
In making his predictions, Professor Anderson said he has assumed that the prevailing patterns of sexual activity with multiple partners will continue in Africa. In contrast with the pattern in the United States, AIDS in Africa is spread mainly through heterosexual intercourse.
For African countries that have been hit hardest by the AIDS epidemic, the implications of Dr. Anderson's results are considerable, researchers say, especially because African leaders have generally been reluctant to take the AIDS epidemic seriously. Other than some education programs and attempts to distribute condoms, researchers say, there is little evidence that Africans have changed their behavior in a way that would lead to a slowing of the epidemic.
"Generally, there has been a failure in Africa to accept the magnitude of the problem," Professor Anderson said in an interview here. He said he hoped that his projections would awaken policy makers in the West and in Africa to the gravity of the situation.
"We must galvanize society," he said. "This the most serious threat to humankind in modern times and the situation calls for massive investment to find a vaccine."
 
Sentiment of Hopelessness
 But other researchers argued that the work by Dr. Anderson and other mathematical modelers could encourage sentiment that the situation was hopeless. Some officials in government already privately contend that family planning is not as necessary in Africa because AIDS will take care of the rapid growth in the population.
"Do we invest in population control when the population is about to be decimated?" asked a senior official in the African bureau at the State Department. "Do we invest in the training of people when they will die a few years later?"
Professor Anderson's findings are considered controversial by some AIDS researchers because they rely on assumptions about sexual behavior for which there is still only imprecise data, a situation the professor acknowledged. For instance, his figures assume a high degree of sexual contact between older men, who tend to be infected, and younger women, who tend not to be.
In the last several years, researchers have noticed a growing tendency by urban African men, infected with AIDS but unaware of it, to seek younger sexual partners who are free of the virus. This has become common behavior in the Ugandan capital, Kampala, where 35- to 45-year-old "sugar daddies" pay school fees and give gifts to teen-age girls in return for sex.
The infection of young women with H.I.V. would send the population growth rate plummeting not only because the women die but also because their children have a 30 to 40 percent chance of being born with the virus, Professor Anderson said.
 
Changes in Central Africa
 He said the most clear-cut changes in population would occur in Central African countries where the epidemic started earlier and has hit hardest.
Within particular countries, there would not be a uniform leveling of population but rather "patchiness." Some areas like the Rakai district in southern Uganda, where there are more than 20,000 children orphaned by AIDS, could see their population almost wiped out, while others would remain almost unscathed.
Dr. Anderson said that aside from alerting African countries to the demographic impact of AIDS, mathematical modeling was also useful for assessing how to best curb the rate of infection.
Significant resources, Dr. Anderson said, should be directed toward inducing behavioral changes early. In Nigeria, for instance, where the infection in the general population is still limited, education and condom distribution should be aimed at high-risk groups like prostitutes and their clients, he said.
But in countries like Malawi, Tanzania and Uganda, where there is wider distribution of H.I.V. infection among the general population, it is probably "too late" to reach already sexually active people, Dr. Anderson said. Rather, educators should focus on teen-agers who are not yet sexually active.
The United States Agency for International Development, together with Kenyan researchers, recently used mathematical modeling in an study on the the impact of AIDS in Kenya.

HEADLINE: Trail in Kidnapping Case Leads to Carolina Resort

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, June 21

 BODY:
Several days before his arrest on charges of kidnapping an Exxon executive, Arthur D. Seale visited the luxurious South Carolina resort of Hilton Head Island, reminisced about his life there in the mid-1980's and mused about living there again and buying a marina, a woman who said she had dinner with him on the island recalled today.
Mr. Seale was calm, casual, upbeat and apparently eager to resettle in Hilton Head, said the woman, who dined with her husband and Mr. Seale at Kyoto, a Japanese restaurant at the resort. 
 "He was very likable, very open, and very friendly," the woman, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said by phone from Hilton Head. "We had every indication he and his wife were considering moving here."
Her account offered new details on the life of Mr. Seale and his wife, Irene, who were arrested on Friday after the authorities followed a trail of ransom notes and telephoned instructions stretching over three counties. The Seales are being held without bail, awaiting a second appearance in Federal court here on Monday.
 
Nomadic Existence
 Since their arrest, there has been no word on the whereabouts of Sidney J. Russo, the 57-year-old president of Exxon International, who they are charged with kidnapping.
From the mid-80's, the Seales' nomadic financially troubled pursuit of a grand life style brought them to resort towns, first in Hilton Head and then at Vail in the Colorado ski country. Their stays in each lasted only about two years, through late 1989, and eventually the couple returned to live with his parents, who are retired, at their home in Changewater, a hamlet on the Musconetcong River in western New Jersey.
While living in Hilton Head, the Seales owned a furniture and interior decorating store called Insiders. As the economy started slidding toward recession, the business failed and they lost the store, as well as their home.
F.B.I. agents spent much of the weekend in Hilton Head, questioning the Seales' old neighbors and acquantainces in Sea Pines Plantation, one of the wealthiest corners of the island. The arrests stunned former acquaintances of the couple.
 
Plenty of Shock
 "The mood around here is of absolute disbelief, shock, and confusion," said the woman who had dinner with Mr. Seale recently.
She said she and her husband met Mr. Seale for the first time at the restaurant. Mr. Seale's teen-age son, Justin, a friend of the couple's daughter, was staying at their home on Hilton Head and Mr. Seale had gone to visit him. Justin is said to have spent most summers on the island since his parents left here in early 1988, and he arrived there recently after completing his freshman year at college in Vermont.
The woman said Mr. Seale was relaxed and buoyant at Kyoto. "In fact, when we first met him at the restaurant, he was in the parking lot, throwing a ball to the owner's son, who is about 4," she said. The woman could not recall the date of the dinner. Other acquaintances, however, said Mr. Seale came to the island about two weeks ago.
That would have been about the time, the Federal authorities say, that the Seales had made a ransom call from a pay telephone at a gasoline station in Pooler, Ga., a small town near Savannah about 30 miles west of Hilton Head. Court documents say the call was made on Monday, June 8.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
4 Airlines Will Settle Suit on Pricing

BYLINE: By Reuters

DATELINE: ATLANTA, June 22

 BODY:
The nation's biggest airlines said today that they would pay more than $400 million in cash and ticket vouchers to settle a suit charging that they conspired to fix prices through a computerized reservation system.
Delta Air Lines Inc.; the American Airlines unit of AMR Corporation; the United Airlines unit of UAL Corporation; and USAir Inc. will pay $44 million in cash and issue $368.5 million in vouchers to settle the class-action suit without admitting liability. The vouchers will be valid on any of the four airlines for as much as 10 percent off the price of most tickets and 20 percent off round-trip tickets priced at less than $100. 
 The settlement is subject to the approval of a federal judge in Atlanta, where the suit was filed in 1990.
 Pitts Carr, a lawyer for the plaintiffs in the case, estimated that 10 million purchasers, about a third of them businesses, would be eligible for the program. He said ticket buyers "should receive significant economic benefits."
 Virtually anyone who bought a ticket on the airlines for domestic travel between Jan. 1, 1988, and June 30, 1992, could be eligible for the program, he said. "We've already heard from thousands, but we haven't publicized it that widely," Mr. Carr said. "We expect millions will participate."
The suit charged that nine airlines used the computerized listings of the Airline Tariff Publishing Company -- which the airlines own -- to control fares.
In their settlement, the airlines denied the charges of the suit, which said the carriers developed a code to signal whether prices were going up or down and to discipline airlines that failed to conform.
NWA Inc.'s Northwest Airlines and the Trans World Airlines unit of Icahn & Company previously agreed to pay a total of $37.5 million to settle the suit. Other defendants in the suit were Continental Airlines, which is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, and Midway and Pan Am, which have gone out of business.
The suit initially was brought by about 50 individuals but was expanded to class-action status last year by Federal District Judge Marvin Shoob in Atlanta. At the time the airlines estimated that the suit covered some 50 million customers, making it one of the biggest class-action cases ever.
Buyers who think they may be eligible for the voucher program can send a letter to a clearinghouse set up by the airlines. The address is Airline Antitrust Litigation, P.O. Box 209, Philadelphia, Pa. 19107.

HEADLINE: Winning the Game of 'Global Smokestack Chasing'

BYLINE: New York Times Regional Newspapers>

DATELINE: SPARTANBURG, S.C., June 22

 BODY:
In choosing to build its first United States production plant in South Carolina, the German auto maker BMW is following a path taken by a number of prominent European manufacturers.
The state has courted international companies since the 1960's, when officials lured the German chemical and fiber company Hoechst A.G. to Spartanburg. The list of other foreign companies subsequently drawn to the area includes the Michelin tire group, which moved here in the early 1970's; the Robert Bosch Corporation, in 1985; Bertelesmann A.G. Distribution, in 1986; Adidas U.S.A., in 1988, and Hitachi Electronics Devices in 1989. 
 "By the 1980's, everybody was in the game of global smokestack chasing," said Doug Woodward, a research economist with the University of South Carolina's College of Business Administration. But he said north-central South Carolina, well positioned between Charlotte, N.C., and Atlanta, had taken the lead.
 South Carolina has the highest per-capita foreign investment in the nation, according to the Spartanburg Area Chamber of Commerce. And the largest chunk of that investment comes from Germany.
"South Carolina has this great location," Mr. Woodward said, citing its three ports and extensive interstate highway system. "They say Atlanta is the capital of the South. It should be Charleston."
Officials involved in recruiting BMW, which is expected to announce its decision on Tuesday to build a plant here, say South Carolina's successes have been based on creating a favorable business climate.
S. Hunter Howard Jr., executive vice president of the South Carolina Chamber of Commerce, said of foreign companies, "They see incentives, they see the tone of the legislature being pro-business, and those things combined with the quality of life and labor issues -- I just think it's a composite decision."
 Incentives for new and expanding businesses approved by the state include tax credits for companies that locate their headquarters here or that create new jobs, as well as sharp reductions in property taxes.
"We've reduced the corporate income tax rate from 6 to 5 percent, the lowest rate in the Southeast and one of the lowest in the country," Mr. Howard said.
While South Carolina is known primarily for its textile-related industries, officials say the development of auto-related businesses had laid the groundwork for BMW's arrival. That industry, largely developed over the last 10 to 20 years, now includes more than 600 companies with more than 67,000 workers, according to figures provided by the South Carolina Development Board.
One of the first important auto suppliers to move to the state was Michelin, a French company, in the 1970's. Michelin now has four plants in South Carolina, including two in Spartanburg and Greenville that employ a total of 5,400 workers.
Michelin's arrival was followed by a wave of other foreign companies, led by the German and Japanese, that have moved into the state and established auto-related manufacturing plants.
But many in South Carolina considered BMW the crown jewel of foreign investments and went to great lengths to bring it here. BMW, which will build the plant on a 1,200-acre site near the Greenville-Spartanburg airport, is expected to invest $645 million eventually and employ up to 4,000 workers.
State officials were withholding comments today on specifics of the agreement with BMW until Tuesday's announcement, but incentives known to have been offered the German auto maker total $145 million. These include $30 million to buy and prepare land for the factory; $10 million for road projects near the site; temporary office space offered at reduced rates in Greenville or Spartanburg; 35 free apartments in Greenville and 20 in Spartanburg, and expansion of the Greenville-Spartanburg airport runway to accommodate 747 jetliners.
In addition, tax law changes would allow BMW to save as much as $50 million over 20 years in water and sewer costs. And a state income tax credit of $1,500 per employee would create savings of $2.7 million a year.

HEADLINE: A Plan for More Affordable Housing in Harrison

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARRISON, N.Y., June 22

 BODY:
Municipal workers and other middle- income residents of this affluent community will share homes with low-income residents of the town under a plan announced today.
The concept could become a model for development throughout the state, according to state and local leaders who gathered here to endorse the plan developed by Andrew M. Cuomo, son of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. The lack of affordable housing has become an acute problem in Westchester County, where the median price of a single-family home is $270,000. 
 The plan calls for the construction of 25 two-family homes, built for $154,000 to $184,000, on a 4.5 acre county-owned site on Main Street. The sale price of the homes will be based on the buyer's income.
 
Owners on the First Floor
 The homes would be purchased by municipal workers, school staff and young families working or living in Harrison who earn between $28,000 and $64,000. They would live on the first floor.
Upstairs, a second unit would be occupied by families who qualify for Federal housing subsidies, who would then use the subsidies, usually about $700 a month, to pay rent to the landlord living below.
The county has 7,000 families on a waiting list for aid under the Federal program known as Section 8, officials said, adding that 6,000 people who already get vouchers for rent under the program often can not find landlords willing to accept them.
Andrew Cuomo has become a familiar figure in Westchester as the president of Westhelp, a nonprofit corporation that provides temporary housing for homeless families.
But he said the transitional housing "only works if you have something permanent to move into."
"You have to help middle-income and low-income families in a way that allows them to help themselves," said Mr. Cuomo, who also heads a new company, Equity Homes, a nonprofit corporation that will seek government subsidies and develop the site. The project is eligible for state housing grants of up to $25,000 a unit, Mr. Cuomo said.
Calling the plan an example of "common sense" government, Governor Cuomo, who was present at the announcement today, said: "If you don't do this housing with the help of government, it won't happen. Why should anyone in private industry want to make less money by building housing for middle- and low-income families?"
Andrew Cuomo's plan comes three months after Harrison became the first Westchester municipality to endorse a proposal by Westchester County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, to build 500 units of housing on 20 county-owned sites for people earning $28,000 to $64,000 a year. Most other municipal officials, however, have remained wary of the plan.
Mr. O'Rourke's proposal followed a ruling in March by the State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, that gave counties the authority to build and finance low-cost housing and override local zoning if necessary.
Praising Mr. Cuomo's plan, Mr. O'Rourke said: "We'll have 25 brand new homes for people who could never have gotten a mortgage earning $28,000. They just don't make enough. With the Section 8 rental income help, they'll be part of the American dream of home ownership."
