HEADLINE: 4 Named to Executive Posts at CUNY

 BODY:

JOYCE F. BROWN
Vice chancellor for student affairs and urban programs
Currently the City University of New York's vice chancellor for urban affairs, Dr. Brown will also assume the position of vice chancellor for student affairs and urban programs. As such she will oversee areas like financial aid, admissions and student activities for the 200,000-student CUNY system. 
 A 1968 graduate of Marymount College in Tarrytown, Dr. Brown received her Ph.D. in counseling psychology from New York University. From 1968 to 1983, she was director of instructional testing and research and director of tutoring at the Borough of Manhattan Community College, one of the 21 branches of the CUNY system. In 1983, she was named CUNY's dean for urban affairs, a post in which she was the university's chief liaison with the Board of Education and other city agencies. Starting in 1987, Dr. Brown served as acting vice chancellor for student affairs for two years, and she served as acting president of Bernard M. Baruch College in Manhattan during the 1990-91 academic year.
 
RICHARD M. FREELAND
Vice chancellor for academic affairs
Named as the City University's vice chancellor for academic affairs, the 51-year-old Dr. Freeland will have primary responsibility for developing and starting universitywide programs as well as for reviewing degree offerings throughout the 21-campus system. Dr. Freeland, a historian, has spent the last 21 years at the University of Massachusetts at Boston in a variety of teaching and administrative positions.
The dean of the College of Arts and Sciences there for the last 10 years, Dr. Freeland has also been dean of the College of Professional Studies, director of the Office of Educational Planning and assistant to the chancellor.
Like the City University, the University of Massachusetts has been beset with major financial problems in the last few years and Dr. Freeland has spent a large part of his time husbanding the College of Liberal Arts and Science's scarce resources. Nevertheless, he has managed to foster the growth of a small number of doctoral programs, revitalize the school's core curriculum and help restructure teacher education.
A 1963 graduate of Amherst College, Dr. Freeland received his doctorate in American civilization from the University of Pennsylvania in 1968.
 
AUGUSTA SOUZA KAPPNER
Acting president of City College
Chosen to lead the oldest and best-known branch of CUNY, Dr. Kappner is a highly respected City University administrator, considered diplomatic and tough enough to handle the often volatile City College campus. For the past seven years, she has served as president of Borough of Manhattan Community College, the largest of the the university's seven two-year schools. Like Dr. Bernard W. Harleston, the man she is replacing, Dr. Kappner has had to face deep budget cuts and militant student protests over tuition increases that have roiled the university over the last three years.
Before being named to lead the Borough of Manhattan Community College, Dr. Kappner served for two years as university dean for academic affairs with oversight in the areas of continuing and adult education and freshman skills assessment. From 1978 to 1984, she was dean of continuing education at Fiorello H. La Guardia Community College in Long Island City.
A graduate of Barnard College in 1966, Dr. Kappner received a master's degree in social work from Hunter College in 1968 and a doctorate in social work from Columbia University in 1984.
 
VERNON E. LATTIN
President of Brooklyn College
Dr. Lattin, 53, who will lead one of the flagship campuses of the City University, has for the past three-and-a-half years been vice president and provost of Arizona State University. As such he oversaw the development of academic policies and regulations for the 43,000-student university and had chief administrative responsibility for the ASU West campus in Phoenix.
Dr. Lattin received a bachelor's degree in business administration in 1960 and a master's degree in English in 1965, both from the the University of New Mexico. He received a Ph.D. in English from the University of Colorado in 1970.
Starting in 1965, Dr. Lattin held various teaching positions before becoming director for Latino and Latin American Studies at Northern Illinois University in 1978. In 1982, he became associate vice president for academic affairs for the University of Wisconsin.

HEADLINE: Confidence Index Rises

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
A closely watched measurement of American consumer confidence increased in mid-June, economists are saying, substantiating evidence that the recovery from recession is strengthening.
The University of Michigan's index of consumer sentiment registered 80.6 in a preliminary reading, up from 79.2 at the end of May, 77.2 for April and 76 for March. 
 The Michigan survey is not publicly distributed but is sent by fax to private clients on Thursday evenings at the middle and end of the month. Talk of the results quickly circulates among financial market traders and economists. The final June reading will come out July 2.
Kathleen Stephansen, an economist at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation in New York, said results of the preliminary reading suggested consumer confidence was slowly improving, buttressing other statistical and anecdotal evidence of a gradually advancing recovery.
After an early-year spurt in spending, signs emerged that consumers were holding back this spring, which raised fears that the rebound from the 1990-91 recession might falter.
In May, for example, retail sales reported by the Commerce Department rose only two-tenths of a percent, instead of the surge that had been expected. Moreover, the gain for April was revised downward.
Still, other measurements of consumer confidence have continued to show signs of slowly growing strength. The Conference Board, a New York business research group that tracks consumer confidence on a monthly basis, reported last month that its May index grew for the third straight month.

HEADLINE: Court Lifts Barrier to Skyscraper Project

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
A Federal appeals judge lifted the last legal obstacle to a huge skyscraper project at Columbus Circle yesterday that opponents had argued would make Manhattan's air pollution problem worse.
Overturning a decision by Judge Shirley Wohl Kram of Federal District Court in Manhattan, the appeals court ruled that the two proposed towers would not violate the Federal Clean Air Act and that the developer Mortimer B. Zuckerman would not be liable for a $15 million fine that Judge Kram had threatened to impose. 
 The city's Corporation Counsel, O. Peter Sherwood, called the appeals court ruling "a complete victory."
Noting that the real-estate market had slumped since the project was first proposed, he said the developer might want to have further negotiations with the city. "But there is a contract with provisions that commit them to move ahead," he said. "They've put essentially a deposit down and they're obligated."
 
What's Next?
 It was not immediately clear whether Mr. Zuckerman, through his Boston Properties company, would go ahead with the long-disputed project, which has been revised and scaled down twice since he first proposed it in the mid-1980's. Robert Selsam, the vice president of Boston Properties, said no decision had been made on what to do next.
Jerry H. Goldfeder, a lawyer for coalition of neighborhood groups that brought the lawsuit, said they had not decided whether to appeal to the United States Supreme Court.
But officials of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which has a contract to sell the land to Mr. Zuckerman for $339 million, said they were looking forward to discussions with Boston Properties on closing the deal. "The case is basically over," said Susan Weiner, the authority's deputy general counsel.
The latest blueprint for the project calls for a 752-foot-high, twin-towered structure to be built at the southwest corner of Central Park on the site of the New York Coliseum. Because of the depressed real-estate market, there have been doubts in the last couple of years about who would lease the office space or whether Mr. Zuckerman would have to scale the design down again.
 
'It Made No Sense'
 The project has been controversial since it was first unveiled. The original proposal was for a 925-foot-high tower whose shadow, opponents claimed, would have blocked much of the sunlight over Central Park. That plan was defeated in court.
But opponents focused on the environmental impact of the Zuckerman proposal, even as Linda Young, an assistant corporation counsel, had argued that "it made no sense to hold this project hostage for a problem it has nothing to do with."
The opponents maintained that the city had reneged on a Federal mandate to draft an air pollution reduction plan by 1992.
The three-judge appeals panel disagreed. The opinion by Judge Jon O. Newman, who was joined by Judges Amalya L. Kearse and Richard J. Cardamone, said that the city had not "failed to fulfill its commitment" to meet a new 1995 deadline.
Opponents of the project had argued that it would worsen an air pollution problem caused by automobile exhaust emisions, particularly at a "hot spot" east of Central Park, on 59th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues. But after ruling that the proposed project itself would not cause pollution, the appeals court said it was up to the city, not the developer, to do something about the problem on 59th Street.
"Right now the city can continue to lease the Coliseum and make some money," Mr. Goldfeder said. "The Mayor would be well advised to speak to the developer and plan a much more environmentally sound project that would fit in with the neighborhood and that would be more in keeping with Mort Zuckerman's aversion to economic risk. That's a cumbersome way of saying what I mean, which is, it's probably in the developer's interest to do a smaller-scale project, given the economic situation."
Asked what size project the opponents would accept, Mr. Goldfeder said, "I never negotiate in the press." But he added, "We're open to a rationally planned, environmentally sound project that fits into our neighborhood."

GRAPHIC: Drawing: A rendering of a huge skyscraper project at Columbus Circle. A Federal appeals judge yesterday lifted the last legal obstacle to the project, saying the towers would not violate the Federal Clean Air Act. (Skidmore, Owings & Merrill)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends the Day Lower Except for Rise Against Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday against all leading currencies except the Japanese yen, which was troubled by a deteriorating economic scenario at home.
Gold prices advanced after falling overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $343.70 a troy ounce, up $2.90 from Friday. The Republic National Bank said gold rose $2.50 an ounce to a late bid price of $343.20. 
 "All the economic data coming out of Japan are looking worse and worse," said Randolph Donney, research director at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
Further putting pressure on the yen was another steep drop in the Tokyo stock market. The leading 225-issue Nikkei stock average fell 3.6 percent to close at 15,921.22, the first plunge below the 16,000-point level in five and a half years.
The dollar benefited as traders sold the yen against other leading currencies, Mr. Donney said. "The anticipation of an interest rate cut by the Bank of Japan gave people an excuse to sell the yen," he said.
Elsewhere, the German mark continued to strengthen. "It is shining as a bright light in Europe even with the uncertainty" surrounding European political and economic union, Mr. Donney said.
With no fresh economic data emerging from the United States, "people played the safe bets -- selling dollars and buying marks," he said.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 127.47 yen, up 0.55 yen from Friday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 127.10 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 127.15 yen, up from 127.00 yen on Friday,
In London, the British pound rose to $1.8615, from $1.8595 late Friday. In New York it cost $1.8615 to buy one pound, more expensive than Friday's $1.8590.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.5665 German marks, down from 1.5730; 1.4155 Swiss francs, down from 1.4195; 5.2755 French francs, down from 5.2960; 1,184.50 Italian lire, down from 1,190.25, and 1.1946 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1973.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.5665 German marks, down from 1.5705; 1.4050 Swiss francs, down from 1.4170; 5.2725 French francs, down from 5.2870; 1.7645 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7691; 1,184.00 Italian lire, down from 1,188.50, and 1.1945 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1978.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $342.40 a troy ounce, from $343.75 late Friday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Crude Oil Contracts Higher After an Iraq-Related Drop

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Energy futures prices slumped early yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid speculation about Iraq's oil export talks with the United Nations, but prices closed higher after it appeared that a tentative agreement would not mean the swift return of Iraqi oil to the world market.
In New York, light sweet crude for delivery in July settled 22 cents higher at $22.48 a barrel; July home heating oil was 0.38 cent higher at $61.84 a barrel; July unleaded gasoline was 0.40 cent lower at 64.95 cents a gallon, and July natural gas fell 1.1 cents, to $1.545 for 1,000 cubic feet. 
 United Nations officials and Iraqi negotiators have been working since Friday on details of Iraq's proposed sale of crude oil. Iraq has been barred from selling oil under economic sanctions imposed in August 1990 during the Persian Gulf war.
Traders worried that if Iraq reached agreement with the United Nations to resume oil exports, prices already burdened by summer demand that had been lower than normal would slip further, said Stephanie Rzasa, a broker with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in New York.
Two previous rounds of talks failed to produce agreement on terms of a proposed one-time sale of $1.6 billion of Iraqi crude oil, with strict monitoring to insure that profits were used for Iraq's humanitarian needs. United Nations officials said late yesterday that they had reached tentative agreement with Iraq on technical conditions for the sale, subject to approval by the Security Council and the Iraqi Government.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, grains and soybeans futures prices ended lower in lackluster trading as investors shied away from those markets on reports of cooler weather and beneficial rain.
Wheat for July delivery settled down 3 cents at $3.5425 a bushel; July corn was 3.25 cents lower at $2.48 a bushel; July oats were down 3.5 cents at $1.2925 a bushel; July soybeans were down 7.75 cents at $5.955 bushel.
Cattle prices on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange ended lower, under pressure from weaker cash-market prices and sluggish beef sales. Pork futures prices ended mixed as live hog futures were helped by lighter marketings, and frozen pork bellies were under pressure from position-squaring in advance of the monthly Agriculture Department cold storage figures.
Live cattle for June delivery were 0.15 cent lower at 73.15 cents a pound; August feeder cattle were 0.22 cent lower at 78.35 cents a pound; June hogs were up 0.75 cent at 51.05 cents a pound; July frozen pork bellies were 0.17 cent lower at 33.05 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: Aerospace Trade Gains

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 22

 BODY:
Despite the global recession and military cutbacks, the United States aerospace industry posted a trade surplus in the first quarter of the year.
The aerospace trade surplus increased about 2 percent, to $9.3 billion, in the first three months of 1992, from $9.1 billion in the fourth quarter of 1991, the Aerospace Industries Association said today. 
 Aerospace exports rose about 1 percent, to $12.5 billion, in the first quarter, from $12.4 billion in the fourth quarter. Aerospace imports increased more than 5 percent, to $3.3 billion from $3.1 billion, the trade association said.
Foreign orders for American-made commercial jets provided a source of strength for the domestic economy over the last several years. Demand, however, has sagged as the recession weakened airline traffic. In addition, Pentagon orders have tapered off since the end of the cold war.

HEADLINE: $880 Million Is Set for Cambodia, But Khmer Rouge Pose a Threat

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 22

 BODY:
The nations that served as architects of the Cambodia peace process committed over $880 million to reconstructing the country today, but said the effort could collapse unless Pol Pot, the leader of the Khmer Rouge forces, agrees to disarm and allow United Nations forces to deploy throughout the country.
The warning came at the end of a 32-nation conference here on reconstructing Cambodia, one that quickly turned from the details of financing the rebuilding of the country to a broad effort to keep the fragile peace from unwinding. But senior officials of the Khmer Rouge attending the conference refused to commit themselves to carrying out their obligations under the peace accord unless a long series of new demands were met. 
 Instead, they simply watched in stoic silence as representatives of a host of countries harshly criticized the faction for threatening to plunge the country back into civil war and said Khmer Rouge-controlled parts of the country would suffer most if the United Nations transitional authority in Cambodia was blocked from dispensing aid.
"There is no peace without reconstruction," said Yasushi Akashi, who heads the 16,000-member United Nations transitional forces in Cambodia. "But there is no reconstruction without peace."
The final declaration of the ministerial conference expressed "serious concern" over "the refusal of one party to allow the deployment" of United Nations forces throughout the country and called for "timely implementation" of the Paris accord.
 
Japan Seeks a Leading Role
 Despite the conflict over the Khmer Rouge, Japanese officials, who are making the Cambodia peace process into a test of their ability to take the political lead in an Asian crisis, declared that the ministerial conference that ended tonight was a success. The $880 million in pledges made by more than a score of nations today -- including $150 million to $200 million from Japan and $135 million from the United States -- was far above the $600 million that the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, said was needed to complete the first phase of rebuilding the country.
"It exceeds the very urgent needs we have identified," said William H. Draper 2d, the administrator of the United Nations Development Program.
The funds will go toward the resettlement of more than 350,000 refugees awaiting repatriation from border camps in Thailand, the restoration of long-destroyed ports, roads and railroads, and a last-ditch effort to halt the disintegration of Cambodia's civil service, particularly teachers and health workers. Many are paid little or nothing now, and are leaving their jobs.
The other large commitments came from France, which offered $57 million; Australia, which offered $40 million, and Sweden, $38 million. A number of international institutions -- including the Asian Development Bank, the World Bank, the United Nations Development Program and the European Community -- offered a total of roughly $250 million.
The conference was overshadowed, however, by the challenge posed by the Khmer Rouge, who controlled the country in the 1970's and were responsible for the deaths of many Cambodians in a fanatical effort to build a wholly agrarian society; estimates of the number of victims have ranged from hundreds of thousands to more than a million.
 
U.N. Helicopter Attacked
 The guerrilla group's power to disrupt was underscored by an attack on a United Nations helicopter over the weekend, for which the Cambodian Government blamed Khmer Rouge forces. There were injuries but no deaths.
At a news conference tonight, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, who was restored as the head of state under the peace accord, charged that the Khmer Rouge's "final aim is to take power again by military means." He said they were trying to sabotage the peace process before it leads to national elections next year. "They cannot understand democracy," Prince Sihanouk said, "only totalitarianism."
Under the second phase of the Paris peace plan, all four factions should be entering United Nations-sponsored camps for disarmament and repatriation into society as civilians. While several other factions have begun the process, the Khmer Rouge have said they are refusing to disarm until there is proof that the Vietnamese Army, which ousted them from Phnom Penh in 1979, had left the country. They also maintain that the aid flowing through United Nations hands is propping up the Government of Hun Sen, who was installed by Vietnam.
Mr. Akashi said today that he would insure that funds were distributed "in an equitable manner" to areas controlled by each of the four factions. But he also issued what sounded like a warning that Cambodians under the Khmer Rouge's control would suffer the most for the refusal to comply with the peace accord.
 
Curbs by Khmer Rouge
 "The Khmer Rouge has not allowed any freedom of movement for United Nations military or civilians in areas they control," he said. "And it is very hard for us to distribute aid and assistance under we determine needs in those areas."
Some Cambodia experts have suggested that the Khmer Rouge is engaged in a negotiating ploy to obtain funds and more influence in the Supreme National Council, headed by Prince Sihanouk and made up of all the warring factions. But Mr. Akashi said in a brief conversation tonight: "I think it is more than just a tactical move. It is fundamental. It goes back to their deep suspicion of foreigners, of Vietnamese and of Prince Sihanouk."
Mr. Khieu Sampan, a veteran of the Pol Pot Government of the 1970's who has been living under guard in Phnom Penh since dodging a lynch mob there in December, seemed unmovable during the talks, perhaps because he was not authorized to make compromises.
"Khieu Sampan is a figurehead," Prince Sihanouk said. "And he cannot take a decision tonight until he reports to Pol Pot." Mr. Pol Pot is believed to be hiding in the mountains in territory held by the Khmer Rouge.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Mayors Applaud Clinton's Promise to Remake American Economy

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, June 22

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton took his new economic line of taxes for the rich and development schemes for the poor before the 60th annual gathering here of the United States Conference of Mayors today and won several rounds of vigorous applause when he declared it would remake America economically.
In a major revision of his earlier economic blueprint, Mr. Clinton promised to cut the budget deficit in half by 1996 by taxing the rich and foreign corporations, and by slashing military spending, the Federal bureaucracy and a sweeping collection of Federal programs he deems wasteful or unnecessary. 
 And at the same time, his plan includes a $200 billion program to rebuild the nation's highways, communications system and its inner cities, a program that he says will generate a million new jobs a year.
 
'It Is a Bold Plan'
 "It is a bold plan," Mr. Clinton said. "We can change. We can do better."
The Arkansas Governor also hopes the plan will help him do better. Mr. Clinton, who won the Democratic primary campaign, is at a critical juncture in his quest for the Presidency, running last in public opinion polls, short of money and frequently criticized as lacking a clear message.
The new blueprint sharpens the Governor's proposals. He urges direct spending on things like new roads, bridges and railroads, including a high-speed rail system, and on a national fiber-optic network.
In addition to aiming money directly at improvements in the environment, social services and education, he emphasizes steps to put 100,000 more police officers on the nation's streets.
Many of them would come from the "national service trust" he has proposed, in which young people who borrowed money for college would have the option of paying it back through a few years of community service, including police work.
Mr. Clinton said the financing for his proposals would come from increased taxes on the rich and on foreign companies, and from cutting Government costs.
 
Taxing the Wealthy
 "We can't ask the middle class to pay more," he said. In the 1980's, "their incomes went down and their taxes went up."
He added: "We must say to the wealthy, you have to pay your fair share. We also have to say to foreign companies, there's something wrong with our tax code, if your income went up 65 percent in the 1980's, and your taxes went down 15 percent. And that's exactly what happened. You've got to pay your fair share if you want to do business in this country."
In his speech today, Mr. Clinton did mention a change in his tax proposals for the middle class. During the primary campaign, he had urged both a children's tax credit and a lower income tax rate for the middle class, but in the new plan families may only choose one.
Mr. Clinton said 100,000 jobs could be eliminated from the Government by attrition "over the next couple of years." He vowed to cut the White House staff by a quarter, and to urge Congress to do the same with its staff.
The Governor also promised "the toughest possible system to reform the health care system," saying that Government spending cannot be reined in "until health care costs are brought in line with inflation."
The blueprint calls for cutting the Federal budget deficit by more than half in four years. Mr. Clinton said that it would be unrealistic to try to eliminate the deficit "until we invest in those things that will give us a high-wage, high-growth future."
 
'He Helped Himself -- Some'
 If the comments of mayors here are any measure, Mr. Clinton may have made progress.
"I think he helped himself -- some," said Mayor Bob Lanier of Houston after hearing Mr. Clinton's speech. "He talked about the things that concern mayors and had some solutions to propose. So at least here's one candidate who's come up with a definite plan for something." Mr. Lanier is an independent.
Several dozen Democratic mayors from cities large and small called a news conference and lined up to praise Mr. Clinton. The most effusive praise came from Mayor Maynard Jackson of Atlanta.
"This is a new day in the Clinton campaign, a benchmark," he said. "This is a definite plan. People are going to buy into this. Where are the other candidates? Where are their plans? Bill Clinton is the man with the plan."
Mr. Clinton has seemed for the last several days to sense that perhaps there is a change in the political air for him. He is notably relaxed, lingering longer than usual to banter with prospective voters, sometimes hanging around even after the cleaning crews have moved in. He is also offering up more humor than usual and even some self-deprecation, never an easy play for a politician.
 
Seeking Investment
 This morning he was preceded on the dais by Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp, a former professional football player, and Senator Bill Bradley, the New Jersey Democrat who played professional basketball.
"I was jealous -- two great athletes," he said. "I was always the slightly overweight bandboy and I've resented them all my life."
Mr. Clinton told the mayors that the key to getting the United States back on its economic feet was investment, especially in people. That was a major theme of his economic plan and he says he will continue to hammer on it.
"You have to put people first," he said.
He asserted that Republicans had so mismanaged the country that there were now two deficits, one in the budget and the other in investment in people. He promised that as President he would not only reduce the monetary deficit but also the deficit in investment in people by injecting money into social programs, particularly education.
 
Political Danger in Plan
 "When you invest in the future," he said, "you create wealth. We cannot afford to ignore the investment deficit. We've got to do it. You've got to demand that it be done. We've got to restore belief and faith in the future." He pounded his fist on the lectern for emphasis. Some of the mayors broke into applause.
There is political danger in Mr. Clinton's plan, particularly in the specificity he offers in programs and their costs. It leaves him vulnerable to Republican charges that he is just another tax-and-spend Democrat.
But the Governor's aides said he and his top strategists decided the risk was justified, with the need to get the campaign moving again taking precedence over Mr. Clinton's usual on-the-one-hand, on-the-other-hand approach to issues.
In coming weeks, Mr. Clinton is expected to try to give his campaign a further boost by announcing his choice for vice president. He has refused to disclose his thoughts, but his aides say he is not limiting his deliberations to a running mate who would simply add geographic and ideological balance to the ticket.

Mr. Clinton spoke of development plans for the poor and higher taxes for the rich. (F. Carter Smith for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Excerpts From Clinton's Speech on His Economic Proposals

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, June 22

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the text of a speech by Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas today to the United States Conference of Mayors here.
 
INFRASTRUCTURE
 My plan is a bold plan. It offers $50 billion in new investments over the next four years in each of the next four years. New incentives for the private sector, an investment tax credit, urban enterprise zones, new business tax incentives, research and development incentives and others. 
 It offers $20 billion a year in hard Federal dollars every year for the next four years, to build an economy for the 21st century, to invest in new roads and bridges, and streets and rail systems, to develop high-speed rail and a national fiber optic network, to develop new environmental technologies to clean our waters and our air, and to recycle more of our solid wastes. In short, to do those things which we are not doing today.
All of you know, as well as I, that our competitors for the future are investing far higher percentages in their income than we are. And it make me sick inside to think what's going to happen to the incomes in the future of the American people if we don't make a commitment to invest in our capacity and our economy.
This $20 billion will create a million jobs a year in each of the next four years, driving funds into your cities. It will help us to do the things you said you wanted, when you issued your call for a $35 billion program in one year. This will do more over the next four years.
This will enable us to fund those ready-to-go projects you want funded. It will enable us to spend more in infrastructure, and in law enforcement, and in education, and in social services. It will enable us to expand the community development block grant program, which, as a governor, I also believe strongly in. And this will happen without spending one red cent of state or local money or private sector money.
When we leverage that, we can dramatically increase this program. The Rebuild America Coalition under the leadership of one of your number, Mayor Maynard Jackson, has recommended a number of things which can be done to leverage more local money and private sector money with this $20 billion commitment, including state revolving loan funds for many projects, and a Federal infrastructure development bank, on-bank.
I support the recommendations of The Rebuild America Coalition, and I will work hard to leverage this money so that we can generate even more investments and create more jobs.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
TAXES
 How do we pay for this? About half and half through raising money and cutting spending at the Federal level.
We have to ask the wealthiest Americans to pay their fair share again. Their incomes went up in the 1980's and their taxes went down. We can't ask the middle class to pay more. Their income went down and their taxes went up. No nation would do what we have done willingly.
For the first time since the Roaring Twenties, the top 1 percent of Americans control more wealth than the bottom 90 percent. We must say to the wealthy you have to pay your fair share. We also have to say to foreign companies, there's something wrong with our tax code, if your income went up 65 percent, in the 1980's, and your taxes went down 15 percent. And that's exactly what happened. You've got to pay your fair share if you want to do business in this country.
 
CUTTING GOVERNMENT
 But we can't just do that. We also have to change the way the Federal Government operates, too. The General Accounting Office, Congressman Dorgan's commission on government waste, and my own experience as a governor working, repeatedly cutting budgets and restructuring government tells me that there is a lot of money to save there.
I have recommended that we eliminate by attrition, not by firing anybody, but by attrition, 100,000 people from the Federal work force over the next couple of years.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
HEALTH CARE
 And we're going to adopt the toughest possible system to reform the health-care system, and bring health care costs under control. You will never be able to control this government spending until health care costs are brought in line with inflation.
And you live in the only advanced country where your nation has not taken a national approach to controlling health care costs by reforming the insurance market, by reducing bureaucracy, simplifying the billing procedures, and doing those things which other countries take for granted to keep costs in line with inflation. We must do that.
 
DEFICIT
 Now, a lot of people say to me, and this is an important big idea that you have to decide whether you agree with, they say, "Well, Governor, why don't you take all this money and reduce the deficit?" Because under my plan, we will increase investment and reduce the deficit by more than 50 percent over the next four years, but not eliminate it entirely.
"Why don't you just take it all and put it against the deficit?" I'll tell you why, because we have two deficits: a budget deficit and an investment deficit. And we cannot grow this economy until we put people back to work, and until we invest in those things that will give us a high-wage, high-growth future. We cannot do it. . . .
This plan will dramatically reduce the deficit, and dramatically increase investment. That is the only way to get economic growth. You must demand a four-year investment plan. You must go beyond what you have asked for. Go beyond your $35 billion one-year plan and say we have to invest for four years.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Assessment -- Clinton's Retreat;
Change on a Tax Cut for the Middle Class Could Forestall Accusations of Pandering

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 22

 BODY:
In putting forward a major new economic blueprint to help pull his campaign out of third place, Gov. Bill Clinton has retreated from one of his most controversial proposals: calling for an income tax cut for the middle class.
His new economic program, announced Sunday, focuses on ways to rebuild America's economy, but its most significant change from previous plans was Mr. Clinton's scaling back on his call for a middle-class tax cut, which he had long insisted was needed as a matter of fairness. 
 Governor Clinton's plan aims to speed economic growth by investing $200 billion to improve education and job training and to rebuild the nation's highways, communications system and inner cities. His proposal won vigorous applause in Houston today from the nation's mayors. [Page A19.]
Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, a rival in the early primaries, had accused Mr. Clinton of pandering to voters in supporting the tax cut, and some campaign experts said he had altered his position to solidify Mr. Tsongas's support and to forestall future accusations that he tells voters what they want to hear.
Previously, Mr. Clinton offered middle-class taxpayers both a children's tax credit and a lower income tax rate, worth about $350 per family. In the new economic plan, he is offering them one or the other, but not both. The original plan would have cost about $26 billion, and the new plan about half that, campaign officials say.
Bruce Reed, the Governor's deputy campaign manager for policy issues, said the chief reason Governor Clinton changed his position was his growing concern that the Federal budget deficit needed to be reined in. After he was criticized for pandering on the tax cuts, that would certainly be an important change. Concern about the deficit mushroomed during the recent debate for a balanced budget amendment, and Ross Perot has been lambasting the White House and Congress for expanding the Federal debt to $4 trillion.
With economic growth beginning to pick up, a middle-class tax cut is no longer as necessary to spur the economy.
Governor Clinton's plan calls for stepped-up spending to improve education and job training to give American industry better workers and to give American workers better jobs. He vows to reduce class sizes, set up a national examination system in math and science and develop a national apprenticeship program to teach a trade to students not going to college.
His plan also calls for building a 21st-century transportation and communications system to create jobs and a better environment for doing business. This would include 200-mile-per-hour trains linking major cities and a computer network linking every home, business and classroom.
"The only way America can compete and win in the 21st century is to have the best-educated, best-trained work force in the world, linked together by transportation and communication networks second to none," Governor Clinton said in his economic plan.
 
In the Party Tradition
 Mr. Clinton's package, notwithstanding a few conservative flourishes, is very much in the Democratic tradition: seeing an active role for government to supplement the free market.
His blueprint, which is far more specific than any economic plan offered by President Bush or Mr. Perot, seeks to do far more than outline his vision of a reborn American economy. It also aims to force his two main opponents to replace their vague economic oratory with specific plans and to shift the campaign's focus onto the area where he feels most comfortable: issues.
He vowed to cut the Federal budget deficit in half in four years. And to raise revenues, he said he wanted to increase taxes for the richest 2 percent of the population.
The Arkansas Governor argued that it was time to move on from the Reagan-Bush era's laissez-faire policies, which he said cut taxes for the rich in the hope that they would invest and create jobs for the less well-off. He said that this trickle-down approach has failed, and he instead backed what some call a trickle-up approach. His hope is that by strengthening workers' skills and by creating modern infrastructure in which to do business, his program will keep and attract industries that provide high-paying jobs.
 
Drawing Criticism
 But his plan quickly drew criticism from many Republicans. "His investment plan just sounds like it's high tax, high spend," said Lawrence Kudlow, a Reagan Administration economist who is now the chief economist with Bear Stearns. "I think he will have a devil of a time defending it."
Still Mr. Clinton took pains to show that he was not just another tax-and-spend Democrat. He pledged to cut the budget deficit to $141 billion in 1996 from close to $400 billion this year. He said he would eliminate 100,000 jobs in the Federal Government and would order Government departments to reduce their administrative expenses by 3 percent a year for four years.
His plan also called for cutting the White House and Congressional staffs by 25 percent and would save $2 billion a year by asking for the line-item veto "to eliminate pork-barrel projects and cut government waste." He also said he would cut the military budget by $37 billion more than President Bush plans to over the next four years.
"This is a governing program," said Robert J. Shapiro, a Clinton economic adviser who is vice president of the Progressive Policy Institute, a research group in Washington. "This has a level of specificity one expects from a president, not from a candidate."
Using language that the Republicans are bound to attack as promoting class warfare, Mr. Clinton said: "Millions of Americans are running harder and harder just to stay in place. While taxes fall and incomes rise for those at the top of the totem pole, middle-class families pay more and earn less."
For one of the first times in the campaign, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady attacked the opposition. In a statement on the Clinton plan, he said, "If you want to decrease jobs, increase taxes -- particularly on small business men and women -- discourage savings and investment, fuel the engine of big government and drive away foreign investment, this is the perfect plan."
The Governor's proposals share some of Mr. Perot's populism. Mr. Clinton called for limiting a corporation's ability to deduct more than $1 million for the salaries of chief executive officers. He would also eliminate tax deductions for lobbying expenses. In addition, focusing on an issue that Mr. Perot has hammered away at, he said he would require officials to refrain for five years after leaving office from lobbying government agencies within their responsibilities.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Poll;
Bush and Clinton Sag in Survey; Perot's Negative Rating Doubles

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
The two major party candidates show remarkable weakness in the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. President Bush's handling of the economy is now as unpopular as President Jimmy Carter's ever was, while only a third of American voters see strong leadership qualities in Gov. Bill Clinton.
Ross Perot, the all-but-declared independent candidate, is faring better with this disgruntled electorate, but even his apolitical allure is showing its limits. Mr. Perot is now essentially tied with Mr. Bush in first place when voters are offered a choice among the three. But the percentage of voters who view the Dallas billionaire negatively has more than doubled in six weeks. 
 The poll, conducted Wednesday through Saturday, showed nearly all politicians facing a landscape filled with peril four and a half months before Election Day.
 
4 in 10 Still Dissatisfied
 Four in 10 registered voters said they were still not satisfied with the three candidates now running for the White House and wanted more choices. Almost half said the Government might work better if the people voted into the Congress and the White House were all new. And 69 percent agreed with the proposition that there was no connection between what a Presidential candidate promised and what he would do if elected, suggesting that the candidates face a wall of cynicism this year.
The survey also gave new insight into the demographics of Mr. Perot's support: His backers tend to be younger, tend to have higher incomes and tend to come from the West. In addition, confirming earlier polls, the survey showed Mr. Perot drawing support more heavily from men, from whites and from the ranks of self-described independents.
Discontent with Mr. Bush runs throughout this poll, which was based on telephone interviews with 1,315 adults. Only 34 percent approved of the way Mr. Bush was doing his job, down from 39 percent in early May. Seventy-eight percent disapproved of the way he was handling the economy, surpassing the 74 percent who disapproved of Mr. Carter's economic stewardship in June 1980.
 
Wary of Economy
 Charles Black, a senior adviser to the Bush campaign, said, "It's clear that no matter what the economic statistics show, voters still do not feel the economy is getting better."
Mr. Bush gets far better marks on foreign policy, with an approval rating of 46 percent. And in the afterglow of the visit of President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia to Washington last week, 69 percent said they approved of Mr. Bush's handling of relations with the Russians. Still, domestic issues remain a powerful drag on Mr. Bush's popularity.
In a three-way race, 32 percent of the registered voters said they would prefer Mr. Bush, 30 percent Mr. Perot and 24 percent Mr. Clinton. Since the last Times/CBS Poll, conducted in early May, both Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton have slipped and Mr. Perot has gained.
In a head-to-head race, Mr. Bush and Mr. Perot would be essentially tied, 42 percent to 43 percent. And in a head-to-head contest with Mr. Clinton, Mr. Bush is ahead, but not significantly, given the survey's margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points: Mr. Bush is at 45 percent, while Mr. Clinton is at 40 percent.
 
Two Downward Trends
 Ominously for Mr. Bush, his personal ratings have also declined significantly in the past three months. In March, 42 percent said they viewed Mr. Bush favorably, and 41 percent unfavorably. The latest poll showed Mr. Bush was viewed favorably by 29 percent and unfavorably by 44 percent.
But he can take heart from Mr. Clinton's standing. The Governor of Arkansas had hoped to use this time before the Democratic Party convention next month to repair his image after a bitter primary season dominated by "character issues," including charges that he avoided the draft, which he denied. But Mr. Perot has largely dominated the limelight, and the survey showed that Mr. Clinton's favorable ratings had actually declined over the past few months.
In April, for example, Mr. Clinton was viewed favorably by 26 percent and unfavorably by 40 percent. The latest poll showed Mr. Clinton viewed favorably by 16 percent, with 40 percent holding unfavorable views.
At the same time, the percentage of people who saw Mr. Clinton having strong leadership qualities dropped from 56 percent in March to 35 percent today. In contrast, 61 percent said in the new poll that they saw those leadership qualities in Mr. Bush and 54 percent saw them in Mr. Perot. Bush strategists are still counting on this perception of leadership ability to save their candidate this fall.
James Carville, a top strategist to Mr. Clinton, sought a philosophical tone. "It takes a while for things to happen," Mr. Carville said. "But we've had a good couple weeks, and I think he's starting to define himself. We've had our primary season. This summer is Perot's."
Mr. Clinton is given points for detailing his positions. Forty-three percent said he was telling them enough about where he stood on the issues, while 30 percent felt that way about Mr. Bush and 22 percent said they were hearing enough detail from Mr. Perot.
Mr. Perot's recent offering of new detail in one area, with his suggestion that affluent senior citizens give back some benefits to help with the Federal budget deficit, seemed a resounding dud. Only 10 percent of the registered voters said they would be willing to give some benefits back, and Mr. Perot's supporters were no more willing to do so than anyone else.
Mr. Perot is showing other bruises from his season of scrutiny. In late April, 21 percent viewed him favorably, and 9 percent unfavorably. In the new poll, 26 percent viewed him favorably, and 20 percent unfavorably.
Still, he is clinging to his forthright, unpolitical image, more so than his rivals. Forty-three percent agreed that Mr. Perot said what he believed most of the time, while 34 percent said he was just saying what he thought the voters wanted to hear. Thirty-seven percent said that Mr. Bush said what he believed most of the time, while 28 percent saw that level of candor in Mr. Clinton.
Mr. Perot's success as a businessman seemed even more of a draw than his image as an outsider: 33 percent said they most liked the fact that he was independent of the two political parties, while 40 percent said they most liked his image as a wealthy businessman who could get things done.
Still, when people were asked what most concerned them about a Perot Presidency, the most frequently volunteered answer was his lack of political experience.
Mr. Perot continues to draw supporters from the ranks of Democrats, Republicans and independents, and his backing has a strongly centrist cast. On three issues, however, Perot backers looked distinctive: They were most in favor of a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution; they were most likely to say the United States should have continued the fighting in the Middle East until President Saddam Hussein of Iraq was ousted, and they were least likely to support economic aid to the former Soviet Union.
The poll also indicated that 58 percent of those surveyed agreed with the idea that the "the country needs a new political party to compete with the Democratic and Republican parties in offering the best candidates for public office."
But by a margin of 4 to 1, those people said Mr. Perot should not be the one to start a new party, indicating that they preferred his continued independence. Perot supporters were particularly in favor of creating a new party, with 76 percent of them saying they supported that course.
On other matters, the poll suggested that not everyone considered this to be the "year of the woman." Fifty-two percent said it was "not so important" to elect more women to the Senate this year, while 43 percent said it was "very important." And fewer than a third said they wanted to see one Presidential candidate name a woman as his running-mate; 57 percent said it did not matter much to them.
Even women seemed to be less than consumed with the idea of adding a woman to the ticket: only 37 percent said they wanted a candidate to name a female running-mate, while 49 percent said it did not matter much and 12 percent rejected the idea flat out.
But women were far more likely than men to put a priority on adding women to the Senate: 50 percent said it was "very important," while 35 percent of the men said that.

"How the Poll Was Conducted"
 The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Wednesday through Saturday with 1,315 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii, of whom 1,029 said they were registered voters.
 The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen so as to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened so that calls would be placed to residences only. Within each household one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the poll.
 The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age, and education.
 In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
 The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for results based on those registered voters who said they would vote for Ross Perot for President, it is plus or minus six percentage points.
 In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. (pg. A18)

HEADLINE: Movement Builds to Fight Harmful Projects in Poor Nations

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN a broadening movement that could change the way poor nations develop, environmentalists and human rights groups are joining forces to give the people in those countries the same power to scrutinize and oppose damaging projects that citizens of richer nations enjoy.
In an era when environmental debate has often pitted the developing nations against the industrialized countries, this new trend is marked by cooperation across borders and income levels. 
 Human rights and environmental groups say they are joining forces because governments of developing nations put development ahead of everything else, neglecting both human and environmental consequences. The Natural Resources Defense Council and Human Rights Watch issued a joint report, "Defending the Earth: Abuses of Human Rights and the Environment," earlier this month in which they said: "Repressive governments often defend their practices by asserting that human rights -- particularly freedoms of expression, association and participation in decision making -- are esoteric, and must take a back seat to the need to preserve order or foster economic development. We believe otherwise."
The strength of the movement and the potential power it can wield over international organizations was demonstrated for the first time last week with the publication of an independent review commissioned by the World Bank that condemned in strong terms the human and ecological destruction being caused by a $11.4 billion hydroelectric and irrigation project in India.
 
Bank Reassess Role
 The bank is now reassessing the project, the Sardar Sarovar complex of dams and canals in central India, on which more than $1.4 billion has already been spent for preliminary work.
After receiving a copy of the team's report, Lewis T. Preston, the bank's president, said, "We should proceed only if a practical way can be agreed to insure that the pace of further construction of the dam is adjusted to whatever extent is required to permit a fully responsible approach to the resettlement and environmental concerns." He also called for remedial actions like the improvement of how the bank looks at such projects, including local consultation with people affected.
The Government of India has not commented on the report.
Earlier last week, the United States voted against World Bank financing for a $55 million hydroelectric dam in Malawi. The project was approved on Wednesday despite the opposition of the United State, which was alone in its stand, but environmental groups plan to step up pressure to make the project an issue.
The Environmental Defense Fund, the International Rivers Network and Greenpeace International said in a letter to the bank before the vote that the project on the Shire River near Blantyre would threaten an already endangered elephant population, flood part of a wildlife sanctuary and disrupt the livelihoods of fishing families downstream.
Malawians are denied the right of dissent by a one-party government. A group of donor nations recently froze aid to the country to protest a spate of violent repression this spring.
The joint Natural Resources Defense Council-Human Rights Watch survey looks at Brazil, Eritrea, India, Kenya, Malaysia, Mexico, the Philippines and the former Soviet Union as well as the United States. In all cases, the survey tried to rely as much as possible on local sources of information, giving the people involved an outlet for sharing experiences.
 
9 Months of Research
 The team that conducted the independent review of the hydroelectric project in India for the World Bank was led by Bradford Morse, an American who was formerly Under Secretary General of the United Nations and head of the United Nations Development Program, and Thomas R. Berger, a former judge on the Canadian Supreme Court.
The team drew on the expertise of South Asian specialists in social sciences, health and engineering. The review had been prompted by a barrage of human rights reports in Europe, the United States and Japan charging abuses against those who protested the forced relocation of at least 100,000 people and the drastic alteration of the Narmada River valley with over 3,000 dams, one of them 535 feet high and nearly 4,000 feet long, and 47,000 miles of canals. In some areas that are expected to be flooded within a month as waters rise behind the dams, people have refused to be resettled.
"This has been a test case for the way international groups can work with grassroots organizations in developing countries," said Patricia Gossman, director of the Washington office of Asia Watch, which issued its own report last week on the Sardar Sarovar project, "Before the Deluge: Human Rights Abuses at India's Narmada Dam."
"The Narmada case had widest cooperation worldwide," she said. "Groups with many mandates came together because they saw their interests were closely linked."
Last year Japan froze its $230 million contribution to the project, under pressure from environmentalists and human rights groups.
India plans to generate 1,450 megawatts of power, irrigate 4.4 million acres of land and provide drinking water to 40 million people from the project, which would stretch into three states.
"We received over 500 submissions from people in India who wanted to comment," said Donald J. Gamble, a leading Canadian environmentalist and resources specialist who directed research for the World Bank's independent review. "Everyone from government agencies to small groups of women in tribal villages."

HEADLINE: While Broadway Is Feasting, Small Troupes Are Starving

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
It may be boom time on Broadway, but this has not been a good season for a number of New York City's small nonprofit theater companies. The 13-year-old Manhattan Punch Line will close its doors by the end of June; the 24-year-old AMAS Musical Theater has indefinitely suspended operations, and managers of the 25-year-old Negro Ensemble Company say they will have to shut down by the end of the year if they cannot raise $250,000 to keep going.
The Double Image Company, an ensemble of actors, directors and writers that ran the Samuel French One-Act Play Festival, has halted production. And a dozen other theater companies are in serious financial trouble but will not say so publicly. 
 "It's dangerous to make a public announcement that you might go under," said Douglas Turner Ward, the president of the Negro Ensemble Company. "It can become a self-fulfilling prophecy. We waited for a year, until we had no other choice."
 
Build Subscribers or Perish
 Other casualties in recent seasons have included Chelsea Stages at the Hudson Guild Theater, the South Street Theater Company, the Apple Corps Theater, the New Theater of Brooklyn and the Quaigh Theater.
There has always been an ebb and flow among arts groups, as declining older companies have been replaced by newer ones. And indeed some of the city's best-known nonprofit theaters, like the Manhattan Theater Club, Playwrights Horizons and the Roundabout Theater, are thriving, mainly because their productions have attracted a healthy number of subscribers, and donors to match.
But observers of the nonprofit scene say this is the worst crisis in years for companies that lack large subscriber lists and thus must rely almost solely on public and corporate financing for their existence. City, state and Federal arts budgets are being deeply cut, as are corporate, foundation and private donations.
"Clearly this is one of the most difficult times ever to be a nonprofit," said Virginia P. Louloudes, the executive director of ART New York, the trade group representing 140 theater organizations in New York City. (She said there were 200 nonprofit theater companies in the city.)
 
Bad Now May Be Worse Later
 Others worry about the future as well. "We are seeing the first wave of closures now, in response to the terrible pressures on small- to medium-size theaters," said Robert Crane, a foundation executive who is an organizer of the Arts Forward Fund, a consortium of 32 major private and corporate contributors that raised $1.6 million last year to support arts organizations in New York.
"But I suspect there will be a real shakeout in the next few years," he added. "A lot of theaters are at the edge even if they are properly managed."
For the Negro Ensemble Company, financial crisis has always been a way of life, but during the last year the company has faced the serious possibility of extinction. Although the company has customarily mounted four major productions a year, it has been inactive for more than a year. Its last major show was "The Little Tommy Parker Celebrated Colored Minstrel Show," in March 1991. The paid staff of 10 is now 4 volunteers.
"We haven't had the production money," said Mr. Ward.
The Negro Ensemble Company's Federal and state financing has been cut by $270,000 in the last few years, to $300,000, Mr. Ward said. "All of our financial problems were held at bay until finally, with these major cuts, our vulnerability was exposed," said Mr. Ward in the company's comfortably cluttered office at 155 West 46th Street in Manhattan.
The company has a deficit of $250,000 to $300,000, said Mr. Ward, and the group will close its doors by the end of the year if it can't raise enough to pay its creditors. "We're not crying wolf," he said. "This is for real."
Founded by Mr. Ward, Robert Hooks and Gerald Krone, the Negro Ensemble Company has won two Tony Awards, a Pulitzer Prize for "A Soldier's Play," by Charles Fuller, and a wall full of Drama Desk and Clarence Derwent Awards. Among its other major productions were "Ceremonies in Dark Old Men," "The River Niger," "Colored People's Time," "The Great MacDaddy," "From the Mississippi Delta," and Mr. Fuller's four-play, 20-actor epic on black Americans during the 19th century. The company's alumni include Roscoe Lee Browne, Rosalind Cash, Larry Fishburne, Frances Foster, Danny Glover, Moses Gunn, Phylicia Rashad, Roxie Roker, Esther Rolle, Hattie Winston and Denzel Washington.
Though black performers, writers and directors have increasingly found their way into the mainstream -- three of this season's major productions on Broadway, "Two Trains Running," "Jelly's Last Jam" and "Five Guys Named Moe" have almost exclusively black casts and were written and directed by blacks -- Mr. Ward insisted that the Negro Ensemble Company had not outlived its usefulness.
"The country needs an institution that has as its goal the production of black works," he said, "and if our company ceased to exist it would be necessary for someone to create the whole thing again."
For the AMAS Musical Theater, at Fifth Avenue and 104th Street, time and money have run out. The company is suspending operations this month "until we can find the money to continue," said Rosetta LeNoire, the founder and artistic director.
AMAS mounted three to four professional productions a year that have included "Mama I Want to Sing," "Bubbling Brown Sugar" and "Gunmetal Blues." Ms. LeNoire said the company had lost 90 percent of its Federal funds and 65 percent of its city funds, and had to let go its paid staff of three.
One nonprofit company, the venerable La Mama Experimental Theater Club, seemed to be tottering on the brink of extinction in March, but has undergone at least a temporary rebirth thanks to a widespread flurry of fund raising, especially among the numerous artists who have performed there. "We raised enough money to finish the season, and we cut into our deficit a bit," said Meryl Vladimer, an associate director of La Mama. "We're not out of the woods, but at this point we are planning for a season next fall."
Manhattan Punch Line could not generate such support, and is closing "because there comes a point where you can't tighten your belt any more," said Steve Kaplan, the group's artistic director. Its financing from the New York State Council on the Arts had dropped from $55,000 three years ago to $15,000 this year and its total budget was $19,000 this year, compared with $250,000 in the mid-1980's.
The Punch Line, which has offered 250 productions since 1979 to more than 50,000 people, including original plays by Howard Korder, Ted Tally, Terrence McNally and Horton Foote, decided to go out laughing, with its Eighth Annual Festival of One-Act Comedies, which ended last Sunday in the Judith Anderson Theater on West 42d Street.
A number of other small companies are furloughing their employees for a while, hoping for a better fiscal future. "We're laying off five people -- our entire administrative staff -- this summer," said Woodie King Jr., the founding and producing director of the New Federal Theater, the 22-year-old company at the Henry Street Settlement. "After that we can keep going, but we won't have a four-play season. It will be only three, or maybe two."
To survive, said Robert Crane of the Arts Forward Fund, small theater groups "have to adapt to a new era in which, unlike the 1970's and 80's, they cannot count on the availability of growing Federal, state and corporate arts funding." He said they need to develop new sources of earned income, to market themselves more effectively to their target audiences, and to cut costs by sharing resources and space with other arts groups.
Otherwise, they may become what Mr. Kaplan of the Punch Line calls "an endangered species."

HEADLINE: Russians in Antarctica Stage Protest Over Pay

BYLINE: By WALTER SULLIVAN

 BODY:
SCIENTISTS at Russia's five stations in Antarctica say they have stopped sending data home to protest the difficulties their families face in Russia.
In a statement signed by Dr. Vladimir Nazarov, leader of the Vostok station, the Russians cited their nation's severe inflation and said: "The miserable salary of Russian polar explorers, working in the rigorous climate of Antarctica, is hardly enough for our families even to buy food. We cannot help them. We can only send moral support by telephone." 
 Since past pleas for more pay had no result, the scientists have stopped sending scientific information to Moscow and St. Petersburg, although they are still collecting data.
The Vostok station is the most remote of any in Antarctica. The site is 11,300 feet above sea level on the central plateau of the polar ice sheet, which is thousands of feet thick.
 
125 Degrees Below
 In past winters temperatures there have been lower than anywhere else on earth, falling below -125 degrees Fahrenheit. Winter, with its almost perpetual darkness, began on Saturday.
Officials in Moscow and St. Petersburg say they are aware of the protest and have already increased the pay of those in Antarctica. The scientists' request to be paid, at least partly, in hard currency could not be met, said Yuri F. Zubov, head of the Committee of Hydrometeorology and Environment Monitoring of the Russian Federation.
At Vostok the Russians have been drilling holes deep into the ice. The most recent, as well as an earlier one, has reached 8,370 feet. Dr. Michael Bender at the University of Rhode Island said that ice from the bottom of the hole came from snow thought to have fallen between 190,000 and 230,000 years ago during the next-to-last interglacial period.

HEADLINE: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD;
When Patient's Life Is Price of Learning New Kind of Surgery

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, M.D.

 BODY:
"SEE one, do one, teach one."
That is the classic doctors' description of the way new procedures and operations are taught.
But the credo seems destined for deserved oblivion. 
 Alarmed about rising numbers of deaths and serious injuries from a new method of gallbladder surgery, in which surgeons use miniature video cameras and instruments inserted through tiny incisions, the New York State Health Department has demanded tighter regulations. It has directed hospitals to be stricter in deciding which surgeons can perform the procedure and to pay more attention to their results.
New York's action is forcing doctors and health officials elsewhere to begin to deal publicly with a fundamental issue they have long failed to address: the learning curve.
There are at least two kinds of learning curves in surgery. One is when young surgeons first perform an established operation. The other is when established surgeons first perform a new operation.
For either, learning surgery invariably involves errors until practice makes near perfect. Usually the initial practicing is done on animals. But there comes a time for each surgeon's first patient. Although surgeons have long accepted the inevitability that some patients will be injured from the learning curve, rarely have they or health officials spelled out the limits or the rules. Instead the key decisions have been left to individual surgeons and hospitals.
But New York health officials were emphatic in saying that a learning curve was not justification for serious injury to patients. The Health Department insists that surgeons not be allowed to perform the new laparoscopic procedures independently until they have shown adequate skill in at least 15 supervised cases.
The learning curve is a complex policy issue. It involves the tangled web of medical politics -- turf battles between specialties, and town-gown conflicts between professors in teaching hospitals and practicing surgeons in community hospitals. It also involves consumerism and the economic interests of equipment manufacturers and the health insurance companies that pay the bills.
Doctors generally greet new techniques with caution because history teaches that initial waves of enthusiasm are often tempered by the discovery of unexpected complications. While a few new techniques succeed, many others fail, and it takes time to sort them out.
But any caution for the laparoscopic gallbladder operation among surgeons has been offset by surging patient demand of a magnitude rarely seen in medical history. The prospect of less pain and a return to work several weeks earlier leads most people facing gallbladder surgery to choose the new procedure over the traditional one. And not surprisingly, the laparoscopic procedure is rapidly replacing the older operation among the 500,000 Americans who have gallbladder surgery each year.
In the procedure, several small holes are cut in the abdomen. A laparoscope, a device with a light and camera that is attached to an external video monitor, is inserted for a close-up view of organs and tissues. Instruments are inserted through the other holes and manipulated from outside the body.
The learning curve for laparoscopy is important. One reason is that the required hand-eye coordination differs significantly from that used in traditional abdominal surgery. Laparoscopy is an indirect approach: when surgeons watch a television screen and pivot long-handled instruments through a hole, they lose the feel for the tissues. They have to adjust to new ways to judge how much pressure to apply in finding pathways and cutting through tissue.
Another reason is the restricted field of vision imposed by laparoscopes, even those with wider angle lenses. Operators have a much more limited view of the anatomy when cutting with the laparoscope than in the traditional operation, where they look directly at organs and tissues and can handle them.
While most operations go smoothly, the complications that can result from laparoscopy include some that are not generally seen with the older operation. Many complications are not recognized until days, even months, after laparoscopic surgery.
Strong economic pressures have compelled many surgeons to learn the new technique because those who can do only the old one risk losing patients to competitors who offer the laparoscopic procedure.
Most new operations have been developed in academic medical centers and some are scrutinized in scientifically controlled studies before being made standard for practice. Such introduction tends to be slow as younger surgeons, who learned the technique during training, go off and practice in community hospitals.
But the new technique, introduced by surgeons in France and the United States in 1989, is one of the few major procedures to come out of community hospitals. Its development and rapid acceptance caught most teaching hospitals off guard.
In a break from the usual collegiality in surgical teaching, some surgeons who performed it initially charged other surgeons $500 to watch them do one procedure. Responsible surgeons then practiced on animals and moved on to patients by assisting colleagues already skilled in the procedure. But some surgeons began doing the procedure on their own with little further training.
Soon courses were set up, often financed by equipment manufacturers as is customary. Most courses are conducted on weekends, where the tuition fees run up to $4,000. The curriculum and quality vary widely. Beyond lectures and videotaped instruction, the best courses offer hands-on practice on animals, often pigs.
Early on, few teaching hospitals offered courses to teach the laparoscopic gallbladder technique to practicing surgeons. Now, in an unusual twist, many community surgeons are teaching the professors.
From the start, there were warnings about the prospects of botched laparoscopic gallbladder surgery. But the exact rate of complications is not known because of the lack of scientifically controlled studies and a national registry.
A few regional and national surveys have been carried out. But because they were based on voluntary reporting, experts say the frequency of botched operations is probably seriously underestimated.
Several surgical groups have published their experience with laparoscopic gallbladder surgery. But because surgeons tend to report their best results, statistics in medical journals seldom offer a realistic picture of practice in all hospitals.
The American College of Surgeons in Chicago has said that laparoscopic gallbladder surgery should be performed by surgeons qualified to perform the traditional operation because they are the only ones with the skills to treat any complications.
Knowing how to do the traditional operation is critical because problems in about 10 percent of cases force surgeons to switch immediately to the standard one.
But an unresolved issue is that with the rapid disappearance of the older operation, few younger surgeons will know how to do it in the future.
"It is only when you feel confident with the older gallbladder operation, knowing where the ducts and arteries are, that you should be tackling the laparoscopic technique," said Dr. Christopher G. Eliades, a surgeon in Nashua, N.H., who has performed 50 laparoscopic gallbladder operations.
The college's statement also reflects the turf battle with gynecologists who learned laparoscopic techniques long before general surgeons picked it up.
The American College of Surgeons has never issued a document on the learning curve. And the college has not addressed the issue of how credentials are obtained to perform laparoscopic gallbladder surgery because it considers it a matter for individual hospitals, said Linn Meyer, a spokeswoman for the college.
Dr. Hiram C. Polk Jr., the chairman of surgery at the University of Louisville, said: "If the public has to wait a few months while a corps of people are being trained, that is not all bad, particularly since you are not talking about a cure for cancer. You are talking about a traditional treatment that was certainly safe and had good long-term results."
Many surgeons insist that the new gallbladder technique is safest when carried out by two surgeons. For example, Dr. Mohan C. Airan, associate head of surgery at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Chicago, said no major injuries to the common bile duct occurred among more than 1,000 cases in Chicago hospitals that adhered to strict criteria, including the presence of two surgeons.
But despite the widespread belief that the new procedure saves money, many insurers are not paying for a second surgeon, jeopardizing patient safety, Dr. Airan said.
Limited data from published studies suggest that most complications occur among a surgeon's first 20 or so laparoscopic gallbladder operations. Despite centuries of experience with the learning curve, surgeons seldom tell patients they are the first to undergo a procedure in their hands.
Now, as public officials and medical leaders tackle the learning curve issue, they might consider offering a steep discount to a surgeon's first patients and then work out a sliding scale of fees for successive cases.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Laparoscopic gallbladder surgery requires surgeons to be retrained. Last weekend a group of surgeons practiced on a pig at the Advanced Laparoscopy Training Center, a private facility in Marietta, Ga. (Thomas England for The New York Times)

 BODY:
The French Government is selling more than half its stake in the state-controlled oil company Total S.A.
