HEADLINE: Now, Where's Their Beef?

 BODY:
So far, Bill Clinton is the only Presidential candidate to offer an economic plan. He has just issued a revised version, and it gives a sound answer to every important question:
How much must the deficit be cut? In half, Governor Clinton says, which avoids dogmatic calls to eliminate it no matter what the consequences.Should taxes be raised? Yes, he answers, with some political courage, by $150 billion. Can spending also be cut? Yes, by an equal amount -- and he would plow the savings into a $200 billion program of public investment. 
 The new plan, like the one he published last winter, trips over details and is full of election-year feints and evasions. Even so, it puts Mr. Clinton a full lap ahead of his opponents in the substance sweepstakes. Ross Perot is still hiding behind vapid promises to act smart. President Bush doesn't even bother to promise. By offering his plan, Mr. Clinton may constructively impel his opponents to tell, in some detail, what they stand for.
Mr. Clinton's new plan withdraws his pledge to eliminate the deficit within four years, proposing instead to draw it down to about $150 billion a year. At that level, the deficit would not strain private capital markets. But it would allow Mr. Clinton to pump money into public infrastructure, education and worker training. Facing up to fiscal reality, he also has reduced the middle-class tax cut he promised early in the primary campaign.
Mr. Clinton's document nevertheless reflects a high political polish. He would have voters believe that the deficit can be controlled by raising taxes only on corporations and the super rich. He proposes taking only a nick out of entitlements, even though they are expected to explode by 2000. He takes easy shots at unpopular targets like high executive pay, foreign corporations and domestic firms relocating abroad. The plan pretends that bold solutions will be painless.
But at least Mr. Clinton addresses problems, which is more than can be said of his opponents. Mr. Perot writes off social problems with empty assumptions. Whatever the problem -- health care, deficits, crime, urban blight -- the answer is the same: "Let's figure out what has to be done and just do it."
Does that mean older adults should be called on to give up cost-of-living adjustments to retirement benefits? Should middle-class families pay higher taxes, farmers give up subsidies and homeowners part with their mortgage-interest deduction? Mr. Perot doesn't say.
President Bush so far won't even make promises. He renews tiresome calls for pending legislation on crime, job training, enterprise zones, homeownership and school choice. Not one of these talking points includes serious dollars or matches the magnitude of the problems.
Beyond the specifics of his new plan, Governor Clinton now offers thoughtful voters the start of a credible debate. For the moment, alas, it's the sound of one hand clapping, and voters are left waiting to hear the other two.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Rent Increases Approved as 2 Resign From Board

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
Amid the usual boisterousness of its annual public meeting, the New York City Rent Guidelines Board passed rent increases Monday night, including a continuation of a 5 percent vacancy allowance that spurred the board's two tenant representatives to resign.
The board approved rent increases of 3 percent on one-year leases, 5 percent for two-year leases and a 5 percent vacancy allowance, the amount a landlord may raise the rent when a tenant moves out. Throughout the meeting at Police Plaza, the board's actions were greeted by jeers as landlords and tenants played out their customary clash at the annual meeting. 
 At its meeting on May 11, the board agreed to propose the increases on one- and two-year leases but dropped the vacancy allowance. When the vacancy allowance was agreed to by a majority of the board, the two tenant representatives, Galen Kirkland and Oda Friedheim, announced their resignations. Their replacements will be named by Mayor David N. Dinkins, who appoints all board members.
 
A Landlords' View
 "It became apparent we were not making progress toward establishing fair rents," Mr. Kirkland said yesterday. "I believe that the vacancy allowance is not necessary because the owners are able to cover expenses through other increases allowed under the rent-stabilization system."
But a landlord representative, John Gilbert, president of the Rent Stabilization Association, felt that the increases were inadequate. "The board committed economic suicide," he said. "The results of these votes are going to be more abandonment, more homelessness and reduced city services, because property owners are going to go out of business."
"Property taxes went up on average 11 percent; water and sewer taxes 18 percent," Mr. Gilbert added. "How can an owner pay these increases on a 3 percent rent increase?"
In 1991, the board adopted increases of 4 percent on a one-year lease, 6 1/2 percent for a two-year lease and 5 percent for a vacancy. The new increases will affect about 600,000 of the 900,000 rent-stabilized apartments in the city where the leases expire in the coming year.
The board's executive director, Timothy Collins, said the increases were "consistent with research indicating what is necessary to cover changes in operating costs on a dollar-for-dollar basis."
"We do the research and report the results," Mr. Collins added, "and let the advocates interpret as they will."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
American to Lift Fares 4.4%

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

DATELINE: NEW YORK, June 23

 BODY:
American Airlines said today that it wanted to raise fares by at least 4.4 percent to cover higher fuel costs in what appeared to be a belated response to Northwest's attempt to push up prices by 10 percent across the board.
Although the move by American, a unit of AMR Corporation, sent the competition scurrying, the giant carrier from Fort Worth, Texas, said it was not concerned about creating any public perception that the airlines are rigging the fare system. 
 "We're not fixing prices," a spokesman, Tim Smith, said. "It's up to the others what they do with this. We think it makes good economic sense. Others will have to decide whether it makes sense for them."
 
Jet-Fuel Prices Take Off
 But American will likely abandon the higher fares, set to take effect July 7, if the competition does not match them.
The carrier said in a statement it would first restore all its prices to levels set on April 9, when American unveiled what it called a simplified pricing system. Since then, competitors have lowered fares in some markets and American matched the lower fares.
American said that once the April 9 fares were back in place, it would push up all fares by 4.4 percent across the board to cover jet fuel costs that have risen by 11.2 percent since winter. Oil has been more expensive since Saudi Arabia, the world's dominant petroleum exporter, recently said it was willing to see the price of crude rise this summer.
Mr. Smith estimated the overall increase would be less than 5 percent.
As a sample of the higher fares, American said passengers going from Dallas to Seattle would see the price rise to $400 from $350, either for a full-fare, one-way ticket or for a round trip on a 14-day advance purchase leisure ticket.
Passengers going from Washington to Miami would see prices rise to $300 from $290, on the same types of tickets, while passengers going from New York to Chicago would see such fares rise to $260 from $250.
American said it was rejecting the Northwest fare proposal because some of the cheaper fares introduced by competitors were not fairly based on the distance flown.
"A 10 percent overall increase at this time, as others have announced, would only perpetuate the inequity inherent in such pricing," said Mike Gunn, senior vice president of marketing at American. "We have elected instead to adhere to the principles of fairness and simplicity of the original value plan."

HEADLINE: STRIKE AT AMTRAK POSTPONED 2 DAYS

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr.

 BODY:
Rail maintenance workers last night postponed for two days their threatened strike against Amtrak after failing to reach agreement on a new contract by a midnight deadline.
After a day of intense negotiations during which Amtrak reached agreement with several of its smaller unions, the reprieve by the Brotherhood of Maintenance of Way Employees relieved mounting tension over the possibility of a nationwide strike against commuter, intercity passenger and freight lines. 
 "Despite the efforts by Amtrak to force us into a strike, and because we do not want to inconvenience the public, the B.M.W.E. will not strike Amtrak for at least the next 48 hours," said Jed Dodd, the union's top negotiator.
 
More Negotiations
 He said the union would continue to negotiate with Amtrak for the next two days.
But the late announcement did not clarify whether the union would strike Amtrak later, or whether its members would shut down Conrail, a large freight railroad that is involved in a separate dispute with its unions. Mr. Dodd said the union was continuing to negotiate with Conrail and did not intend to strike immediately, but was concerned that Conrail might unilaterally impose conditions on the union. A company spokesman said early this morning that Conrail had imposed new work rules effective immediately, but did not elaborate.
Nor is it clear whether the International Association of Machinists will continue bargaining with most of the nation's other freight railroads, which like Conrail imposed new work rules on the machinists.
The machinists union immediately began picketing CSX, a large freight railroad, but it appeared that the union was striking CSX alone as opposed to a nationwide action that might invite Congressional intervention.
Just before a midnight deadline, Amtrak initialed agreements with four of its unions.
The threat of a nationwide rail strike had raised the specter of serious damage to the economy, and had put Congress in the position of having to consider legislation imposing a contract settlement on the reluctant unions. President Bush yesterday urged Congress to stop any rail strike on the day it began.
But while the decision not to strike Amtrak gave immediate relief to travelers who might have been stranded by a strike, the outcome is no more certain than the union's motives in forgoing a strike against Amtrak.
 
Perhaps a Tactical Move
 For example, the union's decision may be simply a tactical move, perhaps one intended to keep the pressure on Amtrak and Conrail without risking a Congressionally imposed settlement, or perhaps one meant to delay a strike until Congress leaves town for the Fourth of July recess.
But officials following the negotiations said Mr. Dodd seemed pleased with the progress in the talks and did not want to break off talks and send his members onto the picket lines. Instead, it appears that the union will pause in its talks with Amtrak and continue the marathon sessions with Conrail.
President Bush did not give the unions any encouragement yesterday. After meeting with Transportation Secretary Andrew H. Card Jr., President Bush said, "The public good is not served by a prolonged strike, so it ought to end the day it begins."
Representative John D. Dingell, the Michigan Democrat who heads the House Energy and Commerce Committee, suggested at a news conference that Congress might take a few days to act in the event of a strike. "We will first find out what the facts are," he said. But he also said, "Congress will not sit idly by."
In April 1991, Congress halted a rail strike 17 hours after it began, imposing contract terms that had been recommended by a Federal mediation panel.
 
Criticism of Bush
 Mr. Dodd said he hoped Congress would not move swiftly to stop a strike this time, especially one that did not affect the entire rail industry. He accused Mr. Bush of intervening on the side of railroad management.
"When it looks like workers can lose a strike, President Bush supports the right to strike," Mr. Dodd said. "When it looks like workers can win a strike, President Bush opposes the right to strike."
The Senate yesterday passed a Republican-sponsored nonbinding resolution that "Congress needs to act immediately to forestall a possible railroad strike." It was not immediately clear what Congress would or could do to follow through on the measure.
 
Bitterness Among Workers
 Conrail employees interviewed at a job site in the New York area were unanimous in calling for a strike unless the giant freight railroad agreed to their demands, including a retroactive pay increase.
Wolfing down eggs, bacon, cereal and coffee in the makeshift quarters that the rail workers share during the workweek, they spoke bitterly of receiving no pay increase in five years, of lacking job security, and of proposed changes in work rules that they said would make their jobs scarcely worth the $26,000 a year that the average union member earns.
Every week Kevin Bellinski, one of the workers, drives from his home in Canton, Ohio, to join what the laborers call a "tie gang," a group of itinerant laborers who work four 10-hour days plus overtime before returning home. This week, the drive was to northeast New Jersey.
Mr. Bellinski and his fellow workers, most of whom also said they commute long distances, live in cramped boxcars austerely outfitted with bunk beds, bathrooms and kitchens. The cars periodically move along the rails, providing a base from which the workers deploy each morning.
According to the union, Conrail wants to change seniority rules in a way that will force many workers to travel even farther from their homes than they already do.
The union wants a benefit paid to employees on furlough to more than double. Workers with enough seniority can work almost year round, but those with less seniority often go months without work, collecting only $155 a week in benefits.

 * The Long Island Rail Road would suspend service to and from Pennsylvania Station during a strike. Trains would terminate at Jamaica, Woodside, Shea Stadium, Long Island City and Richmond Hill in Queens and at Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, where riders could connect with city subways.

HEADLINE: ISRAEL'S LABOR PARTY WINS CLEAR VICTORY IN ELECTION; READY TO FORM A COALITION

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Wednesday, June 24

 BODY:
Israel's opposition Labor Party won a resounding victory over the right-wing Likud Party in Tuesday's national election, nearly complete results showed today. The vote creates the possibility of a center-left coalition committed to greater flexibility in Middle East peace talks.
For the first time since its tumble from political dominance in the 1970's, Labor was in a clear position to form a Government, although it fell short of a parliamentary majority of its own. 
 Given the party's stated willingness to exchange land for peace with the Arabs, its apparent victory seemed likely to be welcomed by the United States, which has grown weary of the Likud Government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and views him as intransigent in the peace process.
 
No Security Lessons
 After his defeat became clear, Mr. Shamir strongly suggested that he might retire from political life.
Yitzhak Rabin, the Labor leader and almost certainly the country's next Prime Minister, pledged early this morning that the coalition he will begin shaping today will "include all the positive forces in the nation that identify with our way: furthering peacemaking while safeguarding our security."
In an obvious reference to Likud, which had accused Labor of being soft on Israel's defense, Mr. Rabin told cheering supporters in Tel Aviv, "No one will teach us what responsibility for security is."
 
Shamir Near Retirement?
 He then echoed a basic campaign theme, saying that "we will change the order of national priorities."
In recent months, he repeatedly said that high on his list of altered priorities would be a shift of Government money from settlement-building in Israeli-occupied territories to social and economic needs in Israel proper.
Although Mr. Shamir stopped short of announcing his resignation, he gave an unmistakable impression that his political career was about over.
 
Parliamentary Majority
 "It's natural and understandable that in political life, under these conditions, I am at the end of my personal road," he told an Israeli television interviewer this morning.
With 97 percent of the ballots counted, projections showed Labor winning 45 seats in the 120-member Parliament, far more than the 32 forecast for Likud and a sharp departure from the last election, in 1988, when the two major parties were nearly balanced.
The projections also gave 12 seats to the left-wing Meretz Party, a natural coalition partner for Labor, and a total of 5 to two Arab parties. Combined, Labor, Meretz and the Arabs have 62 seats, a parliamentary majority and more than enough to block Likud from regrouping the religious-right alliance that it led for the last two years.
A big complication is that Mr. Rabin has said he would not govern with the Arabs, thus leaving Labor and Meretz by themselves four seats short of a majority. Nonetheless, his lead was solid enough to put him in a commanding position to do much as he pleases in piecing together a working coalition.
The leaders of several small religious parties, which collectively lost ground this time, signaled almost immediately after exit polls were flashed on television screens that they were ready to deal even though their natural inclination is to align themselves with Likud.
In his speech to supporters early this morning, Mr. Rabin emphasized that he would seek a coalition that will "express the central current among our people, a coalition that will enable us to carry out our policy."
Some political analysts said it was possible that the Labor leader, who was Prime Minister in 1977 when his party first lost power, had not entirely ruled out a coalition with Likud along the lines of one that prevailed through much of the last decade.
While others thought that an unlikely development, many politicians in both parties are convinced that Mr. Rabin -- a former military hero and a man who is appreciably more hawkish than many in his party -- would feel more comfortable working with Mr. Shamir than with the ardent doves in Meretz and even in Labor.
"He doesn't want to be completely in the hands of Meretz," said Shlomo Avineri, a pro-Labor political scientist at Hebrew University. "He also doesn't want to be in the hands of the religious."
 
'No Bargaining'
 Whatever happens, the 70-year-old Mr. Rabin left no doubt this morning that he was in charge, a point that seemed directed also at Shimon Peres, a longtime archrival whom he displaced as Labor leader in February in Israel's first party primary.
"I will determine who the ministers will be," he said as supporters interrupted him periodically with a blast from a ram's horn and chants of "Rabin, king of Israel!" "There will be no bargaining," he continued.
At Likud headquarters, the mood was decidedly grim as senior officials acknowledged that they were about to enter the opposition. Some said that internal bloodletting would soon follow, especially if Mr. Shamir, who is 76, does leave politics after having served as Prime Minister for seven of the last nine years.
But through the gloom, Mr. Shamir cautioned that his party, while down, was not out.
 
Harbor for the Disaffected
 "We all know that tonight there are people all over the world and in the Middle East and other places who are happy and gleeful now that their dangerous enemy, the Likud, which raised the prestige of the people of Israel higher and higher in recent years, is coming down," he told Likud stalwarts in Tel Aviv. "I say to them, 'Your joy is premature."'
From the minute voting ended on a clear, mild election day, it became apparent that Labor's strategy to regain power had paid off.
It concentrated most of its energies on Mr. Rabin, holding him forth as tough about security and therefore a safe harbor for disaffected Likud supporters eager to register a protest vote but uneasy about swinging to Labor because they perceive it as overly dovish.
For many, Likud had overstayed its welcome for many reasons -- lack of clear progress in the peace process, a deterioration in relations with the United States and, perhaps most important, high unemployment and a general sense that the country is not being run right.
 
'A Lack of Trust'
 "We're talking basically about a lack of trust in Likud's ability to govern," said Gadi Wolfsfeld, a Hebrew University political scientist.
To a large extent, the inherent tension between a relatively hawkish Labor leader and many of his followers contributed to a blurring of key issues, which were not discussed in depth during the election campaign. Nonetheless, differences between Labor and Likud are plain on pivotal issues of peace and security, notably Mr. Rabin's willingness to give up some of Israel's occupied territories and his call for a reduction of Jewish settlements on those lands.
Those positions are certain to gladden the Bush Administration, which had made clear its unhappiness with Mr. Shamir's no-compromise stand on territory and his insistence on building settlements to "the horizon's edge."
"It's a decidedly unambiguous defeat for the Israeli right and its policies on all fronts," said Yaron Ezrahi, another political scientist at Hebrew University and a Likud opponent.
 
First-Time Voters
 Still, polls and pre-election interviews suggested that many Israelis were not focused on peace and security as much as on bread-and-butter concerns.
According to voter surveys at polling places, the several hundred thousand new immigrants from the former Soviet Union voted for Labor over Likud by a margin of 47 percent to 18 percent, mainly because of their unhappiness over failed economic policies that have left 40 percent of them unemployed. The newcomers did not vote for several ethnic Russian parties in sufficiently large numbers to give any of them a parliamentary seat.
First-time voters, normally hawkish, also shifted toward Labor and Meretz and away from Likud. Many of them, survey takers said, also voted for a small right-wing party, Tsomet. Although it demands that Israel not give up any territory, its greater appeal to many voters was as a good-government party interested in electoral change and an end to perceived abuses of state funds. According to projections, Tsomet will increase its parliamentary strength from 2 seats to 7.
Among Tsomet's targets were the religious parties, some of which in theory do not recognize the state of Israel but depend on it all the same for money for their seminaries and other institutions. They slipped from 18 seats to a projected 17, in good part because their strength was diluted by the overwhelmingly secular Jews from Russia and other former Soviet republics.
They were not the only losers as the welter of 15 parties in the old Parliament seemed likely to dwindle to 10 -- sparse by Israel's fractious standards.
Tehiya, a far-right party that had three parliamentary seats, did not qualify for a single seat this time, making it one of the day's big losers.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Ultimately, Nissan Calls Car 'Altima'

BYLINE: By Adam Bryant

 BODY:
WITHIN months, the Nissan Motor Company will roll out a replacement for its slow-selling Stanza compact with the ambitious goal of winning over car shoppers inclined toward the Honda Motor Company's popular Accord and the Toyota Motor Corporation's Camry.
Nissan faced an equally daunting challenge in 1987 when its executives sat down to name the car. The Stanza moniker was often criticized for being too much like Nissan's subcompact Sentra, which shares four of six letters with Stanza. "For some reason, the Stanza never stuck in anyone's mind," said Earl Hesterberg, vice president and general manager of the Nissan division of the parent's American arm. Many industry watchers considered Stanza the second misnomer from Nissan, which confused consumers in the early 1980's by switching its nameplate from Datsun to Nissan. 
 The new compact's name: Altima. Its derivation from the Latin "altus" suggests "a higher order," as does its similarity to the word ultimate, Mr. Hesterberg said. The "ima" ending may cause some confusion with the top-of-the-line Maxima, Mr. Hesterberg said, but that problem would be preferable to confusion with the economical Sentra.
Whether consumers find the name pleasing is no small matter. As auto makers improve the quality of their wares, car buyers increasingly decide among models by the emotional appeal of a car's styling and image. The role of the name, therefore, is "to trigger that emotion," said Charles Brymer, president of the Interbrand Corporation, which counts among its work naming Mazda's new luxury division, Amati. Nissan hopes to induce the right emotions often in September, when it will introduce the car with its most expensive new-car advertising campaign.
Is Altima, coined by David Wood Associates of New York, a good name? The reviews from other identity consultants are mixed, underscoring not only the highly subjective nature of this science-cum-art, but also some of the subtleties of fashioning marques in the hotly competitive auto industry.
The first point of disagreement appears to be whether the correct pronunciation of Altima is readily apparent. Ira N. Bachrach, president of Name Lab Inc. in San Francisco, says consumers generally tackle unfamiliar names by borrowing pronunciation from a similar word, such as altitude. That would suggest a straightforward AL-ti-ma. But others noted that consumers may also see "ultimate" in the wording, and venture another guess, maybe UL-ti-ma. In recent months, in fact, many Nissan executives and dealers have served up many versions. The official pronunciation, according to Mr. Hesterberg: Borrow the "a" sound from alternator. Thus, AHL-ti-ma.
The uncertainty of a new name's pronunciation can be both an asset and a liability, said Kate Moran, senior vice president in charge of naming for Lippincott & Margulies, whose work includes dubbing Nissan's Infiniti luxury division and the Cadillac Allante. Those who know how to pronounce an unusual car name may feel part of an exclusive group, but those outside it may be irritated by the uncertainty, she said.
Of course, many new car names are not easily discernible until they are trumpeted in commercials. For example, how many consumers knew how to say Camaro when they first saw the word, or Miata?
Ms. Moran applauds the Altima name for its "foreign and romantic" ring, while others say it sounds too much like other products. Ms. Moran also speculated that it might be among the last car names, at least for a while, that begin and end with the letter a. With Honda's Acura division, Oldsmobile's Achieva compact and Nissan's Altima, the device is "a little overworked," she said, much as the letter "x" was, when it caught corporate fancies, resulting in such names as Nynex and USX.
Given the plethora of concocted names for automobiles, Ms. Moran predicts that auto makers may start scouring dictionaries once again for words like Quest, the name Nissan has given to its new mini-van due out later this year. Indeed, Mr. Hesterberg said he would prefer to use existing names because they garner more immediate recognition. "You don't have to work as hard" to familiarize the public with the name, he said.
Nissan may not be entirely clear of confusion over the Altima name. The car's official name is Stanza Altima, and Government regulations apparently require the auto maker to include the Stanza name on the trunk, even though Stanza will not be included in Nissan's marketing. Mr. Hesterberg said the decal would also help ease the transition for consumers from Stanza to Altima.

HEADLINE: Philanthropic Giving Rose 6.2% in '91, Study Says

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
Philanthropic giving across the nation increased last year to $124.7 billion, a 6.2 percent rise over 1990, a new study says.
Americans continued to demonstrate generosity to religious and educational institutions but slighted nonprofit hospitals and human service organizations, the study found. Major art museums did well, receiving important works, but dance groups suffered. 
 The study was performed by the Trust for Philanthropy, the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel's research arm, which annually estimates the donations from individuals, corporations and foundations to the country's nonprofit organizations.
That the total of giving rose to a record level despite the sluggish economy and high unemployment was welcome news for most larger nonprofit organizations, officials of the Trust for Philanthropy said. But some officials, noting that the increase was only 1.4 percent when adjusted for inflation, expressed disappointment.
"You would have to be a fool not to expect giving to be very healthy, because of two phenomena," said Martin Grenzebach, chairman of the Trust for Philanthropy. "There are 10 times more millionaires today than in 1980, and the baby-boom generation is moving into the 34-to-65-year age group, considered the prime giving years, when discretionary income goes up and individuals can be more generous. But the reality is Americans' per-capita giving to charity is much less than some of us anticipated."
But Ann Kaplan, author of the study, said a number of nonprofits and officials in the philanthropy field regarded the increases as remarkably strong. Giving by individuals in 1991 accounted for 89 cents of every dollar contributed to nonprofits -- $103.1 billion from living donors and $7.78 billion in bequests. Foundations gave $7.76 billion, an increase reflecting the growth of their assets because of improved stock market performance. Corporate giving totaled $6.1 billion.
 
Religious Groups Gain
 As usual, the largest share of philanthropic giving went to religious organizations: $67.6 billion, which came almost entirely from individuals. Education received $13.3 billion, giving to environmental groups increased to $2.5 billion, and giving to international affairs rose to $2.6 billion.
Giving to the arts rose from $7.9 billion in 1990 to $8.8 billion in 1991, in part because some donors hurried to take advantage of a preferential tax treatment that had been expected to expire last Dec. 31. That tax provision, allowing donors to deduct the appreciated value of the artwork instead of just their purchase price, was extended for six months, and Congress is considering a further extension.
Contributions for health organizations dropped to $9.7 billion last year from $9.9 billion in 1990. Giving to nonprofit groups providing human services dropped to $10.6 billion from $11.8 billion.

HEADLINE: Watts Organizer Feels Weight of Riots, and History

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 23

 BODY:
Terry Watkins was recently driving through Watts, past the low-income housing with the gardens, the senior center, the homeless shelter, all of them built by the community organization her father, Ted Watkins, founded 27 years ago. Here were glimpses of hope in a place that has never recovered from the first riot in 1965.
Then, as she turned onto Central Avenue, the skyline of downtown Los Angeles emerged through the smog. All those glass and steel skyscrapers full of bankers, lawyers and foreign investors were just eight miles north, while here, outside Ms. Watkins's car window, groups of young men were standing around on another weekday afternoon. 
 "Less than 30 years ago the tallest building you could see was City Hall, which is 27 stories," she said. "Now look at it. They built the whole downtown. And what does Watts have? A shopping center and a few houses. These men aren't here because of the riots. They're unemployed."
That view embodies all of the frustration of Ms. Watkins and her father over the contrast between what was promised for their community after the 1965 riot and what has been done. "Everyone kept saying, 'Watts will never happen again,' " said Ms. Watkins, who is 45 years old.
But it did, this spring in South-Central Los Angeles, which includes Watts. Among the hundreds of burned-out buildings this time were the headquarters of the Watts Labor Community Action Committee, which Mr. Watkins founded shortly before the first riot.
While his daughter, who works as her father's assistant, was giving a tour to a visitor, Mr. Watkins was in his makeshift office in what used to be the store where his organization sold modestly priced furniture to the community. All the furniture was gone, carried off by looters.
 
A Lot of Talk
 These is a lot of talk these days about rebuilding the South-Central neighborhood. President Bush, Gov. Bill Clinton and Ross Perot have been there, along with contingents of business executives and movie stars. The Ford Foundation even sent Mr. Watkins's group $2 million to rebuild.
Mr. Watkins, who is 68, has toughed out a double-bypass heart operation, the amputation of his leg because of diabetes and the loss of both kidneys, and now this, his second riot. He says he finds it difficult to think about the task of rebuilding. He says he remembers what happened the last time.
"Nothing like the riot had ever happened before," he said. "There were a lot of guilt feelings on the part of the majority community. Finally, they admitted all these things were wrong. Everyone came to Watts -- Hubert Humphrey, McGovern, the Kennedys, Martin Luther King Jr., Stokely Carmichael. They were all going to rebuild L.A.
"There were going to be Model Cities and urban redevelopment. There were reports done by different commissions, the Kerner Commission, the McCabe Commission, and recommendations for change. There were all these new opportunities."
For a while, Watts was alive with possibility. There was plenty of money, much of it from the Federal Government, for all kinds of employment, social and cultural programs. Mr. Watkins' organization alone put 1,000 youths to work every summer, clearing weeds, painting benches and planting more than 30,000 trees.
Another group, Job Power, taught painting and janitorial skills. Green Power produced Watts Walloper baseball bats. Operation Bootstrap made black dolls. The Watts Movie Theater opened, with first-run movies and 25 cents admission.
"Then all of a sudden it started flattening out," Mr. Watkins said. "They'd send a letter: 'This contract is ending.' Time had run out."
Some of the experiments in Watts had not worked, or were poorly managed. But many programs had transformed people's lives. Tommy Beard was 14 and living in Nickerson Gardens, one of Watts' most notorious housing projects, when he started working summers for Mr. Watkins.
"I wanted my own things," said Mr. Beard, who is 41 now. "The only way I knew to get it was to earn it. All the kids around here knew they could go every summer to W.L.C.A.C. and get a job."
Mr. Beard, who is rearing three children in Watts, still works for the Watts Labor Community Action Committee, as a cook in the adult day-care center. But the organization has had to cut its payroll from 3,000 at its peak to fewer than 300. And life in Watts, Mr. Watkins and his daughter say, is worse than before.
"This riot was much deeper, and more dangerous," Mr. Watkins said. "More ethnic groups were involved."
Ted Watkins had arrived in Watts alone at age 13 from Vicksburg, Miss., to escape a lynching threat. "I was walking on the sidewalk when a white Western Union messenger came along and told me to move," he said. Blacks "weren't supposed to be on the sidewalk. I hit him."
In Watts, he went from washing cars to a job as a body and fender man at the Ford Motor Company, where as an officer with the union he developed the organizing skills he would later put to use in his community. He has spent most of his adult life taking on politicians, developers, drug dealers and anyone else who got in the way of his crusade for a better Watts.
And so when 200 rioters swarmed into his headquarters, he held his ground, a man in the electric cart that serves as his wheelchair, physically frail, but with a powerful voice. Finally his son made him go home.
"I was shouting at them, 'This is a black organization, we're from the community,' " he recalled. "It didn't make any difference. A lot of them only spoke Spanish anyway. They weren't listening to anybody."
 
Lost History
 Now, in his cart, he was surrounded by 30,000 square feet of ashes and emptiness. Here, in addition to the headquarters, had been the food stamp office and what the looters had been after: a large supply of furniture, VCR's and refrigerators that had been available for sale at a fair price.
Everything had been taken, or burned up, including the historical record of one man's devotion to his community. The first cup, inscribed "Made In Watts, 1966," produced in the youth center kiln. The plaque from the residents of Benedict Canyon thanking the children of Watts for helping them dig out of the mud after the floods of 1968. The hundreds of letters from Watts residents who had found jobs or housing or a hot meal because of Ted Watkins. The photographs of Mr. Watkins shaking hands with Senator Edward M. Kennedy and Cesar Chavez, receiving the Medal for Entrepeneurial Excellence from Yale, being honored at the White House.
Last week Mr. Watkins received the Ford Foundation's check. Even so, he said, there are times when what is before him seems overwhelming.
"There is so much tension in the air," he said. "And so much work to do."
And, returning to his office, he got back to it.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ted Watkins, who lost a leg to diabetes, also has suffered through two riots in Los Angeles. He spoke outside the ruins of his office of his fear of history repeating itself. After 1965, "They were all going to rebuild L.A.," he said. "Then all of a sudden it started flattening out." (Bart Bartholomew for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Manhattan Is in a Battle To Keep Unicef's Offices

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
An intense behind-the-scenes struggle that pits New York City against New Rochelle, Queens against Brooklyn, and private developers against public officials is being waged over who will house Unicef by 1995.
At the moment, the leading choices for the United Nations Children's Fund seem to have narrowed to the International Design Center New York, in Long Island City, Queens; the Renaissance Plaza office and hotel project in downtown Brooklyn; and two new proposals, one in Long Island City and one in downtown New Rochelle. 
 A decision may be made by Unicef's executive board as early as Friday.
 
A Plum Ready for Picking
 The United Nations agency, with its worldwide renown and 950 employees, would be a prize for any landlord at any time. But with New York fighting to retain its international stature (it happens to be competing with Germany for three other United Nations agencies now based in Manhattan), and with landlords battling ferociously for tenants, the stakes are even higher.
"Clearly, the city is committed to keeping the U.N. and all of its constituent agencies here," said Carl Weisbrod, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation. "It's essential not only because of the jobs and the direct impact on the economy, but because it's one of the factors that establishes New York as a premier international city."
Unicef's headquarters currently are in leased space at Unicef House on East 44th Street, between First and Second Avenues. It also rents office space in two buildings nearby, as well as in buildings in Long Island City and Secaucus, N.J.
 
A View to Expansion
 The agency, which is expanding, hopes to consolidate its operations in one or two buildings by 1995. Possible strategies range from keeping most of its space in Unicef House to moving most of its operations elsewhere and perhaps owning the space it occupies.
Since it invited proposals last September, Unicef has received 34 detailed responses, said Timothy E. Boakes, the agency's director of administrative management. These have now been winnowed to four, he said, and new proposals have come in from Queens and Westchester County.
Although Mr. Boakes would not identify the four, they are understood in the real-estate industry to be the following.
*The International Design Center. It was originally built for the furnishing industry but now has a variety of tenants. The complex has proposed housing Unicef in 318,000 square feet of office space in the Center One building, on Thomson Avenue between 30th Place and 31st Street, and in 115,000 square feet of warehouse space in Center Three, the former Executone Building, between 29th and 30th Streets.
*Renaissance Plaza. The Muss Development Company of Forest Hills, Queens, which has proposed putting Unicef in the plaza on a block bounded by Jay, Willoughby, Adams and Johnson Streets. There would be a 23-story office tower atop a seven-story base, including a 384-room Hilton Hotel.
*A new building in Long Island City. The Rockrose Development Corporation of Manhattan wants to put Unicef in offices it would erect on a parking lot it owns at 43d Avenue and Crescent Street. A company vice president declined to be more specific.
*Land in New Rochelle. The city government has proposed a 20-story, 575,000-square-foot building on what is now a two-acre municipally owned parking lot on Huguenot Avenue, at the foot of Le Count Place. This would be developed by the Starrett Housing Corporation-HRH Construction Corporation, designed by Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates and financed by 30-year bonds issued by New Rochelle.
 
Accessibility Stressed
 Officials representing all four sites stress that their properties are close to mass transportation, easily reached from New York airports and surrounded by ethnically diverse populations.
New Rochelle's commissioner of development, Joseph G. Madonna, said an entire United Nations district could be developed in the vicinity of what would be the new Unicef headquarters.

HEADLINE: Rabin Incentives: Spurred Talks, U.S. Guarantees

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Wednesday, June 24

 BODY:
If the Israeli Labor Party leader, Yitzhak Rabin, keeps his campaign pledges, a government under his stewardship would step up the pace of Arab-Israeli peace talks, curb settlement activity in the occupied territories and push for agreement on Palestinian autonomy in the disputed areas within several months.
Such policies would be a pronounced departure from the path taken by the departing Likud Government and could significantly improve Israel's soured relations with the United States.
 
Relations With U.S.
 Specifically, they could help Israel obtain $10 billion in badly needed American loan guarantees to resettle a flood of immigrants from the former Soviet Union. The loan guarantees have been denied because of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's refusal to freeze settlement activity. 
 Throughout the election campaign, Mr. Rabin has promised to stop the construction of "political settlements" not vital for Israel's security, and invest instead in the ailing economy to create more jobs. Labor's party platform goes further, and calls for a one-year moratorium on construction of new settlements while peace talks are under way.
Though Mr. Rabin has not specifically defined "political settlements," he is known to oppose settlement in heavily populated areas of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. Labor has supported settlement in areas like the Jordan Valley and the environs of Jerusalem.
Mr. Rabin has promised to conclude an agreement on interim autonomy arrangements in the occupied territories within six to nine months, as a first step to a peace settlement.
He says such a settlement can be reached through "territorial compromise," an exchange of land for peace, though he rules out a return to Israel's borders before the 1967 war or establishment of a Palestinian state in areas returned to Arab control.
Mr. Rabin also accepts the principle of territorial compromise in negotiations with Syria on the future of the Golan Heights, though he insists that Israel must maintain a presence there.
While suggesting a more flexible negotiating position toward the Palestinians and the Arab countries, Mr. Rabin has maintained a firm stance on questions of internal security. As Defense Minister, he pursued tough policies against the Palestinian uprising, and he has promised similar measures, including sealing off the occupied territories if necessary, to prevent Arab attacks inside Israel.
The flexibility of a Rabin-led government depends on its composition, and on the distribution of cabinet portfolios in a future coalition.
Mr. Rabin, a former general, is a hawkish leader of a party list peppered with doves. He served notice in confident remarks early this morning that he alone would determine the assignment of ministerial posts. And he insisted that he would work to form a centrist government, despite his party's alliance with Meretz, a coalition of liberal and leftist parties.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Clinton Asks Foes for Economic Plans

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr.

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton boasted yesterday that he had come up with the most sweeping economic blueprint for the country ever offered by a Presidential candidate and challenged President Bush and Ross Perot to match it.
At the same time, he promised that if elected President, his first 100 days in office would be governmentally "explosive," with Congress and Federal agencies under intense pressure to get the country's economic and social programs moving again. 
 "We have to make choices, and I've made choices," the Arkansas Governor and presumed Democratic nominee said yesterday morning in New York on the ABC News program "Good Morning America" as he promoted and defended his new proposals.
"We've got a President of the United States who's been President for four years and who has no program on any of this," he said. "We've got a guy who wants to be President who has no program. At least I've given you an indication of what I'll do. This is the most detailed program ever developed by anybody running for President. I'm telling you more about what I'm going to do than anybody else who's ever run."
 
Praise From Democrats
 Neither Mr. Bush nor Mr. Perot, who is expected to become a Presidential candidate soon, has yet to put a major economic proposal before voters or commented substantively on Mr. Clinton's plan. But some Bush Administration officials have asserted that the Clinton plan marks the Governor, an ideological centrist, as "another tax-and-spend liberal Democrat."
By contrast, a number of Democrats have praised the plan, including several dozen mayors now attending the annual meeting of the United States Mayors Conference in Houston.
Mr. Clinton badly needs such endorsements because the latest polls, including one by The New York Times and CBS News, show he is still running behind the President and Mr. Perot and slipping even further back in "favorability" ratings. Equally bad, the latest campaign finance figures show he is out of money and almost $4 million in debt.
Yet Mr. Clinton has seemed notably upbeat in recent weeks, and yesterday he said that things were going well, including fund-raising. He credited an intense round of national television appearances -- ABC kept him on the air for two hours -- and the release over the weekend of his new economic plan.
"It's all clearly tied to the strategy of directly communicating with the voters," he said yesterday afternoon in Washington at an appearance with Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan, one of the leading blacks in Congress. "It takes a long time to get known in this country, and I feel that I really started almost all over again two weeks ago. So I couldn't be more pleased with the last two weeks. The consensus around the country is that it's moving. I just need to keep hammering this plan, saying we've got to change things. I think we're going to win this race."
In his ABC television appearance and later in a series of interviews, Mr. Clinton said that if elected President he would present his economic plan to Congress immediately after taking office and demand quick action.
"I intend to have a legislative program ready on the desk of Congress on the day after I'm inaugurated," he added. "I intend to have an explosive 100-day action period."
He said later that he was confident he could get early action from Congress because the 1992 election would produce a Congress well aware of the electorate's deep frustration with inaction.
"The ones who get elected, or survive, are going to be elected on a promise to do something," he said. "They won't get elected unless they are committed to make and take new action."
Mr. Clinton acknowledged that major economic proposals he had touted earlier in the year were noticeably absent from his new economic plan or had been greatly modified. For example, a proposal made before the primaries to cut taxes on the middle class by 10 percent has been revised downward to about 5 percent.
He conceded such changes left him open to criticism, but he said that economic factors like deficit estimates and interest rates had changed and that he had changed accordingly.
The economy did not grow as fast as had been anticipated, he said, and so he cut back on the tax break for the middle class in order to save enough money to start up new programs to improve the nation's deteriorating highways, schools and communication systems. The improvements, he argued, would constitute "investments" that would get the country moving again economically and would correct neglect by the Reagan and Bush Administrations.
The new plan also calls for major new taxes on the wealthy and foreign corporations and cuts in a wide array of Federal programs that Mr. Clinton deems wasteful or unneeded.
"I said all along I was going to put out a plan early and would learn in the primary season and would revise as I went along," he said in a brief plane-side news conference at La Guardia Airport before flying to Washington for an overnight stop.

He stopped to talk with a group of demonstrators supporting mental health spending after appearing on the ABC News program "Good Morning America" in Manhattan. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Libyans' Patience With Qaddafi Ebbs

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRIPOLI, Libya, June 21

 BODY:
The large yellow ship that makes the overnight trip to Malta leaves Tripoli harbor crammed full of passengers, watched by couples and groups of young men strolling along the wide corniche that hugs the city's Mediterranean coastline. Behind them, strings of green and white carnival lights blink in the gathering dusk, casting a soft glow over the white fronts of the city's buildings.
The scene is tranquil, but the daily departure is a reminder that the ferry is one of the few links this country has with the outside world, foreign flights having been suspended under United Nations sanctions imposed in April. Not only has Libya become an international outcast, its economy is in shambles, its Government is in disarray, and many of its people are seething with resentment at the erratic 23-year rule of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. 
 "He is finished," said one young man on the corniche. "Now we just wonder when and how he will go."
The imposition of United Nations sanctions came after Libya's refusal to turn over two security agents who are suspected of involvement in the deaths of 441 people in the bombings of a Pan American World Airways jet over Scotland in 1988 and a French plane over Niger in 1989. The sanctions have pushed many Libyans, usually cowed by the secret police, to call for Colonel Qaddafi's removal.
"Probably 90 percent of the Libyan people favor a turning over of the two suspects to the United States," one Libyan official said.
But the related issues of Libyan Government-sponsored terrorism and the sanctions are only part of a long list of complaints.
 
Questions in Parliament
 The discontent has even come to the surface in the country's Parliament, normally a rubber stamp for Colonel Qaddafi's policies. When one woman stood up during the current session to complain that her region of the country was "economically deprived," she was silenced by the Secretary General, who told her that "there are no deprived areas in the great people's republic." She did not appear at the next day's session.
"Colonel Qaddafi is cornered," said one European Ambassador. "If he fulfills the United Nations sanctions, he can combat the growing discontent among the populace. But if he extradites the two suspects, the security apparatus, the very pillar of his rule, will turn on him."
Because of the sanctions, 1,700 Russian military and technical advisers have left the country. Western diplomats contend that without the Russian specialists who ran it, the country's air defense system has been severely crippled by the withdrawal.
Colonel Qaddafi's costly political and economic projects, like the drive to produce an army of one million out of a population of four million people, have eaten up the billions of dollars in revenues from the 1.1 million barrels of oil produced in this country every day.
Despite the large number of failed gradiose projects, like the vast steel works at Misurata and an effort to build a $25 billion artificial river, many Libyans live without basic services like water and sewer systems. Hospitals lack equipment and qualified staff. Schools teach from the Green Book, the collection of the Colonel's thoughts, but they have no desks or chalk. Postal and telephone services operate only sporadically.
 
Attendance Down at Protests
 Government orchestrated demonstrations, like one a few days ago in front of the Saudi Arabian Embassy, are able to draw only a few dozen people, most of whom stand passively in the baking sun while a few militants unleash tirades into a megaphone.
"All we talk about is how to get rid of Qaddafi," said a young man at the City Sports Club. "The best thing that could happen is that the United States bombed again, only this time managed to get him."
United States planes struck Libya in 1986 after Libya was implicated in the bombing of a German nightclub that killed two American servicemen.
Libya, because of the sanctions, has been stripped of 1,700 Russian military and technical military advisers. Western diplomats contend that the country's air defense system, manned by Russian specialists, has been severely crippled, if not rendered ineffective, by the withdrawal.
"He is in trouble," said one senior diplomat. "Maybe he won't go this year, but he does not have the hold on power he once had."

HEADLINE: Medical Waste Divides Mississippi Cities

BYLINE: By FRANCES FRANK MARCUS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PASCAGOULA, Miss.

 BODY:
Beyond the long sandy beaches of Mississippi's Gulf Coast, among the moss-draped oak trees of the region's eastern industrial edge, two old communities, predominantly white Pascagoula and mostly black Moss Point, have coexisted for years in relative peace.
But now an unusual fight is driving a wedge between the two, with one side accusing the other of "environmental racism." 
 Doctors and parents, churches and labor unions, Republicans and Democrats, blacks and whites, are all rallying against Pascagoula's decision late last year to allow the city's garbage incinerator to start burning medical wastes for profit. The wastes, up to 50 tons a day, would come from all over the region to Pascagoula's incinerator -- which is in Moss Point.
 
No Fuss When Built
 Pascagoula, population 25,678, and Moss Point, population 15,771, sit side by side in Jackson County. Pascagoula is the richer of the two, and when its residents objected to garbage-truck traffic, the city looked elsewhere for an incinerator site. There was no fuss in Moss Point when the incinerator was built by a now defunct French company that designed it. And when it opened in 1985, Moss Point was simply pleased to have its own garbage burned.
But seven years later, the incinerator is prompting concern about health risks that could be created by exhausting toxic wastes from the smokestack. Although the state is requiring that the incinerator be upgraded before it can start burning tons of medical wastes each day, opponents say that more than 12,000 people have signed petitions protesting the plan.
"I have no choice but to fight it," Mike Vice, a white Moss Point alderman, said at an opposition rally last month outside the Jackson County Courthouse. "I think the city of Pascagoula has forgotten this is a democracy."
 
'Environmental Racism'
 Deirdre S. Janney, executive director of the Mississippi Civil Liberties Union, told the rally, "It's a classic case of environmental racism."
In a telephone interview, Helen Hershkoff, the A.C.L.U.'s associate legal director, said, "We all know about the wrong side of the tracks. It's where we put our poor people and people of color. It's where we put our toxic wastes."
Ms. Hershkoff said the Moss Point case was "unique, because it is so stark in its presentation of the issue."
At the time the incinerator opened, financed by a low-interest, $6.9-million Federal loan to Pascagoula, the economics seemed sound. The heat generated by burning garbage is used to produce steam, which is sold to a nearby chemical plant at a rate that is tied to the price of natural gas.
Pascagoula planned to repay the loan with its profits. But soon after the plant opened, the price of natural gas collapsed and with it, the price of steam. Now the plant does not make enough money to pay even the interest.
"We've asked for forgiveness of the loan," said Melvin Mitchell, the Pascagoula City Attorney. "The U.S. Government would not agree, but they haven't foreclosed."
 
Secretive Action Claimed
 Many people here say Pascagoula intended to start burning the medical wastes before Moss Point could muster the forces to stop it.
"We were never officially notified about this," Mr. Vice said. "I don't know of another case where the rights of an entire city have been violated by the politicians of another."
Mr. Mitchell said there was nothing secretive about the decision to burn the wastes.
Mayor Tom Hewlett of Pascagoula says he is confident the burning of medical wastes will not be a health threat, adding, "We want that facility to be able to pay its debt service. It gives us some control of our destiny in being able to control our municipal wastes.
"We're at a point now where the costs of landfills are going to be exorbitant," Mayor Hewlett said. "And the nature of soils in this region limits the practicality of landfilling. The water table's real high; if you dig a hole someplace, it fills up with water.
Two lawsuits have been filed to block the burning of medical wastes, one by Jackson County Physicians and Citizens for a Healthy Environment, the other by the city of Moss Point. The Jackson County Board of Supervisors has agreed to join Moss Point's suit against the Mississippi Department of Environmental Quality.
The incinerator is near the Escatawpa River and within two-and-a-half miles of three public elementary schools, a junior high school, two church schools and several day-care centers. Nearby are homes with vegetable gardens and chicken coops.
The lower Escatawpa was a fishing hole for Moss Point until industrial pollution caused most of the fish to vanish long before the incinerator arrived. Thanks to clean-up measures that began in the early 1970's, the trout and bream are returning. But now, Mr. Vice said, "The mercury levels in the fish are beginning to climb because of the incinerator."
John Adams, a retired paper plant worker who lives near the incinerator, said he paid no attention to it "until it began to put out an awful odor and people began complaining about sinus problems." He did not protest when the incinerator was built nor when it began to smell, he said, but he is collecting signatures now to protest the plan to burn medical wastes.
Mr. Adams, who is white, sees the issue as a symbol of big business dumping on the powerless. "They pick out little towns like us that don't have any money to fight it," he said.
Despite the outcry, the Pascagoula City Council voted in December, 6-to-1 -- 6 whites against 1 black -- in favor of letting a Tennessee company, CFB Inc., which runs the incinerator, burn the medical wastes.
 
Hired a Chemist
 Moss Point tried to fight back, arranging for an expert to testify against the plan. But when the expert, Dr. Paul Connett, a chemistry professor at St. Lawrence University in Canton, N.Y., was unexpectedly unable to meet the March 17 deadline set by the State Department of Environmental Quality, the department denied an extension.
Dr. Connett spoke here anyway, a few days after the deadline, to 350 people who had gathered to hear him. He said that the widespread burning of medical wastes, which contain high amounts of plastics, was a national crisis.
He said that such burning released dioxins and similar compounds called furans, along with mercury and cadmium. The metals "emerge from the stack as gases, tiny particles that can penetrate deep down into the lungs," he said, adding that some of the particles would be captured in pollution-control devices, but that inevitably some would escape into the environment in waste water or fly ash.
Unpersuaded, Mr. Hewlett, the Pascagoula mayor, insisted that the incinerator posed no health threat and said that the city was going forward with its plans -- in Moss Point.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The decision of Pascagoula, Miss., to burn medical waste has stirred the residents of its normally neighborly neighbor, Moss Point, to anger. John Adams, who gathered signatures on petitions protesting the plan, said, "They pick out little towns like us that don't have any money to fight it." (Steven Frame for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Civilian Mission Is Proposed For Military After Cold War

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee today proposed using military engineers, medics and other specialists to help civilian agencies and private groups address problems of inner cities.
The chairman, Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, cited the Los Angeles riots when arguing that the routine training of specialized military units should be coordinated with specific needs of American cities. Combat engineers, for example, might rebuild bridges or schools as part of their instruction. Army National Guard instructors might assist job-training programs for inner-city youths. 
 Under the plan, the military's primary mission would remain national security. But in recognition of its growing role in relief and other nonmilitary missions as the cold war wanes, the Pentagon would change its training programs to provide or supplement assistance where private or Government services are lacking.
"By using the capabilities we have in the military, we can assist civilian authorities in addressing the critical fundamentals upon which a healthy society and economy are built," Mr. Nunn said in a speech on the Senate floor, in which he outlined his plan and solicited comments and criticisms.
 
Pentagon Declines Comment
 Lieut. Col. Doug Hart, a Defense Department spokesman, said the Pentagon would not comment until it had reviewed Mr. Nunn's proposal. Colonel Hart said the military, including the National Guard Bureau, already performs many civic services, but only those that other agencies or private groups cannot perform.
Other senior Defense Department officials said the Pentagon is unlikely to support broadening its responsibilities to include social services.
With the demise of the Soviet Union, Congress and Pentagon planners are mapping out new missions for the shrinking American armed forces. In recent years, for example, the Pentagon has become increasingly involved in fighting drug trafficking and providing humanitarian relief to refugees.
In his speech, and in an interview afterward, Mr. Nunn said that his program would be operated at the discretion of the Defense Department. He said the aim of the plan would be for individual military bases around the country to share their particular talents with the surrounding community.
 
Serving Communities' Needs
 "In each community, the military, private sector, labor unions and other agencies would decide where the voids were and where military training requirements might meet local needs," Mr. Nunn said in the interview.
Senate Republicans expressed interest in the plan, but like Pentagon officials, they wanted to examine its details.
"In a peacetime situation, it's fully appropriate that these forces be used to enhance human and physical resources," said Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana.
Private groups expressed keen interest in the proposal. The Rockefeller Foundation in New York City, for example, has financed two research grants for a military-based domestic youth training corps, a proposal included in Mr. Nunn's plan.
 
Skeptical Voices
 But some military and social policy analysts questioned whether the armed forces should assume a role perhaps better left to local, state or Federal agencies.
"You have to be careful and decide whether you want the military to be the last resort for humanitarian aid or a social-services agency," said Gordon Adams, director of the Defense Budget Project, an independent research organization here.
Mr. Nunn said he did not expect the plan to increase Pentagon spending.
Senate officials said the proposal might be deliberated as early as late July, when the Senate is to consider the military's $281 billion budget bill for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Finances;
Trailing in Polls, Clinton Campaign Falls Deeper in Debt

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
Trailing both Ross Perot and President Bush in public opinion polls, Gov. Bill Clinton reported today that his campaign fell deeper into debt last month and that it now owed an Arkansas bank almost $4 million.
The disclosure was another sign of how deeply Mr. Perot's independent candidacy has cut into Mr. Clinton's quest for the Presidency. 
 The latest figures, in a filing with the Federal Election Commission, show that at the end of last month the Clinton campaign had assumed an additional $1.2 million in debt and that it had cash on hand of $161,853.28, enough to buy about 10 minutes of prime-time television.
Mr. Clinton's money raisers say Mr. Perot's surge in opinion polls combined with the weak economy have discouraged donations. The primary campaign also took a heavy toll on Mr. Clinton's finances.
Even though the Arkansas Governor went into the June 2 California primary significantly ahead of his rivals in the delegate count and had all but locked up the nomination, he had to spend almost $1 million in California, most of it in May. The New York primary in April, his second most expensive race, cost $979,484.
And even though it was becoming clearer in May that he would be the party's nominee, Mr. Clinton raised $52,000 less in private contributions than in April.
In contrast, Mr. Bush's treasury grew by more than $1 million in May to nearly $8.2 million, and it is debt free.
Mr. Perot has said that he will spend $100 million or more from his personal multi-billion-dollar fortune and that he will take no taxpayer money to pay for his all-but-declared candidacy. Through May, Mr. Perot's campaign had spent almost $3.8 million, much of it donated or in the form of loans from Mr. Perot himself, according to a disclosure statement made public today.
Trailing in money-raising at this point in the election season is far from fatal, but it is a barometer of a campaign's condition. Four years ago this month, the campaign of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, with $3.6 million, held nearly twice as much money going into the conventions as Mr. Bush's campaign did that year.
After the national party conventions in July and August, the campaigns of Mr. Clinton and Mr. Bush will each receive $55.2 million from the Government for the general election campaign, and their parties will get $10.3 million each that can be spent for the conventions and the general election.
The loans for the Clinton campaign were taken from the Worthen National Bank of Little Rock, Ark. It is primarily owned by the Stephens family, an influential group that has helped Mr. Clinton raise money in his campaigns for Governor and has also contributed substantially to the Republicans.

HEADLINE: In Trial, M.I.T. to Defend Trading Student-Aid Data

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
It was the first week of April 1988, and officials from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the eight institutions of the Ivy League had gathered in Wellesley, Mass., for their annual rite of spring. They were deciding how much financial aid to offer about 3,000 students who had been accepted by more than one of their institutions.
A student accepted by both Cornell University and M.I.T. posed a fairly typical problem. Based on financial aid forms, Cornell figured that the student's family could afford to pay $12,249 of the roughly $20,000 annual tuition, room and board. M.I.T., where a year cost about the same, estimated the same student's family contribution at $13,550. 
 After a discussion that lasted no more than two minutes, the two financial aid officers got down to business. They split the difference. Cornell raised the student's family contribution to $13,000; M.I.T. matched it.
The same type of horse-trading went on for many of the 3,000 students on the universities' lists, just as it has every spring since the late 1950's. But was massaging the numbers illegal price-setting, or a way of stretching financial aid to as many students as possible?
That is the heart of an extraordinary trial about to start in Philadelphia tomorrow. M.I.T., and by extension the Ivy League, is accused of conspiring to violate antitrust laws, impeding competition and thereby denying students all the financial aid they might otherwise receive.
 
Vow to Fight Government
 The suit has already provided an intriguing glimpse into the inner workings of some of America's most honored institutions. While maintaining their innocence, the eight members of the Ivy League signed a consent decree last May in which they promised to discontinue the spring meetings and stop sharing information.
But M.I.T. called the Government's bluff. Institute officials refused to sign the decree, vowing that if M.I.T. had done nothing illegal, it had no reason to change its practices. Institute officials have argued that the suit by the Antitrust Division of the Justice Department will actually harm needy students, not help them.
While not a stated policy of M.I.T., a court victory could allow the university and the others to resume the spring meetings.
Many educators have praised M.I.T.'s tough stance, which they see as standing up to a kind of Government persecution. "I admire M.I.T. so much for fighting back," said David Riesman, a sociology professor at Harvard University and a respected authority on higher education. "They're defending an area where these institutions truly were doing something wonderful."
But preparing for the trial has already cost the institute almost $1 million, and the Government has shown no signs of backing down.
 
Confederation Challenged
 The Government's case involves the actions of the so-called Overlap Group, a loose confederation comprising the Ivy League members plus M.I.T. In contending that the Overlap Group unfairly restrained trade, the Government focused on the group's most sensitive practices:
*Agreeing to base financial aid awards on need, not on high grades or academic potential.
*Adopting uniform principles for determining financial need.
*Meeting regularly to discuss the financial situations of individual students.
M.I.T. acknowledges that these arrangements continued until 1990, when the Justice Department was in the middle of its investigation. But university officials say that the Government is applying antitrust laws blindly. The universities did not fix prices somehow to enhance their revenues, M.I.T. administrators argue; rather, they cooperated in the charitable act of providing financial aid.
"The effect of the overlap meetings was not to raise price, as is typically associated with price fixing," said Dennis W. Carlton, a University of Chicago economist, in an analysis he completed for M.I.T. and submitted to the court, "but rather to transfer dollars primarily from students with higher-income parents who would otherwise receive non-need-based aid to other students."
The reason for having the Overlap Group, M.I.T. court documents say, is to insure fairness in distributing financial aid. By awarding aid only to students who need it, the universities can spread their money further than if they gave merit scholarships based on academic performance.
Distributing financial aid uniformly also makes it possible for students to select the institution that best suits them over the one that offers the most money, university officials say.
Last year, 57 percent of M.I.T. students received financial aid. Twenty percent received merit-based scholarships from local civic groups, employers and others, according to institute officials. Only 20 percent of undergraduates paid full tuition.
M.I.T. argues that the Government's case is flawed because it allows the Ivies to continue to provide need-based athletic scholarships. Furthermore, the universities say, without the Overlap constraints they would eventually be forced into bidding wars to attract especially gifted students.
"We have no desire to get into bidding wars for 'stars,' " the former president of M.I.T., Paul E. Gray, is quoted as saying in the Government's trial papers.
Government lawyers point out that the Overlap universities are a Northeastern exception. Most universities do not restrict financial aid to need or share financial information.
Government lawyers also reject M.I.T.'s argument that antitrust laws do not apply to universities because they are nonprofit organizations. They said the Supreme Court has rejected numerous "social policy" justifications for price fixing in areas like bridge repair contracts or the costs of providing dental care. "M.I.T.'s defense that price fixing is necessary to achieve a social policy goal must also be rejected," the lawyers said in a court brief.
The trial, before Judge Louis C. Bechtle in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, is expected to last two weeks.


GRAPHIC: For about 30 years until 1990, nine universities, using a system called "overlap," determined the amount of money tat students and their parents would pay for a college education. These students, recently close to 3,000 each year, had been accepted by two or more of the universities using the overlap system and had requested financial aid form those institutions. The universities involved were the eight Ivy League colleges and universities -- Brown, Columbia, Cornell, Dartmouth, Harvard, Princeton, Yale, the University of Pennsylvania - and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. This is a simplified explanation of how the overlap system worked.
Chart: "What Happened Behind Closed Doors"
 1. A student, Jan Doe, applies to and is accepted by Cornell and M.I.T. With her application, she submits a request for financial aid. Financial aid applications are usually a combination of standard forms and the university's own.
 2. Each university puts the financial aid forms in a package that includes, among other things, data on Jane's assets, her parents' assets, notes from Jane's interviews with admissions officials or alumni, and sometimes Federal income tax returns. Her application to the colleges is kept separate.
 3. Each university then determines the portion of tuition that families and students must pay. Cornell, using the information it has gathered, deciees that Jane and her family will be responsible for $12,249 per year. M.I.T., using its data, decides on $13,550.
 4. Rosters are compiled by Student Aid Services, a for-profit corporation owned by the administrators of overlap colleges and universities. The rosters list the students who have been accepted by two or more of the overlap universities -- in Jane's case. Cornell and M.I.T. -- along with their financial aid packages.
 5. Financial aid officers from the nine universities meet in the spring for a two- to three-day session.
 6. The financial aid officers from all the universities to which a particular student's family contribution. The representatives either decide that their differences are negligible, negotiate a compromise or agree to disagree. Jane Doe is among the students discussed by officers from Cornell and M.I.T. The estimates of Jane Doe's family contribution differ by $1,301, enough to trigger a brief round of negotiations about how much financial aid she will be offered.
 7. After a two-to-three minute conversation, the two financial aid officers decide to split the difference and agree that Jane and her family will contribute $13,000 per year. The rest of the tuition at each university will be financed by some combination of grants and loans.
