HEADLINE: BUSH CALLS ON FED FOR ANOTHER DROP IN INTEREST

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
Showing election-year eagerness to speed up economic growth, President Bush urged the Federal Reserve today to lower interest rates further, saying the central bank was wrong to worry that such a reduction would fuel inflation.
"I'd like to see another lowering of interest rates," the President said in an interview with The New York Times. "I think there's room to do that. I can understand people worrying about inflation. But I don't think that's the big problem now." 
 His call for the Federal Reserve to lower rates was by far his strongest jawboning statement this year on interest rates and shows the President's frustration over the slow recovery of the nation from its longest postwar recession.
 
Differing Views on Inflation
 The President's new pressure on the central bank comes after the Federal Reserve's governors signaled in recent weeks that they believed no further easing was needed because the economy was picking up steam. In recent interviews, several of the governors said they worried that the potential inflation danger from further rate cuts outweighed the need for added stimulus.
But in his remarks today, the President disagreed with their economic calculus. "I think inflation appears to be pretty well under control," he said. "I don't think the argument that lowering the rates will stimulate the long-term -- shoot the long-term rates up -- is valid anymore. And so, yes, I'd like to see it come down."
The Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, would not respond to Mr. Bush's comments.
But in recent interviews, Federal Reserve officials said they feared that further cuts in short-term rates could push up long-term rates because investors might conclude that the Federal Reserve was not going to be tough in cracking down on inflation.
Various Federal Reserve officials have contended that reducing long-term rates is crucial for strengthening economic growth because home mortgages, home building and capital investment are largely influenced by long-term rates.
Administration officials have been encouraged by several economic reports, including the increase in industrial production and housing starts in May. But they were disappointed by the jump in the unemployment rate to 7.5 percent in May, even though they asserted that it resulted principally from more people returning to the labor force because they were encouraged by improved conditions.
In recent months, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, have spoken more gingerly than the President did today, often suggesting in speeches that the Federal Reserve should lower rates if the recovery falters.
President Bush's remarks did not have such hedging. While noting that he wanted "to be a little careful about Fed bashing," he said, "I don't know of any President that would like to advocate higher interest rates, and certainly I'm not one." He added that he would like to "see them as low as they can possibly be."
 
Frustration Over Perceptions
 The President also expressed frustration that most Americans believed the economy was still declining even though he said statistics showed that it was growing. His approval ratings have dropped sharply since the Persian Gulf war, largely because, White House officials acknowledge, the recovery from a prolonged recession has been so slow and weak.
A New York Times/CBS News Poll of 1,029 registered voters nationwide, conducted June 17 to June 20, found that 78 percent disapproved of the way the President was handling the economy.
The President's argument that inflation is so low that the Federal Reserve can reduce rates received some indirect support from Congressional testimony last week by Mr. Greenspan.
The Federal Reserve chairman said, "The U.S. economy has made considerable progress toward price stability over the past decade, trimming the core rate of inflation to below 4 percent, and it appears poised to make further advances."
But, seeking to nudge long-term rates lower, Mr. Greenspan vowed to remain vigilant, adding that the Federal Reserve "fully intends to guard against reigniting inflation."
The Federal Reserve last lowered rates on April 9, reducing the Federal funds rate -- the rate at which banks lend money to each other overnight -- to 3.75 percent from 4 percent. That put short-term interest rates at their lowest level in two decades. At the time, Federal Reserve officials said they worried that the weak growth in the money supply could slow, and perhaps even reverse, the recovery.
The central bank cut rates more aggressively on Dec. 20, lowering the Federal funds rate to 4 percent from 4.5 percent, and reducing the discount rate -- the rate at which the Federal Reserve lends money to banks -- by a full percentage point, to 3.5 percent from 4.5 percent. At that time, the central bankers were worried that the recovery had stalled and they faced private pressures from the Administration to ease monetary policy.
 
A Crucial Committee
 Federal Reserve officials say that at the May 19 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee -- the main policy-setting group -- the central bankers decided to adopt a neutral policy, favoring neither easing nor tightening. Before that meeting, the committee had adopted a policy in favor of easing.
Many economists say they doubt that the central bank will ease rates in the near future, partly because it might appear that policy makers were bowing to political pressures.
Some economists say that because several Federal Reserve governors remain concerned about continued slow growth in the money supply, there remains a chance that the Open Market Committee might decide to ease further at its meeting next Tuesday and Wednesday.
The Bush Administration has frequently looked to the Federal Reserve to ease monetary policy as a means of stimulating growth because the huge budget deficit has limited the Administration's ability to use traditional pump-priming measures like tax cuts or increased spending.
More than 100 prominent economists, including 6 Nobel Prize winners, have urged the White House and Congress to speed growth by spending $50 billion more a year in public investment projects, like building roads. But Administration officials have said such a plan could worsen the deficit and spur inflation.

HEADLINE: Yields Lower On C.D.'s and Bank Funds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit moved lower for the week that ended today, according to The Bank Rate Monitor.
Analysts at the interest rate publication note that the steady erosion of bank yields indicate that there has been no substantial start to economic recovery. 
 "Without loan demands there is no need for banks to go out to drum up fresh deposits to replace cash that would ordinarily have been lent out," said Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor. "If the economy were to pick up, you'd see loans rise and bank deposit yields not far behind."
At Monday's closely watched auction of new three- and six-month Treasury bills, where many interest rate watchers view the results as a good barometer of what many banks could be paying their depositors in the weeks ahead, the average discount rates inched up after a four-week downward trend.
The average rate on a three-month bill was 3.66 percent, up a basis point from the previous auction, while the six-month bill was up 2 basis points, to 3.77 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Over all, returns at New York area banks were off slightly again, with a money market account down 2 basis points, to 3.36 percent; a three-month certificate of deposit off a basis point, to 3.49 percent, and a six-month certificate off 3 basis points, to 3.64 percent.
Commercial banks, which are part of the New York area average, were a little less aggressive this week than their savings-bank competitors. Commercial banks lowered the average money market account by 2 basis points, to 3.14 percent, and the average yield of three- and six-month C.D.'s was down a basis point, to 3.34 percent and 3.43 percent, respectively.
The higher-paying savings banks cut their money market accounts by a basis point, to 3.59 percent and their three-month certificate by 2 basis points, to 3.64 percent. Most of the deep cuts were in the six-month certificate, which dropped 4 basis points, to 3.86 percent.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Narrowly Mixed

BYLINE: BY KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed and interest rates little changed yesterday as dealers placed bids at a record $15 billion auction of new two-year notes.
Prices of securities outstanding fell slightly in trading before the 1 P.M. auction, and the dip proved sufficient to stimulate good demand for the new notes.
The securities were sold at an average yield of 5.11 percent, down a touch from the 5.13 percent average yield at the last two-year note auction on May 20. 
 It is the lowest yield on a two-year note since the Jan. 22 auction, when the notes were sold at an average yield of 4.99 percent.
"The two-year was given an excellent reception, which shows there is still some buying power in the market as the second quarter comes to a close," said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds.
 
Banks Active Bidders
 Mr. Sullivan and others said commercial banks were active bidders, continuing a trend that began more than a year ago.
"There is a lot of interest in short-term securities," one government-bond trader said. "The fact that noncompetitive tenders totaled $1.3 billion at the auction shows that."
Dealers were only a tad less optimistic about the prospects for today's sale of $10.5 billion of new five-year notes.
"The five-year is a little bit harder," the trader said, "but there is so much interest in that sector that it should go well."
Late yesterday the five-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 6.47 percent, compared with 6.45 percent late Monday.
Aside from the auction, trading activity was influenced by comments from Finance Minister Domingo Cavallo of Argentina, who suggested to reporters in New York that his country, as part of its debt-restructuring agreement, might be more inclined to buy 30-year zero-coupon bonds directly from the Treasury than in the open market.
Those remarks pushed down prices of long-term Treasury issues slightly.
 
Rebound in Sales
 So too did a survey of chain-store sales by Johnson Redbook showing that sales for the first three weeks of June were up by 2 percent from May, a sharp turnaround from the 4.5 percent decline reported for the first two weeks of the month.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 10125/32, down 3/32, to yield 7.84 percent, compared with 7.83 percent late Monday.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 10129/32, unchanged on the day, to yield 7.22 percent. And the 5 7/8 percent three-year notes were offered at 1012/32 up 1/32, to yield 5.47 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates rose modestly.
Three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 3.66 percent, up one basis point, or one one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 3.76 percent.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, the Louisiana Land and Exploration Company offered $100 million of unsecured 10-year notes through an underwriting group led by Morgan Stanley & Company.
The 8 1/4 percent notes were priced at $100, or par, a percentage point over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The noncallable securities are rated Baa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
United Illuminating Issue
 Morgan Stanley also acted as lead manager for an offering of $100 million worth of five-and-a-half-year notes for United Illuminating, a utility based in New Haven.
The noncallable 7 3/8 percent securities mature Jan. 15, 1998, and were priced at $99.511 to yield 7.483 percent, a percentage point over the prevailing when-issued yield on the new five-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
The notes are rated Baa-3 by Moody's and BBB- by Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, participants said that prices of most widely quoted issues were unchanged in slow trading.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of two-year Treasury notes:

HEADLINE: Nordstrom in No-Frills Arena

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
In the department store world, the Nordstrom name is synonymous with service. During a rainstorm, a shopper may duck into a store in search of waterproof boots only to leave with new heel taps on the shoes on her feet, too, at no charge.
Now, Nordstrom Inc. is about to try its hand at a completely different retail game -- what the industry calls the off-price business. Off-price stores sell brand-name merchandise at discounts of as much as 75 percent, as opposed to discount stores like Wal-Mart that for the most part sell high volumes of less expensive merchandise. 
 Stepping into the no-frills arena might seem an odd choice for a retailer that has refused to put merchandise on sale regularly. But as department store sales stagnate, the Seattle-based retailer has had to look elsewhere to continue the rapid pace of expansion it set in the 80's. And its entry into the off-price business is further indication that the budget-conscious consumer has come of age.
 
Price Becomes the Key
 "Less is the populist thing to do," said Paul Hunter, a Nordstrom vice president who conceived of the Nordstrom Rack, the company's chain of highly lucrative closeout stores that are the source of the new off-price concept. "The whole off-price business is expanding exponentially, driven by the consumer that has become sensitive to budgets and cost-consciousness and will probably stay that way."
Indeed, sales of apparel in off-price stores grew at a compounded annual rate of 15 percent from 1986 through 1990, compared with 6 percent for total retail sales and total general- merchandise sales, according to a report by Alex. Brown & Sons, a Baltimore-based investment company. Robert Buchanan, a retail analyst at Alex. Brown, estimates that about 5 percent of the $200 billion Americans spend on apparel each year goes to off-price stores.
 
Service Is Expensive
 Also motivating Nordstrom's new venture is the high price of delivering the kind of intensive service it built its reputation on, particularly as retailing sales have leveled off and profits have dwindled.
"Like everyone else, we're faced with the fact that the cost of doing business is growing faster than sales," said John A. Goesling, the earnest and solemn chief financial officer whose plainspokenness epitomizes the culture of Nordstrom's upper echelons. "But unlike everyone else, if we cut any more, we might cut into what we are and do irreparable damage to our service culture."
Jim Nordstrom, co-chairman of the family-run business, elaborated on that idea in an interview at company headquarters: "The more high-end the merchandise, the more it takes to sell it, so you have to have salespeople to drive those sales. That means higher operating costs, which is something we can't afford right now but also something we can't sacrifice in our existing business."
 
A Surprise Announcement
 The announcement of Nordstrom's new strategy came casually. Mr. Nordstrom jolted the retail community -- and most of his siblings, in-laws and offspring who populate various rungs of the corporate ladder -- when, in an off-the-cuff remark at the company's recent annual meeting, he said Nordstrom planned to open two stores a la Loehmann's and Filene's Basement sometime this year. Still, Mr. Nordstrom says that it is just an experiment and that the press has made too much of it.
The two off-price stores, which will probably not have an overt link to the Nordstrom name, will show up later this year in areas far enough away from Nordstrom's existing stores to avoid cannibalizing their business. They will carry some of the same brand-name merchandise as the regular Nordstrom stores, though the goods will be there later in the season. The discounts will be 20 to 70 percent off the regular Nordstrom price. And the staff, Mr. Nordstrom says, will cater less to customers than in the regular stores.
Nordstrom's clearance merchandise will continue to go to the Racks closeout stores; the new stores will offer goods bought expressly for them.
Nordstrom has been one of the few retailers making a concerted effort to maintain its prices, refusing to mark down clothes to increase volume, and at times it has paid the price. Refusing to hold sales, it eventually had to ship unsold goods to its closeout stores, which cut its profit margins. Through the Racks and the new off-price format, Nordstrom hopes to have it both ways.
"This is a hedge that can be a good thing for them," said Cynthia Cohen Turk of Marketplace 2000, a retail consulting firm in Coral Gables, Fla. "They're figuring that, net-net, they probably won't do badly in both price segments at the same time."
Ms. Turk said the off-price stores would also increase the company's influence with suppliers, who will get bigger orders, and will aid Nordstrom's own cost efficiency in shipping. Nordstrom will also be able to buy more opportunistically, taking manufacturers' overruns and canceled or returned orders that would not normally find a home in its stores.
Nordstrom's is not the first chain to try this strategy. In 1987, Bealls, a Florida department store chain selling moderately priced goods, opened off-price stores selling brand-name goods at an average price of $8.
Even as the Bealls department-store business has lost momentum because shopping center builders lack financing for development, the company's 65 outlet stores have been selling $75 million of goods annually and making a handsome profit, said Robert M. Beall, the company's president.
"Your investment and your risk is a lot lower, because with a five-year lease at a good rate in a strip center, if you don't do well, you can just pick up and leave at very little cost," he said.
 
Sticking to What They Know
 In 1984, Bealls tried a chain of outlet stores that sold higher-priced goods but scrapped the plan after it decided it did not really know how to sell more expensive merchandise. It took the idea in a different direction.
"I think the off-price business may be headed for a little bit of a shakeout," Mr. Beall said. "But given the economy and a whole feeling by people that they just don't want to pay retail prices, I think it's still a good idea."
While off-price operations will help Nordstrom cut costs, Mr. Buchanan of Alex. Brown said the company already had a fairly lean expense structure, spending about 25 percent of its total sales to pay salaries and other administrative expenses.
"Given the way their stores look and the service level they provide, they're very productive for the high end," he said. "They can't shave too much more off their regular business, so off-price doesn't seem like a bad idea."
 
Target of Lawsuits
 Nordstrom, some charge, has used a compensation plan that has allowed it to keeps expenses low. The company has been named in two class-action lawsuits in recent years, charging that its managers encouraged employees to work extra hours without pay to meet sales goals and provide customers with the vaunted service. The lawsuits are pending. Litigation analysts say the suits are unlikely to affect the bottom line, but Nordstrom has established a $15 million reserve for wage claims to redress the problems. By the end of 1991, it had paid about $3 million to employees making claims.
The company sees an additional benefit to its nascent off-price business. Its expansion in regional shopping malls across the country has been impeded by the difficulties developers are having in getting financing. And Nordstrom's proposals to open stores are facing increasing opposition from its competitors, who are filing lawsuits and environmental complaints that delay the company's expansion plans, said David Mackie, vice president for real estate.
The May Department Stores Company, for example, has opposed Nordstrom's plans to rebuild its store in the Washington Square mall in Portland, Ore., saying the project would cause parking and other traffic problems. Woodward & Lothrop filed a complaint when Nordstrom said it would open a store in Annapolis, Md.
"Most of these delaying tactics are simply that, but walking away becomes a possibility when you consider the time and legal costs," Mr. Mackie said. "We don't like it because it lessens our already constrained opportunities."
Some analysts contend that real estate issues are simply a smokescreen that Nordstrom is using while it slows expansion to reassess and refine its strategy. In 1988, Nordstrom was a regional chain with 53 stores in the West. Since then, while other retailers were closing stores or halting growth, Nordstrom has added 15 stores, a 28.3 percent increase.
 
Basis for Expansion
 Having stores outside the Western region has helped mitigate the harm from the economic downturn in California, where about half of Nordstrom's stores are. "People have criticized us for expanding in a down economy and for our decentralized operations, but it means that when we make a mistake in one region or when the economy is worse in one part of the country, it doesn't hurt us quite as much," Mr. Nordstrom said.
The company will open a Nordstrom in the Mall of America outside Minneapolis later this summer, and another store in Freehold, N.J., in August. It has plans for opening a few others in the next year.
Mr. Nordstrom acknowledged that the company had dragged its feet on technology but he said most computer systems designed for retailers worked to centralize inventory and accounting functions -- antithetical to Nordstrom's decentralized culture.
At Nordstrom, each region or cluster of stores makes its own buying and planning decisions, a strategy that analysts generally praise. Other retailers, including the Dillard Department Stores Company and Federated Department Stores Inc., have used technology to consolidate buying and planning, which sharply cuts expenses but eliminates some individuality as well.
Nordstrom is testing a system it designed in one of its divisions, and Galen Jefferson, one of the company's four co-presidents, said she was seeing benefits like improved inventory management and sales analysis.
"The key reason for doing it is that it has enhanced customer service," she said. "Others invested in technology to save costs; we've invested in it to support our salespeople and increase their ability to serve the customer, not to replace them."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed on Quiet Day; Gold Is Higher Worldwide

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed yesterday in light, uneventful dealings on world currency markets.
Gold prices advanced worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $344.50 a troy ounce, up 80 cents from Monday. The Republic National Bank said gold added 90 cents an ounce, to a late bid price of $344.10. 
 Traders began selling the dollar sporadically in foreign markets overnight. When activity shifted to domestic markets, many were inclined to take profits in the wake of the dollar's advance in the previous session.
Sentiment toward the United States currency has been bearish recently as traders turn their attention toward Europe. Speculation about the ultimate success of European political and economic union has dominated trading.
 
No Fundamental Reason
 The dollar gained ground in a rare across-the-board showing on Monday, but not for any fundamental reason.
"People are just waiting for more impetus to trade," said Kevin Lawrie, director of foreign exchange at the Bank of Boston.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 126.96 yen, down 0.51 yen from Monday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 127.10 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 127.28 yen, up from 127.15 yen on Monday.
In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.8620, up from $1.8615 late Monday. In New York it cost $1.8625 to buy one pound, more expensive than Monday's $1.8615.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.5660 German marks, down from 1.5665; 1.4175 Swiss francs, up from 1.4155; 5.2710 French francs, down from 5.2750; 1,184.00 Italian lire, down from 1,184.50, and 1.1968 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1946.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.5650 German marks, down from 1.5665; 1.4150 Swiss francs, up from 1.4050; 5.2710 French francs, down from 5.2725; 1.7635 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7645; 1,184.00 Italian lire, unchanged, and 1.1965 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1945.
Gold traded in London at $344.35 an ounce, up from $342.40 bid late Monday. In Zurich, gold rose to $343.80 an ounce from $342.10. In Hong Kong, gold rose $1.41 an ounce to close at $343.68.

HEADLINE: Pass the Spelt. A Little Ketchup With Your Algae?

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
PEOPLE who eat strange foods like blue-green algae and spelt bread may seem like eccentrics who have nothing to do with ordinary Americans who toss burgers on the grill at night.
But avant-garde eaters often serve as a testing ground for innovative foods, and what they like to eat now may be the trendy new food on the kitchen tables of mainstream eaters tomorrow. After all, foods that now appeal to millions of people, like yogurt, granola bars and rice cakes, were once favored by fringe eaters and available only in natural-foods stores. 
 It is hard to say which unusual products will be the next foods to find their way into ordinary supermarkets. But suppliers and retailers say certain foods are selling so well that they may eventually have wide enough appeal to interest the big food companies.
The impulse driving sales in natural-foods stores is an enduring one: the desire for health and long life. But unlike 20 years ago, there now are vast numbers of people of diverse economic means who are simultaneously discovering that mortality is not an abstract concept.
"There's a wave of baby boomers hitting the big 40, and their bodies are talking back," said John Goodman, the vice president for sales and marketing for Arrowhead Mills in Hereford, Tex., which makes organic grains, cereals, breads, flours and baking mixes. They are looking for foods that might help them live better and longer, he added, and they are looking outside the mainstream.
To that end, sales are booming in foods that are fat free, or free of ingredients like milk and wheat that cause allergic reactions in many people. Organic ingredients are sought after, too, because many people consider them to be tastier, healthier and more ecological. Selling very well, too, are Chinese herbal and homeopathic remedies, said Frank J. Lampe, the editor of Natural Foods Merchandiser, a trade journal published by New Hope Communications in Boulder, Colo.
But customers in natural-foods stores are also affected by the same forces that shape supermarket shoppers. Busy and not always willing to cook, they are seeking convenience, but with a twist: they are snapping up prepared products, both frozen and on the shelf, made of organic and natural ingredients, even if they are slightly more expensive than their mainstream counterparts.
Manufacturers of natural foods, previously unsophisticated in the art of marketing, are now much more attuned to convenience and packaging. "They are starting to think like big companies," said Kathy Ordan, the director of marketing for the Fresh Fields natural-foods stores in the Washington, D.C., area. Even cooking accessories are being made in natural but convenient forms. Fresh Fields, for instance, is selling charcoal made from wood in an instant, easy-to-light form with none of the chemicals found in the usual instant-light charcoal.
Despite a concern with health, many people are not willing to give up snacks. "Chips and popcorn and permutations thereof have gone bonkers," said Chris Kilham, a consultant to natural-foods companies. "It's like walking down the snack aisle of a regular supermarket, but all the ingredients are good." Aside from organic blue-corn tortilla chips and organic air-popped popcorn, there are yogurt and green-onion potato chips made from unpeeled potatoes, and cheese puffs made from natural blue cheese and cheddar. Also flourishing are popcorn cakes, a new product similar to rice cakes.
Cookies are also doing well, especially those by Health Valley, an Irwindale, Calif., company that makes a variety of natural foods. It has 19 varieties of cookies described as fat free, including flavors like raisin oatmeal and apple cinnamon. (Although they are labeled as fat free, that is accurate only for each serving, not for an entire package. One serving, or three cookies, contains less than 1 gram of fat.)
Retailers said the quest to avoid foods that may cause allergic reactions is one of the largest factors affecting sales. "More and more people who haven't felt good in a long time are finding that their doctors are telling them to give up wheat or milk," said Cate Conniff, the food-information manager for the six Bread and Circus natural-foods stores in Massachusetts and Rhode Island.
Shoppers can find pizza made with soy instead of mozzarella, ice cream made with rice instead of cream and bread and cereals made with grains other than wheat.
Two of the most rapidly growing alternatives to wheat are spelt and triticum polonicum, popularly known as Kamut. Both are ancient grains in the wheat family with a slightly different chemical structure that makes them easier to digest for wheat-sensitive people. Arrowhead Mills introduced Kamut cereal six months ago and expects annual sales this year to be more than 360,000 boxes, a lot for a new organic cereal.
Rudi's, a bakery in Boulder, came out with a spelt bread last October, and it is now the company's leading national line. The company, which has increased production from 1,000 loaves of spelt bread a month to 10,000 loaves, recently started making bagels and hot-dog and hamburger buns with spelt.
There has also been a profusion of wheat-free pastas and grain mixes, with choices now available in rice and spelt, as well as other ancient grains like quinoa and amaranth. To some extent, they appeal to those who simply seek variety.
Although the allergy connection has fueled the surge in nondairy alternative products, there is also a broader health goal: the reduction of fat and cholesterol. In most cases, the ingredient that substitutes for dairy products is soy. "Soy-milk sales were up 40 percent last year," said Richard Youngman, the president of Stow Mills, a distributor in Chesterfield, N.H., that sells to more than 2,000 stores in the East. Also booming are soy products like burgers, hot dogs, chili, sloppy Joes and cold cuts.
But some of the big-selling nondairy alternatives are made with rice, like Rice Dream frozen desserts and beverages.
These products also appeal to a growing number of people interested in vegetarian dishes, especially those who want to send their children to school with lunches that do not contain meat but also do not saddle them with the label of peculiar food.
"Kids are ostracized if they pull out something that is obviously tofu," said Ms. Conniff, of Bread and Circus.
In new natural-foods stores, the allocation of space makes it clear which areas are growing: there is much more space for frozen foods, where shoppers can now find healthy versions of typical American foods. "Prepared dinners do very well," said Spencer Brown, who manages Integral Yoga, a natural-foods store in Manhattan that once carried almost no convenience foods. Selling especially well, many retailers said, are organic potpies and lasagna made by Amy's; Indian dinners made by Taj; pizzas without cheese, like Original Rice Crust Pizza and Pizsoy, and Veggie Pockets, enchiladalike sandwiches.
Also popular are convenient foods sold on shelves, like cereals, organic canned tomatoes and juice blends, especially those with rain-forest ingredients -- juices from fruits that are grown in Central and South American rain forests, like guanabana, guava and star fruit.
Retailers are also expanding bulk-bin space for customers more concerned about price. "Economics has got something to do with it," said Mary Harvat, the director of purchasing for Texas Health Distributors, which sells primarily to the Whole Foods Markets chain. Bulk sales provide savings by eliminating packaging and advertising.
But what about that blue-green algae? Some products in natural-foods stores are still considered fringe items, even if they are selling better than a few years ago. One such category, green food, includes algae that supposedly provide energy and strengthen immune systems.
"Five years ago, I only carried one green food," said Richard Antonelli, the sales manager for Cornucopia Inc., a wholesaler in Dayville, Conn. Now he sells tens of thousands of dollars worth of green foods; his newest offering is Klamath Blue Green Algae, harvested by Klamath Blue Green in Mount Shasta, Calif., from a lake in southern Oregon.
But algae is still a very specialized food. Environmentalists need not worry yet that avid algae-eaters will upset the ecological balance.
 
AVANT-GARDE GROCERIES
 THESE are some of the foods gaining popularity in natural-foods stores.
AMARANTH: An ancient high-protein grain with a woodsy flavor that was popular with the Aztecs and is used in a number of cereals and breads.
GREEN FOOD: A category that includes supplements made from various grasses and algae. The manufacturers say they are high in beta-carotene and improve mental and physical functioning.
KAMUT: This is the name given by Bob Quinn to an ancient wheatlike grain. His family's company, Montana Flour and Grains in Big Sandy, Mont., is the main grower and promoter of Kamut. Mr. Quinn picked the name because he believed it was the ancient Egyptian word for wheat -- but later found out that it was not. Kamut has more protein than regular wheat.
QUINOA: An ancient Incan grain with complete protein, quinoa has a slightly nutty flavor.
RAIN-FOREST INGREDIENTS: Fruits that are grown in Central and South American rain forests, like guanabana, guava and star fruit, are especially popular now in juice blends.
SPELT: An ancient grain in the wheat family, it can be tolerated by many people who are sensitive to the more common strain of wheat.

HEADLINE: Chamber Society Seeks Lost Listeners

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN

 BODY:
There is one point on which everyone connected with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center agrees: the 23-year-old organization, once one of the New York music world's biggest success stories, is in the market for a miracle. In the three years since the retirement of the society's charismatic founding director, Charles Wadsworth, ticket sales have dropped by at least 30 percent.
The drop has been ascribed variously to changes in the society's roster made by Fred Sherry, Mr. Wadsworth's successor, and to Mr. Sherry's aggressive programming of contemporary music. Although the performances earned generally enthusiastic reviews, the audience did not return, and after Mr. Sherry's first season, the society cut back on the number of concerts it gave. Last year, Mr. Sherry announced that he would stay on as a cellist with the society but that he would not continue as director when his three-year term ended. 
 At the society's spacious new offices in the Samuel B. and David Rose Building at Lincoln Center, the hope is that Mr. Sherry's newly appointed successor, the clarinetist David Shifrin, will lure back former subscribers and attract new listeners. But the consensus in musical circles is that he is facing a formidable challenge, and that in addition to hostilities that may remain from Mr. Sherry's tenure, the society must now face the consequences of its own success.
 
Innovations and Competition
 "They represent an important new kind of organizational and artistic structure within the chamber-music world," said Dean Stein, the executive director of Chamber Music America, a service organization for small ensembles. "They showed that there was an alternative to the traditional kind of chamber group, which is a permanent touring ensemble with fixed instrumentation. And they became a model that many organizations around the country have replicated."
But the replication also occurred on the Chamber Music Society's doorstep. Merkin Concert Hall, which opened at the end of 1979, quickly became a home for new chamber groups. Chamber music flourished at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Frick Collection, and the 92d Street Y started its own series, directed by Jaime Laredo, who was once a violinist in the Chamber Music Society.
Lincoln Center itself has been competing with its resident society by presenting touring chamber-music groups in its Great Performers series, and Carnegie Hall has added chamber music to its programming. And this year the French Institute/ Alliance Francaise started a chamber-music series at its four-year-old Florence Gould Hall.
The society's own success may have spawned a level of competition that has outpaced the appetite of the chamber-music market, particularly in a recession. But the problem of maintaining an audience has not been universal.
"In terms of subscription renewal and ticket sales, the chamber-music audience is the most loyal audience we have, and we don't seem to have seen the effects of either the recession or the crowded field," said Raymond T. Grant, the director of the Tisch Center for the Arts at the 92d Street Y.
Mr. Shifrin's term does not officially begin until July 1, but he has already started grappling with the audience problem he has inherited. In programming the 1992-93 season, his first response to the dwindling subscription figures has been to soften the society's repertory. With a budget of about $2 million at his disposal, he has outlined a season heavily weighted with repertory staples and light on new music.
"What I would like to do with the Chamber Music Society is present a survey of the great literature, representative of all periods and all instrumental combinations," Mr. Shifrin said. "There are certain works -- the Mozart string quintets, the Brahms quintets and sextets, the Mendelssohn Piano Trios and the Beethoven Septet, for example -- that should be looked at over the course of five years, and then repeated."
Music of the 20th century has not been exiled entirely. But except for a few premieres, the season's 20th-century offerings are drawn from the list of modern works that have found their way into the standard repertory.
"I'm doing somewhat less contemporary music than Fred did," Mr. Shifrin said. "I would like to leave a certain area of new music to groups like Speculum Musicae, Music Today, the New York New Music Ensemble and the others that specialize in it. That's not to say that we won't commission new works or play new music. But I don't feel the Chamber Music Society needs to be a proving ground."
New music and premieres have always been an important component of the society's programming, and Mr. Sherry did not present a great deal more of it than Mr. Wadsworth had. The difference was in presentation and, to a degree, in style. Mr. Sherry was more attracted than Mr. Wadsworth to atonal and Serial music, and where Mr. Wadsworth tended to include new works in mostly standard programs, Mr. Sherry often grouped contemporary works. Mr. Shifrin's approach to new music seems more conservative than that of both his predecessors.
Mr. Shifrin, who is 42 years old, joined the society in 1989. He grew up in New York City and has been principal clarinetist with several orchestras, including the Cleveland Orchestra and the Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra. Since 1980 he has been director of Chamber Music Northwest, a summer festival in Portland, Ore., which he says he patterned after the Chamber Music Society. Mr. Shifrin won his new job when the Chamber Music Society board scanned the first 10 seasons of his Portland programming and decided that they were safely in the mainstream.
Whether accessible programming alone will help him overcome the problems of recent seasons is a question on which few in the music business are willing to comment. Both managers and musicians refuse to speak critically of the society on the record, for fear of losing high-profile engagements with the group. But some point out that there may still be resentment about Mr. Sherry's decision to replace some of the society's original members with younger musicians. On this topic, Mr. Wadsworth leaped to his successor's defense.
"There was a serious misperception about what happened," Mr. Wadsworth said. "Some of the changes Fred made were changes I had considered myself. I told some of the players that I was unhappy. But I felt a strong personal obligation to some of the musicians who had been there the first 20 years, and I chose to let them round out the time. That was probably my mistake, which Fred paid for."
Charles Kargacos, the society's executive director, said he hoped that subscribers who left to protest the roster changes would return now that Mr. Shifrin is taking over.
"Certainly Fred was a recipient of a great deal of ill will, fairly or unfairly," Mr. Kargacos said, "but David comes without any of the taint of that time."
Mr. Kargacos added that in the few weeks the society's glitzy new brochures have been available, subscriptions have been selling more briskly than at this time a year ago, and he is projecting a 10 percent increase in sales. Ticket income has risen as well, although that is partly because prices have been raised. This year, a 12-concert series cost $180; next season, it will cost $215. A four-concert series is going from $80 to $95.
But even the increase of 10 percent Mr. Karcagos projects will not return the society to the sold-out status it enjoyed during Mr. Wadsworth's tenure. And some critics have wondered whether the society's problems may be a sign that it has outlived its original purpose.
When Mr. Wadsworth started the society in 1969, the chamber-music literature -- with the exception of the string quartet repertory -- was a poorly traveled byway in American concert life. By convening a flexible ensemble, augmented by starry guest musicians, Mr. Wadsworth helped push the music into the mainstream, an effort often credited with precipitating the chamber-music boom of the early 1980's.
That boom has taken on a life of its own, however, and with so many ensembles, both permanent and temporary, exploring the mixed-timbre repertory, the Chamber Music Society sometimes seems to need a new sense of mission.
Mr. Shifrin, for one, said he does not see it that way. "I think all the imitation and replication bears out this organization's usefulness," he said. "We're in the position of being in the biggest arts center in the country, and being the organization chartered by that center to play the chamber-music repertory. We have the distinction of being the primary resident of Alice Tully Hall, which I have always considered one of the best places to play chamber music. And we have the resources to go after the finest performers and put on the best performances of the best music. I feel like a kid in a candy shop."

HEADLINE: Food Notes

BYLINE: By Florence Fabricant

 BODY:

A New Bakery in Town
If the turquoise trim on the brick storefront at 672 Ninth Avenue (46th Street) that houses Amy's Bread is not arresting enough, the sumptuous display of breads in the window should do the trick. This new wholesale-and-retail bakery specializes in unusual, attractively shaped breads, many seasoned with olive oil, herbs, raisins, bits of olive, copious sprinklings of nuts and rich whole grains.
The owner, Amy Scherber, who is 32 years old and largely self taught, baked bread at Mondrian Restaurant until recently. Most of the breads, a well-crafted assortment of around two dozen, are sourdough, and many are made with a starter that Ms. Scherber said has been kept going by various bakers for around 100 years. 
 Her offerings include a swirled semolina bread stippled with black sesame seeds ($3.25) and another semolina bread studded with golden raisins and perfumed with fennel ($3.25). Among the other stars are chewy triangles thick with nubbly toasted walnuts ($1.65); a flattened round baked with olive oil, raisins and rosemary ($1.25); various kinds of focaccia ($1 to $4) and an oval of earthy whole wheat bolstered with toasted pecans, wheat berries, fruits and golden raisins ($4.50).
 
The World of Queens<HE<
In terms of culinary diversity, Queens probably tops all the other boroughs. And on Saturday and Sunday from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M., as part of the Queens Festival in Flushing Meadows Park, visitors will be able to sample the foods of 20 countries. The stands selling food will be clustered around the Fountain of the Planets. Admission is free.
 
Tropical Produce
 J. R. Brooks & Son, a produce company in Homestead, Fla., has published a handy guide to the tropical fruits and vegetables it grows. The foldout pamphlet describes 20 products, and explains their storage and use. It has color photographs and a nutritional chart.
Copies are available free from J. R. Brooks & Son, P.O. Drawer 9, Homestead, Fla. 33090.
 
Local Talent on L.I.
 Local Talent, a caterer in Cutchogue, L.I., has opened a retail shop on Route 25 (Main Road) in nearby Aquebogue. The roster of prepared dishes changes daily, but invariably includes tasty grain, bean and lentil salads ($6 a pound), chunky chicken salads, often seasoned with curry ($10 a pound) and excellent quiches in combinations like leek and bacon ($3.25 each).
The shop prepares rotisserie ducks and chickens, and gives customers one bird free with a purchase of eight. Local Talent's sumptuous brownies are also available at the shop, as are coffees, cheeses, assorted packaged foods and some cooking utensils.
 
Culinary Careers
 Careers Through Culinary Arts, a program that provides culinary training to students in New York City's public high schools, is only about two years old. But this month it granted scholarships totaling $77,000 to help 11 graduating seniors continue their education in the food field at schools like Johnson & Wales University, the French Culinary Institute and New York City Technical College. More than a dozen summer internships at restaurants and supermarkets were also awarded.
Richard Grausman, a cooking teacher and cookbook author, who started the program, works with home economics teachers in the New York City school system to prepare them to teach more advanced professional skills to their students. He has also obtained donations of equipment and ingredients for the schools from many companies and is organizing similar programs in other cities.
 
Coffee Gear
 Bodum, a Danish manufacturer of coffee-making equipment, has opened its first retail shop in America, at 673 Madison Avenue (61st Street). Besides glass coffeemakers that operate on a plunger system and sell for $19.95 and up, the shop carries cups, coffee carafes and, starting at $59.95, the handsome Osiris kettle designed to boil water very efficiently. The shop also sells Starbuck coffees from Seattle for $6.90 to $13.95 a pound.
 
A Chef Is Remembered

On Sunday at 5 P.M., the Ballroom, at 253 West 28th Street, is holding a party to unveil its second mural by Marion Pinto. The first one, depicting SoHo notables of the 70's, is in the front room of the restaurant. The new work honors the Ballroom's former chef, Felipe Rojas-Lombardi, who died last year. The party, with tapas and wine, will benefit the Felipe Rojas-Lombardi Scholarship Fund, which will give grants to people of Hispanic origin for culinary study, starting in 1994. Tickets, $55 each, can be reserved by calling (212) 675-4984.
 
FOOD NEWS FROM JAPAN
 AMONG the specialized culinary newsletters is Gochiso-sama!, a quarterly published in English in Japan, and filled with short but serious articles about Japanese food.
A recent issue discussed the history of ramen noodles, with recipes, and recommended ramen restaurants in Japan. The newsletter also provides information about regional Japanese ingredients, food tips, cookbook reviews and comments from readers.
Annual subscriptions are $20 (or 2,500 yen) and are available by writing to Gochiso-sama!, Yagoto Fujimigaoka 13-2, Tenpaku-cho, Showa-ku, Nagoya 466, Japan. Payment by traveler's check is requested.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Illinois Power Sells Mortgage Bonds

 BODY:
The Illinois Power Company entered the corporate debt market yesterday to sell $197 million of first-mortgage bonds in two parts, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch.
One part consists of $72 million of noncallable bonds due in 2004, carrying an interest rate of 7.95 percent. They are priced at 99.724 to yield 7.986 percent, or about 73-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. 
 The remaining part consists of bonds due in 2021 with an interest rate of 8.75 percent. They are priced at 99.905 to yield 8.759 percent, or about 90-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasuries with a like maturity. These bonds are callable by the company after five years.
Both issues are rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB+ by S.& P.

HEADLINE: Recycling Makes More Sense for New York Than Incineration

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"New York, Amid Doubts, Broadens Recycling Plan" (news article, May 27) fails to mention the high cost and risks of incineration and misleads the reader about the Mayor's plan to construct as many as seven giant incinerators.
For fiscal years 1993-96, the plan envisions at least $520 million for expanding three barely operational Queens and Brooklyn incinerators and constructing the Staten Island ashport and ashfill, to hold the toxic residue of the incinerators. Compare the $24 million budgeted citywide in fiscal year 1992 for waste prevention, reduction, composting and recycling. 
 The $520 million does not include the public health cost of incineration, such as increases in special education for children suffering from birth defects, brain damage and cancer, or lost wages and productivity because of increased suffering from asthma and respiratory diseases. The city's own environmental impact statement expresses concern about mercury contamination, which could taint fish and mothers' milk.
Who are your unnamed "most committed supporters" who question if we can make recycling work? The city's data show an astounding rate of cooperation, considering the failure of city leaders to embrace the issue, the paltry funds allocated for education and the poorly implemented program. Who are these unidentified "recycling proponents" who worry if recycling "makes economic sense in this densely packed financially hobbled and ethnically diverse world of towering apartments houses"?
A study by Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman says maximal recycling will save the city as much as $3.9 billion over 20 years. Jobs and businesses will be created by committing ourselves to composting and recycling, instead of incineration. Contrary to your assertion, such communities as the Hasidic and Hispanic communities of Williamsburg, and economically diverse Riverdale and South Bronx, are working together.
Incineration is a nonsolution to the solid-waste problem, benefiting companies that own nonrecyclable resources, incinerator companies, their consultants and investment bankers. With incineration, the proposed ashfill on Staten Island will be exhausted in eight years.
 
KEN AMRON
Chmn., Solid Waste Subcommittee
New York City Sierra Club
New York, June 10, 1992

HEADLINE: Part of Rwanda's Problem Begins in U.S.

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"In Rwanda, Births Increase and Problems Do, Too" (front page, May 31) relies on the flawed logic of population-control ideology and fails to examine the real problems facing Rwandans and others in the developing world. The high birth rate in Rwanda is not the cause but rather a symptom of poor living conditions.
Although you quote a World Bank report stating that "educated women have smaller families, and their children tend to be healthier and better educated," you present a decreased birth rate as a solution in itself to Rwanda's problems. Decades of coercive family planning programs, which offer women birth control and sterilization, but do not provide comprehensive health care or address their wider needs, have shown this strategy is doomed to failure.
We should address the real issues. It is estimated that 200,000 women worldwide die of illegal or unsafe abortions each year, yet our Government refuses aid to facilities in the developing world that offer abortions or abortion counseling. Birth control methods considered unsafe in this country, such as Depo-Provera injections, given at clinics in Rwanda, are widely used on third world women (and low-income women at home) without their knowing the risks.
The unequal distribution of wealth between industrialized and developing nations, and within developing nations themselves, perpetuates the poverty, illiteracy and powerlessness that lead women to have more children than they are able to feed.
The United States, with 5 percent of the world's people, accounts for one-third of the world's use of nonrenewable resources, making our per capita consumption of energy several hundred times that of the average Rwandan. Is it not hypocritical and racist to complain about the effects of "overpopulation" on the environment and do nothing to curb our overconsumption?
 
RACHEL ROSENBLOOM
New York, June 10, 1992
 
The writer is a member of Women's Health Action and Mobilization.

HEADLINE: That's Entertainment?

BYLINE: By Leonard Garment; Leonard Garment was White House counsel under President Richard Nixon.

DATELINE: ZUG, Switzerland

 BODY:
The telephone call found me in a small, neat hotel room in a small, neat Swiss town. Had I seen Vice President Dan Quayle's latest speech on values? Fax me a copy, I said, and walked to the lake, where swans and ducks paddled peacefully and bourgeois families strolled, to smoke a cigar and drink a beer.
Switzerland is as smooth and creamy as its chocolate. There is little unemployment, and the land lives mostly in homogeneous middle class harmony. Clocks, trains and civic virtues run on time. The people are friendly, hard-working and God-fearing. But these attractions soon pale, for the Swiss lack the intellectual and cultural debates and the class, racial and religious diversities that make a country absorbing. An American wit described Switzerland as "Scarsdale with mountains." 
 Back at the hotel was the Quayle speech, with its assertion that there are "two cultures" in America, "the cultural elite and the rest of us," and its argument that "we Americans" should speak out against the other side in the great culture wars. Not long afterward, I discovered that the main shortcoming in the speech was not its disapproval of Hollywood's morals: The problem was that the disapproval did not go deep enough.
While flying home, I saw Oliver Stone's film "J.F.K." Virtually everyone, according to Mr. Stone, was in on the plot to murder John F. Kennedy and usurp the Government. The C.I.A. was in on it. Lyndon B. Johnson was in on it. Not content with killing a President, the same guys murdered Robert F. Kennedy and Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
When "J.F.K." came out, plenty of people in the professional political community looked askance at it. But in Mr. Stone's artistic world hardly anyone laughed or criticized. Few seemed to think his reputation should suffer a penalty for the film's paranoid, pernicious lunacy. It was no surprise Hollywood should have seen "J.F.K." as reasoned political discourse. We viewers are familiar with a staple theme: the President, C.I.A., military, police, businessmen, legislatures and electoral politics are all useless and corrupt.
The entertainment community's political activities are organized around the view that politics do not work properly and that performers must save the Republic through their power to command media attention.
My point is that we should worry not just about the TV and movie view of illegitimate children but about the entertainment community's view of American society and political life.
Many people believe that our political system can't do the things that need to be done. We read about how dirty politics is. Every act of official discretion is said to be a mask for favoritism, every assertion of confidentiality is presumed to be a cover-up, every connection an official may hold to people and organizations outside government is seen as a corrupt conflict of interest.
Thus has Ross Perot become a credible candidate. Here is a man whose positions are still largely undiscoverable, who proposes to smash the budget deficit by asking upper middle class people to give up hunks of Social Security benefits, who boasts of his ability to disregard the conventional electoral process by buying the Presidency (for the people, he assures us), who would replace a democratic legislature with pseudo-plebiscitarian town meetings, who wants to fight drugs through the constitutionally appalling tactic of cordoning off and searching neighborhoods, whose reversal on taxation makes George Bush's "no new taxes" gaffe look like a model of coherence, who threatens his opponents with compromising photographs, who has taken an unwholesome interest in the dress and appearance of his employees.
Mr. Perot is taken seriously only because so many trust so little in our politics. They do so in no small part because their news and entertainment are full of this message. The media have legitimized the idea that the way to break out of the political morass is through the use of -- what else? -- the media. It is no accident that Mr. Perot leans heavily on mass communication and mass rallies to bypass the messy democratic details of conventions and campaigning.
Instead of a man on horseback, we are watching the arrival of the man riding the TV call-in show. The scene should be far more disturbing than the sight of new mother Murphy Brown or the sound of Dan Quayle taking her to task.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: S.E.C. Acts On Behalf Of Holders

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
In a far-reaching effort to make the nation's companies more accountable to shareholders, the Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed major changes in corporate rules, including a requirement that companies for the first time justify executive pay levels.
The executive compensation proposal consists essentially of requiring companies to convert what are now often large masses of text into a series of tables, graphs and notes providing greater detail. 
 In addition, companies would be required for the first time to present the specific factors on which the executives' pay is based and to describe how this package is related to company performance.
A new summary table is to show all forms of compensation, including stock options, paid the chief executive and the four top-paid officers over the preceding three years.
There would also be a graph showing shareholders' return on investment over a five-year period in comparison with a group of peer companies and the Standard & Poor's 500 stock market index.
The new series of measures, under development by the S.E.C. for three years, would also give large stockholders access to corporate proxy statements to express opinions about the performance of management and directors.
 
2 Proposals Left Out
 At the same time, the commission did not include two significant changes it had espoused. It decided that companies should not be required to hand over lists of their stockholders to insurgents or other shareholders and it decided that when shareholders send written material to other shareholders they must file copies with the S.E.C., although under a far-simpler procedure than under current law.
Still, today's proposals represent a significant expansion of shareholder rights and they brought praise from at least one group representing investors.
"These proposals respond to the shareholders' call for more useful information about executive compensation and to allow more free and open communication among shareholders," said Ralph V. Whitworth, president of the United Shareholders Association, a group founded by T. Boone Pickens, the oilman and corporate investor. "This marks the beginning of the end of the S.E.C.'s role as corporate America's thought-control police."
Before formally adopting these proposals, the commission will consider comments submitted during the next 60 days.
 
Proposals are Modified
 The proposals for enhanced communications modify similar, even more ambitious ones, put forward in June 1991. Those proposals were withdrawn because of strenuous opposition by various corporate groups, including the Business Roundtable, made up of top executives. The companies said they feared that the absence of any filing requirement would lead to collusion by cliques of large stockholders, a complaint addressed today by the rule calling for a copy of written material to be mailed to the S.E.C. within 10 days.
Although this procedure applies only in cases in which the shareholder seeks no proxy authority, such as votes to elect him or her to the board, it is seen as a vast improvement from prevailing rules.
Currently, if a shareholder communicates with 10 or more other holders about a coming meeting or other corporate matter, the shareholder must not only file a detailed disclosure about himself but he must also distribute it to all those who receive the communication. If it is transmitted by mass media, for instance, a newspaper advertisement, the proxy statement must be mailed to all other stockholders, perhaps millions of them.
Today's proposal would eliminate current filing requirements for purely oral communications not seeking proxy authority. Thus, shareholders who discuss a company's performance over the telephone will no longer have to worry that their conversation could be deemed a proxy solicitation.
Under the modified plan, companies would not be required to supply shareholder lists to dissidents or other shareholders. But companies would be required to mail solicitations on their behalf -- and to aim them, if desired, at specific groups, like large institutional holders.
In opening this morning's three-hour hearing on the two sets of initiatives, both of which were adopted by votes of 4 to 0, Richard C. Breeden, the S.E.C. chairman, said some people had come to regard the shareholders' role in corporate governance as "perfunctory," citing in particular the issue of executive pay.
"When a company whose stock has plunged in value 'resets' the management's stock options to lower the strike price, many shareholders ask, 'Who is the board representing?' " Mr. Breeden said. "That looks like the old game of 'heads I win, tails you lose' because the management profits if it is successful, but it also profits if it fails."
But senior officials at the Treasury Department have suggested in recent weeks that the commission might be going too far, particularly in looking at more complete disclosure and at more accurate accounting for grants to executives in the form of highly lucrative stock options.
In a speech on Monday before a group of bankers here, Deputy Treasury Secretary John E. Robson complained of "aspiring meddlers in executive compensation" who "want to get their mitts on employee stock options."
Congress has taken considerable interest in compensation of late, seeking under a House bill extending unemployment benefits to curtail executive pay by denying corporate tax deductions for pay exceeding $1 million.
Today's proposal on proxies also called for the elimination of prior S.E.C. review of solicitation materials, a requirement for "unbundling" related stockholder proposals so each could be voted on separately and allowing someone seeking election to a board to run with a slate of management people so his supporters are not disenfranchised.
The measure that would introduce statements of management performance in proxy material resulted from a proposal by Edward V. Regan, Comptroller of New York State. This would allow statements by any person or group that has held half of 1 percent of a company's stock for at least three years.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Los Angeles Inundated by Sublet Space

BYLINE: By Morris Newman

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
AN unaccustomed abundance of space available for subleasing in the downtown office market here has led to vigorous activity, particularly among tenants seeking bargains in rent. Yet nobody seems to be making money except office brokers.
Of the eight million square feet of office space available for lease in downtown Los Angeles, 1.7 million square feet is sublease space, according to the Cushman Realty Corporation, a local real estate brokerage. In 1988, only about 680,000 square feet of sublease space was available in the same market. 
 The flood of sublease space is creating a hardship for landlords, who find themselves competing within their own buildings with tenants eager to let giant blocks of space they no longer need. And because sublease space is typically offered at a discount of 10 to 50 percent off market-rate rents, the availability of the cheaper space is depressing rents in an already troubled market.
"You can really name your price," said James N. Travers, president of the Travers Realty Corporation of Los Angeles. "People are in a position where they must accept." He added that subleases were going for $12 to $18 a square foot, compared with $17 to $28 for space leased directly from landlords.
The current flood of sublease space is a combined product of an overbuilt office market and a poor business climate. Many important tenants, particularly law and accounting firms, have failed to achieve the rapid growth they had expected in the 1980's and are now returning much of their space to the market. Law firms alone are offering 30 floors of space in the downtown area, according to Mr. Travers.
Recent deals in downtown Los Angeles include two floors that Northern Trust of Chicago sublet from I.B.M. at the Wells Fargo Center, where the computer giant has offered six floors for sublease. In the same building, Kemper Securities of Los Angeles has leased 1.25 floors from the law firm of Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue.
Besides a price advantage, subletting often offers tenants the advantage of "move in" space, which is already built and furnished. In some cases, tenants can also have the use of furniture, telephones and even computers, as well.
Moving into furnished space relieves tenants of paying construction costs, which are typically factored into rent. Move-in space also spares tenants the obligation of providing personal guarantees to landlords that tenants will make the rent payments. "In a weak credit market, such arrangements appeal to many small tenants," said Margaret Duskin, vice president of TRI Commercial Real Estate Services of San Francisco.
Subleasing has been a source of seemingly endless dispute between landlords and tenants, particularly regarding who has the right to profit from the sublease. When markets are strong and rents are rising, landlords often attempt to prevent tenants from offering their space to subtenants at a markup.
In March the California Supreme Court reversed, by a 7-to-0 vote, a ruling in Carma Development Inc. v. Marathon Development (California) Inc., that a landlord can terminate the lease of a tenant who attempts to sublease, when the right to do so is clearly stated in the lease contract.
Although the decision won wide attention among lawyers and legal scholars, the real estate community viewed the case as largely irrelevant, since the case dated back to the early 1980's, when rents in California were skyrocketing. That era seems a world away from the current doldrums, in which tenants are less concerned with realizing profits than with limiting losses.
In many cases, tenants with subtenants in place are still losing "millions of dollars," according to Steve Marcussen, a vice president of Cushman Realty. Tenants who originally rented for $30 a square foot, he said, "are happy to get $16 a square feet and lose only $14."
Since sublease space tends to be taken more quickly than landlord space, landlords might reasonably expect the supply to be absorbed soon, giving them a chance to regain control of the office market. Yet an uncertain economy continues to play havoc with an already out-of-balance market.
The merger of BankAmerica and the Security Pacific National Bank by itself is expected to leave an additional 1.4 million square feet on the market in the next two years, while Carter Hawley Hale, the parent company of several department-store chains, is expected to vacate 110,000 square feet at 444 South Flower Street in the near future.
Despite the spate of leasing deals and the low rents, some potential tenants for sublet space hold back because they see a catch in some of the deals. The disadvantage is that at the end of a short-term sublet, another move, with all its attendant disruptions and costs, may have to be made. The way around that problem is to seek a lease for the space from the landlord that would phase in at the end of the sublet term.
