SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 2155 words

HEADLINE: Perot Under Fire: Sifting Facts and Motives

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
Only a short while ago Ross Perot had the sort of public image that would make any politician salivate: self-made billionaire, just-folks tycoon, scourge of the Ayatollah, straight-talking guy. But lately a more ominous portrait has emerged: J. Edgar Perot, a man obsessed by conspiracies and beset by enemies in his mind, willing to use tactics of espionage and intimidation to destroy those who stand in his way.
Mr. Perot, in an aggressive public relations campaign over the last few days, has denounced that characterization as false -- "fairyland," "animal crackers" and "Mickey Mouse tossed salad" were a few of his more colorful dismissals. And he says this effort to redefine, and malign, his character has been orchestrated by President Bush and his re-election committee. 
 It appears, so far, that both things are at least somewhat true. Mr. Perot does have a history of using investigators and threats against opponents. And officials of Mr. Bush's White House and re-election committee have not been shy about publicly discussing that history while, more privately, an "opposition research" team has been running the sort of aggressive investigation into Mr. Perot's past that Mr. Perot has conducted against others.
"It is correct that we have opposition research, not just on Perot but on Clinton, too" said the chairman of the Republican National Committee, Rich Bond. He acknowleged that the opposition research does produce information about Mr. Perot, and that this information is sometimes given to inquiring reporters. "There are a number of reporters who call us looking for facts, and if we have the facts, we provide them."
But he defended the research as legitimate politics, saying "Mr. Perot wants to put a legitimate inquiry into the guise of so-called dirty tricks, and nothing could be farther from the truth," he said.
 
Episodes Support Picture
 There appears to be no proof that the Bush operation has fabricated accusations that Mr. Perot has used investigators and threats from lawyers. It need not. There have been a number of episodes in Mr. Perot's life that support the picture of him that the Bush campaign is now happy to see displayed.
The most recent example of Mr. Perot's behind-the-scenes use of lawyers, investigators and reporters against those who have displeased him can be found in his now-revealed dealings with The Washington Post and its premiere investigative reporter, Bob Woodward. It is an episode that illuminates the close line Mr. Perot has walked in his efforts to embarrass Mr. Bush and the risks inherent in those ways.
Mr. Perot and reporters at the Washington Post now acknowledge that in 1988 Mr. Perot provided information in extended interviews and in two three-inch black vinyl binders to the newspaper while he knew it was preparing to write a series of articles about Mr. Bush.
The articles were prepared under the supervision of Mr. Woodward, who was not available for comment today.
 
Information on a Deal
 The information came largely from a Washington law firm that was paid $10,000 by Mr. Perot and his longtime aide, Tom Luce, to gather details about a highly profitable land deal engineered by the Pennzoil Company and its head, J. Hugh Liedke, a close friend and former business partner of Mr. Bush.
The lawyers, from the firm of Verner, Liipfert, Bernhard, McPheron & Hand, had investigated a deal involving a 500,000-acre parcel in Northern New Mexico known as Vermejo Ranch. Mr. Perot said he was offered the ranch for $24 million in the early 1970's. It was instead acquired by Pennzoil.
The investigation never showed that Mr. Bush had done anything improper, and Mr. Perot insisted today that his motives were not to harm Mr. Bush. But Walter Pincus, one of the Washington Post reporters who received the information from Mr. Perot in 1988, said, "I don't think he was doing it to help him."
Mr. Perot said that in 1986, Pennzoil came to him and offered to sell 400,000 acres of the ranch for $50 million and that he learned that Pennzoil had received a $48 million tax credit for donating the other 100,000 acres to the Forest Service.
 
Contacts With Reporters
 Mr. Pincus recalled today that Mr. Perot had been providing information to Mr. Woodward in January 1988 about the Iran-contra scandal when he happened to volunteer that he also had information on the land transaction. Mr. Perot arranged for a Washington breakfast with Mr. Luce and the two Post reporters.
Mr. Perot said today that some information was provided after it was requested by the Post. Mr. Perot's spokesman, James Squires, said that Mr. Perot provided the information to The Post "to find out whether a fraud had been committed on taxpayers."
Last Sunday, Mr. Woodward wrote a front page article in the Post outlining Mr. Perot's investigation into the land deal. Mr. Squires, the Perot spokesman, suggested today that the article violated an agreement Mr. Perot had with the Post that his identity be kept confidential.
Mr. Pincus said that he recalled The Post had originally received the information about the Pennzoil deal in a confidential manner but that he did not know what had occurred in recent weeks between Mr. Woodward and Mr. Perot that might have altered that agreement.
"Bob's got his own sort of view," Mr. Pincus said, adding that he felt his remarks had been made off the record.
Mr. Perot's anger with Mr. Bush, then the Vice President, reportedly stemmed from a feeling that he and Administration officials in general, were paying insufficient attention to Mr. Perot's effort on behalf American servicemen he believed were still held in Southast Asia.
More than a decade ago, Mr. Perot provided seed money to the Vietnam Veterans Memorial Fund for construction of a memorial in Washington, but he openly criticized the design picked by the fund's selection committee. Several officials involved in the memorial said that to get his way, Mr. Perot began a campaign to discredit them.
As part of the effort Mr. Perot hired Roy M. Cohn, the New York lawyer who, in his most famous role, had been counsel to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy during the heyday of the Senator's power.
 
Battle Over Vietnam Memorial
 "We trusted him at the beginning, but then he wanted to get rid of the wall," said John Wheeler, who was the chairman of the veteran's fund. "He wanted me as chairman to abandon the wall. He pushed me and pushed me to give up the wall. He said, 'I'll wipe you out.' It was like being sliced with a knife. The next thing I knew I was getting threatening phone calls."
Officials involved in the memorial said in interviews that in the early 1980's Mr. Perot repeatedly asserted that the memorial fund had been tainted by financial improprieties. Both Mr. Perot and Mr. Cohn demanded access to the fund's records to conduct their own audit but were rebuffed.
Rather than give the records to Mr. Cohn, the fund assembled its own independent audit committee to investigate Mr. Perot's allegations. But that did not satisfy Mr. Perot either, officials said, so the fund turned to the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, to conduct an inquiry.
Finding no evidence of impropriety, the agency concluded that the fund's operations "were proper and that the numerous allegations raised regarding the fund were not valid."
In business dealings, Mr. Perot has sometimes been accused of similarly rough tactics. In 1980 he led an extremely aggressive campaign to overturn a decision by a Texas agency to take away a contract for processing Medicaid claims from his company, the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, and award it to a bidder from New York.
Mr. Perot's efforts to reverse the decision included private meetings with the Governor, the Attorney General and the members of the board of human resources, which awarded the contract.
His efforts also included gathering a dossier of negative information about the New York bidder, the Bradford National Corporation, and some of its directors, said the chairman of the human resources board.
Hilmar Moore, the mayor of Richmond, Tex., who was at the time the board chairman, said Mr. Perot had tracked him down to Salt Lake City, where he was vacationing. He said Mr. Perot told him he had some information about Bradford and wanted to come up and show it to him.
 
$2 Billion Contract
 "He just called and asked if he could come on up," recalled Mr. Moore. He said Mr. Perot flew from Texas to Utah on a private plane with one aide and presented him with a folder, which he recalled contained copies of legal complaints against Bradford and some of its directors.
"There was nothing personal in it," Mr. Moore said. "It was all designed to show that Bradford couldn't handle the business." The contract was worth about $2 billion a year to Mr. Perot's company.
Mr. Perot also convinced Mr. Moore that senior state accountants had been incorrect in concluding that giving the contract to Bradford would save the state money. Mr. Moore said he had welcomed the information and decided to work to rescind the award to Bradford.
In another Texas case, Mr. Perot has been accused of using both his wealth and threats to expose extramarital affairs to overwhelm an opponent who had battled for two years to collect $250 million in damages from Mr. Perot and his son, Ross Perot Jr.
Near the end of a two-year court fight that ended in April 1990, the opponent, Richard Salwen who was once a close legal adviser to Mr. Perot, said in court documents that the Perot camp was trying to "economically harass and punish" him.
Mr. Salwen, who was hired as the chief legal officer for the Dell Computer Corporation in 1989, worked for Mr. Perot first as a lawyer at the Electronic Data Systems and then for the Perot Group after Mr. Perot resigned as chairman and chief executive of E.D.S. at the end of 1986.
In his last few years at E.D.S., and until 1988 at the Perot Group, Mr. Salwen said he had worked mainly as an agent for the Perots on projects to acquire 16,000 acres north of Fort Worth and Dallas, and then on several projects related to the development an airfield owned by the City of Fort Worth.
Mr. Salwen's lawsuit against the Perots asserted that his work enhanced the value of the Perots' land by $250 million. Yet he contended that the Perots had never granted him the ownership stake in the property that they had promised when they lured him to leave his job at E.D.S.
In court documents, the Perots said Mr. Salwen was never promised an ownership position. In related affidavits, two other participants in the land investments with the Perots and Mr. Salwen, Mervin L. Stauffer and J. Michael Poss, who had close ties to the Perots, said the Perots were not obligated in 1988 to grant them specific ownership positions. Mr. Salwen acknowledged in court documents that he had no written commitment from the Perots.
In February 1990, J. Patrick Horner, president of Perot Systems, the computer-services company controlled by Mr. Perot, informed the chief financial officer at Dell Computer, Donald D. Collis, in two telephone conversations that the Perots had information about Mr. Salwen's involvement in an extra-marital affair. Mr. Collis was Mr. Salwen's supervisor at Dell.
Mr. Salwen's lawyer, C. L. (Mike) Schmidt said that when he learned of Mr. Horner's contacts, "I hit the ceiling." He protested the contacts by Mr. Horner in court documents, asserting that they had caused Mr. Salwen "emotional distress and loss of his professional reputation." Within a matter of weeks, Mr. Schmidt said in an interview, the case was settled for an undisclosed amount of money.
In 1990, Mr. Perot took the unusual step of obtaining a court order permitting the inspections of a house he rented and hiring off-duty Dallas police officers to conduct three inspections of the house each day.
According to a 1990 lawsuit, Mr. Perot took the action because the tenant, H. Wayne Hayes Jr., had failed to pay his rent in March 1990 and because Mr. Perot feared he might damage the house next to Mr. Perot's North Dallas estate. Mr. Hayes paid $7,500 a month in rent on the home, which is valued at nearly $2 million.
 
Patrol Cars and Dogs
 In remarks today on the NBC News program "Today," Mr. Perot said he had been obliged to take action because of drug use and fistfights on the property.
A lawyer for Mr. Hayes, Tim Jones, said there was no reason to believe Mr. Hayes would damage the property.
A report by a private investigating team, which was made public by Mr. Hayes's wife, said officers for Mr. Perot drove marked patrol cars and led a drug-sniffing dog through the house. Mr. Jones said that went beyond the court order approved by both sides.
Mr. Hayes, 35, is now in prison in Hawaii after pleading guilty last year to two charges of mail fraud in a Federal securities case.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "The Perot Disputes: Attack and Parry"
 
Land deal involving Bush friend
 
Background
 Mr. Perot said he was surprised to discover that the Pannzoil Company, when headed by a close firend of then Vice President Bush, received a $48 million Federal tax credit for donating to the Government one-fifth of a larger parcel of land that he was offered a few years earlier for $24 million.
 
Accusation
 Mr. Perot hired Washington lawyers to investigate the transaction and secretly provided information to The Washington Post in an effort to embarass Mr. Bush.
 
Perot's Response
 Mr. Perot said he gathered the information only to decide whether to buy the land, and that he provided information to The Post mostly because the paper asked for it, although a Post reporter said that Mr. Perot volunteered it. A spokesman for Mr. Perot said Mr. Perot investigated the deal to determine whether a fraud had been perpetrated on taxpayers.
 
Richard L. Armitage investigation
 
Background
 Mr. Perot was active in efforts to locate American servicemen who were missing in Vietnam and believed that the Defense Department was not not making adequate efforts to search for them.
 
Accusation
 Mr. Perot asserted that Richard Armitage, an Assistant Secretary of Defense, had a friendship with a Vietnamese-American woman that compromised efforts to find missing American servicemen in Asia. Mr. Perot spread unfounded information about Mr. Armitage, including data gathered by an undercover police officer in Virginia.
 
Perot's Response
 Mr. Perot said he did not solicit the information about Mr. Armitage but received an unsolicited file from the officer. In follow-up interviews, Mr. Perot admitted he made the initial call to the police officer who had the information. Mr. Perot said he passed on the information to "appropriate law enforcement authorities" by handling it to the F.B.I. But he also acknowledged keeping a copy in his safe.
 
Vietnam War Memorial
 
Background
 Mr. Perot provided nearly $200,000 in seed money for design and construction of a Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington. But he was openly critical of the design selected for the memorial by a panel.
 
Accusation
To undermine the project, Mr. Perot sought to dig up improprieties about officials of the fund. He demanded financial records from the fund, and hired Roy M. Cohn, who was former chief counsel to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, to help him.
 
Perot's Response
 Mr. Perot has denied that he was seeking to discredit officials of the fund. He said he had concerns about the fund's business practices and was acting on behalf of many veterans who did not like the memorial's design.
 
Dispute with business partner
 
Background
 Richard Salwen, once a close legal adviser to Mr. Perot, filed a $250 million lawsuit against him, contending that Mr. Perot and his son had reneged on giving him an ownership stake in property. He left the Perot family businesses over the dispute in 1988.
 
Accusation
 Mr. Perot, through an intermediary, spread rumors linking Mr. Salwen to an extra-marital affair. Mr. Salwen also accused Mr. Perot of intimidation, saying he threatened him and his lawyer: "I will bury you guys with hourly-rate lawyers."
 
Perot's Response
 Perot spokesman James Squires said Mr. Perot "never sought to intimidate Mr. Salwen with the use of personal information." -- RICHARD L. BERKE

HEADLINE: THE ISRAELI VOTE;
RABIN PLANS TO ACT ON MIDEAST TALKS AND SETTLEMENTS

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, June 24

 BODY:
Yitzhak Rabin said today that his priorities as Israel's next Prime Minister would be peace negotiations to bring about Palestinian self-rule in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, and an end to construction of "political settlements" there.
Mr. Rabin, the victorious Labor Party leader in the national election Tuesday, added that he hoped in the process to improve relations with the United States, which have been seriously strained over the settlements issue. 
 "Every penny that goes to them is a blow to the things that are most important to Israel," he told a television interviewer tonight, referring to settlements not explicitly needed for Israeli security. "As far as the national budget is concerned, the building will stop."
 
Peace and Security
 Mr. Rabin spoke only in general terms and for the most part reiterated basic themes from his campaign as he savored the first day after a stunning Labor victory over the long-governing Likud Party. [Palestinians in the occupied West Bank cautiously welcomed the Labor victory. Page A14.]
Nevertheless, he sought to emphasize that many of his principal concerns would be different from Likud's, with the exception that he is no less committed to Israel's security.
"I believe that peace that doesn't contribute to security has no meaning and isn't worth the name 'peace,' " he said at a separate news conference.
 
'National Consensus'
 Mr. Rabin's triumph does not mean he has a Government yet, for he still needs to find coalition partners to give him a working majority in the 120-member Parliament. In fact, he suggested concern that the incomplete alliance he now leads may lean too far to the left, and he raised the possibility of religious and right-wing parties helping him to form a "broad national consensus."
In an apparent gesture toward the right, the Labor leader urged his left-wing allies in a coalition called Meretz not to press demands for a Palestinian state or for a complete freeze on Jewish settlements, whether defined as "political" or otherwise.
Though Mr. Rabin has not been specific about which settlements are political, they are generally considered to be those not in or around Jerusalem.
And he said that even if Palestinians gained self-rule -- a status that he has said he hopes to realize within nine months of taking office -- it did not mean that all 140 settlements built in the West Bank and Gaza over the last 25 years would disappear.
"We're not going to uproot settlements as we did in Sinai," he said, evoking what for many Israelis was a traumatic leveling of Jewish communities in the Sinai Desert a decade ago as part of a peace treaty with Egypt.
As praise of the Labor victory and expressions of hope for peace flowed in from the United States, Europe and Arab countries, Mr. Rabin and his strategists began to deal with the complex political arithmetic involved in putting together a stable coalition. They talked about having a Government in place in three to five weeks, and some of them set as a target July 13, when the new Parliament is scheduled to convene.
While there are several uncertainties, one point is obvious. Labor's rout of Likud could scarcely have been more thorough -- 45 parliamentary seats to 32, in the unofficial final tally. Likud, which held power for 15 years, now finds itself a dispirited and disoriented opposition party, one that its officials assume will endure debilitating internal arguments and possible schisms before its fortunes improve.
Its leader of the last decade, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, was widely expected to step aside before too long. Mr. Shamir hinted at that possibility in a television interview early this morning.
"We have to revamp the party," said Benjamin Netanyahu, one of several young party officials who would like to succeed Mr. Shamir. "It's very clear that the biggest message voters sent to us was: You've been there too long, and you forgot that you're accountable. And they're right."
 
Religious Party Role
 Still, as convincing as the Labor victory was, it left Mr. Rabin short of a working parliamentary majority.
One natural partner is Meretz, which won 12 seats. Added to Mr. Rabin's total, it gives him a total of 57. In theory, he could also throw in 5 seats won by two Israeli Arab parties, but he has said repeatedly that he will not accept them in the Government.
So to reach the 61 seats that it needs, Labor has no choice but to turn to some of the religious parties and perhaps also to a far-right party called Tsomet, which had been allied with Likud until now.
It is not impossible that Mr. Rabin could even ask Likud to join him in a "national unity government," along the lines of a broad coalition that prevailed from 1984 to 1990. But several officials in both major parties said that seemed highly unlikely, given the widespread opposition to such an arrangement within Labor and the unacceptable junior status that Likud would get if it went along with the idea.
In his television interview tonight, Mr. Rabin said that several parties of rigorously Orthodox Jews were possible partners. He also hinted at possible negotiations with Tsomet, which increased its parliamentary strength from two seats to seven, in good part because its leader, Rafael Eitan, is perceived by many voters as honest and straightforward.
At no point was Mr. Rabin specific about which parties he would approach. He insisted that he had forbidden any substantive discussions until after the vote totals are declared final, probably on Friday.
Those negotiations could prove delicate because his potential allies could not be more varied on several key questions.
Yet somehow that seemed like a mere detail today in the first blush of Mr. Rabin's victory, which left him holding all the important cards and able to do what he wants.
 
Likud's Internal Problems
 "The religious will come to us because they cannot survive in the opposition," Haim Ramon, a top Labor strategist said, exhibiting the party's new self-assurance.
With no complete statistical breakdown yet available, it was difficult to say precisely why Israelis voted as they did. But there was more than enough anecdotal evidence, along with a few numbers.
New immigrants from the former Soviet Union, displeased with their high levels of unemployment, punished Likud and flocked to Labor by margins of 47 percent to 18 percent, according to exit polls.
A graphic example of general dissatisfaction with Likud's stewardship was the vote total in Bat Yam, a working-class suburb of Tel Aviv. Bat Yam became a symbol of Israeli fears of terrorism after a 15-year-old girl was stabbed to death last month by a Palestinian from Gaza. Her killing set off several hours of anti-Arab rioting.
Normally, Bat Yam is Likud country. And normally, an attack of that sort could be expected to produce a backlash that works to Likud's advantage. This time, Bat Yam voters seemed to say that they did not trust the Government to protect them, and they gave Labor a plurality.

HEADLINE: Irish Ridicule New U.S. Envoy Over Gaffes

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DUBLIN, June 24

 BODY:
In his first week as American Ambassador to Ireland, William FitzGerald, an 82-year-old businessman and friend of President Bush, has been hit by what a diplomat called "the Irish Welcome Wagon."
Major newspapers have mocked Mr. FitzGerald in front-page articles because of errors he made about fundamental issues facing Ireland in testimony on June 3 in hearings in Washington on his appointment. 
 Appearing before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, he said the Irish had already voted in a referendum to approve the European Community's treaty on union of economic, foreign and security policies. Corrected on this point by Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, who pointed out that the referendum would not be held until June 18, Mr. FitzGerald apologized and said he was thinking of projected results, not the actual vote. The treaty was approved by 68 percent of the voters last week.
Questioned about his views on the sectarian violence in Northern Ireland, Mr. FitzGerald said he was glad that the United States Congress was providing money "to encourage dialogue and cooperation between the Unionists and the Loyalists." Both terms, as nearly every Irish person knows, are used to describe the same group: the Protestant majority in Northern Ireland.
Most people here assume that Mr. FitzGerald also intended to refer to the opposing group, the Roman Catholic "nationalists" of Northern Ireland, who say they are discriminated against in jobs and housing. Some of them are seeking union with Ireland.
In a brief debate in Parliament on Tuesday, Pat Lee, a member of the opposition Fine Gael party, said "the mind-boggling decision of President Bush defies logic."
"I feel this nation has been slighted," said Dr. Lee, a 47-year-old Dublin doctor. He said Mr. Bush should explain to Irish-American voters "why he holds our country in such low esteem."
The Irish Times has run three articles on Mr. FitzGerald in the last week, including a front-page article today with the headline "New Ambassador is an insult; Irish-Americans complain."
The Irish Government of Prime Minister Albert Reynolds has not commented on Mr. FitzGerald's gaffes, which have been reported on national television and are being discussed with some fervor on radio call-in shows. Mr. FitzGerald, who is to present his credentials on Friday to President Mary Robinson, has also declined to comment on the criticism. Mr. FitzGerald replaces Richard A. Moore, 79, who will work on Mr. Bush's campaign.
Appointments of American Ambassadors to Ireland have often stirred controversy. Margaret M. Heckler came here reluctantly in January 1986 after she was dislodged from her post as Secretary of Health and Human Services, a reassignment that led Irish commentators to complain that their country was viewed a booby prize. Ultimately Ms. Heckler won respect for her intense study of Ireland's politics.
A Western diplomat argued that because of the friendship, Mr. FitzGerald would "be able to get Bush on the phone any time he wants anything for Ireland," an access that a younger, career diplomat might be denied.
The spokesman for the American Embassy, John Treacy, reacted scornfully. "No blow is too low. No shot is too cheap," he said, adding, "This is just a case of the Lilliputians firing their arrows at the emmisary of Gulliver."

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Hopes to Lend Russians a Quick $1 Billion

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
In a move to speed aid to Moscow, the International Monetary Fund plans to lend the Russians $1 billion to help pay for crucial imports in a simplified reform agreement that the agency hopes to complete in the next two weeks.
The I.M.F.'s plan, as described by its officials, represented a scaling back of original plans for a multibillion-dollar package requiring more sweeping reforms by the Government of President Boris N. Yeltsin. 
 The fund's officials said they were acting because Moscow needed cash immediately, and because they wanted to give Russia and the other former republics of the Soviet Union more time to work out a plan to determine which of them would continue to use the ruble as a step toward stabilizing their currencies.
I.M.F. officials and negotiators for Russia said the fund had eased demands on Moscow like one for a lifting of oil-price controls over the next few months -- a faster pace than many Russian officials thought the people could tolerate. Russian officials, and some American ones, have said that with Moscow's economy in deep crisis, the I.M.F. should not demand an accord so strict that it might conceivably spur people to rise up in protest.
 
Balancing Act
 "We're trying to balance all the pressures we're facing while maintaining our standards for a solid program," an official of the fund said.
The new plan has taken shape as the United States has been pressing the I.M.F. to act quickly to aid Russia.
According to officials close to the negotiations, the I.M.F. and Russia are aiming to complete the scaled-down agreement before the economic summit meeting of major industrial nations -- the Group of Seven -- in Munich July 6-8.
Fund officials said they expected Russia to try to follow up the scaled-back agreement by requesting a larger aid package that would require more comprehensive reforms. When the Group of Seven unveiled its $24 billion aid package for Russia in April, it anticipated that the I.M.F. would lend Moscow $2.5 billion to $3 billion this year.
These officials cited a key stumbling block, one that made it difficult for Moscow and the fund to negotiate a more comprehensive agreement over the next few weeks: the fact that Russia and the other republics were still trying to sort out which republics would continue to use the ruble.
 
Who Uses the Ruble?
 Until the republics figure that out, it will be difficult for Russia to gain full control over its money supply because central banks in other republics might continue to print billions of rubles -- rubles that could find their way into Russia in the course of commerce. Thus, the second agreement, coming once it was determined which republics would use the ruble, could set more definite targets for limiting inflation and growth in the money supply.
Only then, officials close to the negotiations said, could Russia seek to peg the ruble at a set rate. This would also open the door to Russia's tapping a planned $6 billion multinational fund to stabilize the ruble.
"I don't think anyone loses in this," said David Lipton, a Washington-based economist who is a consultant to Russia on the negotiations. "The truth of the matter is the Russians have taken a lot of important steps. It is an important moment for the West to be weighing in with some aid, and with this mechanism, the West is weighing in."
In most I.M.F. agreements, the fund disburses money in installments every few months, with each piece conditioned on a country's satisfying certain targets, like reducing its budget deficit to a specified level.
The fund has occasionally used scaled-down agreements before, as they place less stringent conditions on a country than in the broader agreements.
The American Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, David C. Mulford, said in a speech Monday in Zurich, "The Russian situation is unique in certain respects and may require creative solutions."
He added, "An agreement is needed in a matter of weeks, not months."
Negotiations between Russia and the I.M.F. are scheduled to resume late this week in Moscow.
Officials from the fund and from the Bush Administration officials said that under the expected package, Russia knows that it would not receive more than the expedited $1 billion if it backed off from its commitment to economic change.
The officials say that Mr. Yeltsin has been courageous in pushing ahead with bold reforms to create a market economy, although they are concerned that inflation and money-supply growth are not under control.
In his speech, Mr. Mulford said that to satisfy the I.M.F., Russia had to reduce its budget deficit to a level that could be financed without having to print money, a process most economists regard as inherently inflationary. He also said Russia had to control the printing of money and establish a currency with a stable value to help link its economy to the world's hard-currency economies.
He also said Moscow had to create legal structures and a system of private rights based on private ownership for Russian and foreign investors.
He added that the I.M.F. and Russia are in "broad agreement" on these points. "The differences of course, concern the details," he said.
Fund officials said that Yegor T. Gaidar, Russia's acting Prime Minister, made significant progress toward this scaled-down pact last week when he met with the I.M.F.'s managing director, Michel Camdessus. Mr. Gaidar was here during Mr. Yeltsin's meetings with President Bush.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Excerpts From Interview With President Bush on First Term and Future

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from an interview with President Bush in the Oval Office on Tuesday. The questioners were R. W. Apple Jr., Joel Brinkley, Steven Greenhouse and Andrew Rosenthal of The New York Times. Some questions have been edited or paraphrased because of space limitations.
Q: We would like to talk to you about your record for the first term. As you look back over the last three and a half years, can you tell us what you consider your most significant domestic initiatives that you have originated, promoted and seen through to fruition?  
 PRESIDENT BUSH: I think clearly the education initiative, where we set with the governors six educational goals, and where we're now trying to implement them. Some need Federal, some of it needs Federal legislation; much of it doesn't. There are many America 2000 communities, schools across the country, communities across the country, and so I think clearly that's a major one.
I think I'd put down, in terms of accomplishments, I'd put down our child care and the A.D.A. bill as early accomplishments.
I think what we've done on the Federal bench. I said ahead of time what I was going to do; we have good, quality judges. I think I'd take that as a significant accomplishment.
And I think I'd also put down, in terms of legislative accomplishment, the revision of the Clean Air Act.
What we really want to do relates more in the broad subjects, like anticrime, education. And we started, we've mapped out, put down a road map, but we're not there yet.
Q: Are there other parts of your record in a larger sense than these domestic issues that you think best recommend you for another term?
A: Obviously I think we've made great accomplishments. Great, earth-shaking.
Q: Which specifically?
A: Well, standing here with Yeltsin the other day, getting rid of all SS-18's, getting rid, agreeing to get rid, of all these MIRV'ed ICBM's is a significant accomplishment.
The changes in the world, I think, we get blamed if things went wrong. We should get credit if they've gone right. And they've gone right. Reunification of Germany. Democracy in this hemisphere. Pushing for, but not having accomplished, free-trade agreements. . . . We can't say that's done, obviously, but I think we're on the right track for free trade, as opposed to protection.
I think handling the changes inside what used to be the Soviet Union and the C.I.S. has been good, and I am very pleased that ancient enemies are talking to each other in the Middle East.
And, of course, Desert Storm was a significant and major accomplishment, because it said to aggressor nations: You can't just go take over a friendly country next door.
 
Goals for a Second Term
 Q: You've been in public life a long time. But there still seems to be this sense among people, when we interview them and in polls and when you talk to people even in your own party, that people don't quite understand what you stand for or what you'd like to do. Where would you like to take this country?
A: I'd like to see it . . in the first place, I'd like to see it set in an environment of world peace.
Secondly, I think at home, changing, fundamentally revolutionizing education is critical.
And I'd like to see a domestic environment where we have a return to safety in the streets, and we have it where mothers don't worry about their children walking home from school. And that means winning the battle against drugs, certainly, and doing better in the crime field so we have domestic tranquillity. And that means, of course, a lot of things that go with it. It means help for the cities, it means battling against crime by passing better legislation.
And so it's got to be the whole domestic tranquillity in a better-educated America.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q: Economic growth has been slow in the first three and a half years of your Administration. What would you say has caused this?
A: A long recession with not enough investment and not enough----. And it's longer than it needs to have been because we could have stimulated the economy to get out of it. And so it's a long recession.
I don't know, I can't remember all the studies I undertook when I studied economics about business cycles, but I think the answer to the recession would have been, and still is, stimulating growth.
I think one of the reasons for the discouraged economic outlook relates to the deficit and to the, well, to the anemic growth itself.
Q: What do you think should be done now to stimulate growth?
A: I think we need to do what I've been trying to get the Congress to do for some time: to selectively stimulate the economy.
I happen to think the economy is better than most of the people in America think. We saw polls somewhere last week 60 percent of the people think the economy is getting worse. The economy is getting better. In some areas, it's not getting better, but I think we should stimulate it through the methods that we've talked about. You know, the litany of growth initiatives. And I feel committed to them, and I wish that we could have done it, and still wish that we can do it.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Help for the Cities
 Q: Mr. President, you said that one thing you wanted to do in a second term is to help the cities. Even some black Republicans don't feel that this Administration has paid much attention to the plight of black people in the center cities. What do you think the Federal Government can do and what do you think it can't do to break this cycle of poverty and crime and general decay in the cities?
A: Three weeks ago I was sitting with some people in Los Angeles. All of whom -- Democrat, Republican, private sector, public sector, liberal Mayor, conservative Governor -- all wanted enterprise zones.
Q: So that's one thing they can do?
A: It's one thing they can do, yes. I would expect those black Republicans would have given enthusiastic support for that. We've been trying to get that done for a long time. With a renewed sense of urgency, we brought that back with Pete Wilson, Ueberroth and Mayor Bradley . . . we got the bipartisan leadership together; they made the pitch: Please pass this.
We can do this. Set it out alone, and let's get it done. And it is frustrating that it's not been done, not simply in the wake of the riots from Los Angeles but over the years that we've been trying to get it done. So there's one area we'd start with.
Another one is this new program "Weed and Seed," which I think has broad support. The name implies you weed out the criminals, you seed the areas. And there are some 40 different programs I think are connected with our weed-and-seed initiative that would help, from labor to health to certain education programs.
Longer run, I'm convinced that educational reform is essential for the cities, and I would like to see the crime bill passed. So there's four.
And home ownership, I mean that's something we've been advocating. There's a little progress been made on that. But I think those are the directions that we ought to go to help the cities.
Q: And the directions we shouldn't go?
A: Well, we ought to find out what hasn't worked and not do it. We ought to reform the welfare system so we do everything we can to get families to stay together. When the mayors came to see me, John, they said that the decline in the family was the single most important cause for what went wrong, what's wrong in the cities. And we talk about family values and keeping families together, and there's a little ridicule factor out there, and we are right on target in talking about it and trying to find ways like welfare reform to strengthen the family. . . .
 
Civil Rights and Family Values
 Q: Do you feel that more moral leadership, more exhortation, more calls on the country to cease discrimination, to view a black American the same as a white American, the same as a brown American, are needed from the White House?
A: Well, I think it's needed from everybody, and I've tried very much to do that, speaking out against discrimination, against discrimination of any kind. . . . But I can't argue that it shouldn't be done more, no. I think we should. Find every opportunity to do it.
I take pride in the civil rights bill. I think it's forward-looking. I think it is against quotas, and I think it is against discrimination in the work place. I'm very proud of it as I am of the A.D.A. bill, both of them forward pieces of civil rights legislation.
And to those who want to redefine it and say that I caved in on quotas, they're wrong. They want to say I was dragged kicking to the finish line, they're wrong. We had a good piece of legislation. We kept working with Congress and we finally got it right.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q: The family values that you brought up -- Vice President Quayle's been talking a lot about -- I wonder if you could address those issues. Is it wrong for the entertainment industry to make single motherhood or even unwed motherhood appealing, glamorous, exciting in any way? Is it wrong for people of the same sex or unmarried people to be parents? And why?
A: Yes, it's -- in my set of values, people of the same sex to be parents?
Q: That's right, or unmarried people.
A: No, not unmarried people at all.
But I can't accept as normal life style people of the same sex being parents. I'm very sorry. I don't accept that as normal.
And I believe in the traditional family values. And the best shot that a kid has is to have a mother and father that love that child, that will educate that child, that will care for that child. . . .
But to glamorize life styles that are, in my view, not the normal life style, I don't approve of that. I don't want to censor it, but I don't approve of it.
We've gotten away from our fundamental strengths, which are traditional family values. And I think all the Vice President is trying to do is say we ought to return to that as much as possible. That doesn't condemn every single -- every person that's divorced. But I think when you see the decline of the family, as the mayors were telling me, we'd better find ways to strengthen them.
When you see some of the filth on television, you ought to speak out about it. I mean, I'll spare you the program, but Barbara and I saw one the other night at Camp David. I couldn't believe it. The words. And to think my 15-year-old granddaughter might be listening to that in Miami, Fla.
And people know that it's gone too far. People know that this is bad for the family, putting too much pressure on it. So I applaud speaking out for and trying to find constructive ways to strengthen the family.
 
Problems of Inner Cities
 Q: One of the other points that the Vice President has made is that we've had a change in our moral behavior over the last 20 or so years. And that the poor people in this country, particularly in the inner cities, were more affected by that than you or anybody in this room was. Do you agree with that? Why do you suppose that's the case?
A: Well, I think if you look at the demographics you would see that there are a lot, many more single-parent homes in that kind of an environment. Some of it's economic, I'm sure. Some of it's lack of educational opportunity, quality of education. Some of it is slipping in, then, to practices like the drug culture. Some of it is condoned because of economics, getting involved in selling drugs.
So there's a whole lot of reasons, there's a host of reasons that -- where the pressures are enormous on those families. A lot of it economic.
Q: Do you have to address the economic problem before you----?
A: Yes, we do. Try to get jobs in the inner cities, jobs with dignity. Try to break the welfare dependency, break the cycle of welfare. Everyone knows it's bad. I haven't heard anyone defend it, and they shouldn't.
 
Balancing the Budget
 Q: Mr. President, you spoke very eloquently on behalf of the balanced-budget amendment proposal. If you're re-elected, would you intend to eliminate the deficit during your second term, and how would you go about doing that?
A: We've got a program before the Congress right now, and it leans heavily on controlling the growth of mandatory spending programs. That's the way we would do it. There's a 32-page, 32 pages of alternatives and options up there right now before the Senate. And it is detailed. And I regret to see an editorial in The New York Times today saying that one candidate, Bill Clinton, has put some detail out there and we have not, because that is not factual.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q: The competitiveness of many American industries has declined vis-a-vis the Japanese over the past decade or two. Many Americans, including Mr. Perot and Governor Clinton, are saying that the Government should take a more active role in helping the industries of tomorrow. What do you think is the proper role for the Government?
A: I don't think we ought to have industrial planning. I don't believe in targeting.
I think what we need to do is do what we suggested on research and development and education. Therein lies the answer, and I do not want to see the Government pick winners and losers. Shouldn't do that. Maybe we have a fundamental difference we can talk about in the fall when we get into the campaign mode.
 
U.S. Role in Yugoslavia
Q: Mr. President, you spoke a few minutes ago about your pride in what had been achieved in Desert Storm. . . . I wonder if you could differentiate for me between the situation that we sought to remedy there and the situation in Yugoslavia?
You talked about a friendly country being overrun by an aggressor. I think some people, at least, would describe the Serbian Government as an aggressor attempting to overrun Bosnia and Herzegovina. I think that the loss of life certainly has been greater in Bosnia and Herzegovina than it was in Kuwait. What makes us reluctant to consider military steps by the United Nations or by the United States and the coalition it put together to try to protect these people?
A: I think in the instance of Iraq moving into Kuwait you had one country taking over another country. The Yugoslavian situation is complicated by the fact that you have one country that seems to be disintegrating, or going forward . . . depending on who you are arguing the case----
Q: But we have recognized----
A: ----into many other republics. So you've just started this process. And you have citizens from one entity or another living in another person's country. And so you've got similar----. The situation is more analogous, it seems to me, to what's happening in the western part of the former Soviet Union than it is analogous to what's happening in----.
Q: Moldova.
A: Yes, or Moldova or where else. I mean, look at the map. And so I think that's the thing that has made it different.
Now, the human suffering is enormous, and I am very much concerned about the loss of life there. We are considering what next the United States might do about it.
But I think that is what differentiates the two in the eyes of the whole world. In the eyes of the United Nations, I might add, in the eyes of the E.C.
Q In the months that led up to Desert Storm you said repeatedly that we were not going to exclude any form of response. Are you keeping your options open, vis-a-vis the Yugoslavian situation?
A: Yes.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Relations With Congress
 Q: In any discussion of what this Administration has been able to accomplish or not accomplish comes the complaint that Congress has blocked many of the initiatives you put forward. Well, you're not the first President to face an opposition Congress. Other Republicans have had greater or less luck than you facing the Democratic Congress. Do you think it is legitimate to judge a President, at least in part, based on how well he is able to work with Congress?
A: Whether I think it's legitimate or not isn't the question. I think that will be one criterion to judge the President. I would look back and say that when you have a divided, when you have a divided Government, a President does much better if he controlled one house or the other of the Congress.
There are some vivid exceptions to that rule. Jimmy Carter had control of both houses, and God knows, we don't want to go back to the misery index where it was when he left office. So I can't argue that getting control alone solves all the problems.
What hasn't been tried in the last 35 years is a Republican President and Republican control of both houses of the Congress. When Reagan came into office and I was the Vice President, he got a lot done in the first term because he controlled one house of the Congress. And it makes it an awful lot better if you control, say, one house, say nothing of two.
So I think, yes, you'd have to have people say that's one measure.
But I wasn't elected to do it the way the liberal Democrats that control Congress want, and so I've had to stand up to them. And that's not the measure of how I want to be President.
So I will say to the people this fall, 'Let's try something that hasn't been tried in the last 35 years. Let's try the Republican President whose values, I believe, are in keeping with the values of the American people.'
I think they want stronger crime legislation. I think they'd like a new approach to education. I think they want to see enterprise zones tried, if, indeed, they'd even focused on that question. I think they'd like to see the economy stimulated. I think they'd like to see us try to do a better job on the spending side.
And I'm going to say, now, here's a way to get that done: Give me control of both houses. Give the people a Republican President and control of both houses of Congress. You've tried it with the Democrats, both houses; that was abysmal failure. You've tried it partially with a Republican President, and when that happened, things moved pretty well. But now, try it the way it hasn't been tried.
Q: Is there any reason to believe that if you do not win both houses, or even one house, that you'll have any better luck getting your initiatives through?
A: Yes, because I think I've got problems, but they're nothing compared to what Congress has. And so I think the turnover is going to be important. I think the election will be enormously helpful in that regard, because these values we're talking about and the legislative initiatives I'm talking about will have support from the American people. We will take that case, clearly, to them.
So I think . . . when you first get in, if you're first elected, no matter what the situation, you can get more done. We got the clean-air bill done pretty quick when we first got here, the child-care legislation. We had to fight like the devil to do it against an old-thinking Congress, but we got it done.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q: What do you think when you look back on your career when you see a Governor of a small state, and a man who's never held public office, running you even or better? Aside from the hostility of Congress, what do you think has got into the American public? Is it just the problems with Congress?
A: No, no.
 
The Mood of America
 Q: Is it just the economy?
A: No. It's more.
It's the decline in the American family. It is the fact that there's a negative perception out there, driven largely by the economy. Right track, wrong track. Think you'll be better off tomorrow or not?
The economy has driven it largely. If not, why would things look so much better in polls -- that fortunately I didn't refer to that much -- a year ago? The answer is the economy.
But it's more than that. It is also this feeling against crime. It's the feeling of the decay and decline in the American family. And we're going through, kind of, what I think is a transitional phase. As the economy recovers, I think you're going to see this optimism that has an innate quality of America come back. And I think we're dealing at it from a very low ebb here. The economy is moving, and people think it's getting worse. Now how do you explain that? . . .
And we're going to get it in focus in the campaign, the positive things.
But more fundamental than that, the economy is going to move. And we're still going to have these big problems to face, but we're not going to be facing them against such a negative backdrop. . . .
In the final analysis, people are going to say, who do you want sitting at that desk? Who has the temperament? Who has the experience? Who do we trust? And that's why I'm going to win this election; you watch.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Undeclared Candidate;
Perot Traces Spying Rumors To Bush 'Dirty Tricks' Staff

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 24

 BODY:
Denying reports that he had employed private investigators to uncover information that could be potentially embarrassing to President Bush, Ross Perot today called the accusations part of an orchestrated effort by the "dirty tricks crowd" in Mr. Bush's re-election campaign.
"You all know what's going on, so let's don't pretend that we don't," Mr. Perot told a news conference here after a dockside rally with his supporters. "There has been a 90-day effort to redefine my personality by a group called opposition research of the Republican Party. They're generally known as the dirty tricks crowd." 
 Mr. Perot, the undeclared independent candidate, who is at or near the top of public opinion polls in the three-way Presidential race, used his appearances at the news conference and on television today to try to quash efforts by Republican Party officials to depict him as a dangerous person who, as President, would abuse the powerful Federal apparatus and trample civil liberties. In seeking to refute such assertions, Mr. Perot went on the offensive and engaged in the type of mudslinging that he and his aides have said they would not use.
Mr. Perot was also interviewed live on the NBC "Today" program and on "Larry King Live," the Cable News Network talk program.
 
Pledge on Economic Plan
 Besides denying the Republican accusations, Mr. Perot, touched a number of other issues in his hourlong news conference. He promised that he would have a detailed economic plan that would be "discussed" with the American people before the election. He denounced sexual harassment in the military and said the alleged molestation of women at a convention of Naval aviators last year was "inexcusable."
He told reporters that before he could support a free trade agreement with Mexico, he would have to be sure it would not eliminate American jobs. And without saying it outright, he hinted that he was uncomfortable with the idea of racial preference programs.
Aides to Mr. Perot said the appearances today were intended to "set the record straight" and halt Republican efforts to define the Texas billionaire.
"This press conference was about going to the press and saying, you've heard the following stories, you're writing the following stories, now here are the facts and you write the way you want to," said Mort Meyerson, a senior adviser to Mr. Perot.
Mr. Perot laid the blame squarely at Mr. Bush's feet for the spate of critical reports about him. "He is in charge of the whole process," he said on the "Today" program. "That party does not run out there out of control."
But Mr. Perot predicted that the harsh attacks would backfire on the Republicans "because the American people are just furious with this little theater program they run" in Washington. "The American people want action," he said. They want something to happen in this country. Washington is a master of deception, cover-up and deceit."
Recent news reports have contended that Mr. Perot provided information on what he considered a questionable land deal involving a close friend of the President, investigated Mr. Bush's children and hired private detectives to shadow his own children. At his news conference, Mr. Perot either denied the allegations outright or provided what he said were justifications for his behavior. But when pressed for details in other cases, he avoided direct answers.
Some officials in the Bush campaign today denied that the reports about Mr. Perot's investigtions had been spread by them, the White House or other Republican officials. But Rich Bond, the Republican chairman, freely admits that Republican campaign workers have passed along damaging information about Mr. Perot, though he denies that this constituted "dirty tricks."
Administration officials seem intent on keeping the heat on, and continue to hammer away at the theme of Mr. Perot's purported instability. "Mr. Perot's paranoia knows no bounds," Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, said at his daily briefing.
The news conference today was reminiscent of those held by Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas in the wake of allegations that he had had an affair with a cabaret singer. Perot aides appeared concerned that the Texan's drive could be blunted by accusations about his character. Mr. Meyerson noted that in some surveys, the number of people who do not approve of Mr. Perot has doubled.
Mr. Perot denied that he had sought out information on Mr. Bush's children. He said he had merely received reports from a source he declined to identify that one of Mr. Bush's sons was consorting with a gun-runner for anti-Communist guerrillas in Nicaragua. He said he had passed along the information to Mr. Bush, then Vice President, as "one father to another."
Perot aides gave reporters photocopies of a handwritten note from Mr. Bush, written in December 1986, thanking Mr. Perot for providing him with the information. "You see, I was very touched by your call about my kids," Mr. Bush wrote, adding that his children "are all straight arrows, uninvolved in intrigue."
But Mr. Perot avoided answering a question of why, if he suspected shady dealings in a 1982 land deal involving the Penzoil company, he had given material relating to the deal to The Washington Post, rather than to the Internal Revenue Service. In the transaction, Penzoil, headed by Hugh Liedtke, a former business partner of Mr. Bush, was granted a $48 million tax deduction for the gift of 100,000 acres to the Federal Government.
 
Questions About Deal
 Instead, Mr. Perot engaged in a long, rambling discussion of the value of the land, and asked: "How and why did they get such favorable treatment? Why did they get such a huge evaluation on the land?" He said that he had "casually" mentioned the transaction to Bob Woodward, an assistant managing editor at The Post, and that when Mr. Woodward later asked for documents, he gave him documents obtained by a Washington law firm retained by Mr. Perot. "That's not walking around with a Sherlock Holmes hat and a magnifying glass," he said.
An assistant to Mr. Woodward said the editor was away for the next two weeks and could not be reached to corroborate Mr. Perot's account.
Throughout the news conference, Mr. Perot displayed his customary pugnacious style. At one point he dismissed the controversy that has swirled around him in recent days as "Mickey Mouse, tossed salad." In response to a question about whether he had hired a detective to shadow his children and check up on their friends, Mr. Perot said whatever he did was out of a desire to protect his children, adding, "It is a huge gap between making sure they're safe, and investigating my children and/or their friends, or whatever else some fruitcake alleges."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Voices -- Chicago;
3 Views on the President's Domestic Record

 BODY:
Political experts, local officials and ordinary voters in several cities were asked to appraise George Bush's performance as President.
 
Andrew Sohn
36 years old; lawyer in a small Chicago firm
I think one of Bush's problems is you really can't point to a single domestic program that you can call an achievement. In a way, his neglect has been the most significant thing. As a few months pass and you get some sense of who this guy is, you see he has a distinctly right-wing, almost extreme conservative mindset. I was taken aback by how cool and harsh his opinions were. 
 I think he is basically a decent guy. I got into a lot of fights with some of my younger friends after the L.A. riots. They were trying to lay the blame at George Bush's feet, implying he had contempt for the poor. I don't think that's true. But he certainly doesn't have the ability to convey any compassion.
I don't think he's got the inner gift that either a Kennedy or a Reagan had. I didn't like Ronald Reagan, but he had a gift for conceptualizing issues and communicating them. Bush just doesn't have that.
 
Paul Green
49 years old; political scientist and director of the Institute for Public Policy at Governors State University
If the guy gets blamed for the economic recession, then we have to give him credit for defeating communism. [He has kept his promises] as well as any candidate. Campaigns are basically competing wish lists. Whether you like him or dislike him, he basically hasn't changed. He's what he said he would be. He has done as well as expected. He has basically done a satisfactory job.
No one should be surprised by the last four years. I think basically, it has been a continuation of the Reagan era. Basically, it's a suburbanized view of America; those people who are predominately white, middle-income, college-educated. Those are people who should benefit from the policies of the Reagan-Bush era, and basically they have.
If this election year was a referendum on foreign policy, George Bush would be a shoo-in. Unfortunately, other issues of this country have completely overshadowed that. The bottom line is, Where are you going to get the money and who are you going to spend it on?. You could spend a stealth bomber on any major city and you know what, you'll have marginal, if any, change.
 
Barbara McCollum
33 years old; a carpenter
With the Gulf war, he spent a lot of time and diverted a lot of money away from domestic issues that needed to be dealt with. I think he wanted to rally a lot of Americans or reinvent that feeling that America was No. 1. That was good.
But I think we need to work on things in this country. Like getting rid of drugs, cutting down the crime rate, creating jobs. I think going to war just diverted our energy away from those issues. We generated this nice, good feeling, but we wasted a lot of resources on the war.
The only two promises I can remember was that he would be the environmental President and that he would be the education President. I think the way he took such a hands-off approach to Exxon's polluting of Alaska showed he really wasn't the environmental President. And I don't think he has committed any extra resources to education, so he hasn't come through on that one either.
He is the kind of leader who says the right things but does nothing. He talks about the family and how important the family is, but there's no decent day care in this country. We don't have national health insurance. We haven't done anything to provide low-cost housing so young couples can get a place. That's supposed to be the American dream.
I think we need to be able to compete economically and it's more than just bashing people who buy Japanese cars. I don't think he is capable of coming off the sound bites and dealing with these issues."

That's supposed to be the American dream." -- BARBARA McCOLLUM (Photographs by Jack Spratt for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Most of Rail Network Shuts Down In Response to Strike at One Line

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr.

 BODY:
Most of the nation's freight railroads shut down yesterday in response to a limited strike against just one of them, and they immediately began urging Congress to step into the labor dispute by passing legislation imposing contract terms on recalcitrant unions throughout the industry.
Amtrak, the passenger railroad, was hobbled by the shutdown because most of its trains outside the Northeast run on lines owned by the idled freight railroads. But many of the nation's biggest commuter lines, including those in the New York area, were not greatly affected. 
 Still, tens of thousands of travelers were inconvenienced, and there remained a possibility that more passenger trains would be canceled after the next strike deadline, which one union set at 12:01 A.M. on Friday.
 
Accusation of Bad Faith
 The unions, which had granted most of the railroads a reprieve by offering to continue working and negotiating beyond the previous deadline of 12:01 A.M. on Wednesday, yesterday accused the freight railroads of bargaining in bad faith. Union officials said the railroads were effectively locking out workers nationwide in order to create an artificial emergency.
At a hearing of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, which was considering whether Congress should legislate an end to the shutdown, the chief negotiator for the Brotherhood of Maintenance of Way Employees, Jed Dodd, said, "What the carriers are doing is creating a national emergency out of a local strike so that this committee and the Congress imposes onerous agreements on our members."
That union went to Federal District Court in Washington yesterday seeking an order preventing the freight lines from locking its members out of work. A hearing was scheduled for today.
It was not clear how quickly Congress might act, if at all.
Lawmakers might simply order the railroads and their employees to resume operations under contract terms proposed by a Federal mediation panel before the talks broke down. But some members of Congress were said to favor a simple extension of the negotiating period, moving the strike deadline until later in the summer, perhaps after the political conventions.
In April 1991, Congress halted a rail strike 17 hours after it began and imposed contracts similar to those that had been recommended by a Federal mediating panel. The current dispute is a continuation of last year's.
The nationwide shutdown began early yesterday the International Association of Machinists set up pickets shortly after midnight against the CSX Corporation, one of many railroads with which the machinists had been negotiating.
 
The Railroads' Argument
 The railroads argued that the nation's freight lines formed a "seamless" system that could not properly function if a big piece like the 33,601 miles of track owned by CSX, the nation's third-largest railroad, was removed from service.
"Freight is lost, freight is delayed, freight is backed up," the Association of American Railroads said in a statement. "Rather than grind to a halt over a 24-hour period, attempting to make connections and failing to serve the shipping public, the railroads thought it in the interest of their customers and the public to promptly notify them as to the effect the I.A.M. strike would have almost immediately."
As the day wore on, there were mounting strains on the transportation system and the manufacturing base.
"The Council of Economic Advisers' best estimate is that the economy will lose about a billion dollars every day the strike continues," said Michael Boskin, head of the White House economic office.
Although several railroads continued to try to provide normal service, at least over shorter distances, in the face of problems switching cars to other lines, the majority were in the process of shutting down.
The machinists union said it picketed relatively few locations of CSX, a railroad that was made the union's target because its routes are largely duplicated by those of other carriers.
"There is no reason that one passenger or one ounce of freight cannot be carried on the nations' railroads, except for the irresponsible behavior of the freight carriers," John F. Peterpaul, the machinists' vice president, said in a written statement.
But the railroads said they always bargain as a group to avoid a single member from being isolated and forced to capitulate, at which point other railroads would be struck one at a time.
"Employers in a multi-employer bargaining group must shut down in defense of their struck member of the group, not solely to protect the struck member but also to protect the bargaining group itself from the ultimate result of exorbitant and costly settlements," the railroad association said.
 
Warnings From Manufacturers
 Thomas Hanna, president of the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association, said on ABC's "Good Morning America" program that if the shutdown continued beyond 24 hours, about of quarter of the plants making cars or their components would begin to be effected. "With a week, the industry could effectively be shut down," Mr. Hanna said.
But a spokesman for the General Motors Corporation, which gets a quarter of its parts by rail, said customers would not feel any immediate effects since dealers have several weeks of cars on hand waiting to be sold.
Food-industry executives and analysts said that they did not expect the rail shutdown to have a significant impact on the manufacture and delivery of food products in the near future.
In recent years the industry has increasingly turned to trucks to carry food. For example, Kraft General Foods Inc. expects only a few shipments to be disrupted.
Officials of the Ferro Corporation, a maker of coatings, plastics and specialty chemicals based in Cleveland, said a rail shutdown would have to last nearly a month to affect the company's supply and distribution patterns.
Transportation Secretary Andrew H. Card Jr., urging Congress to legislate an end to the shutdown, said in Congressional testimony that he had been told of a Texas plastics maker that would end normal production after one or two days, and of a New Jersey chemical company whose clients would have to shut down in two days because the chemical company could no longer supply them with vital chlorine.
Although there was some disruption to passenger travel, it did not seem to be as severe as had been feared in the last few days of bargaining.
Tom Clancy, the writer of popular thrillers, was briefly stuck in Salt Lake City with a party of family and friends who were traveling by Amtrak on a private car to Las Vegas. They rented a van and continued on their way yesterday morning.
But in Orlando, Fla., a vacationing Briton named Iain Bebbington said he did not know how he would get to New York for his flight home on Saturday. Amtrak trains in Florida rely on CSX track and dispatchers and were not running. Mr. Bebbington's rail pass, mostly used up, did not have enough remaining value for him to get a refund from Amtrak to pay the air fare to New York, but he did have the option of a 22-hour trip on a Greyhound bus.
In the Boston area, Amtrak maintained commuter service to about 70,000 people who ride trains into the city from the North and South Shores, although many thousands chose to drive to work instead because of the uncertainty.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Most freight railroads shut down yesterday in response to a strike against CSX. In Atlanta, Arty Puryear, left, a striking CSX machinist, talked with B. T. Bartlett, a machinist locked out by Norfolk Southern. (Associated Press)
 
Chart: "Empty Tracks: Behind the Rail Dispute"
 The International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, representing 7,800 workers at 40 freight railroads went on strike against one line, the CSX Corporation. Other freight lines then shut down, saying the strike against CSX left them no choice. The Brotherhood of Maintenance ofWay Employees, representing 2,000 workers at Amtrak and Conrail, said they would not strike until at least 12:01 A.M. Friday while talks continue. These are the two main rail unions in the negotiations.
 The railroads have offered the same basic wages and work rules that Congress imposed last year.
 
The main issues besides wages involve:
 * Contracting out of work and reducing crew sizes. The railroads argue that they need the cuts to operate more efficiently. Unions have already lost hundreds of jobs to the cuts.
 * Health benefits. The railroads want to pay a smaller share.
 * Collective bargaining. The unions are concerned that the railroads are avoiding real bargaining by halting operations and then asking Congress to intervene and impose a settlement. The railroads are concerned that any agreement with the two main unions that differ from those imposed on the other unions last year could make the other unions dissatisfied.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Detroit auto makers have not suffered significant harm from imported Japanese mini-vans, a Federal trade agency ruled. The landmark decision prevents the Commerce Department from imposing tariffs on the imports. [Page A1.]
Enterprise zones to spur the economy of 50 impoverished areas were voted by the House Ways and Means Committee. [D1.] 
 Most of the nation's freight railroads shut down in response to a limited strike against just one of them. [A18.]
New orders for durable manufactured goods fell 2.4 percent in May, an unexpected and significant decline. [D1.]
Sales of domestically made cars rose a slight 1.5 percent in mid-June, with strength mainly from trucks and rental cars. [D6.]
Shearson Lehman Brothers and two senior traders were fined $600,000 by the New York Stock Exchange for manipulating the price of Conagra stock immediately before a public offering. [D16.]
 
International
Crazy Eddie's founder, Eddie Antar, was arrested in Israel on charges of securities fraud. He was accused of having made more than $74 million from selling company stock while knowing that financial statements were falsified. [D1.]
Reichmann family interests borrowed millions from their flagship real estate company a year and a half before it filed for Canadian bankruptcy protection, lawyers testified. [D5.]
International Totalizator has a contract to provide a lottery and keno system to the former Soviet republic of Georgia. [D16.]
 
Companies
Robert H. Smith said that he would resign as the second-ranking executive at BankAmerica. [D5.]
Dell Computer is negotiating to put I.B.M.'s OS-2 personal-computer operating system directly on its hard drives. [D5.]
Galeries Lafayette expects to lose more in 1992 than the $3.6 million it lost in 1991 on its Fifth Avenue store. [D2.]
David Coleridge, chairman of Lloyd's of London, urged angry investors not to jump ship despite "appalling" losses. [D6.]
 
Markets
The stock market made scattered gains thanks to declining interest rates, with the Dow average up 5.08 to 3,290.70. [D10.]
Treasury securities rose in price, and interest rates slipped, propelled by the weak report on durable orders. [D19.]
Copper futures prices surged as a shutdown of the American freight-rail system raised prospects of tight supplies. [D21.] The dollar fell as fresh economic data called the strength of the economic recovery into question. [D21.]
