HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Rail Shutdown Lifts Prices Of Heating Oil and Copper

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
A shutdown of the American freight-rail system sent copper futures prices up sharply yesterday and contributed to a steep rise in the prices of heating oil futures.
Copper for June delivery jumped 2.10 cents, to $1.0685 a pound on the Commodity Exchange in New York. The buying reflected fears that the halt in rail shipments would aggravate an already tight supply levels. 
 "Most people have been carrying marginal inventories," said Stephen Platt, metals analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds.
 
Could Turn Bearish
 The nation's freight trains stopped rolling yesterday after a union struck one rail company and the rest of the industry shut down. The unions accused the companies of a lockout.
Although initially bullish for copper, the rail shipping halt could become a bearish factor if it lasts long enough to put a damper on the economic recovery because copper is a basic metal in many industries. That point may be about two weeks away, said James Steel, an analyst withRefco in New York.
Copper prices were rising before the rail strike. Copper for June delivery had climbed about 4 cents a pound since late May on signs of relatively tight world supplies and the threat of a copper strike in Poland.
Poland exports about 200,000 tons of refined copper to the West annually, Mr. Steel said.
Mr. Steel said the rail strike also contributed to a surge in heating oil futures prices on the New York Mercantile Exchange, though the rally was rooted mainly in an industry report late on Tuesday that American stocks of petroleum distillates, products like heating oil, were nearly 6 percent below the five-year average. The American Petroleum Institute also reported an unexpectedly steep drop last week in crude oil stocks.
Mr. Steel said the rail stoppage had helped lift heating oil because more goods likely will be shipped by trucks, which are heavier users of diesel fuel, a close relative to heating oil.
The rail strike also could increase air-shuttle traffic in the New York-Washington corridor, he said. That would prompt increased demand for jet fuel, which is also closely related to heating oil.
Home heating oil for July settled at 63.66 cents a gallon, up 1.55 cents. Heating oil for next-month delivery had not settled that high since Nov. 20, when the final price was 63.73 cents a gallon.
Unleaded gasoline for delivery in July settled at 65.15 cents a gallon, up 0.02 cent. Crude oil for delivery in August settled at $22.89 a barrel, up 30 cents. Natural gas prices were higher, with contracts for delivery in August settling at $1.521 for 1,000 cubic feet, up 3.8 cents.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls on Indications Of Weak Recovery in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar lost ground again yesterday on world currency markets, depressed by fresh economic data that called into question the strength of the economic recovery in the United States.
Gold prices were mostly lower. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $342.80 an ounce, off $1.70 from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank said gold had fallen $1.45 an ounce, to a late bid price of $342.65. 
 The dollar tumbled on a report showing that new orders for durable goods had fallen an unexpectedly sharp 2.4 percent in May -- the steepest drop since December -- underscoring the uneven nature of the economic recovery. Most economists had anticipated an advance of three-tenths to nine-tenths percent.
"The dollar really needed to see some good economic reports," said Mike Faust, an analyst with MMS International. "And when we didn't see it, it set the stage for some pretty solid dollar losses." Mr. Faust said trading had been heavy after the release of the report.
 
Effect of Call for Lower Rates
 The dollar was further pressed by President Bush's call for the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates to give the economy a boost. Lower interest rates tend to make dollar-denominated securities less valuable, reducing investors' demand for dollars.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 127.03 yen, up 0.07 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 126.60 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 126.45 yen, down from 127.28 yen on Tuesday.
In London the pound rose to $1.8780, from $1.8620 late Tuesday. In New York it cost $1.8795 to buy 1, more expensive than Tuesday's $1.8625.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.5500 German marks, down from 1.5660; 1.4005 Swiss francs, down from 1.4175; 5.2185 French francs, down from 5.2710; 1,173.00 Italian lire, down from 1,184.00, and 1.1957 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1968.

HEADLINE: Stride Rite's Net Up 16%

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 24

 BODY:
The Stride Rite Corporation, which makes Keds brand and other shoes, said today that second-quarter earnings rose 16 percent.
It warned, however, that analysts' estimates for the full fiscal year were "a little too high," which sent the company's stock plunging $4.625 a share, closing today at $20.375 on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 Stride Rite said second-quarter net income rose to $21.8 million, or 42 cents a share, from $18.8 million, or 37 cents a share, a year ago. It said sales for the quarter ended May 29 increased to $171 million from $153.9 million.
John J. Phelan, vice chairman and chief financial officer, said percentage gains for the full fiscal year 1992 will be below those recorded in the second quarter because the recession has made customers cautious about buying.
Analysts' estimates for full-year net income of $1.45 to $1.55 a share, on sales of $615 million to $620 million, are "a little too high," Mr. Phelan said.
In the fiscal year ended Nov. 30, the company earned $66 million, or $1.28 a share, on sales of $574.4 million.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Patchwork Outfield Works Out for Yanks

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 24

 BODY:
Figure this one out, if you can. The Yankees did not have Danny Tartabull or Roberto Kelly available tonight and they had a pitcher who could not throw strikes in his last start. No chance for victory, right? Wrong.
Any doubt about their outfield was eliminated when Dion James and Jim Leyritz, the replacements for the two starters, helped the Yankees score four runs in the first inning. And any doubt about Jeff Johnson's pitches was erased inning after inning as he cruised past the Royals for seven strong innings. 
 The result of the unexpected performances by these three Yankees was an unpredictable, but highly acceptable 6-3 victory over Kansas City at Royals Stadium.
The triumph gave the Yankees a chance to finish their lengthy road trip with an even record because they stand at 6-7 with one game remaining, Thursday afternoon.
"It would certainly be nice to do that," said Manager Buck Showalter. "We would have liked to do better, but it would be nice to win tomorrow."
 
First Victory Since April
 Johnson's pitching gave the Yankees a chance to dream about him actually being a viable part of their rotation. The left-hander has yet to show he truly belongs because he has been so erratic and still seems to be one bad start away from the minors. But he earned his first victory since April 19 by scattering eight hits and walking only two.
After Johnson was hammered for eight hits and six earned runs in two and two-thirds innings in his outing against Baltimore, he might have been hanging in the majors by a thread. But pitching coach Mark Connor met with him two days ago, told him to be aggressive and start proving himself and Johnson obeyed.
"He's had 30 starts in the big leagues and it is time for him to pitch well, to be consistent," Connor said. "He's got to go out there and pitch six or seven innings, whether he has his good stuff or not."
 
No Easy Task
 Staked to the quick 4-0 lead in the first, Johnson did not fool around with batters, used his curveball often and tossed 93 economical pitches while lasting into the eighth. Though Johnson claimed the conversation with Connor boosted him, he refused to view tonight as integral to remaining in the majors. He has done that previously and it overwhelmed him.
"Wins don't come too easy for a guy like me," said Johnson, who has a 5.72 e.r.a. after allowing two earned runs in seven innings. "If you put added pressure on yourself and worry about going to Columbus, you'll really be in trouble. I'm not doing it anymore."
Reciting what Connor had told him, Johnson said, "I've got a year in the big leagues and it's time for me to start doing something."
The Yanks did something against Rick Reed after the national anthem by raking him for four runs and four hits. Andy Stankiewicz started the frame by singling to right field for the first of his four hits and James followed by doubling him in with the first run.
Don Mattingly clubbed a single to right, Mel Hall popped out and Kevin Maas walked to load the bases. Leyritz, who was starting his second career game in right field, made the lineup look terrific with a sacrifice fly to give the Yanks a 2-0 lead.
Reed induced Matt Nokes to hit a grounder near second base, but it glanced off Keith Miller's glove for a costly error and allowed Mattingly to score. Charlie Hayes added a run-scoring single that gave the Yankees a comfortable 4-0 lead. Both Leyritz and James were super subs with three hits each while the team pounded 15 against four pitchers.
"It was nice to get ahead early and get the momentum going in our way," said Stankiewicz, after the first four-hit game of his career. "That's my job and it was nice to do it. That's what the big guys behind me want me to do."
 
INSIDE PITCH
 ROBERTO KELLY will miss two to four days with a bruised left shoulder blade he incurred from being hit by a pitch Tuesday. . . . Since DANNY TARTABULL is with his wife and newborn son in New Jersey, DION JAMES will handle center with JIM LEYRITZ and RANDY VELARDE getting playing time in right. . . . KELLIE TARTABULL, Danny's wife, gave birth to a 7-pound, 20-inch boy late Tuesday and named him ZACHARY. The baby was born three weeks premature and is in intensive care at a Teaneck, N.J. hospital because his lungs are not yet fully developed. Tartabull will likely rejoin the club Friday.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Studying Soccer Violence by the Civilized British

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

Among the Thugs
By Bill Buford
317 pages. W. W. Norton. $22.95. 
 We think of England as being civilized. (It is we Americans who are violent.) And so apparently did Bill Buford, the American expatriate editor of the literary magazine Granta, who has lived in England since 1977. At leasthe thought the English civilized until one Saturday evening in 1982, when he took a train from Wales to London and saw the appalling evidence of what English soccer fans had done that day. (Or football supporters, as he calls them, using British terminology throughout his report.)
"My journey . . . offered up a vision of the English Saturday, the shopping day, that was different from the one I had known: that in the towns and cities you might find hundreds of police, military in their comprehensiveness, out to contain young, male sports fans who, after attending an athletic contest, were determined to break or destroy the things that were in their way. It was hard to believe."
It was so hard to believe that he felt compelled to take a closer look. He went to a soccer match on his own, experienced what he calls "a movable crush" and saw nothing of the game because there were too many people in the way. He wanted to befriend some likely looking thug, was at first regarded as "a deviant homosexual who deserved to be injured badly," but soon met "someone who was truly spectacular to look at, qualifying for that special category of human being -- one of its most repellent specimens."
He got to know the subculture, won the trust of the people he met for being "a good geezer," and traveled with his new companions around England and Europe during a decade when the behavior of soccer fans was making world headlines. Out of his adventures comes a book, "Among the Thugs," that is both funny and scary and is filled with violence that at least in one incident surpasses Shakespeare's "Titus Andronicus." If the book didn't have an ultimately serious purpose, one would be tempted to say it was all too much.
Mr. Buford pushes the possibilities of participatory journalism to a disturbing degree. He reports getting so drunk with his hooligan pals that he sometimes had trouble remembering what happened. He witnessed violence that he might have been able to impede, though probably at the cost of becoming its victim. He became part of rioting crowds that inflicted property damage and bodily injury. And at times, being part of it all, he even enjoyed himself.
But his joining in seems justified to the reader because he was always working out a theory on what he was witnessing, an important part of which has to do with the stages of a crowd's behavior. To understand the terrifying phenomenon of English soccer hooliganism, you could not simply take a snapshot and run away from it.
He thought at first that the violence was a protest. "So many young people were out of work or had never been able to find any. The violence, it followed, was a rebellion of some kind -- social rebellion, class rebellion, something." But as he got deeper into it, he discovered a multitude of subtle nuances. He began to focus on the surprising psychology of the crowd experience. He discovered that a violent crowd is a being unto itself, that there are elements of it inside every one of us and that getting caught up in the frenzy can be ecstatic.
As for why young males in England were rioting every Saturday: "They do it for the same reason that another generation drank too much or smoked dope or took hallucinogenic drugs or behaved badly or rebelliously. Violence is their antisocial kick, their mind-altering experience, an adrenaline-induced euphoria that might be all the more powerful because it is generated by the body itself, with, I was convinced, many of the same addictive qualities that characterize synthetically produced drugs."
This of course is only part of an answer. And Mr. Buford presses on, concluding that the rioters need their fix of violence because English society is somehow realigning itself, and the old working class has disappeared in the new service economy. This seems pale and abstract beside his colorful observations on crowd behavior. It hardly accounts for shocking outbursts of racism and nationalism that suggest a genetic drive to wage war against the outlander, as if the English soccer thugs were unfulfilled soldiers grown restless from waiting too long for King Henry V to return and lead them in another battle of Agincourt.
But the author distracts us from any dissatisfaction we may have with his sociology by relating how he finally paid for his involvement with the thugs. Despite being fed up with his friends, he went to Sardinia for the 1990 World Cup semifinals, was caught in the middle of another riot and suffered a brutal beating at the hands of the Italian police, much as Hunter S. Thompson was punished for his journalistic curiosity at the end of his book "Hell's Angels," when he was beaten by one of the motorcycle gangs he was investigating. We can admire Mr. Buford for his daring, but he also permits us to feel superior in our detachment.
Meanwhile, the reader can't help dwelling on an interlude a third of the way into the book in which a police superintendent questions the author about American football matches: " 'Am I mistaken, Mr. Buford,' the superintendent continued, 'or is it the case that there are also very few policemen in the grounds of these American football matches?'
"Very few, I assured him.
"'And yet,' Superintendent McAllister continued, 'there is no trouble?'
" 'None.' "
"Among the Thugs" does severe damage to the conventional wisdom that England and Europe are bastions of civilization, while the United States is the country whose character has been forever scarred by violence.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
Two Old Rivals Now Running Together

SERIES: 30 Days to Barcelona -- Eighth article of a series on the Summer Olympics.

 BODY:
Professional antagonists for so long, Magic Johnson and Larry Bird are finally together, both on the same team and in pursuit of the same goal: a gold medal in men's basketball at the Olympics this summer.
They've waited years for this, haven't they? When they first met, it was 1979, in the Final Four championship game, Johnson playing for national champion Michigan State, Bird for runner-up Indiana State. And later, in the National Basketball Association, they waged memorable battles throughout the 1980's, Johnson taking the Los Angeles Lakers to five league titles and Bird helping the Boston Celtics soar to three. 
 Theirs was a mutual, if sometimes grudging, admiration. But not until this week in La Jolla, Calif., have they played side by side on the same court. They are preparing for an Olympic qualifying tournament that starts Saturday in Portland, Ore.
"This could be the last hurrah for both of us," said Johnson, who effectively announced his retirement last November because he had contracted the virus that causes AIDS. "You never know. So this one isn't just for Laker fans, or just for Celtic fans, it's for basketball fans everywhere."
Bird, 35 years old, concedes he is nearing the end, especially after being limited to 45 games this season because of problems with his lower back after surgery last summer. Like Johnson, however, he has refused to say anything official about retirement.
He does, however, talk about getting a chance to play on the same team with Johnson, once his rival but now his friend and teammate.
"This is nice," he said today, "because Magic's been out all year and there's no question that our careers are close to being over. It's a great honor, yes, but like I've said, we're here for one reason and that's to win a gold.
"Just playing on the team is not going to do it. We came here to accomplish something, and hopefully we can do it together."
 
Albania Seeks a Way
 "Gervish Per Te Fituar," translated as "Scratch for Win," is the logo on Albanian lottery tickets intended to generate funds for the country's Olympic team. Unless $100,000 is raised within a few weeks for the squad, some Albanian athletes will be scratched from competing in Barcelona.
Jorgoni Arben, Albania's deputy Minister of Youth Sports and Culture, said most of the $150,000 raised for the team in lottery sales has not been released by the Government because of economic difficulties. The Albanians, though, are still hoping to field 15 athletes in 5 events in the country's first Olympic Games since 1972.
"The most important thing is just to take part for the first time as a democratic state," said Arben, whose country ousted its Communist leadership in free elections last March. "The goals of sports will spread in the country and the Olympic movement will increase."
Albania has raised $500,000 over all since it began selling lottery tickets six months ago. Tickets are 50 cents apiece, with a minimum purchase of two, and prizes range from a free ticket to $5,000.
Lottery sales have slowed recently because of difficulty obtaining tickets and a sluggish economy. To remedy the problems, tickets will soon be available in stores rather than banks and new types of lottery games will be implemented.
 
Changing Faces
 Three major stars of the old Soviet Union failed to make the track and field team that will represent the Commonwealth of Independent States at the Barcelona Olympics.
In trials this week in Moscow, Yuri Sedykh, the leading hammer thrower in history, and his greatest rival, Sergei Litvinov, did not finish among the top three. Sedykh, the 37-year-old Olympic champion in 1976 and 1980 and the world champion last year, was fourth behind Igor Astapkovich, Andrei Abduvalyev and Igor Nikulin. Litvinov, 34 years old, the 1988 Olympic champion and world champion of 1983 and 1987, did not advance to the final eight.
Between them, Sedykh and Litvinov have the 19 longest throws in history, led by Sedykh's world record of 284 feet 7 inches. That is nearly 18 feet farther than the best ever by an American, Jud Logan's 268-8. With a throw of 262-10 on his final effort today, Logan was among the top finishers at the United States trials today. The other qualifiers were Lance Deal (262-3) and Ken Flax (254-5).
Another leading athlete from the former Soviet Union who did not make the team was Galina Chistiakova, the world-record holder in the long jump. She finished 10th in the Commonwealth trials.

HEADLINE: Keep the U.N. -- and America's Word

 BODY:
Mayor David Dinkins has mounted a catch-up campaign to keep four United Nations agencies from leaving New York City for cheaper pastures in Germany or suburban New Rochelle. That's a start. But this is not just a municipal matter. It also involves winning world respect for America's word.
The Mayor needs help from Congress and the Bush Administration. They're to blame for America's abysmal failure to pay, in full and on time, the dues owed the world organization. 
 It won't do simply to snipe at Chancellor Helmut Kohl, as if he were a crafty Rhine maiden trying to lure unwary U.N. workers to sleepy Bonn. When Germany's capital moves to Berlin, there will be ample space in a not unpleasant city. Mr. Kohl is offering free rent and moving expenses to the U.N. Development Program, the Population Fund and the Development Fund for Women.
He has a solid advantage: Germany has paid its U.N. dues, and even promises to increase its added voluntary contribution. Uncle Deadbeat, by contrast, owes $555 million in general dues and $112 million for peacekeeping. Much of the shortfall results from a fiscal gimmick. Though dues are payable on Jan. 1, the check does not go into the mail until October, when the U.S. begins a new fiscal year. American procrastination invites other members to follow suit, thereby deepening the U.N.'s chronic cash shortage.
More noise about this delinquency is in order, especially from New York's two Senators and the City's 14 Representatives. This is not a partisan issue. Polls show strong public support for the U.N.
City Hall has already come up with a competitive offer to dissuade the United Nations Children's Fund from moving to New Rochelle. Deputy Mayor Barry Sullivan proposes a rent reduction of $28 million over 20 years if Unicef remains on U.N. Plaza. And to underwrite future expansion, the city is prepared to issue tax-exempt bonds.
But the German challenge requires more urgent attention, both in New York and in Washington. If Chancellor Kohl prevails, the rest of the United Nations will soon be coaxed elsewhere, diminishing New York's standing and America's special status as a nation of nations.

HEADLINE: New Promise for Peace in Israel

 BODY:
Even Israelis seem surprised by the outcome of their most momentous vote in a generation. Few predicted such a decisive turn to Yitzhak Rabin's Labor Party, ending its 15 years in the wilderness. But enough Israelis voted cautiously for peace to enable him to form a government that's hostage neither to the extreme right or left.
This is an outcome Americans can welcome with relief and considerable hope. For President Bush, who has suffered harsh criticism from some American Jews, the results vindicate a long, tenacious peace initiative. 
 The peace talks he prompted have galvanized such broad support in Israel that even Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir held back his criticism. And now, after long pre-election paralysis, the Rabin victory offers hope to all sides. "It looks like the peace process has been rescued from the Likud's attempts at sabotaging it," Hanan Ashrawi, a leading Palestinian, said yesterday.
Mr. Rabin promises first priority to granting autonomy and self-rule to Palestinians. Moreover, he pledges to curb settlements in the disputed West Bank and Gaza Strip, thus opening the way for U.S. approval of $10 billion in loan guarantees to help Israel absorb Russian immigrants. By quietly refusing to yield on this condition, Washington managed to improve Mr. Rabin's chances without giving Mr. Shamir a provocative target.
The elections spell out the result. The Likud coalition won only 32 seats of the Parliament's 120 seats, its worst showing since 1969. Labor's share increased from 37 to 45. Placing third with 12 seats was the unabashedly dovish Meretz bloc, giving the peace faction new leverage.
Mr. Shamir's defeat owed much to mismanagement of the overtaxed, overregulated economy. Soaring unemployment led to a dramatic drop in Russian emigration; the frustrated newcomers turned strongly against Likud. This debacle was inextricably linked to the Government's frantic effort to build new settlements.
The blunt Mr. Rabin exploited this linkage, while reminding voters that he was also commander in the triumphant Six-Day War 25 years ago. Even fresher is his recent service as Defense Minister, when he confronted the Palestinian uprising with "might, power and beatings."
Yet toughness is scarcely the same as inflexibility. Israelis demonstrably yearn for peace and security in a transformed Middle East. Labor and its new leader speak of national interest and security guarantees, rather than ideological and biblical claims to a Greater Israel. The change to the pragmatic Mr. Rabin offers new possibilities for a land-for-peace compromise vainly sought by successive American Presidents.
This opportunity could evaporate, however, if Palestinians and their Arab allies once again misread the Israeli mood. Reciprocal trust can only be nurtured by matching moderation. In this, further resourceful diplomacy by Secretary of State James Baker can make a difference. It has already paid generous dividends.

SECTION: Section A; Page 31; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 689 words

HEADLINE: Salesman Or Strategist?

BYLINE: By Robert B. Costello; Robert B. Costello was Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition in the Reagan and early Bush Administrations.

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS

 BODY:
No one is in a better position to take a stand on the Government's role in helping U.S. industry compete than Ross Perot. An insider who understands the intricate workings of Government, he used his knowledge to build an industry -- Electronic Data Systems -- and great personal wealth.
The question is: Is Mr. Perot the kind of leader who is willing to make commitments against which he asks to be measured, or is he the slick systems sales pro who will tell us anything to get the job and is never pinned down on specifics? 
 When he was a businessman hungry for public-sector work, Mr. Perot studied the Government's needs. If the tables were turned and he was in charge, we would expect him to define a role for government in using its vast resources to nurture industries critical for U.S. leadership in the 21st century.
Mr. Perot is no strict protectionist. His strategy at E.D.S. demonstrated that he understands the dangers of a go-it-alone industrial policy. He developed the American and foreign resources his company needed to be competitive -- and to build an American data processing industry in partnership with the Government. Thus, he should have more insight than any politician into how government might create opportunities for growth, investment and employment.
We know that the Government can play this role. Important technologies -- computers, semiconductors and jet aircraft -- originated in the Defense Department, the result of wise investments to meet civilian and military needs. The Pentagon supported critical research and development and then proceeded to buy enough of the product to put in place the infrastructure to make the U.S. the international leader in these industries. This was accomplished without restricting trade or limiting the global exchange of technical information.
These breakthroughs were unexpected dividends, since such a public-private partnership was not the original goal. But perhaps it is a model for the future.
The world's largest buyer of goods and services is our Government. With the proper industrial policy, this power can be harnessed to revive our technological and manufacturing leadership.
For too many years, politicians have pushed big pork barrel science projects, like the supercollider, with little regard for building a broader technical base with the potential for benefiting everyone. Germany and Japan have promoted useful projects, supporting industries and technologies from precision instruments to semiconductors.
The hydrogen-cycle internal-combustion engine would have been a good test of the potential role of the Government as a catalyst and leader in industrial development. If we had been able to point to progress on this nonpolluting technology at the Earth Summit, we might have been seen as a leader, not a reluctant follower.
The U.S. had the potential to be far ahead in developing this lightweight engine, which runs on hydrogen and air, producing only water and nitrogen oxides as byproducts. Research and development still need to be done and a market has to be created.
If the military pioneered the use of the technology to build higher-efficiency, nonpolluting vehicles with low emissions, the result could be of far greater importance to U.S. industrial capability than the supercollider.
Only the Government has the resources and well-defined needs to make this happen. After the Pentagon created the market, all Government agencies could be required to use vehicles with hydrogen-cycle engines. Thus, the Government could help build a critical industrial infrastructure.
But Washington had better hurry. The Germans and the Japanese are working on prototypes, though they do not yet have a big enough captive market to insure success.
In technology, trade and politics, bold, insightful leadership is the difference. Ross Perot is either the leader with industrial insight or the consummate salesman whose promises aren't pinned down to measurable specifics. The U.S. needs leadership in the dynamic world of industrial competition -- commitments, not promises. So far we've heard only promises.

HEADLINE: Water Gun Raises Problems of Responsibility

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Controlling the Wrong Guns" (Topics of The Times, June 10), you neglect to mention individual responsibility in the issue of Super Soakers, the water guns whose use has led to real gunplay. Science and technology take developments to their next logical step, whether in nuclear power or Super Soakers. The responsibility of using them falls to the citizenry.
Most city dwellers, including myself, suffer from some urban stress. But if hit by a stream of water, however much it would vex us, we would not resort to violence. But our city is also home to people truly living on the edge. Some of them are armed and dangerous, and would not hesitate to retaliate with real guns, as we have seen in Boston and New York. 
 Teen-agers and younger children are excited at the opportunity to use these high-powered water cannons to act out the fantasies fed to them through television and the movies. Studies have shown that many children, especially boys, do not assess risk well. Some might think it is irresponsible to give youngsters a toy that virtually asks for trouble.
It is easy to say, as the company that makes Super Soakers did: Simply enforce laws to remove real guns from the street. I find it hard to believe that the company that markets the water guns cares much about the urban child. Still, I don't believe in censorship. However, Super Soakers, of themselves, are not dangerous in the sense that shoddily made goods or toxic products are dangerous and therefore removable from the marketplace. The danger comes in how they are used and where.
We may ask the company to stop making them; it probably won't. We may ask stores to stop selling them; they probably won't. We may ask New York City to ban them, but that might turn out to be unconstitutional. If the problem worsens, concerned citizens must work on bringing the kind of economic pressure and embarrassing publicity down on those involved in making this so-called toy available. To suggest that we wait for real gun control to solve the problem of violent retaliation is tantamount to saying, let's do nothing.
Those who live in this city and have children know that they are constantly teaching their children to live defensively, and now there is one more thing to add to the list. Parents and other adults who decide to buy this ballistic water pistol have a responsibility to teach youngsters to assess the risk in playing with this toy.
For the sake of children and bystanders, let's hope people decide the stakes are too high and won't buy the thing.
 
DEIRDRE K. PARKER
New York, June 11, 1992

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Bush in a World Remade: Will the Old Compass Do?

SERIES: The Bush Record -- First article of a series.

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL with JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
As Vice President George Bush accepted the Republican Presidential nomination on Aug. 18, 1988, he told thousands of cheering convention delegates that his goal as President would be to pick up where Ronald Reagan left off.
"The most important work of my life is to complete the mission we started in 1980," he declared. 
 It seemed a fitting declaration for a man who told the convention that he had spent his life carrying out assignments. As a World War II pilot, the first American envoy to Communist China, the Republican Party chairman and the Director of Central Intelligence, he had always set off with a clear mission, Mr. Bush said.
 
An Unfamiliar World
 But soon after his inauguration, the world Mr. Bush had known so well began to dissolve around him. While he exercised his strong hand in foreign policy and left domestic issues largely alone, the Communist menace vanished, the economy soured and Americans confronted a deepening social crisis that crystallized in the rage and violence in Los Angeles.
As his term comes to an end in these circumstances, a crisis of leadership threatens Mr. Bush's re-election. The President himself seemed clearly aware of that as he made his argument for another term in an interview in the Oval Office on Tuesday. [Excerpts, page A24.]
"In the final analysis, people are going to say, 'Who do you want sitting at that desk?' " Mr. Bush said after 30 minutes of discussing his record. "Who has the temperament? Who has the experience? Who do we trust?"
Rising from his wing chair, pushing his gold-trimmed pen back into his shirt pocket and putting on his glasses to show his guests out, his final words were confident: "That's why I'm going to win this election. You watch."
But as voters begin to pass judgment on the very terms Mr. Bush outlined -- his record and his ability to lead -- they are doing so in a world very different from the one in which he was elected in 1988. In 1992, America no longer seems to want a President who can carry out assignments on well-charted ground. The nation and the times demand one who can set new goals and devise the next mission for a people entering wild territory.
Having pursued his career with a bomber pilot's single-minded focus, Mr. Bush now finds himself frozen on the top step, unable to explain clearly what he has tried to accomplish in the last three and a half years or where he would like to take the country.
Asked that very question, the President listed a series of general goals: "In the first place, I'd like to see it set in an environment of world peace. Secondly, I think at home, changing, fundamentally revolutionizing education is critical. And I'd like to see a domestic environment where we have a return to safety in the streets, and we have it where mothers don't worry about their children walking home from school."
But a raft of recent public opinon surveys show that Americans don't really understand what Mr. Bush means by that, how he has tried to lead the country since 1989 or how he intends to achieve his goals if he wins a second term.
The most recent New York Times/CBS News poll, taken on June 17-20, shows Mr. Bush's overall approval rating at an all-time low of 34 percent. A large majority said the Bush Administration was drifting without clear policies. And in the end, a majority of Americans said he had not said enough about where he stands for them to judge what he might do if he won re-election.
Only 9 percent said he had kept all or most of his campaign promises. Indeed, Mr. Bush -- the "read my lips" candidate of 1988 -- has never quite recovered from the damage he did to his standing in his own party by agreeing to raise taxes in 1990.
 
Bush Takes Pride In Foreign Policy
 Mr. Bush easily listed what he considered his accomplishments: an education program that sets general goals for local schools to reach by century's end, and existing legislative ideas he endorsed and helped shape on child care, air pollution and the rights of the disabled. He also cited his appointment of conservative judges to the Federal bench.
In foreign affairs, he spoke of "great, earthshaking" accomplishments, including the recent agreement cutting Russian and American nuclear weapons, the Arab-Israeli peace talks, and his role in the unification of Germany and in the transformation of the former Soviet Union. "And, of course, Desert Storm was a significant and major accomplishment," he said.
Indeed, when people surveyed in the new poll were asked to name Mr. Bush's single most important accomplishment as President, 29 percent said the Persian Gulf war. Another 18 percent said foreign policy in general. But only 1 percent mentioned the economy and leadership abilities, and 39 percent could think of nothing at all.
Of those who listed the victory over Iraq as his major accomplishment, hardly anyone could think of any other notable achievement.
Behind these numbers are other statistics that paint a starkly negative picture of Mr. Bush's first term: record deficits, an anemic economy, low consumer confidence and even lower confidence in government.
Certainly, the President inherited some of his economic problems from a previous Administration, though it was one he helped manage. And Congress shares both credit and fault for much that has occurred.
But as voters assess Mr. Bush's Presidency, the most consistent observation is that while he is a good crisis manager, he has been reactive at a time when the nation needs a creative, forward-looking leader. And his record shows few, if any, domestic initiatives that Mr. Bush or his aides have devised and carried through.
"The premise that Bush set out on his inauguration is in serious trouble," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader, referring to Mr. Bush's vow to continue what Mr. Reagan had started. "What he was saying no longer is relevant or what people desire. They know that the long-term policies we were following have failed, and even putting a human face on them isn't being accomplished."
The White House justly responds that Mr. Bush has shown leadership in the area he clearly cares about most -- foreign affairs, where at times he has demonstrated the power and adroitness that have escaped him on the domestic front.
Much of what Mr. Bush has done, however, has been in response to the startling events that have occurred around him. He has been far less successful at articulating America's mission in a post-cold war world. Critics say that failure has been dramatized by what they see as Mr. Bush's lack of leadership in responding to the civil war in Yugoslavia.
But even his successes in foreign policy seem to mean less to voters now.
"The attitude of the American people is: 'Glad you ended the cold war, defeated the Soviet empire and extended freedom. Which of you guys can do more for me next?' " said Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip. "That's a legitimate question, and it's the challenge that Bush faces as a leader."
 
Echoes of Reagan Strike Fewer Chords
 A few years into the Reagan era, new nouns with unmistakable meanings began popping into the national vocabulary: Reaganism. Reaganomics. The Reagan Revolution. Reagan Country. Reagan Democrats.
The Bush Administration was supposed to be a smooth continuation of the Reagan years. But applied to Mr. Bush, such nouns are non sequiturs to some, terms of derision to others.
While a Reaganism was a folksy articulation of the President's ideology, a "Bushism" is an example of the President's Rubik's Cube speaking style. "Reagan Country" referred to whole regions or voter blocs loyal to Mr. Reagan, but "Bush Country" is hard to find. In fact, several new New York Times/ CBS News polls show that about half of the roughly 13 million Democrats who voted for Mr. Bush in 1988 say they will vote for someone else this year, while more than one-tenth say they don't know how they will vote.
In election years, Mr. Bush has been quick to seize on symbolism, as he did in 1988 with his visits to flag factories. And in this campaign, led by Vice President Dan Quayle, the White House has seized on "family values."
Taking up that theme in the interview on Tuesday, Mr. Bush denounced what he called "the filth on television," and said: "I can't accept as normal life style people of the same sex being parents, I'm very sorry. I don't accept that as normal. And I believe in the traditional family values. And the best shot that a kid has is to have a mother and father that love that child, that will educate that child, that will care for that child."
In normal times, Mr. Bush scorns the kind of symbolism Mr. Reagan frequently waved like a battle standard. Mr. Bush has often said that he hates to be "put on the couch" to give voters a glimpse at his psyche. And he dismisses any need for rhetorical flourishes or other symbolic gestures of leadership.
"He is rhetorically and oratorically a handicapped man," said Thomas E. Cronin, a Presidential scholar at Colorado College. "Americans have the models of F.D.R., Kennedy and Reagan, who exhorted them to some ideal or some version of the American dream or asked for sacrifice. George Bush has not been able to stir the country."
 
Supporters Facing A Crisis of Doubt
 Even those who support Mr. Bush agree that he is facing a crisis of doubt. about his leadership.
"The American people have lost their sense of political efficacy, and that is what the Perot candidacy represents right now," said Representative Vin Weber, Republican of Minnesota. "Bush's problem is that he doesn't look to people like the kind of guy who can challenge a gridlock system and bust it loose."
Politicians and academics across the political spectrum believe that at its core, Mr. Bush's problem is one of credibility.
"People don't think Bush is a crook," said Barbara Bardes, professor of political science at Loyola University of Chicago. "They're just not sure what he's doing, and in that case they think he's doing nothing."
In recent weeks, Mr. Bush and his aides have been scrambling to find actions that will make him seem more Presidential. But after leaving domestic issues largely alone for most of his term, all this activity may not be helping. "Anything they do now has hanging over it the question, 'Why didn't you do it earlier?' " Mr. Gingrich said.
Mr. Bush is highly secretive and prefers to make most decisions himself or in consultation with small groups of close friends. The White House resists discussion of how decisions are reached, or what advice the President weighs in making them. The President "goes ballistic," as he puts it, when a decision is reported before he is ready to announce it.
"There is something very bizarre and dangerous about this President, and that is the extent to which he is into surprises," said James David Barber, author of "The Presidential Character" (Prentice-Hall, 1972), a study of White House leadership.
Mr. Bush likes to trade on his personal relationships with foreign leaders, and to rely on his own experience and knowledge. That approach has failed him at times: critics say it did in relations with China. Mr. Bush, convinced that he could serve as his own adviser on that country after serving there as an envoy in the 1970's, pressed ahead after the 1989 massacre in Tiananmen Square with a conciliatory policy that has produced no tangible results.
But in other instances, this style may have helped. During the gulf crisis, he made decisions with seven top aides, in the Oval Office and in strict secrecy. In the end, Mr. Bush's diplomacy ran smoothly, and his war machine was startlingly efficient, at least in accomplishing its limited goals.
That, his supporters say, adds up to a good crisis manager. "He'd be a good person to be stuck in a snowstorm with," said Lynn Martin, the Secretary of Labor. "You could trust him, and you'd have an awful good chance of getting out of there."
But does that style lend itself to leadership on a grander scale?
"I don't feel that Bush has inner demons, like Nixon or Johnson," said Fred Greenstein, a student of the Presidency who teaches at Princeton. But he said, "What we see is someone who has always been good, dutiful, responded to situations, but just is not very good as a helmsman."
Mr. Bush's term has been an exercise in trying to keep up with expanding horizons on almost every front.
When he moved into the White House, he devoted his energies to foreign policy -- believing, associates say, that the economy was basically sound and needed little attention from him. The cold war seemed to be winding down slowly, and Mr. Bush set himself to tinkering with the relationship with the Soviet Union.
 
White House Surprised By Soviet Collapse
 The sudden disintegration of the Soviet empire surprised Mr. Bush as much as it surprised everyone else. But his aides say the President's caution and personal relationship with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev helped keep the peace during the transition. His critics say it led Mr. Bush to hang onto Mr. Gorbachev far too long.
These days, Mr. Bush talks almost wistfully about having a Republican Congress to help him enact his legislative agenda. "When Reagan came into office and I was the Vice President, he got a lot done in the first term because he controlled one House of the Congress," he said in the interview. "And it makes it an awful lot better if you control, say, one house, saying nothing of two.
"Give me control of both Houses. Give the people a Republican President and control of both Houses of Congress."
Mr. Bush blames Congress for his failure to enact more than a few domestic initiatives. But some say he has not done a good job working with the Democratic Congress.
Mr. Gingrich, sharply critical of Mr. Bush's decision to break his "no new taxes" campaign pledge in 1990, said the President spent too much time trying to play the conciliator with an unwilling Democratic majority in Congress, and then did not fight hard enough when his efforts failed.
"He has resolutely avoided accepting responsibility for what I think is an unavoidable civil war culturally about where this country is going," said Mr. Gingrich, who believes the 1992 election ought to be a moral, philosophical and cultural battle. "All of his social instincts and his personal grace lead him to conciliate. In a civil war, you have to pick sides and win."
 
Who Really Lives In 'Bush Country'?
 If it is difficult to tell which side Mr. Bush is on at times, it is equally hard to tell who is on his side. Interviews over recent weeks produced only one large, unified easily defined voting bloc squarely in his camp: the several million voters who vote for the candidate most squarely opposed to abortion.
Dr. Richard Land, head of the Christian Life Commission for the Southern Baptist Convention, concedes that most of these are one-issue voters who don't care could not care less about the President's record on any other issue.
Like most political analysts and interest-group leaders, Dr. Land had difficulty identifying other large voting blocs that unquestionably belong to the President. "Boy, you know I can't think of any," he said with a long sigh. "I just can't."
Mr. Bush long ago lost the enthusiastic backing of bedrock conservative Republicans.
Michael Sanara, a former Reagan Administration official who now teaches political science at Northern Arizona University, seemed to sum up the focus of Republican disillusionment. "I'm on the list for all the Republican Presidential fund-raisers," Now, he says. "I just write on the solicitation 'No new taxes,' and send it back."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
U.S. Trade Agency Turns Down Car Makers' Complaint on Japan

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
The Federal Government's trade agency ruled today that Detroit's auto makers had not suffered significant harm from imported Japanese mini-vans, a verdict that prevents the Commerce Department from proceeding with plans to impose tariffs on the imports.
The decision by the independent agency, the International Trade Commission, to reject a highly political case is a landmark in American trade policy. It reflects the presence of a new majority, more skeptical of industry claims, on the little-known body, which has the power to block American industries from receiving Commerce Department protection from imports.
 
A Former Member's Analysis
 Three new commissioners -- two Republicans and a Democrat -- have joined the six-member body in recent months, and the two Republicans appear to be taking a much narrower interpretation of the nation's trade law than their predecessors. Their terms will last as long as nine years. 
 "You'll find a pattern of results a little more consistent with the actual data on what the imports are doing to the industry, and not that the industry is doing badly," said Ronald A. Cass, the commission's Democratic vice chairman in 1989 and 1990 and now the dean of Boston University's law school.
But Mr. Cass, like other trade experts, cautioned that the commission might not have been captured by staunch advocates of free trade but rather by lawyers who make a very narrow reading of the law.
A test of whether the commission has actually moved all the way into the free-trade camp will come on Thursday, when it must rule on whether the American softwood-lumber industry has been hurt by Canadian imports. The American industry has lost many jobs, and the Commerce Department has tentatively set a 6.5 percent duty on the imports.
The commission, which is headed by a Democrat, decided by a vote of 4 to 2 today that mini-van shipments by the Mazda Motor Company and the Toyota Motor Corporation had not inflicted "material injury" on American car makers and did not threaten to do so.
Federal law requires the commissioners to consider in each case the domestic industry's output, market share, sales, profits, productivity, capacity, employment and seven other indications of economic health.
The decision was a setback for the General Motors Corporation, the Chrysler Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, which filed the case last year. Before the decision, some auto company executives had even been discussing the possibility of a trade case against imports of Japanese luxury cars, such as the Acura Legend.
Detroit executives and top officials of the United Automobile Workers publicly gloated in recent weeks about the Commerce Department's tentative decision to impose a duty of 12.7 percent on Mazda mini-vans and 6.75 percent on Toyota mini-vans.
The Commerce Department found in December that these mini-vans were being sold below "fair market" prices and determined in May the margin of underpricing, which set the planned tariff.
Thomas H. Hanna, president of the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association, an auto industry trade group, said the fact "that the I.T.C. was unable to see a connection between proof of unlawful trade practices and harm to the U.S. industry is incomprehensible."
 
The Big Three React
 General Motors also called the decision "incomprehensible." Ford characterized the ruling as "a sad development for the American worker." The decision signaled to "Japan that it's O.K. to defy the international rules of trade, and what's more, that it doesn't hurt America," Ford said in a statement.
Chrysler, whose mini-van dominates the United States market, called the decision "a great disappointment," and a blow "to the long-term interests of American consumers and to the ability of our nation's manufacturing segment to compete worldwide."
Mazda, one of the targets of the domestic industry's complaint, said in a statement that it was "gratified." It added, "We have maintained since the beginning of this proceeding over one year ago that our position would ultimately be vindicated."
 
The Appeals Process
 Detroit's auto makers had no immediate comment on whether they would appeal the commission decision to the Court of International Trade, a Federal tribunal in New York. That court's decision could be appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, and after that, the Supreme Court. But few cases have been appealed because of the cost and the New York court's record of frequently sustaining the commission.
No duty is collected from Japanese auto makers during any appeals, and deposits collected for the last six months against eventual duties will be refunded to the importers.
Despite the commission's decision today, Detroit may eventually receive import protection from Congress. The House Ways and Means Committee approved a routine tariff-renewal bill today with an amendment that would raise the duty on imported mini-vans and sport-utility vehicles (like the Isuzu Trooper) to 25 percent from 2.5 percent by reclassifying them as trucks instead of cars.
The measure faces an uncertain future in the Senate, where Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Finance Committee, opposes special protection for the auto industry. President Bush also opposes the tariff increase, and Congress has not overridden any of his vetoes.
Representative Sander M. Levin, Democrat of Michigan, said he would "take a look" at whether to introduce legislation changing the commission's standards for measuring when a domestic industry has been hurt by imports. The law setting the standards was amended in 1988 to help domestic industries, and today's case was the most politically controversial test yet of the revision.
Today's decision appears to signal that the commission's long-term direction is changing. After fairly consistently finding harm to domestic industries in the 1980's, the commission has now ruled against American companies in 6 of its 11 cases this year. The previous five rulings against American companies concerned three obscure chemical compounds, underground electrical cables and some steel rails.
The rulings are all the more striking because domestic industries win any tie votes on the commission and because the Commerce Department investigates trade cases only after the commission has issued an initial opinion that the American industry is suffering. The commission voted 3 to 0 last summer, with one commissioner recusing himself, to allow the Japanese mini-van case to proceed.
One new Republican on the commission, Peter S. Watson, has a term that will not expire until Dec. 16, 2000, suggesting that the commission's new shape may prove enduring. All three Republicans on the commission and one Democrat voted against the Detroit auto makers while the two remaining Democrats voted in their favor. No more than three members of the same party can serve on the panel at the same time; the chairmanship alternates between parties every two years.
Mr. Watson replaced Seeley G. Lodwick, an Iowa Republican who tended to be more receptive to domestic industries' complaints. At the same time, David B. Rohr, a Maryland Democrat whose nine-year term expires at the end of 1994, has also become increasingly willing to vote against domestic interests.
Mr. Rohr and Mr. Watson both voted with the majority and against the Detroit auto makers today. "I find that the information submitted to the commission does not establish that the volume of imports has had more than a minimal effect on the sales of domestic mini-vans," Mr. Rohr said in a statement, adding that he also did not believe that the imports had affected prices.

An article on Thursday about a decision by the International Trade Commission that tariffs should not be imposed on imported Japanese mini-vans referred incorrectly to a court that hears appeals of decisions by the Court of International Trade. It is the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit, not the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

PUB-DATE: June 26, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1531 words

HEADLINE: CONGRESS FORCES END TO SHUTDOWN OF TRAIN SERVICE

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Friday, June 26

 BODY:
Congress approved binding arbitration late Thursday night to settle the labor dispute that shut down the nation's freight lines and threatened commuter rail service, mainly in the Northeast. The legislation was rushed early today to the President, who signed it immediately.
The House of Representatives first passed the legislation by a 240-to-140 vote and then the Senate by a 87-to-6 vote just before midnight. President Bush's signature insured that there would be no further disruption of freight lines as well as Amtrak, the Federally subsidized passenger carrier.
 
'Going Back to Work

 The White House said in a statement, "The President is pleased that Congress, with bipartisan cooperation, has met its responsibility to end the rail crisis." 
 Officials of the freight railroads said they expected to have 75 percent of their trains running again within 24 hours after the legislation was enacted and full service stored within 48 hours.
"The nation's railroads are going back to work as soon as possible," Edwin L. Harper, president of the Association of American Railroads, said in a statement. The measure enacted by Congress Thursday night immediately sends rail workers back to their jobs during a 20-day cooling-off period followed by binding arbitration if no settlement is reached.
But there was lingering discontent with the outcome among many lawmakers who voted for the bill grudgingly rather than risk further damage to the nation's economy from the shutdown.
Like many other Democrats, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who voted for the bill, blamed the railroads for the shutdown because 38 freight lines responded with lockouts when a single union called a strike Wednesday against a single railroad.
"A small band of railroad owners has walked away from the national interest and forced Congress to come to their rescue. So now Congress must act, in order to try and protect the jobs and economic health of America from that cynical and self-interested attitude," Senator Kennedy said during the Senate's brief debate on the measure, which ended with the voting just before midnight.
 
Major League Baseball
 In what its authors described as a novel approach to rail labor disputes, the legislation borrowed an arbitration method commonly used in major league baseball: after a fixed period of negotiation both labor and management submit a "last best offer" to a neutral arbitrator who then picks one. This was the 18th time that Congress has intervened in a rail labor dispute since 1963, applying a variety of approaches over the years.
Secretary of Transportation Andrew H. Card, who like other Bush Administration officials had pressed for quick Congressional action, said Thursday night, "THe solutions represented in this legislation might well become a model that could be used in the future."
Pressure to take some kind of action mounted in Congress all day Thursday despite vigorous lobbying the unions to keep Congress from intervening. In addition to reports of the shutdown's effect on trade and manufacturing, the lawmakers faced the prospect that it might spread to commuter services along the heavily traveled Northeast corridor from Boston to Washington by 12:01 A.M. today.
 
Outrage by Labor
 On Wednesday, unions negotiating with Amtrak and separately with Conrail, a freight railroad whose tracks carry many commuter trains, agreed not to strike those railroads at least until today. But the machinists union began picketing one large freight railroad, CSX, and the railroad industry retaliated by shutting down freight service nationwide.
On Thursday, labor leaders strongly denounced the proposed legislation, saying it would rob union members of their right to strike. In a joint statement, seven railroad unions and the A.F.L.-C.I.O. said they opposed "any action by Congress to intervene in these railroad labor-management disputes."
The unions said that if Congress felt it must act to stop the strike, the least objectionable option would be to extend the negotiations.
"We would vigorously oppose any other intervention, including the imposition of binding arbitration in any form," the statement said.
 
2 Days to Restore Service
 After the proposal passed the House but before the Senate voted on it, the Association of American Railroads grudgingly endorsed it. "We are concerned about launching into a new process untested in the railroad industry," said Edwin L. Harper, the trade association's president. "But we are even more concerned about the need to bring an end to this strike."
Upon final enactment, the association said, service could be 75 percent restored in a day and fully restored in two days.
In Congress the most vocal opposition to the legislation came from Democrats, many of whom rely on political support from unions. They contended that the railroads had contrived a national emergency through the lockout on the freight lines, thus forcing Congress to intervene and short-circuit the union's right to carry out a strike. Representative Gerry Sikorski, a Democrat of Minnesota, said on the House floor, "What we are doing is rewarding the railroads and punishing the unions."
In fact, 124 Democrats in the House voted against the measure while only 112 favored it. The split among Republicans was 136 in favor and 15 against.
 
Idled Freight Railroads
 Most of the nation's freight railroads shut down at 12:01 A.M. Wednesday in response to a limited strike against one of them, CSX. Amtrak has been hobbled by the shutdown because most of the trains outside the Northeast run on lines owned by the idled freight railroads.
The legislation taken up Thursday was crafted in meetings of lawmakers, Congressional aides and Administration officials. The meetings began Wednesday evening and continued virtually without interruption until this afternoon.
Presenting the legislation in the House Subcommittee on Transportation and Hazardous Materials this afternoon, Representative Al Swift, a Democrat of Washington, said, "I have no doubt that all the involved parties will wish we had done something else."
 
Letting Arbitrator Decide
 The crucial compromise in the bill involves applying the mediation technique borrowed from multi-million-dollar salary disputes between major-league baseball.
If the railroads and the unions fail to resolve their differences during the 20-day negotiating period, they would each be required to submit a "last best" contract to a panel of three arbitrators who would then pick between the offers. This process would extend no more than 15 days beyond the end of the negotiating period.
The unions would pick one arbitrator, the railroads would pick another, and those two people would choose the third who would do the actual work of supervising negotiations and then conduct the binding arbitration if necessary.
The arbitrator's decision would then be submitted to the President, and unless he disapproved within three days, it would have the force of law. If the President rejected it, the unions would be free to strike and the railroads could engage in lockouts.
 
History of Intervention
 "I can't imagine a situation in which the President would disapprove the decision of the abitrator," said Mr. Card, the Transportation Secretary.
As a result of Government intervention, a nationwide railroad strike has not been allowed to proceed freely since the shopmen's strike of 1922. On 10 occasions this century, individual companies or the nationwide system of rail carriers have been officially seized by the military through Presidential order to prevent strikes.
"The baseball solution steers a course right between the demands of labor and management and sets up a process that encourages them to negotiate with each other rather than waiting for Congress to legislate a contract," said Representative Dennis E. Eckart, a Democrat of Ohio who is chief sponsor of the legislation and is credited with suggesting the arbitration scheme.
In more than nine hours of hearings Wednesday, unions leaders spoke against any Congressional tampering with their right to strike, and railroad officials asked the lawmakers to immediately impose a settlement on the unions without further negotiations.
When the labor action started Wednesday, two unions announced a 48-hour moratorium on any action against Amtrak, the Federally subsidized passenger rail carrier. That deadline was set to expire less than six hours after the House committee act ed, and union leaders had refused to commit themselves on a course of action if the deadline came while legislation was still working its way through Congress.
"I am skeptical of any arbitration process imposed by Congress," said Mac Fleming, president of the Brother hood of Maintenance of Way Employees, one of the unions involved in the dispute with Amtrak.
 
The President's Role
 Throughout the day on Thursday, President Bush and Administration officials made public statements pressing Congress to take immediate action. "I urge the House and Senate to act to end this strike today, the national interest re quires no less," the President said this morning.

HEADLINE: Emergency or Ploy?;
Railroads Can Turn Sense of Crisis To Advantage Under 1926 Labor Law

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr.

 BODY:
As Congress confronted a costly railroad labor dispute, the antagonists bitterly disputed whether the shutdown of most of the nation's freight railroads was a crisis created by hardline unions or a disruption devised by railroads taking advantage of a decades-old labor law intended to encourage negotiation.
The debate goes to the heart of labor relations in the railroad industry, for on this issue hinges the rights of rail unions to strike, even in a limited fashion, against an industry that has been increasingly aggressive in cutting its labor costs. 
 In three separate sets of contract talks -- one involving machinists and the entire freight rail industry, another with maintenance workers and the freight line Conrail, and the third involving several unions and the passenger line Amtrak -- the unions tried to take the offensive without causing so much disruption that Congress would step in on the industry's side.
But to the unions' dismay, the rail industry on Wednesday turned a regional machinist strike against one big freight line into a nationwide shutdown.
 
Neither Side Pleased
 That brought Congress reluctantly into the fray, and the solution that Congress put together pleased neither the unions nor the railroads. That solution ordered that the shutdown end and established binding arbitration to resolve the two sides' differences.
"We are definitely, absolutely, unequivocally opposed to any process that has binding arbitration," said Mac Fleming, president of the Brotherhood of Maintenance of Way Employees, which is wrangling over new contracts with Amtrak and the Consolidated Rail Corporation.
"If the Congress orders us back to work without our basic fundamental right to strike, then Congress is not doing us any favor," he said.
The railroads had adamantly urged Congress to put an end to the strike, but not to alter in any way the earlier nonbinding recommendations of mediating boards, which the unions rejected a month ago. The railroads had hoped that the nationwide freight shutdown would lead to Congress's imposing those terms on the unions.
Rail labor laws make strikes a last resort, but strikes are not flatly prohibited as long as there have first been long negotiations, and binding arbitration is not usually involved in the elaborate process by which rail contracts are negotiated.
 
Tortuous Negotiations
 In the current disputes, the railroads appear to be making careful use of the negotiating process, which is far different from the norm in other industries. Their goal has been to settle without a strike, despite the seemingly insurmountable differences with the unions over wages, work rules and back pay.
Under the Railway Labor Act of 1926, labor unions can strike only after completing an elaborate negotiating process that can last for years. First the workers must talk directly to their employers. Next, if no progress can be made, talks must resume under the auspices of the National Mediation Board, a Federal agency created to handle labor disputes of railroads and airlines, which cannot dictate binding terms but can keep the sides talking indefinitely.
Even after a mediation board concedes failure, the President can name another panel, known as a Presidential Emergency Board, which reviews the negotiations and drafts a proposed settlement.
The emergency board's proposals are not binding, but after rejecting them, the unions cannot strike and the companies cannot impose new contract terms without first waiting through "cooling-off" periods. These provide a month in which the adversaries can, if they want, engage in last-ditch talks and avoid a strike.
 
Deadlines Coincide
 Only if a strike is so crippling that it constitutes an emergency does Congress step in.
Each of the three separate labor disputes now coming to a head went through this long process separately, starting on different dates and meeting on different schedules. But in each case, the mediation board and the emergency board acted on the three disputes all at once, so that the final cooling-off period in the disputes ended simultaneously early Wednesday.
Perhaps this development, which added to the sense of emergency, was nothing more than a coincidence. But for some time, the railroads have recognized that with careful timing they could turn the negotiating system to their advantage.
Just over a year ago, in a letter to other railroad chiefs discussing the merits of the Railway Labor Act, Robert Schmiege, the chief executive of the Chicago and NorthWestern line, pointed out that individual railroads were not able to withstand a prolonged strike and needed to coordinate their strategies under the law.
"Railroads need a legal framework which makes it difficult for unions to create economic tests of strength," he wrote. "Railroads need a framework that permits us to tactically manage the sequencing of the bargaining and mediation phases."
 
Creating a Crisis
 Mr. Schmiege, urging his colleagues to maintain a unified stance, wrote, "Without the threat that a labor crisis will affect the national economy, our companies are at a terrible disadvantage."
At the end of the latest cooling-off period this week, when the International Association of Machinists struck a single railroad, CSX Corporation, railroads all over the country retaliated by shutting down their operations. That created just the kind of labor crisis Mr. Schmiege had described and prompted Congress to act even though the machinists did not strike nationwide and the other unions chose not to strike Amtrak or Conrail.
At first, the Association of American Railroads argued that the freight lines had no practical choice but to shut down all operations. They claimed that the nation's freight system was "completely integrated" and that interruptions to service anywhere in the country would inevitably ripple through the whole system.
But when the unions pointed out that most of CSX's routes were also served by the Norfolk & Southern line, the railroads offered another rationale for shutting down from coast to coast.
If CSX alone were struck, it might quickly be forced to capitulate to the unions, who would then simply turn their striking power upon another railroad, the railroads said.
Wynn Henderson, the editor of Straight Lines, a labor union newspaper published in Minneapolis, said that the railroads have repeatedly learned in recent years the value of using supposed emergencies to make Congress the ultimate arbiter of rail labor disputes.
As Mr. Henderson sees it, these precedents have left the railroads knowing "that if they just stonewalled, that they could count on the Administration and Congress to eventually intervene to stop any strike, and to impose as law recommendations that would give them more than they could achieve through any process of negotiation."
