HEADLINE: INDUSTRIES GAINING BROAD FLEXIBILITY ON AIR POLLUTION

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
The Bush Administration today issued a rule that will give manufacturers broad authority to increase substantially the amount of hazardous pollutants they can pour into the atmosphere beginning in the mid-1990's.
The Environmental Protection Agency reluctantly issued the new rule, which had been championed by the President's Council on Competitiveness, a Cabinet group headed by Vice President Dan Quayle. The rule will be central to a system of pollution permits that will be established over the next 10 years under the Clean Air Act of 1990. 
 Chemical and drug manufacturers, concerned about the costs of meeting standards in the Clean Air Act, had sought the rule, saying they needed a flexible standard so they could make changes in equipment or production practices that might cause them to exceed air pollution limits.
 
Discretion to Emit More
 Under the new rule, a company can increase the amount of pollution it emits into the atmosphere by up to 245 tons a year without public notice or hearings if it says it is forced to do so by a change in production methods. The company can do this by applying for an increase, and while the application is pending, it may go ahead with its plans.
"Sometimes you have requirements issued by a state or the Federal government to change a product or a process," Dan Lacy, vice president for corporate communications at Ashland Oil said in explaining why the rule would be helpful. "You have certain restrictions on the amount of time you have to do it in. If you are facing that kind of deadline and you're waiting to get a permit to proceed, then that puts the business in a bind."
A giant refinery typically emits millions of pounds of pollutants into the air each year, but small manufacturing plants generally discharge only a fraction of that amount.
The Environmental Protection Agency has 45 days to reject or approve the application, while states have up to 90 days.
 
Waxman Is Furious
 President Bush often cites the passage of the Clean Air Act as one of the singular achievements of his Presidency, a claim he repeated again on Wednesday in an interview. Enacted on Nov. 15, 1990, the law was designed to control virtually every important source of air pollution and substantially reduce health and environmental damage caused by acid rain, smog, urban ozone pollution, toxic chemicals and destruction of the earth's atmospheric ozone shield.
But one of the principal authors of the act, Representative Henry A. Waxman, a Democrat of California, said that the rule issued today eviscerated the law.
"This is a massive loophole, written for political purposes, that carves the heart out of the Clean Air Act," Mr. Waxman said. He called the rule illegal and predicted that it would be challenged in court.
The new rule was also being cited by state air pollution-control officials, some Democrats in Congress and national environmental leaders as more evidence for their argument that the President has blunted the law's effect. He has done this, they said, by missing legal deadlines for issuing some important rules and by altering others to make them friendlier to business.
The Council on Competitiveness, which has played a central role in the White House's management of the law, is already the defendant in separate lawsuits by New York State and Mr. Waxman.
The final rule on permits will not begin to take effect until at least 1995, the E.P.A. said today. States have until November 1993 to complete their pemit programs and to submit them to the environmental agency for review. The agency has until November 1994 to approve state programs. Companies have until 1995 to begin applying for permits, which are to be issued from 1995 through the end of the decade.
The Council on Competitiveness has attracted support from industrial executives and increasing criticism from environmental groups and Democrats because of its growing influence in reviewing, halting, and at times helping to write new regulations, particularly those concerned with environmental safeguards.
 
Vote Called 'Harassment'
 Today, the House Appropriations Committee acted on a proposal by Representative David E. Skagg, Democrat of Colorado, and voted 30 to 18 to eliminate money for the council's eight-member staff.
David C. Beckwith, the Vice President's spokesman, said today that the committee's vote was "harassment," and that the council would not waver in its objectives. "The same Congressional critics who allege the council was operating illegally have abandoned that tactic in favor of political harassment," said Mr. Beckwith. "The council will continue to uphold and enforce all laws at the least possible cost to jobs, consumers and the economy."
The new rule sets up the framework for states to issue operating permits to roughly 35,000 factories, chemical and pharmaceutical plants, refineries, power plants and other important sources of air pollution. Forty states already have some form of permit program, according to the environmental agency. But under the Clean Air Act, the agency is required to set new minimum, uniform standards and to enforce them.
The disagreement on the rule has produced one of the angriest political struggles in the Administration, between William K. Reilly, the E.P.A. Administrator and Vice President Quayle.
Their disagreement focused on whether factories should be able to increase by small amounts the levels of pollution they are allowed to produce.
Mr. Reilly argued that the increases should be small -- no more than five tons annually per company -- and that the public should have the right to review applications by companies.
Mr. Quayle and the Council on Competitiveness said the increases do not have to be small and companies should be allowed to make them without public review. Mr. Quayle's position was strongly supported by the Chemical Manufacturers Association, drug makers, refiners and other large industries. Industrial executives said they should have the flexibility to make changes in their plants that would increase pollution without having to go through a long and exhausting public review.
 
When Bush Intervened
 Last month, Mr. Bush intervened and decided the issue in favor of Mr. Quayle. At the time, the White House and the Environmental Protection Agency represented Mr. Bush's decision as one with minor pollution consequences. Administration officials said companies would not be allowed to increase their air pollution emissions by more than 40 tons each, or 80,000 pounds, a year. They also said it was likely that the final rule would include a provision allowing states to have a short review period to approve or disapprove the increased pollution.
The final rule issued today goes much further. The rule allows any company to increase its air pollution by up to 245 tons, or 490,000 pounds a year, a significant amount for any manufacturing plant, state air pollution-control authorities said today. The rule also allows plants to make the increases as soon as they apply to states. The E.P.A. has 45 days to reject the application, and states have 90 days to approve or disapprove. The public will not be notified or have an opportunity to intervene unless states write such provisions on their own.
 
Big Regional Effects
 In industrial regions, like the Mississippi River corridor between New Orleans and Baton Rouge or the Kanawha Valley west of Charleston, W. Va., such increases could total millions of extra pounds of pollutants in the air every year if a number of chemical plants and manufacturers take advantage of the waiver at once.
Directors of state air pollution-control agencies today condemned the new rule, saying it was a giant loophole designed to allow companies to pollute without penalties. The state authorities also said the rule would make it exceedingly difficult to enforce portions of the Clean Air Act designed to control urban smog, and they predicted that many states would ignore the Administration's regulation and enact tougher standards.
"We don't intend to put this regulation into effect; I don't think many states will," said Thomas C. Jorling, the Commissioner at the New York Department of Environmental Conservation.
But there are some states, like West Virginia, that are prohibited by state law from exceeding Federal environmental standards. "It's an awful rule," G. Dale Farley, the director of the West Virginia Air Pollution Control Commission, said of the new rule. "The whole point of requiring plants to get operating permits is to have some handle on overall air pollution emissions. It allows states to have a management scheme. With this provision, the only thing states can do to keep on top of the situation is just to have a rubber stamp that says, 'We object.' When the applications come in, we stamp them and that will prevent the extra emissions."
Mr. Waxman, in asserting that the new rule is illegal, said the Clean Air Act had directed the Administration to require public notification and review for any modifications in a company's permit. He said in an interview today that the provision for public notification had been included in the law to make it much more difficult for companies to exceed air pollution levels on their operating permits.
But William G. Rosenberg, the E.P.A.'s assistant administrator for Air and Radiation, said today that the new rule would provide the nation with cleaner air by making it easier to enforce the law.


GRAPHIC: April 1991. Administrator William K. Reilly of the Environmental Protection Agency first proposes a rule setting forth procedures governing pollution permits under the Clean Air Act. The proposal requires public notification and public hearings before any company can exceed the level of polution on its operating permit. That proposal goes to the White House for review.
Chronology: "Policing Pollution: 15 Months, 1 Rule"
 May 1991. The Council on Competitveness reviews the proposal and adds provision to allow manufacturers and chemical companies to increase pollution levels without public notification. Under the revised proposal, states have a week to object to applications from companies seeking to modify their operating permits. If a state objects within 7 days, the company can not increase pollution. If a state does not object, the increase can be made.
 Summer 1991. E.P.A. General Counsel Donald Elliott issues a memorandum that says it is illegal to elimate public review. The Clean Air Act signed by Mr. Bush specifically directed the E.P.A. to write a rule that allowed the public to intervene in porposals by companies to increase their polution, he says. Other legal experts in the Government concur, including Charles Bowsher, the Comptroller General, and Richard B. Stewart, the Assistant Attorney General for Lands and Natural Resources.
 October 1991. Mr. Reilly sends up another proposal that once again calls for the public to have the right to be notified and intervene if a company asks to increase its pollution levels. Under the newly revised proposal, if such increases were under five tons, states are directed to expedite the application. Mr. Reilly issues the proposal to meet a November 1991 deadline for making the fule final. Vice President Quayle and the Council on Competitiveness reject this latest proposal.
 May 1992. The President decides the issue in favor of Mr. Quayle and directs Mr. Reilly to write a rule that eliminates public review. Mr. Reilly refuses to issue the rule until the Department of Justice declares such a rule legal. Mr. Bush orders Attorney General William P. Barr to prepare a memorandum to that effect. Mr. Barr isseue the memorandum on May 27.
 June 25. Mr. Reilly issues a final rule on establishing permits for factories and other plants that gives a company the automatic authority to increase pollution by up to 245 tons simply by applying for state permission. States have 90 days to reject the increase. The E.P.A. has 45 days to review the application. (pg. A16)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Bush's Roles on World Stage: Triumphs, but Troubles, Too

SERIES: The Bush Record -- Second article of a series.

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
Conventional wisdom holds that there are two George Bushes: the skilled architect of foreign policy and the neglectful caretaker of domestic affairs. Even some people on the Bush team have come to cultivate this image, since it allows them to explain away the President's shortcomings at home by saying he was too busy saving the world abroad.
But in fact George Bush has also shown at least two personalities in his conduct of the nation's foreign policy. He has often really been the consummate seasoned statesman, but at other times he has seemed distracted and ineffective in a world undergoing dizzying change. 
 There was the George Bush who, working the telephones and personal contacts with other heads of state, skillfully managed the Western alliance's response to the cataclysmic revolutions in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, helping to insure that one of this century's great upheavals went off relatively peacefully.
 
'We Should Get Credit'
 There was the George Bush who was the galvanizing force in building an international coalition to roll back the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and strip Baghdad of its weapons of mass destruction.
And there was the George Bush who encouraged his Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d, to bring together the first full-scale peace talks between Israel and all its Arab neighbors. More recently, it was the George Bush who with Mr. Baker negotiated sweeping nuclear arms cuts with the Russians that were highly advantageous to Washington.
"I think we'd get blamed if things went wrong," Mr. Bush said in an interview, assessing his record; therefore, "we should get credit if they've gone right, and they've gone right. I think handling the changes inside what used to be the Soviet Union has been good, and I am very pleased that ancient enemies are talking to each other in the Middle East. And, of course, Desert Storm was a significant and major accomplishment, because it said to aggressor nations: you can't just go take over a friendly country next door."
But there has been another George Bush as well -- the one who built up Saddam Hussein of Iraq before the Persian Gulf war in the mistaken hope that money and favors would modify his behavior. The George Bush whose disastrous trip to Japan early this year only underscored the degree to which his Administration had ignored a fraying relationship with Tokyo. There was the George Bush who virtually had to be shamed into giving aid to Russia by former President Richard M. Nixon. The George Bush who after the end of the cold war seemed to lose his moorings and began seesawing between engagement and disengagement in such messy post-cold-war problems as Haiti and Yugoslavia.
And finally there was the George Bush who, as Vice President and President, holds at least some responsibility for the ballooning Federal deficit, which has deprived his Administration of precisely the dollar resources it now needs to help consolidate the democratic revolutions the United States helped spawn from Managua to Prague.
"When future historians look back on the Bush foreign policy they will find a lot to like about it," said Michael R. Beschloss, who has written several histories of American foreign policy. "But they will also find it largely reactive. The new world order was a creation not of George Bush but of Mikhail Gorbachev and Boris Yeltsin. They were the event-makers. Bush reacted constructively and creatively to their initiatives and concessions."
 
Policy of 'Status Quo Plus'
 Mr. Bush was most comfortable when he was acting within the boundaries of his traditional cold-war framework. His performance was much less consistent and commanding when the Soviet Union came apart, the cold war ended and he was "called upon to fashion a new template for American foreign policy," Mr. Beschloss said.
If the Bush team came into office with a philosophy, the Administration's first foreign policy review described it best. It was dubbed "status quo plus" -- preserve the cold-war balance of power where necessary while promoting incremental change in relations with Moscow where openings presented themselves.
While it did not openly disdain human rights, the Bush team's refusal to use trade sanctions to modify China's human rights behavior and its lack of concern for democracy in Kuwait after the gulf war underscored that the issue was never its first principle. But the real problem was that soon after Mr. Bush's watch began, the status quo simply collapsed. When it did, the Bush team's instinctive prudence and alliance-management skills seemed to serve the nation well, at least at first. Indeed, when asked what he is most proud of, Brent Scowcroft, Mr. Bush's national security adviser, said it was the liberation of Eastern Europe, the unification of Germany and the dissolution of the Soviet empire "without a shot being fired" across the old East-West divide.
 
'We Were Instrumental'
 "Now, I am not saying we necessarily did this all by ourselves," he said, "but we were instrumental in the way it happened. I think if you asked people 10 years ago if the Soviet Union was going to collapse, would it be this way, I think most people would say no. It is probably going to take place in the context of a grand confrontation."
But prudence is an instinct not a vision. It has its limits, and those limits became clear later in the Bush Administration when the President was called upon not to be just reactive. The times required a proactive, creative leader.
If his public statements are any measure, Mr. Bush was not prepared for this new, unexpected role. Indeed, for a President so preoccupied with foreign policy, it seems odd that he has not given even one memorable foreign policy speech. For Mr. Bush, the theories, the speeches, "the vision thing," as he put it, always came later -- if at all.
Even the hallmark phrase the White House began using midway through the term to sum up Mr. Bush's approach to the changing world came into being by happenstance, not through any real planning.
In late August 1990, Mr. Scowcroft was sitting around the Nonantum resort in Kennebunkport, Me., talking with White House press aides about how to explain the need to confront the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. "Tell them we can't just let Iraq get away with this -- there is a new world order developing," an aide recalled Mr. Scowcroft remarking
"New world order" -- the White House press team liked the sound of that. It was catchy. It was fresh. It had potential. Later, two members of the White House press team were in their office at another hotel, the Shawmut, when Pam Olson, a White House correspondent for CNN, came in.
"We told her it's 'a new world order,' " one of the officials recalled. "She liked it, and 30 minutes later it was on CNN. So the 'new world order' was born at the Shawmut Hotel. It was really just an accident. The philosophy came later."
Unification of Germany
Bush Aids Process Behind the Scenes
 By most accounts, Mr. Bush reacted slowly but effectively to the problems that awaited him when he took office. This was Phase I of his foreign policy.
Behind the scenes he helped refashion the world from one in which the United States confronted the Soviets from Germany to Nicaragua to one in which Moscow and Washington could solve problems together in both those countries and in others, too. His aides and allies say Mr. Bush's work to bring about the peaceful unification of Germany is one of the least known but most important acts of his Presidency.
"Behind the scenes Bush stage-managed the outcome," said Peter Rodman, a former member of the Bush National Security Council. "He stiffened Chancellor Kohl's spine on the question of staying in NATO, when there were great pressures on him to leave. He stroked Mitterand to get the French to re-endorse the NATO alliance and also agreed to adapt NATO, to make it less threatening and address Gorbachev's fears. You really could have had an explosion and an unraveling, and you had just the opposite."
 
Helped by Soviet Decisions
 Mr. Bush's attention to all the parties was undeniably helpful. But Germany would not have reunified smoothly if the Germans had not been willing to buy the Soviets out of Berlin, and had Mr. Gorbachev not been ready to take the billions of dollars that Bonn gave him to resettle his troops and shore up his economy. And at the same time, it was while Mr. Bush was focused on Germany that his Administration went on autopilot in the Middle East and slipped into its policy of continuing to build up Iraq against Iran, even when the Iraqi leader's threatening behavior clearly argued for a new approach.
Mr. Bush's instinctive pragmatism also played well in Latin America, where the President dropped the Reagan Administration's confrontational approach and chose instead to compromise. Again, he was helped by the Soviet retreat and withdrawal of aid from its clients.
"After a decade of civil war, the Bush approach offered space for all of the actors to negotiate terms that permited peaceful political change," said Robert A. Pastor, an adviser on Latin America to President Jimmy Carter.
 
Little Focus on Latin America
 But the same political pragmatism that enabled Mr. Bush to disengage from Ronald Reagan's politically contentious contra policy in Nicaragua also prompted his Administration to focus on the issue only as long as it took to defuse an explosive political problem.
Since its first year and a half, the Administration has devoted little attention to Latin America. Just when aid and attention are needed to consolidate some of the infant democracies America helped create, the Bush policy for the hemisphere seems to have lost energy and focus.
Mr. Bush certainly acted decisively in December 1989 when he ordered the invasion of Panama and seizure of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. But the tear gas Mr. Bush inhaled when he returned to Panama early this month was just one more demonstration that the consolidation of democracy is much more difficult than its forceful installation.
 
The Gulf Crisis
Paving the Way For Peace Talks
 The largest challenge President Bush has faced was the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Even his foes now credit him with deft handling of the crisis after the invasion; he built a coalition unlike any before in modern history. This was Phase II of his foreign policy.
Out of the war, Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker are also given much credit for engineering an opening for Arab-Israeli peace talks.
The Middle East was one area of the world where the Bush team actually worked to overturn a status quo -- in this case the stubborn deadlock over the West Bank.
So far, though, this effort has not produced any concrete results -- largely because it has been based entirely on external pressures and not on any fundamental change of view by Israel, the Palestinians or the Arab states. But the stunning victory of the Labor Party in Israel this week suggests that Israel may now undergo precisely that sort of internal change. If that leads to a breakthrough in the peace talks, that will be attributable, at least in part, to the environment created by the Administration's Madrid peace conference.
 
An Election Setback
Politics Intrude On Foreign Policy
 Phase III of the Bush foreign policy began on November 5, 1991 -- the day the Republicans lost the Senate race in Pennsylvania to a Democratic upstart, Harris Wofford.
The White House drew a hard lesson from that shock; Mr. Bush's success in foreign policy had been turned into a political liability because of the perception that it had come at the expense of domestic policy. On that election day last November, Mr. Bush postponed his long-planned visit to Japan. Then three weeks later, realizing this had been a mistake, he rescheduled the visit, but turned it into an automobile sales mission that was as embarrassing as it was unproductive.
In some ways, Mr. Bush has been lurching back and forth ever since -- and not just because of political concerns. The concurrent problem was that, as the Soviet Union disintegrated, so too did the broad framework for the Bush foreign policy.
 
Soviet Compass Is Lost
 The Soviet Union had been the main problem, around which Mr. Bush's reactive foreign policy was organized and, later, the main partner for many of its diplomatic endeavors. Once it disappeared, the defining core of the policy was lost, and the Administration began having trouble sorting out what exactly was the national interest, where should the United States intervene and with whom this country should work. As one Administration official put it: "There was nothing big to react to anymore."
To make matters worse, foreign policy issues increasingly grew to be intrastate quandaries -- ethnic and national disputes, or environmental problems -- instead of interstate questions. Rather than dealing with the implications of Iraq's invading Kuwait, the kind of problem the President clearly understood, he found himself called upon to confront Serbia's threat to Bosnia or turmoil in Haiti -- situations about which he seemed to know little and care even less.
Even critics of the President acknowledge that he should not have been expected to provide magic answers for these new and beguiling problems. But the Administration seemed to find all these new quandaries disorienting. This seems to account for the oscillations in the Administration's dealings with the crises in Haiti and Yugoslavia; first he ignored them, then there was a sudden burst of activity, and then inactivity again.
Traditional foreign policy problems could be dealt with by mobilizing troops or negotiating arms control agreements. But the conflicts in Yugoslavia and Haiti, the destruction of rain forests or the democratization of the former Soviet Union all required not just creative solutions but money -- money for United Nations peacekeeping operations, money to help Russia make the transition from a Communist to a market economy, money that is no longer available.
This is so in part because Mr. Bush grew to be a victim of the Reagan Administration he had helped to lead. The deficit ballooned during the Reagan years. And Reagan Administration officials even boasted in memoirs that this was deliberate. They said they hoped that under the burden of a record deficit, there would be intense pressure to starve liberal social programs.
 
Hampered by the Deficit
 But years later, that came back to haunt the Bush Administration and tie its hands in the one area where it wanted and needed money. As the historian Ronald Steel put it: "The huge deficit made it impossible for the Administration to fund an activist foreign policy. When all of these opportunities to develop free markets and democracies were out there in Eastern Europe and Russia, we could not afford to nurture them."
The end result, argued Stanley Hoffmann, a Harvard University European affairs expert, is that American foreign policy today seems reduced to two conflicting statements: We are the only superpower left, and we are broke so we can't do anything.
"During the first few years," Mr. Hoffmann said, "I think the Bush people thought they saw the future almost the way it looked in 1945 -- we would be clearly the No. 1 superpower, but the Soviet Union would follow our lead. The two great powers and a few lesser ones would do things together. That is not going to happen. Now we have to shut up or put up, and since we don't want to put up, we may have to shut up."

HEADLINE: House Approves Foreign Aid At Lowest Level Since 1977

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
The House voted today to spend $13.8 billion on foreign aid, the lowest total since 1977 and an amount the Bush Administration called "inadequate."
Final passage came on a surprisingly wide margin as the bill was supported by 297 members and opposed by 124. Republicans backed it narrowly, 92 to 72. Democrats voted for it by a wide margin, 205 to 51. The House's one independent voted no. 
 The bill withstood complaints that it was more important to spend money on problems at home than abroad for two major reasons. First, under the 1990 budget agreement, cuts in foreign spending cannot be transferred to increase domestic spending.
Second, the bill had been trimmed in the Appropriations Committee before it reached the floor, enabling lawmakers to vote for it and still say they had voted for cuts. The $13.8 billion total was $1.3 billion below the Administration request and $628 million under last year's appropriation.
The bill included $417 million in aid for the former Soviet republics, a provision that was hardly remarked on in debate. This bilateral aid is only a small part of the assistance the Administration hopes to provide. Legislation to put more money into the International Monetary Fund to help the former republics is now being kept from the Senate floor by a filibuster over a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced Federal budget.
Representative David R. Obey, the Wisconsin Democrat who heads the subcommittee that handled the appropriation, spoke proudly of one provision in the bill that the Administration attacked, which would gradually end military grants to NATO countries. He called it an end to "the free lunch."
The bill also included a $20 million item for the United Nations Population Fund. The Administration threatened a veto over that issue because it said the fund "supports a program of coercive abortion or involuntary sterilization in China." House Republicans, who considered offering an amendment to delete $1.15 billion for the World Bank, backed down after Administration protests and proposed cuts in the whole bill that totaled only $60 million.
But Representative John Miller, Republcian of Washington, said the $30.9 million reduction for the World Bank was a "very small step" to warn the Bank to "stop the environmentally destructive loans that have caused hundreds of thousands of people to be kicked out of their homes."
A final amendment adopted today cut $24 million from development assistance. Its author, Representative Dan Burton of Indiana, said it was intended to punish India for human rights violations, repressive laws and mistreatment of prisoners in Kashmir and the Punjab. But the amendment did not specify which nation should be cut, so it could affect any country receiving that kind of assistance.

The Economy
Manufacturers will get broad new powers to pollute under a rule issued by the Bush Administration. [Page A1.]
President Bush signed a bill ending the railroad shutdown, which had threatened to damage the nation's economy. [A1.]
The economy grew at an annual rate of 2.7 percent in the first quarter, the briskest pace of the Bush Presidency, but some private economists suggested the economic recovery is too slow. Unemployment claims surged and sales of existing homes fell. [D2.]
A package of tax changes endorsed by the House Ways and Means Committee would help blighted areas and repeal luxury taxes on expensive yachts, furs and jewels. [D16.]
The Supreme Court's ruling on cigarette companies also opens other manufacturers to product liability suits, lawyers said. [D5.]
 
International
Canadian lumber hurt American producers, a Federal trade agency ruled, allowing the United States to impose a 6.51 percent import duty next month. [D1.]
The O.E.C.D. drastically cut its growth forecast for the year, to an anemic 1.8 percent from an earlier 2.2 percent. [D2.]
The Bush Administration was urged to block the proposed sale of LTV's missile division to Thomson-CSF of France by Joseph E. Kelley, a senior Congressional investigator. [D4.]
 
Companies
British Petroleum's chief, Robert B. Horton, quit after only 27 months at the helm. The stock tumbled $6 to $48.375. [D1.]
Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts said it would invest $300 million in TW Holdings, a money-losing owner of restaurants. [D4.]
Citibank settled charges that it failed in the safekeeping of canceled corporate bonds, bank regulators said. [D4.]
Lotus Development shares plunged 23 percent after the software company slashed earnings estimates. [D5.]
Katy Industries shares soared 23 percent after the Carroll family, which holds 51 percent, said it might acquire more. [D4.]
 
Markets
Wall Street zigged and zagged on tobacco stocks, as traders rushed to sell after reading the first headlines on news tickers only to start buying once analysts had their say. [D1.]
Stocks edged down, with the Dow Jones industrial average giving up 6.69 points at 3,284.01. [D6.] Prices of Treasury securities rose and long-term interest rates fell. [D13.]
Heavy selling drove the dollar down sharply against major foreign currencies. [D14.] Grain prices surged on forecasts of more rain in the wheat belt and not enough for corn and soybeans. [D14.]

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN -- Voices: Boston;
Mixed Reviews on Bush's Foreign Decisions

 BODY:
Political experts, local officials and ordinary voters in several cities were asked to appraise President Bush's record on foreign policy.
 
Mark Brogioli
27 years old; insurance adjuster at Safety Insurance in downtown Boston
He's paid no attention to domestic affairs, or very little -- he's spent too much time concentrating on international affairs. I think he should be a little more interested in what's going on at home. He's lucky that things have sort of fallen into place as far as what's going on in the former Soviet Union -- I think that would have happened regardless of who was President. He seems to be letting Russia make the moves and then responding to them. 
 I don't feel George Bush really cares about the individuals in Yugoslavia. China's most-favored-nation trading status -- he claims that it's being done for democracy and whatnot, but I don't really agree with that. A lot of people I talk to support Bush, give George Bush complete credit for the Berlin wall falling, for the Soviet Union collapsing, and I really don't think he had that much to do with any of that.
 
Seyom Brown
59 years old; chairman of the politics department at Brandeis University
In general, I think that there's been a squandering of opportunity for constructive leadership in the dramatically changed international system. What you have, unfortunately, is petty electoral considerations and small-mindedness masquerading under his favorite term, "prudence."
With the end of the cold war it was really a great opportunity for leadership that was handed down to Bush by Reagan on a silver platter. the economic crisis in the Soviet Union that accompanied perestroika really called out for the United States to take the lead in fashioning a Marshall Plan-type of response to the massive reconstruction needs in the post-Soviet areas and also in the Soviet Union itself.
Well, Bush wasted most of the first year of his Administration with what the Administration said was a review of Soviet policy, and from my perspective he played to the conservative gallery with postures of diplomatic toughness toward Gorbachev -- and I think this played right into the hands of Gorbachev's own conservative critics in the Soviet Union.
 
John Graham
36 years old; professor of policy and decision sciences at Harvard University
I think he's been an excellent leader in foreign policy. I think the most impressive accomplishment is the relation with the increasingly democratized Soviet Union. I think they will move increasingly toward a more capitalistic and democratic approach to government, which in the long run, I expect and hope, will make them more our allies. One of the key things he's done is to be careful not to prematurely commit loyalty to any subgroup in the Soviet Union.
I think it would be very tempting, for an inexperienced President in foreign policy, to give too much attention to who happened to be the particular person in power in a situation where things are changing very quickly. I think the President has done a very good job of maintaining United States' interests.
[The question of balance between domestic and foreign policy] in some ways is a false distinction because in some cases, like in the field of environmental policy, the international and domestic issues merge. He has been quite constructive in taking a balanced position on the need for both environmental protection and economic growth. I think that in the long run Bush is right that China is increasingly recognized as a superpower. and I think it's better for us to develop relations at the same time that we try to coax them and encourage them into a more humane approach toward their citizenry.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Platform;
In a Final Draft, Democrats Reject a Part of Their Past

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
In a final draft of its platform for this year's elections, the Democratic Party not only attacks the Reagan-Bush Administrations, but also spurns much of the "big government theory" that Democrats have embraced for decades.
The Democratic National Committee today issued the final draft, which reflects the political philosophy of Gov. Bill Clinton, who has clinched the party's Presidential nomination. 
 The draft is implicitly critical of the party's old thinking and old solutions.
 "We reject both the do-nothing government of the last 12 years as well as the big government theory that says we can hamstring business and tax and spend our way to prosperity," the draft says. "Instead, we offer a third way."
The "third way" is a nickname for Mr. Clinton's political philosophy, which, he says, tries to steer a course between laissez-faire capitalism and welfare-state economics.
Much of the platform echoes themes developed by the Democratic Leadership Council, a group of moderate Democrats headed until last year by Mr. Clinton.
 
New View of Federal Role
 The draft platform rejects the assumption that the government can provide a solution to every social problem.
The 1992 platform reflects an effort by some Democrats to move away from old-style liberalism, rooted in the political orthodoxy of the New Deal and labor unions, and toward a more centrist position.
But Mark E. Steitz, a spokesman for the Democratic National Committee, said it was inaccurate to describe the 1992 platform as being simply "to the right" of platforms adopted by the party since 1972. Democrats prefer to say that they have transcended the old left-right divisions.
In addition, Mr. Steitz said, some issues that have provoked fights among Democrats in the past have faded away with the collapse of the Soviet Union. Those issues include the United States policy on Central America and on nuclear weapons.
The Democrats' draft contains many themes that could be accepted by President Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle. It calls for a cut in the capital gains tax for people who make long-term investments in new technology. It says, "We honor business as a noble endeavor." And it demands a restoration of "basic American values," including a greater emphasis on "work, family and individual responsibility."
 
Opposing Bush's Policies
 But on other issues, the platform offers stark alternatives to the policies of Presidents Bush and Reagan.
The Democratic draft calls for a Federal law to protect a woman's right to have an abortion, regardless of her ability to pay. It says employers should be required to grant unpaid leave to workers caring for newborns or sick relatives. In 1990, Mr. Bush vetoed such a plan.
The Democrats also promise to "provide civil rights protection for gay men and lesbians and an end to Defense Department discrimination." Without being specific, the platform suggests that wealthy people should pay higher taxes, and it endorses tax relief for "middle-class Americans" and for families with children.
The Democratic platform also says, "We will oppose Republican efforts to gut the Clean Air Act in the guise of competitiveness." It says that corporate executives, "who pay themselves 100 times what they pay the average worker, shouldn't get big raises unrelated to performance."
The platform committee will take final action Saturday on the draft. It will go to the floor of the Democratic National Convention in New York on July 14.
The Democratic platform committee is headed by Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado and Representative Nancy Pelosi of California. Clinton delegates account for a majority of the committee. The drafting was coordinated by Representative Bill Richardson of New Mexico and John D. Holum, a Washington lawyer who was active in the Presidential campaigns of George S. McGovern and Gary Hart.
The Democrats' 1992 platform says, "We oppose the Bush Administration's efforts to bankrupt the public school system -- the bedrock of democracy -- through private school vouchers." It deplores "savage inequalities among public schools across the land."
The Democrats, like many Republicans, endorse the goal of "access to quality, affordable health care" for all Americans. But with Democrats divided on the details of a national health-care plan, their platform does not specify how to achieve that goal. It calls for "tough controls on health costs."
In the draft of its platform, the Democratic Party says, "We offer a new social contract based neither on callous do-nothing Republican neglect, nor on an outdated faith in programs as the solution to every problem."
 
Buttressing the Family
 The Democrats' strategy for "strengthening the family" would be palatable to many Republicans: "Governments don't raise children; people do. People who bring children into this world have a responsibility to care for them and give them values, motivation and discipline. Children should not have children."
The draft also says, "The private sector is the engine of our economy and the main source of national wealth." But it denounces "those at the top of the totem pole, the inside traders, quick-buck artists and savings and loan kingpins who looked out for themselves and not for the country" in the 1980's.
Rather than calling for large new Federal programs, the Democratic platform looks to private voluntary associations to help solve social problems. It says the success of American democracy depends on the strength of families, neighborhoods, religious institutions, and civic and charitable organizations -- groups where "the values and character of our citizens are formed."
The platform affirms "our longstanding special relationship with Israel" and promises that Democrats will continue the Bush Administration's efforts to foster Arab-Israeli peace talks. But it accuses the Administration of encouraging Arabs to believe that the United States will deliver "unilateral concessions" from Israel.

HEADLINE: O.E.C.D. Cuts Growth Forecast for the Year

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, June 25

 BODY:
Drastically cutting its growth forecast for the year, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development says that the world economy remains mired in uncertainty, but predicts that a recovery will take hold in 1993.
In its semiannual report, the 24-nation organization slashed its estimate for economic expansion in 1992 to an anemic 1.8 percent from the 2.2 percent it had predicted in December. The group attributed the enduring economic weakness to high German interest rates, the bursting of Japan's speculative bubble, Britain's persistent recession and wariness among businesses and consumers. 
 But the group, which is based in Paris, suggested that while the United States recovery had been hesitant so far, it should gather pace in the second half of the year, contributing to overall growth of 3 percent in the O.E.C.D. countries next year.
"The positive indicators of the economic situation in the United States are now more numerous, and confidence in a recovery is spreading," the O.E.C.D. report said.
The report predicted that American economic growth would be 3.75 percent in the second half of 1992 and 2.1 percent for the entire year. In 1993, the organization said, United States economic expansion should reach 3.6 percent; it foresaw inflation increasing marginally to 3.2 percent, from 3.1 percent this year.
Inflation for all O.E.C.D. countries should total 3.5 percent this year and 3.2 percent in 1993, down from 4.1 percent in 1991, the report said.
Despite its measured optimism for 1993, the O.E.C.D. report was full of gloomy warnings that are certain to figure high on the agenda of leaders of the world's seven leading industrial countries when they gather on July 5 in Munich to review the state of the world economy.
The organization said the current impasse in world trade talks was contributing to a climate of anxiety.
The report also suggested that Germany's fiscal deficit was likely to keep interest rates high in that country and throughout Europe, dampening demand and slowing growth.
The organization warned that economic reform was taking a devastating toll in Eastern Europe, with output likely to slump 18 percent this year in the former Soviet Union and 15 percent in the region as a whole.

HEADLINE: Dow Declines by 6.69 to Finish at 3,284.01

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Stocks ended a listless session with small losses yesterday, as new jitters about earnings kept many investors out of the market.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 6.69 points, to 3,284.01, as volume on the New York Stock Exchange slipped to 183 million shares, from 194.4 million on Wednesday. Advancing issues led declining ones, 861 to 815. 
 The software industry became the latest sector to be hurt by concerns about earnings: Lotus Development said it would not meet second-quarter earnings estimates and that its 1992 profit would be 25 cents a share below estimates. Its stock lost 5 5/8, to 18 3/8. The loss dragged down Borland, off 1 1/4, to 39 1/4, and Microsoft, off 2 1/4, to 70.
Many companies will release second-quarter results in a few weeks, and investors are likely to stay inactive until then, traders said.
 
Weak Economic Data
 In addition, investors are still apprehensive about the recovery after the May durable goods report on Wednesday showed an unexpected 2.4 percent drop in orders -- the steepest since a 5.3 percent drop last December.
The market also remained sensitive to other bad news. Many investors sold shares of British Petroleum after news that its chairman, Robert Horton, had resigned. B.P. lost 6, to 48 3/8. Traders cited concerns that the company's relatively high dividend of $3.99 a share would be cut or eliminated.
Stocks managed to ignore a strong performance in bonds. In late trading, the 30-year Treasury bond was up 19/32 , to yield 7.77 percent, compared with 7.82 percent on Wednesday. Sentiment was helped by a well-bid auction of one-year bills and an unexpected jump in weekly claims for unemployment benefits.
 
Losses in Tobacco
 Shares of some tobacco companies retreated a day after the Supreme Court opened the way for damage suits over cigarettes. Philip Morris slipped 1/2, to 73 1/4; Loews eased, 1 5/8, to 109 3/8; UST fell 1/2, to 27 3/4, and American Brands lost 1/4, to 45 1/8.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks fell 0.71 point, to 403.12; the American Stock Exchange composite lost 0.05, to 374.15; the New York Stock Exchange composite fell 0.28, to 221.53, and the Nasdaq composite closed down 3.19, to 548.20.

HEADLINE: Trade Panel Approves Canada-Lumber Duty

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
In the latest sign that their 1988 free-trade agreement did not settle all trade disputes between the United States and Canada, a Federal trade agency ruled today that imported Canadian lumber had hurt American producers, a decision that will allow the United States to impose a 6.51 percent import duty next month.
Within minutes of the 4-to-2 vote, William A. Dymond, the commercial counselor at the Canadian Embassy, told reporters that Canada would try to overturn the International Trade Commission's ruling by appealing to a binational arbitration panel. 
 The dispute comes as American, Canadian and Mexican negotiators are in the final stages of drafting a North American free-trade agreement, and disputes involving the earlier pact have made it an increasingly controversial model for the next one.
The nature of the decision also reflects a change in the commission's composition, with the addition in recent months of three commissioners who tend to look narrowly at the effect of the imports in question rather than broadly at the political and economic implications of a case.
On Wednesday, the panel ruled in a 4-to-2 vote that the American auto industry had not suffered harm from Japanese mini-van imports.
 
Canadian Success in the U.S.
 Trade experts said that Canadian lumber had a third of the American market while Japanese mini-vans had only an eighth. So the Canadians had more of an opportunity to hurt the American lumber industry by holding down prices.
Over all, the American lumber industry is healthier than the auto industry. But, concentrating narrowly on how trade law is written, the commissioners gave this less weight.
"This is clearly a message to our trading partners and domestic industries that this is a new I.T.C. -- you don't have the predictability that we used to have," said Paula Stern, a former Democratic chairman of the commission.
What happens next in the Canadian lumber case is unclear because of murky language in the 1988 trade pact. The agreement excluded such lumber because that area was addressed in a 1986 memorandum of understanding under which the United States agreed not to impose an import tariff on lumber if instead Canada imposed an export tariff on the same lumber.
Canada canceled the memorandum and its tariff in October, prompting the Commerce Department to file the trade case. Canada contends that since the memorandum no longer exists, lumber is not excluded from the free-trade agreement.
The American lumber industry contends that lumber is exempt, so that any appeal by Canada would have to go to the Federal Government's Court of International Trade in New York instead of a panel of arbitrators from both countries. But Bush Administration officials recently appear increasingly reluctant to side with American industry.
A senior Administration official said this evening that the United States would allow a binational panel to review today's decision. A separate panel will review the Commerce Department's decision in May that set the 6.51 percent duty after concluding that Canadian provinces were subsidizing their exports.
Regardless of appeals, which could last half a year or longer, the Customs Service will begin collecting the 6.51 percent duty next month. Canada exported $2.7 billion worth of softwood lumber, mostly pine boards, studs and beams, to the United States last year, suggesting that duties will total nearly $200 million a year.
C. T. (Kip) Howlett, the chairman of the Coalition for Fair Lumber Imports, a lumber industry group in the United States, said today's decision would save 16,000 American jobs while raising the cost of building an average new home by up to $250.
The Commerce Department initially assessed a duty of 14.48 percent on March 6 but reduced it to 6.51 percent after a review in May. The reduction prompted complaints from American logging companies that the Bush Administration had succumbed to lobbying by Canada and was sacrificing the industry for the sake of bilateral relations.
 
Complaints Are Fueled
 Those complaints were fanned this week when James H. Lake, the chairman of a Washington public relations company and now one of the four deputy managers of President Bush's re-election campaign, said he had twice called a senior White House official on the Canadians' behalf.
Mr. Lake's firm -- Robinson, Lake, Lerer & Montgomery -- is one of a dozen Washington public relations, legal and lobbying firms retained by Canada in the case. Mr. Lake said today that after joining the campaign and after the preliminary Commerce Department ruling on March 6, he called Clayton K. Yeutter, who is President Bush's domestic policy adviser. Mr. Lake arranged for Mr. Yeutter to talk to an American lawyer pleading the Canadians' case.
Mr. Lake said the telephone call involved no impropriety because he had not been involved in lumber issues in his new job.
Mr. Yeutter said that while he had spoken to the lawyer, he had never got in touch with the Commerce Department about the lumber case and so had had no effect on the decision. The Journal of Commerce first reported the call on Wednesday.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "This is clearly a message to our trading partners and domestic industries that this is a new I.T.C. -- you don't have the predictability that we used to have," said Paula Stern, a former Democratic chairman of the commission. (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Havel Calls for Preservation Of United Czechoslovakia

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRAGUE, June 25

 BODY:
President Vaclav Havel appealed today to Czechs and Slovaks to remain one nation, but he acknowledged that prospects for the 74-year-old union had dimmed.
"Perhaps we must truly divide if we are to unite again," Mr. Havel said, a touch of sadness in his mellifluous baritone voice. 
 His remarks came at the opening session of what may be Czechoslovakia's last federal Parliament. It was a bittersweet occasion, one in which small gestures said a lot about the distance this nation has traveled from its rambunctious "velvet revolution" less than three years ago.
When Mr. Havel, the dissident and playwright who became President, finished his speech, Czech deputies stood to applaud. Most of the Slovak deputies also shuffled to their feet, but did not seem to know what to do with their hands. Some jammed them into their pockets; others held them awkwardly at their sides.
In November 1989, it was Mr. Havel's spontaneous enthusiasm that personified Eastern Europe's most joyous anti-Communist uprising, the 10-day velvet revolution in which hundreds of thousands of people shouted a totalitarian Government out of power.
The Government that emerged from the 1990 elections was among Eastern Europe's most eccentric, filled with writers, intellectuals and actors. Frank Zappa, the American rock star who inspired some of the dissidents, was officially named a cultural envoy.
 
Striking a Moral Tone
 Over the next two years, Mr. Havel repeatedly sought to strike a moral tone as President. For instance, he opposed the parliamentary law that banned senior Communists or secret police collaborators from holding high office in the new Czechoslovakia.
Mr. Havel, who is not affiliated with any party, lost that fight to the increasingly powerful right-wing factions in Parliament. Even as Mr. Havel's international standing was rising, his power to move events in his own country was ebbing steadily.
The divisions that were emerging in Czechoslovakia over these years mirrored those generally in Eastern Europe: Nationalists in Slovakia, many of whom were former Communists, favored softening the rigors of economic "shock therapy." They were allied against the aggressively pro-market capitalists who were increasingly prominent in the Czech lands.
In the June 5-6 elections, Vladimir Meciar's Movement for Democratic Slovakia won the largest number of seats in Slovakia and Vaclav Klaus's Civic Democratic Party prevailed in the Czech regions.
Mr. Meciar and Mr. Klaus, with their diametrically opposed views on economics and the very structure of the Czechoslovak state, recently agreed to slash the size of the federal Government. They also decided on a process under which the two regional Parliaments will agree by Sept. 30 whether, or how, to break up the state.
 
Slovaks to Block Re-Election
 In his speech today, Mr. Havel made it clear that he would not preside over the dissolution of this nation, saying he preferred to create rather than destroy.
Czechoslovakia's Parliament is scheduled to vote next week for a new President; Slovak parties have already pledged to block Mr. Havel's election. If that happens, he could remain until Oct. 5 as interim president.
Mr. Havel defiantly brushed aside rumors in Prague that he might resign, pledging to remain a political figure.
"I don't feel the least reason for resigning, for leaving the stage simply because someone whistles at me to capitulate or because there is on the horizon the possibility of another defeat," he said. "I will not leave the ship only because it is rocking."

HEADLINE: Couple Indicted in Kidnapping of Exxon Executive

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, June 25

 BODY:
The New Jersey couple accused of kidnapping Sidney J. Reso were indicted by a Federal grand jury here today, as Federal prosecutors asserted that others were involved.
The assertion was included in the indictment that added two charges to the four counts of kidnapping, extortion and conspiracy that were filed against each of the suspects, Arthur D. and Irene J. Seale, both 45 years old, after their arrests last Friday in a car rental office in Hackettstown, N.J. 
 Without elaborating, the indictment said that "others," who were not identified, joined the Seales in the conspiracy against Mr. Reso, the 57-year-old president of Exxon's international division.
The indictment's kidnapping conspiracy count defined the Seales and others as "members of a conspiracy" that abducted Mr. Reso, wrote and arranged the delivery of several ransom notes to both Exxon and its international division and made calls to a special cellular telephone number established by the F.B.I. for communications with Mr. Reso's kidnappers. The Seales specifically were accused of making calls the night of June 18 that gave instructions for dropping off the ransom money.
 
Ransom Notes Mailed
 The United States Attorney for New Jersey, Michael Chertoff, released the indictment late this afternoon without comment on the investigation or the search for Mr. Reso.
Neither Mr. Chertoff nor the indictment said how many other people may have been involved.
One of the new charges involved using the mails to transmit ransom letters. The indictment said "members of the conspiracy" mailed a ransom letter from New York City to Exxon's corporate headquarters in Irving, Tex., on May 12. That was 13 days after Mr. Reso vanished moments after he left his home in Morris Township, N.J., for the 10-minute drive to his office in Florham Park.
Another ransom letter was mailed from Florham Park to Mr. Reso's office on June 1, the indictment said.
 
A Call From Pooler, Georgia
 The second new accusation involved interstate travel in aid of extortion. The count said the Seales and a third person, who was not identified, travelled from New Jersey to Florida and then to Georgia as part of the plot against Exxon. On June 8, the indictment said, "a member of the conspiracy" made an extortion call from Pooler, Ga., a small town a few miles northwest of Savannah.
Federal and state authorities, meantime, continued a round-the-clock search for Mr. Reso, primarily in the three New Jersey counties that have figured in the case since the April 29 abduction: Morris, Warren and Hunterdon.
Mr. Reso lived and worked in Morris County. The Seales, both unemployed in recent months, lived with Mr. Seale's retired parents in Changewater, a rural hamlet of Lebanon Township in Hunterdon County, which is adjacent to Morris. The couple were arrested in Warren County, across the Musconetcong River from Hunterdon, after F.B.I. agents spent about four hours the night of June 18 following a string of ransom calls and notes through four towns in Morris and adjacent Somerset Counties.
The ransom demanded for Mr. Reso's release, $18.5 million, was never left anywhere by F.B.I. agents that night. The reason, the authorities said, was that a series of calls with ransom instructions ended abruptly after the driver of the car that was being followed by F.B.I. agents saw a roadblock that had been set up because of a fire near Far Hills, N.J., and drove away. Authorities have declined to discuss the arrangements or promises for Mr. Reso's release had the ransom money been left by F.B.I. agents.
 
Assuming He Is Alive
 William Tonkin, a spokesman for the F.B.I., said today that authorities hoped that one or more other people involved in the kidnapping may be holding Mr. Reso.
"We will remain optimistic as to his well-being," Mr. Tonkin said. "Absent information to the contrary, we're going to work on the premise he's still alive. We have no reason to think he's not alive."
Mr. and Mrs. Seale have been held without bail in separate jails since shortly after their arrests. On the advice of their court-appointed lawyers, the Seales have refused to be interviewed by authorities since June 19, officials said. They declined to say what, if anything, the couple said about the case immediately after their arrests.
Mr. Seale worked until 1987 as a security officer for Exxon. A decade earlier, he retired on an officer's disability pension from the Police Department in Hillside, N.J., where he had grown up.
 
A Security Consultant
 Before he and his wife returned to New Jersey in late 1989, they spent several financially troubled years in Hilton Head Island, S.C., and Vail, Colo. About a year ago, Mr. Seale applied for a job with Intertel, a security consultant.
Robert Peloquin, head of Intertel, said today that Mr. Seale was retained twice between last summer and this March at $40 an hour to do part-time record checks for two clients. Mr. Peloquin also said Intertel let Mr. Seale use a desk and a phone in its New York office about twice a week between last summer and March to seek both a permanent job for himself and business for Intertel. Mr. Seale was unsuccessful in both undertakings, Mr. Peloquin said. Intertel broke off contact with him when the company closed its New York office in March and opened a headquarters in Rockville, Md., he said.

HEADLINE: Democrats Offer New Health-Care Plan

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
Seizing the initiative on a politically charged issue, House Democratic leaders today unveiled a health care proposal intended to contain costs and insure more than half of the 30 million Americans not covered by health insurance.
But the fate of the measure is uncertain at best. Even if approved by Congress, it would probably face a veto by President Bush. 
 Nonetheless, after a seven-month effort to reach a consensus within their ranks, Democrats say the health program will clearly mark the goals of the party as it tries to retain its Congressional majority this fall.
 
Aim Is to Reduce Inflation
 House Democrats also noted that the plan dovetailed with proposals offered by Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the likely Democratic Presidential nominee, as the party prepares for its national convention next month.
Calling health care the most important domestic issue after unemployment, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, said: "Even if this bill were signed into law this year, we would still be short of universal comprehensive coverage. But this bill, as opposed to Republican proposals, takes the one step that will enable us to reach that goal: cost containment."
The major objective of the legislation is to reduce inflation for health care to 6 percent from the current rate of 10 percent by limiting the costs of all health procedures and products. The Government would set maximum national payment rates for hospitals, doctors and services based on market conditions, or about 35 percent higher than Medicare rates.
But there would be exceptions to the price controls. States could establish their own payment rates for hospitals and doctors rather than submit to a national standard. And health maintenance organizations would be allowed to negotiate their rates with hospitals and doctors.
The measure would also increase Government regulation of health insurance, establishing standards that would guarantee wider access to people with past health problems and to workers changing jobs who otherwise could be uncovered for months.
In addition, the plan would allow the self-employed to deduct 100 percent of their health insurance expenses after Jan. 1, 1994. Democrats say their plan would require no new taxes.
 
'Lays the Groundwork'
 "It lays the groundwork for insuring all Americans," said Representative Pete Stark, the California Democrat who is the primary author of the bill. "At current inflation rates, health insurance costs are doubling every four years. Workers face benefit cutbacks, while millions are afraid to switch jobs or move for fear of losing insurance coverage. Our bill solves this key problem."
The Stark plan originally attracted no more than lukewarm support from liberal Democrats, who prefer either national health insurance or an arrangement by which private companies would be required to provide coverage or pay into a Government insurance fund. But earlier this month, the California Democrat added provisions giving parents the opportunity to obtain Government benefits similar to those provided by Medicare for their uninsured children.
The bill would also cover all poor pregnant women by 1999, although it would still leave about 10 million underprivileged Americans uninsured.
What makes the plan attractive to liberals will surely attract strong opposition from insurance companies, hospitals and doctors. "We don't believe Americans can afford to trust Government to budget, redistribute and manage $800 billion dollars in personal decisions about health expenditures," said Mike Bromberg, executive director of the Federation of American Health Systems, a lobbying group for private hospitals. "This is like a political shell game where some are more interested in attracting a veto then enacting reforms this year."
Mr. Bromberg said he and other health providers prefered a more modest plan offered by Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, to limit annual increases in premiums and curb the right of insurers to cancel policies because of a person's health.
House Republicans offered a third, less generous plan three weeks ago that would limit malpractice claims and overhaul health insurance plans provided by small businesses.
A senior Gephardt aide conceded that it would take a fight to get the Stark health plan through the Ways and Means Committee, where it will be considered next week. "We're not there yet," he said, "but the pieces are falling together."
 
Criticism by Republican
 Representative Bill Gradison of Ohio, the ranking Republican member of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health, criticized the Stark plan, saying, "These national price controls would lead to rationing and over time would damage the quality of health care in this country."
Asked what could pass this year, he replied, "Nothing, because the Democrats don't want President Bush to have a bill signing ceremony on health care."
The Democrats estimated that if nothing was done, the average annual premium of $4,800 now paid by a family of four would double in 1992 dollars by the year 2000.

HEADLINE: National AIDS Panel Says Administration Has Not Done Enough

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
The National Commission on AIDS said today that the Bush Administration had failed the nation by showing poor leadership in combating the AIDS epidemic.
The commission released a statement after what its members said was an extraordinarily disappointing meeting on Wednesday on AIDS and government leadership with Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services. 
 The commission, a bipartisan panel appointed jointly by Congress and the White House and charged with creating a national consensus on what should be done about AIDS, said in its statement, "President Bush and the Department of Health and Human Services have failed to meet fully their responsibilities in leading the national response to the monumental human suffering and economic loss from the H.I.V./AIDS epidemic."
 
Secretary 'Ambushed'
 A department official said that Dr. Sullivan "was ambushed" by the commission's negative comments after the meeting. Administration officials present at the meeting could not be reached for comment, but the department issued a statement today from Dr. Sullivan:
"The charge by the commission is a total misrepresentation of the facts and the commitment of the Bush Administration. In all of American public health history, no single disease has ever occupied so much attention and commanded so many resources in so short a time.
"H.I.V. infection and AIDS continues to be one of the highest public health priorities of this Administration," he said.
Dr. June E. Osborn, chairman of the commission, said in an interview today that she felt Dr. Sullivan had been "very unresponsive" at the meeting. "He told us that he had a lot of work to do, and that everyone is working very hard," she said. "In other words, business as usual. This epidemic is an immense, historical tragedy and business as usual is not enough."
 
'No Sense of Urgency'
 The purpose of the meeting between the Secretary and the commission members was to review what the department has done to carry out the commission's recommendations last September. At that time, the commission outlined 30 steps that the Government could take to help get the epidemic under control.
The statement said President Bush had given only one speech on AIDS, in March 1990, placed no emphasis on legislative proposals on AIDS and has "signaled no sense of urgency to either the American people, or to his own domestic policy experts."
Further, the statement said, "The United States, with the largest number of H.I.V. infections in the world, is one of the few industrialized nations with no national plan to deal with the epidemic, and no mechanism to create one."
The Government has also not increased funds for programs to prevent AIDS, and has allowed funds for existing prevention programs to drop from $497 million in 1991, to $480 million in 1992, the statement said.
Separately, the AIDS Action Council, a Washington lobbying group for AIDS organizations, said the Administration had failed to issue regulations that would allow people with AIDS to apply for help with housing payments.
The bill appropriating $50 million for that purpose was passed last fall, and the council pressed the agency to make the money available. But by April, when no rule was forthcoming, the council got an agreement from an Assistant Secretary at H.U.D., Anna S. Kondratas, that the rule would be published by June 1. An official at H.U.D. said today that the agency had not meet the deadline but that it would put out the rules soon.
Daniel T. Bross, director of the AIDS Action Council, said that the Government's response was "not good enough for the thousands of people living on the streets and dying on the streets with AIDS."
"This is another indication of the disinterest of the Administration," he said.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
UAL's Prospects For a Recovery

BYLINE: By Agis Salpukas

 BODY:
THE UAL Corporation's United Airlines is a colossus that spans the globe. It is the only carrier in the United States that has a major route system to both the Pacific and Europe.
Yet in spite of its powerful route system, it has been unable to remain unscathed in the current round of fare cuts, rising fuel prices and uncertain future bookings. And the economies of the United States, Japan and other big industrial countries remain in the doldrums. 
 During the first quarter, UAL lost $92.3 million. It is expected to post another loss in the second quarter, which is normally a good one for the industry.
Other major carriers also posted declines in the first quarter, with Delta's loss totaling $151.6 million and USAir's $63 million. Only the AMR Corporation, the owner of American Airlines, posted a small profit -- $20 million.
On Wednesday, UAL was dealt another blow. Standard & Poor's lowered its ratings on $2.9 billion of the company's debt to BBB-, from BB+.
The rating still keeps the company as one that investors should consider, but it means that there is more risk in buying UAL's securities since economic conditions could make it more difficult for the company to pay its debt-service costs.
The company was taken off S.& P.'s Creditwatch, where it had been placed along with six other large carriers on April 21.
Philip Baggaley, an airline analyst at S.& P., said there was an anomaly in looking at UAL. Compared with companies in other industries, he said, UAL has a balance sheet that looks poor. Taking the company's debt and factoring in leases for airplanes, UAL's debt-to-equity ratio stands at 88 percent. Mr. Baggeley said the average ratio of debt-to-equity for triple-B-rated companies was 47 percent.
Also, in the short term, the company faced some difficulties because it has to compete with low-cost Southwest Airlines in two of its key markets, Chicago and California. Continental Airlines, which is operating under bankruptcy protection from its creditors, also competes with United on many routes, particularly in Denver, where both carriers have hubs.
Yet looking at UAL from such a perspective overlooks United Airlines' hidden strengths, which make the airline one of the prime carriers, along with American and Delta, that should be able to capitalize on future trends in the airline industry.
"It has tremendous strengths," Mr. Baggaley said.
UAL has assets of enormous value that it could sell in a pinch -- some $5.2 billion worth -- Mr. Baggaley said, adding that he was using a very conservative measure.
Included are its Pacific routes, which UAL acquired in 1986 from Pan American World Airways for $384 million and which are valued at $3 billion; its Apollo computer reservation system, which is becoming a truly international system and is worth about $500 million, and the airline's gates and hubs at major airports like O'Hare International in Chicago, which are valued at $2 billion.
Thus, Mr. Baggaley does not foresee a cash squeeze for UAL. The strong assets could be used to raise money if the industry remained depressed for a longer period.
UAL management and analysts had hoped that this year would bring a strong recovery for the airline industry, and especially the company, after a disastrous 1991, when the Persian Gulf war doubled fuel prices and traffic slumped because of war-related anxiety.
The industry seemed on the way to recovery earlier this year, but then it became embroiled in a huge attempt to revamp the air-fare structure, a move initiated by Robert L. Crandall, chairman of American Airlines.
One short-term result of the air-fare changes has been a huge sale of low-priced tickets. As a result, planes will be filled this summer with happy passengers flying at bargain prices, while airline executives will be trying to figure out how to pay higher fuel bills with falling revenue.
Even though traffic has picked up on international routes, the signs for a strong recovery are still uncertain.
"Things look more ominous than we thought they would be," said Rose Ann Tortora, an airline analyst at the First Boston Corporation.
"It's not inappropriate to be concerned," she said, referring to the ability of United to pay its debt while spending huge amounts to stay in the race to be a global carrier.
While United has already built up its Pacific routes, it is still expanding in Europe. The carrier was at first reluctant to cut capital spending, since it sometimes did not have enough airplanes to cover all its routes effectively. UAL was also seeking to keep pace with American, which has surpassed it as the nation's largest carrier.
Last January, UAL stepped back from its ambitious expansion drive and said it would cut capital spending by $2 billion over three years to strengthen its balance sheet.
AMR had taken a similar step earlier, saying it would cut its capital spending by $8 billion.
Ms. Tortora said sentiment was growing among investors and analysts that it was time for UAL to pull back from the huge plane orders and expansion plans.
"Let's make some profits with the planes we have," she said.
